Sloka (Sanskrit): धर्मक्षेत्रे कुरुक्षेत्रे समवेता युयुत्सवः। मामकाः पाण्डवाश्चैव किमकुर्वत सञ्जय।।
Sloka (English Translation): On the field of Dharma, the field of Kurukshetra, assembled are the forces of my sons and the sons of Pandu, eager to fight. What did they do, O Sanjaya?
Meaning/Interpretation: Symbolizes inner conflict and moral struggle.
Famous Quotes: Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects the struggle between righteousness and injustice.

Sloka (Sanskrit): सञ्जय उवाच। दृष्ट्वा तु पाण्डवानीकं व्यूढं दुर्योधनस्तदा। आचार्यमुपसङ्गम्य राजा वचनमब्रवीत्।।
Sloka (English Translation): Sanjaya said: O King! Having seen the army of the Pandavas arrayed in military formation, King Duryodhana approached his teacher Dronacharya and spoke these words.
Meaning/Interpretation: Highlights how fear clouds judgment.
Famous Quotes: Fear is the path to the dark side. Fear leads to anger, anger leads to hate, hate leads to suffering.
Comparison/Relations: Shows how fear weakens resolve.

Sloka (Sanskrit): पश्यैतां पाण्डुपुत्राणामाचार्य महतीं चमूम्। व्यूढां द्रुपदपुत्रेण तव शिष्येण धीमता।।
Sloka (English Translation): Behold, O teacher, the mighty army of the sons of Pandu, so expertly arranged by your talented disciple, the son of Drupada.
Meaning/Interpretation: Duryodhana tries to provoke Dronacharya.
Famous Quotes: Your enemies are not those who hate you, but those who play with your mind.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects manipulation tactics.

Sloka (Sanskrit): अत्र शूरा महेष्वासा भीमार्जुनसमा युधि। युयुधानो विराटश्च द्रुपदश्च महारथः।।
Sloka (English Translation): Here in this army are many heroic bowmen equal in fighting to Bhima and Arjuna— great fighters like Yuyudhana, Virata, and Drupada.
Meaning/Interpretation: Lists heroic warriors, symbolizing collective strength.
Famous Quotes: The strength of the team is each individual member. The strength of each member is the team.
Comparison/Relations: Highlights teamwork and unity.

Sloka (Sanskrit): धृष्टकेतुश्चेकितानः काशिराजश्च वीर्यवान्। पुरुजित्कुन्तिभोजश्च शैब्यश्च नरपुङ्गवः।।
Sloka (English Translation): There are also the mighty Yudhamanyu, the valiant Uttamaujas, the son of Subhadra, and the sons of Draupadi, all great warriors.
Meaning/Interpretation: Strength lies in unity.
Famous Quotes: Alone we can do so little; together we can do so much.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects collective effort and unity.

Sloka (Sanskrit): युधामन्युश्च विक्रान्त उत्तमौजाश्च वीर्यवान्। सौभद्रो द्रौपदेयाश्च सर्व एव महारथाः।।
Sloka (English Translation): The courageous Yudhamanyu, the valiant Uttamaujas, the son of Subhadra, and the sons of Draupadi—all great chariot warriors.
Meaning/Interpretation: Family bonds and teamwork in battle.
Famous Quotes: Unity is strength... when there is teamwork and collaboration, wonderful things can be achieved.
Comparison/Relations: Shows strength through collaboration.

Sloka (Sanskrit): अस्माकं तु विशिष्टा ये तान्निबोध द्विजोत्तम। नायका मम सैन्यस्य सञ्ज्ञार्थं तान्ब्रवीमि ते।।
Sloka (English Translation): But let me tell you, O best of the Brahmins, about the distinguished leaders of my army. These I now describe for your information.
Meaning/Interpretation: Overconfidence masks fear.
Famous Quotes: Confidence comes not from always being right but from not fearing to be wrong.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects Duryodhana’s fear masked by bravado.

Sloka (Sanskrit): भवान्भीष्मश्च कर्णश्च कृपश्च समितिञ्जयः। अश्वत्थामा विकर्णश्च सौमदत्तिस्तथैव च।।
Sloka (English Translation): There are personalities like yourself, Bhishma, Karna, Kripa, Ashwatthama, Vikarna, and the son of Somadatta who are always victorious in battle.
Meaning/Interpretation: Acknowledges the strength of Duryodhana's army.
Famous Quotes: Strength does not come from physical capacity. It comes from an indomitable will.
Comparison/Relations: Emphasizes inner strength over physical power.

Sloka (Sanskrit): अन्ये च बहवः शूरा मदर्थे त्यक्तजीविताः। नानाशस्त्रप्रहरणाः सर्वे युद्धविशारदाः।।
Sloka (English Translation): There are many other heroes who have risked their lives for me. They are armed with various weapons and all are skilled in warfare.
Meaning/Interpretation: Highlights loyalty and dedication.
Famous Quotes: Loyalty means nothing unless it has at its heart the absolute principle of self-sacrifice.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects the loyalty of soldiers.

Sloka (Sanskrit): अपरीयतं तदस्माकं बलं भीष्माभिरक्षितम्। परीयतं तदस्माकं बलं भीष्माभिरक्षितम्।।
Sloka (English Translation): Our strength is immeasurable and we are perfectly protected by Grandfather Bhishma, whereas the strength of the Pandavas, carefully protected by Bhima, is limited.
Meaning/Interpretation: Overconfidence in one's own power.
Famous Quotes: Overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects Duryodhana's false sense of superiority.

Sloka (Sanskrit): अयनेषु च सर्वेषु यथाभागमवस्थिताः। भीष्ममेवाभिरक्षन्तु भवन्तः सर्व एव हि।।
Sloka (English Translation): All of you must now give full support to Grandfather Bhishma, standing firmly at your respective strategic points in the formation of the army.
Meaning/Interpretation: Emphasizes leadership and strategy.
Famous Quotes: A leader is one who knows the way, goes the way, and shows the way.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects the importance of a leader in battle.

Sloka (Sanskrit): तस्य सञ्जनयन्हर्षं कुरुवृद्धः पितामहः। सिंहनादं विनद्योच्चैः शङ्खं दध्मौ प्रतापवान्।।
Sloka (English Translation): Then Bhishma, the great valiant grandsire of the Kuru dynasty, blew his conchshell very loudly like the sound of a lion, giving Duryodhana joy.
Meaning/Interpretation: Symbolizes the call to battle.
Famous Quotes: Sound the battle cry! Be strong and courageous!
Comparison/Relations: Reflects the war cry’s motivating force.

Sloka (Sanskrit): ततः शङ्खाश्च भेर्यश्च पणवानकगोमुखाः। सहसैवाभ्यहन्यन्त स शब्दस्तुमुलोऽभवत्।।
Sloka (English Translation): After that, conch shells, drums, bugles, trumpets, and horns were all suddenly sounded, and the combined sound was tumultuous.
Meaning/Interpretation: Describes the chaos before the battle.
Famous Quotes: War is only a cowardly escape from the problems of peace.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects the tension and noise of war.

Sloka (Sanskrit): ततः श्वेतैर्हयैर्युक्ते महति स्यन्दने स्थितौ। माधवः पाण्डवश्चैव दिव्यौ शङ्खौ प्रदध्मतुः।।
Sloka (English Translation): Then, seated on a grand chariot drawn by white horses, Lord Krishna and Arjuna blew their divine conch shells.
Meaning/Interpretation: Symbolizes divine guidance and protection.
Famous Quotes: God himself is present with you; do not fear.
Comparison/Relations: Highlights Krishna's divine presence.

Sloka (Sanskrit): पाञ्चजन्यं हृषीकेशो देवदत्तं धनञ्जयः। पौण्ड्रं दध्मौ महाशङ्खं भीमकर्मा वृकोदरः।।
Sloka (English Translation): Hrishikesha (Krishna) blew His conch shell, named Panchajanya; Arjuna blew his, the Devadatta; and Bhima, the voracious eater and performer of Herculean tasks, blew his terrific conch shell named Paundra.
Meaning/Interpretation: Symbolizes the readiness of Krishna and the Pandavas for battle.
Famous Quotes: Bravery is not the absence of fear but the triumph over it.
Comparison/Relations: Highlights the courage of warriors.

Sloka (Sanskrit): अनन्तविजयं राजा कुन्तीपुत्रो युधिष्ठिरः। नकुलः सहदेवश्च सुघोषमणिपुष्पकौ।।
Sloka (English Translation): King Yudhishthira, the son of Kunti, blew his conch shell, the Anantavijaya, while Nakula and Sahadeva blew the Sughosha and Manipushpaka.
Meaning/Interpretation: Showcases unity and preparation.
Famous Quotes: Unity is strength... when there is teamwork and collaboration, wonderful things can be achieved.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects the united front of the Pandavas.

Sloka (Sanskrit): काश्यश्च परमेष्वासः शिखण्डी च महारथः। धृष्टद्युम्नो विराटश्च सात्यकिश्चापराजितः।।
Sloka (English Translation): The great archer King of Kashi, the mighty warrior Shikhandi, Dhrishtadyumna, King Virata, and the unconquerable Satyaki blew their conch shells.
Meaning/Interpretation: Emphasizes the strength of allies.
Famous Quotes: Alone we can do so little; together we can do so much.
Comparison/Relations: Shows the collective strength of the Pandavas’ allies.

Sloka (Sanskrit): द्रुपदो द्रौपदेयाश्च सर्वशः पृथिवीपते। सौभद्रश्च महाबाहुः शङ्खान्दध्मुः पृथक्पृथक्।।
Sloka (English Translation): Drupada, the sons of Draupadi, and the mighty-armed son of Subhadra all blew their respective conch shells, O King.
Meaning/Interpretation: Represents lineage and legacy.
Famous Quotes: He who has no past has no future.
Comparison/Relations: Highlights the strength of familial bonds.

Sloka (Sanskrit): स घोषो धार्तराष्ट्राणां हृदयानि व्यदारयत्। नभश्च पृथिवीं चैव तुमुलोऽभ्यनुनादयन्।।
Sloka (English Translation): The blowing of these conch shells was tumultuous. It shattered the hearts of the sons of Dhritarashtra and echoed through the sky and the earth.
Meaning/Interpretation: Symbolizes fear in the hearts of enemies.
Famous Quotes: Fear is the path to the dark side... it leads to suffering.
Comparison/Relations: Portrays the psychological effect of war.

Sloka (Sanskrit): अथ व्यवस्थितान्दृष्ट्वा धार्तराष्ट्रान्कपिध्वजः। प्रवृत्ते शस्त्रसम्पाते धनुरुद्यम्य पाण्डवः।।
Sloka (English Translation): At that time, Arjuna, whose flag bore the emblem of Hanuman, seeing the sons of Dhritarashtra arrayed for battle, took up his bow and prepared to shoot his arrows.
Meaning/Interpretation: Depicts Arjuna's readiness for battle.
Famous Quotes: Preparedness is the key to success.
Comparison/Relations: Shows Arjuna’s mental and physical preparation.

Sloka (Sanskrit): हृषीकेशं तदा वाक्यमिदमाह महीपते। सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये रथं स्थापय मेऽच्युत।।
Sloka (English Translation): Then, O King, Arjuna spoke to Hrishikesha (Krishna): 'Place my chariot between the two armies.'
Meaning/Interpretation: Marks Arjuna's moment of introspection before battle.
Famous Quotes: Knowing yourself is the beginning of all wisdom.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects Arjuna’s contemplation and inner conflict.

Sloka (Sanskrit): यावदेतान्निरीक्षेऽहं योद्धुकामानवस्थितान्। कैर्मया सह योद्धव्यमस्मिन्रणसमुद्यमे।।
Sloka (English Translation): Let me see those who have come here to fight, wishing to please the evil-minded son of Dhritarashtra.
Meaning/Interpretation: Represents Arjuna's desire to understand his opponents.
Famous Quotes: Know your enemy and know yourself and you can fight a hundred battles without disaster.
Comparison/Relations: Highlights strategic thinking before battle.

Sloka (Sanskrit): योत्स्यमानानवेक्षेऽहं य एतेऽत्र समागताः। धार्तराष्ट्रस्य दुर्बुद्धेर्युद्धे प्रियचिकीर्षवः।।
Sloka (English Translation): I wish to see those who have assembled here to fight on behalf of the evil-minded son of Dhritarashtra.
Meaning/Interpretation: Shows Arjuna's skepticism about the intentions of his opponents.
Famous Quotes: Suspicion always haunts the guilty mind.
Comparison/Relations: Portrays Arjuna's critical thinking.

Sloka (Sanskrit): सञ्जय उवाच एवमुक्तो हृषीकेशो गुडाकेशेन भारत। सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये स्थापयित्वा रथोत्तमम्।।
Sloka (English Translation): Sanjaya said: O King, thus addressed by Arjuna, Hrishikesha (Krishna) placed the magnificent chariot between the two armies.
Meaning/Interpretation: Depicts Krishna's calm response.
Famous Quotes: A calm mind brings inner strength and self-confidence.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects Krishna's composure.

Sloka (Sanskrit): भीष्मद्रोणप्रमुखतः सर्वेषां च महीक्षिताम्। उवाच पार्थ पश्यैतान्समवेतान्कुरूनिति।।
Sloka (English Translation): In front of Bhishma, Drona, and all the other kings, Krishna said: 'Behold, O Arjuna, these assembled Kurus.'
Meaning/Interpretation: Shows Krishna directing Arjuna's gaze.
Famous Quotes: Sometimes you have to look back to see how far you've come.
Comparison/Relations: Emphasizes perspective and awareness.

Sloka (Sanskrit): तत्रापश्यत्स्थितान्पार्थः पितृनथ पितामहान्। आचार्यान्मातुलान्भ्रातृन्पुत्रान्पौत्रान्सखींस्तथा।।
Sloka (English Translation): There, Arjuna saw standing fathers, grandfathers, teachers, uncles, brothers, sons, grandsons, and friends.
Meaning/Interpretation: Represents Arjuna's realization of his personal connections.
Famous Quotes: The strength of a family, like the strength of an army, is in its loyalty to each other.
Comparison/Relations: Highlights emotional conflict.

Sloka (Sanskrit): श्वशुरान्सुहृदश्चैव सेनयोरुभयोरपि। तान्समीक्ष्य स कौन्तेयः सर्वान्बन्धूनवस्थितान्।।
Sloka (English Translation): Arjuna saw fathers-in-law and well-wishers in both armies. Seeing all his kinsmen present there,
Meaning/Interpretation: Depicts Arjuna's turmoil.
Famous Quotes: The heart has reasons that reason does not understand.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects emotional struggle.

Sloka (Sanskrit): कृपया परयाविष्टो विषीदन्निदमब्रवीत्।
Sloka (English Translation): He was overwhelmed with compassion and spoke these words, filled with sorrow.
Meaning/Interpretation: Highlights Arjuna's empathy.
Famous Quotes: Compassion is the basis of morality.
Comparison/Relations: Shows the depth of Arjuna's inner struggle.

Sloka (Sanskrit): दृष्ट्वेमं स्वजनं कृष्ण युयुत्सुं समुपस्थितम्।
Sloka (English Translation): Seeing my own kinsmen, O Krishna, standing and eager for battle,
Meaning/Interpretation: Depicts Arjuna's growing despair.
Famous Quotes: Empathy is about finding echoes of another person in yourself.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects Arjuna's emotional crisis.

Sloka (Sanskrit): सीदन्ति मम गात्राणि मुखं च परिशुष्यति। वेपथुश्च शरीरे मे रोमहर्षश्च जायते।।
Sloka (English Translation): My limbs fail me and my mouth dries up. My body trembles and my hair stands on end.
Meaning/Interpretation: Represents physical symptoms of anxiety.
Famous Quotes: Anxiety does not empty tomorrow of its sorrows, but only empties today of its strength.
Comparison/Relations: Shows the toll of stress.

Sloka (Sanskrit): न च शक्नोम्यवस्थातुं भ्रमतीव च मे मनः। निमित्तानि च पश्यामि विपरीतानि केशव।।
Sloka (English Translation): I am unable to stand and my mind seems to whirl. I see adverse omens, O Keshava.
Meaning/Interpretation: Depicts Arjuna's mental turmoil.
Famous Quotes: Fear is the path to the dark side. Fear leads to anger, anger leads to hate, hate leads to suffering.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects fear clouding judgment.

Sloka (Sanskrit): न च श्रेयोऽनुपश्यामि हत्वा स्वजनमाहवे। न काङ्क्षे विजयं कृष्ण न च राज्यं सुखानि च।।
Sloka (English Translation): I see no good in killing my kinsmen in battle, O Krishna. I desire neither victory, kingdom, nor pleasures.
Meaning/Interpretation: Highlights Arjuna's internal conflict about war.
Famous Quotes: It is not power that corrupts but fear.
Comparison/Relations: Explores the cost of violence.

Sloka (Sanskrit): किं नो राज्येन गोविन्द किं भोगैर्जीवितेन वा। येषामर्थे काङ्क्षितं नो राज्यं भोगाः सुखानि च।।
Sloka (English Translation): Of what avail is a kingdom, happiness, or even life itself, O Govinda, when those for whom we desire them stand here in battle?
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna questions the purpose of power.
Famous Quotes: What shall it profit a man if he gains the whole world, but loses his soul?
Comparison/Relations: Reflects moral dilemmas.

Sloka (Sanskrit): त इमेऽवस्थिता युद्धे प्राणांस्त्यक्त्वा धनानि च। आचार्याः पितरः पुत्रास्तथैव च पितामहाः।।
Sloka (English Translation): Teachers, fathers, sons, and grandfathers stand in battle, ready to give up their lives and riches.
Meaning/Interpretation: Emphasizes the tragedy of fighting loved ones.
Famous Quotes: War does not determine who is right — only who is left.
Comparison/Relations: Reveals the sorrow of war.

Sloka (Sanskrit): मातुलाः श्वशुराः पौत्राः श्यालाः सम्बन्धिनस्तथा। एतान्न हन्तुमिच्छामि घ्नतोऽपि मधुसूदन।।
Sloka (English Translation): Uncles, fathers-in-law, grandsons, brothers-in-law, and other relatives — I do not wish to kill them, even if they kill me, O Madhusudana.
Meaning/Interpretation: Shows Arjuna's compassion.
Famous Quotes: An eye for an eye will only make the whole world blind.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects non-violence.

Sloka (Sanskrit): अपि त्रैलोक्यराज्यस्य हेतोः किं नु महीकृते। निहत्य धार्तराष्ट्रान्नः का प्रीतिः स्याज्जनार्दन।।
Sloka (English Translation): Even for the sake of dominion over the three worlds, I do not wish to kill the sons of Dhritarashtra — how then for the earth alone?
Meaning/Interpretation: Questions the value of power.
Famous Quotes: Better than a thousand hollow words is one word that brings peace.
Comparison/Relations: Promotes peace over conquest.

Sloka (Sanskrit): पापमेवाश्रयेदस्मान्हत्वैतानाततायिनः। तस्मान्नार्हा वयं हन्तुं धार्तराष्ट्रान्स्वबान्धवान्।।
Sloka (English Translation): Sin alone will befall us if we kill these aggressors. Therefore, it is not right for us to kill the sons of Dhritarashtra.
Meaning/Interpretation: Reflects Arjuna's moral struggle.
Famous Quotes: Conscience is a man’s compass.
Comparison/Relations: Highlights the conflict between duty and morality.

Sloka (Sanskrit): स्वजनं हि कथं हत्वा सुखिनः स्याम माधव।
Sloka (English Translation): How can we be happy, O Madhava, by killing our own kinsmen?
Meaning/Interpretation: Emphasizes Arjuna's empathy.
Famous Quotes: There is no greater agony than bearing an untold story inside you.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects sorrow.

Sloka (Sanskrit): यद्यप्येते न पश्यन्ति लोभोपहतचेतसः। कुलक्षयकृतं दोषं मित्रद्रोहे च पातकम्।।
Sloka (English Translation): Though these, whose minds are overpowered by greed, see no fault in destroying families and no crime in treachery,
Meaning/Interpretation: Condemns greed and treachery.
Famous Quotes: Greed is a bottomless pit which exhausts the person in an endless effort to satisfy the need without ever reaching satisfaction.
Comparison/Relations: Warns against blind ambition.

Sloka (Sanskrit): कुलक्षये प्रणश्यन्ति कुलधर्माः सनातनाः। धर्मे नष्टे कुलं कृत्स्नमधर्मोऽभिभवत्युत।।
Sloka (English Translation): With the destruction of the family, the eternal family traditions perish; and when virtue is lost, vice overcomes the entire family.
Meaning/Interpretation: Describes the consequences of abandoning tradition.
Famous Quotes: Tradition is not the worship of ashes, but the preservation of fire.
Comparison/Relations: Speaks about the importance of preserving values.

Sloka (Sanskrit): अधर्माभिभवात्कृष्ण प्रदुष्यन्ति कुलस्त्रियः। स्त्रीषु दुष्टासु वार्ष्णेय जायते वर्णसंकरः।।
Sloka (English Translation): When vice prevails, O Krishna, the women of the family become corrupt; and from the corruption of women, O Varshneya, arises intermixture of castes.
Meaning/Interpretation: Warns against moral decay in society.
Famous Quotes: It is easier to build strong children than to repair broken men.
Comparison/Relations: Highlights the need to uphold moral integrity.

Sloka (Sanskrit): संकरो नरकायैव कुलघ्नानां कुलस्य च। पतन्ति पितरो ह्येषां लुप्तपिण्डोदकक्रियाः।।
Sloka (English Translation): Such intermixture leads the family and the destroyers of the family to hell; for their ancestors fall, deprived of offerings of food and water.
Meaning/Interpretation: Describes spiritual consequences of moral degradation.
Famous Quotes: The only thing necessary for the triumph of evil is for good men to do nothing.
Comparison/Relations: Warns about inaction against moral corruption.

Sloka (Sanskrit): दोषैरेतैः कुलघ्नानां वर्णसंकरकारकैः। उत्साद्यन्ते जातिधर्माः कुलधर्माश्च शाश्वताः।।
Sloka (English Translation): By these misdeeds of the family destroyers, which cause caste intermixture, the eternal traditions of race and family are uprooted.
Meaning/Interpretation: Highlights the loss of cultural heritage.
Famous Quotes: Heritage is our legacy from the past, what we live with today, and what we pass on to future generations.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects the impact of losing cultural values.

Sloka (Sanskrit): उत्सन्नकुलधर्माणां मनुष्याणां जनार्दन। नरकेऽनियतं वासो भवतीत्यनुशुश्रुम।।
Sloka (English Translation): We have heard, O Janardana, that those whose family traditions are destroyed, dwell in hell for an indefinite period.
Meaning/Interpretation: Speaks about the aftermath of forsaking duty.
Famous Quotes: He who has no discipline can never enjoy freedom.
Comparison/Relations: Connects discipline to moral order.

Sloka (Sanskrit): अहो बत महत्पापं कर्तुं व्यवसिता वयम्। यद्राज्यसुखलोभेन हन्तुं स्वजनमुद्यताः।।
Sloka (English Translation): Alas! We have resolved to commit a great sin by being ready to kill our own kinsmen for the greed of the pleasures of a kingdom.
Meaning/Interpretation: Depicts Arjuna's remorse.
Famous Quotes: Greed is not a financial issue. It’s a heart issue.
Comparison/Relations: Warns about the perils of greed.

Sloka (Sanskrit): यदि मामप्रतीकारमशस्त्रं शस्त्रपाणयः। धार्तराष्ट्रा रणे हन्युस्तन्मे क्षेमतरं भवेत्।।
Sloka (English Translation): If the sons of Dhritarashtra, weapons in hand, slay me unresisting and unarmed in battle, that would be better for me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Conveys Arjuna's preference for peace over war.
Famous Quotes: It is not how the world is, it is how we see it.
Comparison/Relations: Suggests perception shapes actions.

Sloka (Sanskrit): सञ्जय उवाच। एवमुक्त्वार्जुनः सङ्ख्ये रथोपस्थ उपाविशत्। विसृज्य सशरं चापं शोकसंविग्नमानसः।।
Sloka (English Translation): Sanjaya said: Having spoken thus in the midst of the battlefield, Arjuna cast aside his bow and arrows and sat down on the chariot, his mind overwhelmed with grief.
Meaning/Interpretation: Describes Arjuna's surrender to despair.
Famous Quotes: He who has a why to live can bear almost any how.
Comparison/Relations: Highlights the need for purpose in hardship.

Sloka (Sanskrit): सञ्जय उवाच। तं तथा कृपयाविष्टमश्रुपूर्णाकुलेक्षणम्। विषीदन्तमिदं वाक्यमुवाच मधुसूदनः।।
Sloka (English Translation): Sanjaya said: Seeing Arjuna overwhelmed with compassion, sorrowful, and his eyes brimming with tears, Madhusudana spoke these words.
Meaning/Interpretation: Describes Arjuna's emotional turmoil.
Famous Quotes: Tears shed for self are tears of weakness, but tears shed for others are a sign of strength.
Comparison/Relations: Highlights the strength in empathy.

Sloka (Sanskrit): श्रीभगवानुवाच। कुतस्त्वा कश्मलमिदं विषमे समुपस्थितम्। अनार्यजुष्टमस्वर्ग्यमकीर्तिकरमर्जुन।।
Sloka (English Translation): The Blessed Lord said: Arjuna, how has this delusion overtaken you at this crucial moment? It is unworthy of an honorable person, does not lead to heaven, and brings infamy.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna rebukes Arjuna's despair.
Famous Quotes: It is not what happens to you, but how you react to it that matters.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects resilience in adversity.

Sloka (Sanskrit): क्लैब्यं मा स्म गमः पार्थ नैतत्तवयुपपद्यते। क्षुद्रं हृदयदौर्बल्यं त्यक्त्वोत्तिष्ठ परन्तप।।
Sloka (English Translation): Do not yield to unmanliness, O Partha! It does not befit you. Shake off this base faint-heartedness and arise, O scorcher of enemies!
Meaning/Interpretation: Urges Arjuna to rise above his weakness.
Famous Quotes: Strength does not come from physical capacity. It comes from an indomitable will.
Comparison/Relations: Encourages mental fortitude.

Sloka (Sanskrit): अर्जुन उवाच। कथं भीष्ममहं सङ्ख्ये द्रोणं च मधुसूदन। इषुभिः प्रतियोत्स्यामि पूजार्हावरिसूदन।।
Sloka (English Translation): Arjuna said: O Madhusudana! How shall I strike Bhishma and Drona with arrows in battle, for they are worthy of my worship?
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna's moral conflict.
Famous Quotes: Respect for the truth comes close to being the basis for all morality.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects Arjuna's moral struggle.

Sloka (Sanskrit): गुरूनहत्वा हि महानुभावान्। श्रेयो भोक्तुं भैक्ष्यमपीह लोके। हत्वार्थकामांस्तु गुरूनिहैव। भुञ्जीय भोगान् रुधिरप्रदिग्धान्।।
Sloka (English Translation): It is better to live in this world by begging than to kill these great souls, my teachers. If I kill them, all my worldly pleasures will be tainted with their blood.
Meaning/Interpretation: Expresses Arjuna's dilemma about violence.
Famous Quotes: He who conquers others is strong; he who conquers himself is mighty.
Comparison/Relations: Speaks about self-control.

Sloka (Sanskrit): न चैतद्विद्मः कतरन्नो गरीयो। यद्वा जयेम यदि वा नो जयेयुः। यान एव हत्वा न जिजीविषामः। तेऽवस्थिताः प्रमुखे धार्तराष्ट्राः।।
Sloka (English Translation): We do not know which is better — to conquer them or be conquered by them. The sons of Dhritarashtra stand before us, and killing them, we would not wish to live.
Meaning/Interpretation: Conveys Arjuna's uncertainty.
Famous Quotes: In the middle of difficulty lies opportunity.
Comparison/Relations: Points to the struggle of tough decisions.

Sloka (Sanskrit): कार्पण्यदोषोपहतस्वभावः। पृच्छामि त्वां धर्मसंमूढचेताः। यच्छ्रेयः स्यान्निश्चितं ब्रूहि तन्मे। शिष्यस्तेऽहं शाधि मां त्वां प्रपन्नम्।।
Sloka (English Translation): My nature is overcome by a sense of helplessness. I ask You, tell me clearly what is best for me. I am Your disciple; instruct me, I have taken refuge in You.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna surrenders to Krishna's wisdom.
Famous Quotes: He who opens a school door, closes a prison.
Comparison/Relations: Highlights seeking guidance.

Sloka (Sanskrit): न हि प्रपश्यामि ममापनुद्याद्। यच्छोकमुछोषणमिन्द्रियाणाम्। अवाप्य भूमावसपत्नमृद्धम्। राज्यं सुराणामपि चाधिपत्यम्।।
Sloka (English Translation): I do not see anything that can drive away this sorrow which is drying up my senses, not even if I were to obtain an unrivaled and prosperous kingdom on earth, or sovereignty like the gods in heaven.
Meaning/Interpretation: Expresses Arjuna's despair.
Famous Quotes: Despair is the price one pays for setting oneself an impossible aim.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects the burden of hopelessness.

Sloka (Sanskrit): सञ्जय उवाच। एवमुक्त्वा हृषीकेशं गुडाकेशः परन्तप। न योत्स्य इति गोविन्दमुक्त्वा तूष्णीं बभूव ह।।
Sloka (English Translation): Sanjaya said: Having spoken thus to Hrishikesha, Arjuna (Gudakesha), the conqueror of sleep, declared 'I shall not fight,' and became silent.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna's withdrawal from battle.
Famous Quotes: Silence is a source of great strength.
Comparison/Relations: Emphasizes the power of silence.

Sloka (Sanskrit): तमुवाच हृषीकेशः प्रहसन्निव भारत। सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये विषीदन्तमिदं वचः।।
Sloka (English Translation): Hrishikesha (Krishna) spoke these words, smiling as it were, O Bharata, to the despondent Arjuna in the midst of the two armies.
Meaning/Interpretation: Introduces Krishna's guidance.
Famous Quotes: A smile is the universal welcome.
Comparison/Relations: Hints at Krishna's comforting presence.

Sloka (Sanskrit): श्रीभगवानुवाच। अशोच्यानन्वशोचस्त्वं प्रज्ञावादांश्च भाषसे। गतासूनगतासूंश्च नानुशोचन्ति पण्डिताः।।
Sloka (English Translation): The Blessed Lord said: You grieve for those who should not be grieved for, yet speak words of wisdom. The wise lament neither for the living nor the dead.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna rebukes Arjuna for misplaced sorrow.
Famous Quotes: He who has overcome his fears will truly be free.
Comparison/Relations: Teaches detachment from sorrow.

Sloka (Sanskrit): न त्वेवाहं जातु नासं न त्वं नेमे जनाधिपाः। न चैव न भविष्यामः सर्वे वयमतः परम्।।
Sloka (English Translation): Never was there a time when I did not exist, nor you, nor these kings; nor will any of us cease to exist in the future.
Meaning/Interpretation: Emphasizes the eternal nature of the soul.
Famous Quotes: Death is not extinguishing the light; it is only putting out the lamp because the dawn has come.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects on the immortality of the soul.

Sloka (Sanskrit): देहिनोऽस्मिन्यथा देहे कौमारं यौवनं जरा। तथा देहान्तरप्राप्तिर्धीरस्तत्र न मुह्यति।।
Sloka (English Translation): Just as the soul passes from childhood to youth to old age in this body, it similarly passes into another body after death. The wise are not deluded by this.
Meaning/Interpretation: Describes the soul's journey.
Famous Quotes: What we call the beginning is often the end. And to make an end is to make a beginning.
Comparison/Relations: Reinforces the cycle of life.

Sloka (Sanskrit): मात्रास्पर्शास्तु कौन्तेय शीतोष्णसुखदुःखदाः। आगमापायिनोऽनित्यास्तांस्तितिक्षस्व भारत।।
Sloka (English Translation): O son of Kunti, the contact between the senses and their objects gives rise to fleeting experiences of happiness and distress. Endure them bravely, O Bharata.
Meaning/Interpretation: Urges tolerance of sensory experiences.
Famous Quotes: Pain is inevitable. Suffering is optional.
Comparison/Relations: Encourages inner strength.

Sloka (Sanskrit): यं हि न व्यथयन्त्येते पुरुषं पुरुषर्षभ। समदुःखसुखं धीरं सोऽमृतत्वाय कल्पते।।
Sloka (English Translation): The person who is not disturbed by happiness and distress, and remains steady in both, becomes eligible for liberation.
Meaning/Interpretation: Defines the path to liberation.
Famous Quotes: Happiness depends upon ourselves.
Comparison/Relations: Points to inner equilibrium.

Sloka (Sanskrit): नासतो विद्यते भावो नाभावो विद्यते सतः। उभयोरपि दृष्टोऽन्तस्त्वनयोस्तत्त्वदर्शिभिः।।
Sloka (English Translation): The unreal has no existence, and the real never ceases to be; the seers of truth have concluded the same.
Meaning/Interpretation: Differentiates reality and illusion.
Famous Quotes: Reality is that which, when you stop believing in it, doesn’t go away.
Comparison/Relations: Explores eternal truths.

Sloka (Sanskrit): अविनाशि तु तद्विद्धि येन सर्वमिदं ततम्। विनाशमव्ययस्यास्य न कश्चित्कर्तुमर्हति।।
Sloka (English Translation): Know that which pervades the entire body is indestructible. No one can destroy the imperishable soul.
Meaning/Interpretation: Asserts the soul's indestructibility.
Famous Quotes: The soul is placed in the body like a rough diamond, and must be polished.
Comparison/Relations: Strengthens belief in the eternal soul.

Sloka (Sanskrit): अन्तवन्त इमे देहा नित्यस्योक्ता: शरीरिणः। अनाशिनोऽप्रमेयस्य तस्माद्युध्यस्व भारत।।
Sloka (English Translation): These bodies of the eternal, indestructible, and immeasurable soul are perishable. Therefore, fight, O Bharata.
Meaning/Interpretation: Encourages action with detachment.
Famous Quotes: Action is the foundational key to all success.
Comparison/Relations: Highlights the need for righteous action.

Sloka (Sanskrit): य एनं वेत्ति हन्तारं यश्चैनं मन्यते हतम्। उभौ तौ न विजानीतो नायं हन्ति न हन्यते।।
Sloka (English Translation): He who thinks the soul can kill or be killed is ignorant; the soul neither kills nor is killed.
Meaning/Interpretation: Dispels confusion about the soul's mortality.
Famous Quotes: Fear is the mind-killer.
Comparison/Relations: Breaks the illusion of fear.

Sloka (Sanskrit): न जायते म्रियते वा कदाचिन्। नायं भूत्वा भविता वा न भूयः। अजो नित्यः शाश्वतोऽयं पुराणो। न हन्यते हन्यमाने शरीरे।।
Sloka (English Translation): The soul is neither born, nor does it ever die; having once existed, it never ceases to be. The soul is unborn, eternal, ever-existing, and primeval. It is not slain when the body is slain.
Meaning/Interpretation: Reinforces the soul's eternity.
Famous Quotes: Nothing real can be threatened. Nothing unreal exists.
Comparison/Relations: Asserts the unchanging nature of the soul.

Sloka (Sanskrit): वेधमिष्टमयं सद्भिः प्रणिपातेन सेवया। उपदेक्ष्यन्ति ते ज्ञानं ज्ञानिनस्तत्त्वदर्शिनः।।
Sloka (English Translation): Approach those who have realized the truth. Inquire from them with reverence, serve them, and they will impart wisdom to you.
Meaning/Interpretation: Encourages seeking wisdom from the enlightened.
Famous Quotes: The only true wisdom is in knowing you know nothing.
Comparison/Relations: Highlights humility in acquiring knowledge.

Sloka (Sanskrit): न त्वं नाहं जातु नासं न त्वं नेमे जनाधिपाः। न चैव न भविष्यामः सर्वे वयमतः परम्।।
Sloka (English Translation): There was never a time when I did not exist, nor you, nor these kings; nor will any of us cease to exist in the future.
Meaning/Interpretation: Affirms the soul's eternal existence.
Famous Quotes: What we call the beginning is often the end. And to make an end is to make a beginning.
Comparison/Relations: Reinforces the concept of eternal life.

Sloka (Sanskrit): वासांसि जीर्णानि यथा विहाय नवानि गृह्णाति नरोऽपराणि। तथा शरीराणि विहाय जीर्णान्यन्यानि संयाति नवानि देही।।
Sloka (English Translation): Just as a person sheds worn-out clothes and wears new ones, so does the soul cast off its worn-out body and enters a new one.
Meaning/Interpretation: Describes reincarnation vividly.
Famous Quotes: Change is the only constant in life.
Comparison/Relations: Underlines the cycle of rebirth.

Sloka (Sanskrit): नैनं छिन्दन्ति शस्त्राणि नैनं दहति पावकः। न चैनं क्लेदयन्त्यापो न शोषयति मारुतः।।
Sloka (English Translation): Weapons cannot cut the soul, nor can fire burn it; water cannot wet it, nor can wind dry it.
Meaning/Interpretation: Explains the soul's invulnerability.
Famous Quotes: The soul is stronger than its surroundings.
Comparison/Relations: Emphasizes the soul's strength.

Sloka (Sanskrit): अच्छेद्योऽयमदाह्योऽयमक्लेद्योऽशोष्य एव च। नित्यः सर्वगतः स्थाणुरचलोऽयं सनातनः।।
Sloka (English Translation): The soul is unbreakable, cannot be burned, dissolved, or dried. It is everlasting, omnipresent, unchangeable, and eternal.
Meaning/Interpretation: Describes the indestructible soul.
Famous Quotes: Nothing real can be threatened. Nothing unreal exists.
Comparison/Relations: Affirms the soul's permanence.

Sloka (Sanskrit): अव्यक्तोऽयमचिन्त्योऽयमविकार्योऽयमुच्यते। तस्मादेवं विदित्वैनं नानुशोचितुमर्हसि।।
Sloka (English Translation): The soul is said to be unmanifest, inconceivable, and immutable. Knowing this, you should not grieve.
Meaning/Interpretation: Stresses that the soul transcends human perception.
Famous Quotes: Grief never ends, but it changes.
Comparison/Relations: Encourages acceptance.

Sloka (Sanskrit): अथ चैनं नित्यजातं नित्यं वा मन्यसे मृतम्। तथापि त्वं महाबाहो नैनं शोचितुमर्हसि।।
Sloka (English Translation): Even if you think of the soul as constantly being born and dying, still, you should not grieve.
Meaning/Interpretation: Argues against sorrow, regardless of belief.
Famous Quotes: Life is a cycle of beginnings and endings.
Comparison/Relations: Acknowledges cyclical life views.

Sloka (Sanskrit): जातस्य हि ध्रुवो मृत्युर्ध्रुवं जन्म मृतस्य च। तस्मादपरिहार्येऽर्थे न त्वं शोचितुमर्हसि।।
Sloka (English Translation): For one who is born, death is certain; and for one who has died, rebirth is inevitable. Therefore, you should not lament the inevitable.
Meaning/Interpretation: Explains the law of birth and death.
Famous Quotes: Death is not the opposite of life, but a part of it.
Comparison/Relations: Reinforces the natural cycle.

Sloka (Sanskrit): अव्यक्तादीनि भूतानि व्यक्तमध्यानि भारत। अव्यक्तनिधनान्येव तत्र का परिदेवना।।
Sloka (English Translation): All beings are unmanifest before birth and after death, they are unmanifest again. Only in the interim do they manifest. Why then the grief?
Meaning/Interpretation: Questions the logic of mourning.
Famous Quotes: Why should we grieve for what is inevitable?
Comparison/Relations: Strengthens stoic thought.

Sloka (Sanskrit): आश्चर्यवत्पश्यति कश्चिदेनमाश्चर्यवद्वदति तथैव चान्यः। आश्चर्यवच्चैनमन्यः श
Sloka (English Translation): Some see the soul as amazing, others speak of it as amazing, and some hear of it as amazing, yet none truly knows it.
Meaning/Interpretation: Describes the soul's mystique.
Famous Quotes: The soul is a mystery that even wisdom cannot unravel.
Comparison/Relations: Praises the soul’s profundity.

Sloka (Sanskrit): स्वधर्ममपि चावेक्ष्य न विकम्पितुमर्हसि। धर्म्याद्धि युद्धाच्छ्रेयोऽन्यत्क्षत्रियस्य न विद्यते।।
Sloka (English Translation): Considering your dharma, you should not waver. For a warrior, there is nothing more honorable than a righteous war.
Meaning/Interpretation: Encourages fulfilling one’s duty.
Famous Quotes: It is not what we do, but also what we do not do, for which we are accountable.
Comparison/Relations: Stresses duty and accountability.

Sloka (Sanskrit): यदृच्छया चोपपन्नं स्वर्गद्वारमपावृतम्। सुखिनः क्षत्रियाः पार्थ लभन्ते युद्धमीदृशम्।।
Sloka (English Translation): Fortunate are the warriors who achieve such an opportunity for a righteous battle, which opens the gates of heaven.
Meaning/Interpretation: Describes duty as a path to higher realms.
Famous Quotes: Fortune favors the brave.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects courage in duty.

Sloka (Sanskrit): अथ चेत्त्वमिमं धर्म्यं संग्रामं न करिष्यसि। ततः स्वधर्मं कीर्तिं च हित्वा पापमवाप्स्यसि।।
Sloka (English Translation): But if you do not fight this righteous war, abandoning your duty and honor, you will incur sin.
Meaning/Interpretation: Warns against abandoning duty.
Famous Quotes: Honor is the reward of virtue.
Comparison/Relations: Links duty to moral integrity.

Sloka (Sanskrit): अकीर्तिं चापि भूतानि कथयिष्यन्ति तेऽव्ययाम्। सम्भावितस्य चाकीर्तिर्मरणादतिरिच्यते।।
Sloka (English Translation): People will speak unendingly of your disgrace, and for a person of honor, dishonor is worse than death.
Meaning/Interpretation: Emphasizes reputation and honor.
Famous Quotes: Reputation is an idle and most false imposition.
Comparison/Relations: Draws attention to honor and disgrace.

Sloka (Sanskrit): भयाद्रणादुपरतं मंस्यन्ते त्वां महारथाः। येषां च त्वं बहुमतो भूत्वा यास्यसि लाघवम्।।
Sloka (English Translation): The great warriors will think you withdrew from battle out of fear, and those who once respected you will now hold you in contempt.
Meaning/Interpretation: Highlights the importance of courage.
Famous Quotes: Courage is resistance to fear, mastery of fear—not absence of fear.
Comparison/Relations: Encourages bravery.

Sloka (Sanskrit): अवाच्यवादांश्च बहून्वदिष्यन्ति तवाहिताः। निन्दन्तस्तव सामर्थ्यं ततो दुःखतरं नु किम्।।
Sloka (English Translation): Your enemies will mock your strength and speak ill of you. What could be more painful than this?
Meaning/Interpretation: Warns against the pain of dishonor.
Famous Quotes: Our enemies' opinion matters not; our own conscience does.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects on inner strength.

Sloka (Sanskrit): हतो वा प्राप्स्यसि स्वर्गं जित्वा वा भोक्ष्यसे महीम्। तस्मादुत्तिष्ठ कौन्तेय युद्धाय कृतनिश्चयः।।
Sloka (English Translation): If you die, you will attain heaven; if you win, you will enjoy the earth. Therefore, rise and fight with determination.
Meaning/Interpretation: Urges decisive action.
Famous Quotes: Victory belongs to the most persevering.
Comparison/Relations: Promotes unwavering resolve.

Sloka (Sanskrit): सुखदुःखे समे कृत्वा लाभालाभौ जयाजयौ। ततो युद्धाय युज्यस्व नैवं पापमवाप्स्यसि।।
Sloka (English Translation): Be equanimous in pleasure and pain, gain and loss, victory and defeat. Engage in battle without incurring sin.
Meaning/Interpretation: Stresses emotional balance.
Famous Quotes: Equanimity arises when we accept the way things are.
Comparison/Relations: Teaches balance and acceptance.

Sloka (Sanskrit): एषा तेऽभिहिता साङ्ख्ये बुद्धिर्योगे त्विमां श्रृणु। बुद्ध्यायुक्तो यया पार्थ कर्मबन्धं प्रहास्यसि।।
Sloka (English Translation): I have explained to you the knowledge of Sankhya philosophy. Now listen to the knowledge of Yoga, by which you can break free from karma.
Meaning/Interpretation: Introduces the concept of Karma Yoga.
Famous Quotes: Yoga is the journey of the self, through the self, to the self.
Comparison/Relations: Explains liberation through action.

Sloka (Sanskrit): नेहाभिक्रमनाशोऽस्ति प्रत्यवायो न विद्यते। स्वल्पमप्यस्य धर्मस्य त्रायते महतो भयात्।।
Sloka (English Translation): In this path, there is no loss or adverse result. Even a little practice of this dharma saves one from great fear.
Meaning/Interpretation: Affirms the safety of spiritual practice.
Famous Quotes: Every step taken in the right direction brings you closer to your goal.
Comparison/Relations: Motivates steady effort.

Sloka (Sanskrit): व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिरेकेह कुरुनन्दन। बहुशाखा ह्यनन्ताश्च बुद्धयोऽव्यवसायिनाम्।।
Sloka (English Translation): O descendent of the Kuru dynasty, those who are resolute in purpose have one-pointed intelligence, but the intellect of the irresolute is many-branched.
Meaning/Interpretation: Stresses the importance of resolute focus.
Famous Quotes: Concentration is the secret of strength.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects focused determination.

Sloka (Sanskrit): यामिमां पुष्पितां वाचं प्रवदन्त्यविपश्चितः। वेदवादरताः पार्थ नान्यदस्तीति वादिनः।।
Sloka (English Translation): Unwise people speak flowery words, attached to the Vedas' rituals, claiming there is nothing else.
Meaning/Interpretation: Criticizes superficial knowledge.
Famous Quotes: Beware of false knowledge; it is more dangerous than ignorance.
Comparison/Relations: Warns against shallow understanding.

Sloka (Sanskrit): कामात्मानः स्वर्गपरा जन्मकर्मफलप्रदाम्। क्रियाविशेषबहुलां भोगैश्वर्यगतिं प्रति।।
Sloka (English Translation): Desiring sense pleasures and heaven, they indulge in many rituals to obtain enjoyments and power.
Meaning/Interpretation: Warns against materialistic desires.
Famous Quotes: Materialism coarsens life.
Comparison/Relations: Critiques excessive attachment to material gains.

Sloka (Sanskrit): भोगैश्वर्यप्रसक्तानां तयापहृतचेतसाम्। व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिः समाधौ न विधीयते।।
Sloka (English Translation): The minds of those attached to pleasure and wealth are carried away, and they lack resolute intellect.
Meaning/Interpretation: Emphasizes the danger of attachment.
Famous Quotes: Wealth consists not in having great possessions, but in having few wants.
Comparison/Relations: Teaches contentment over greed.

Sloka (Sanskrit): त्रैगुण्यविषया वेदा निस्त्रैगुण्यो भवार्जुन। निर्द्वन्द्वो नित्यसत्त्वस्थो निर्योगक्षेम आत्मवान्।।
Sloka (English Translation): The Vedas deal with the three modes of material nature. Transcend these modes, O Arjuna.
Meaning/Interpretation: Advises transcending material nature.
Famous Quotes: True wealth lies in freedom from desire.
Comparison/Relations: Encourages spiritual elevation.

Sloka (Sanskrit): यावानर्थ उदपाने सर्वतः सम्प्लुतोदके। तावान्सर्वेषु वेदेषु ब्राह्मणस्य विजानतः।।
Sloka (English Translation): All purposes served by a small well are equally served by a vast lake. A Brahmin who knows the Absolute sees the Vedas in this light.
Meaning/Interpretation: Promotes broad spiritual wisdom.
Famous Quotes: True knowledge is like an ocean, not a puddle.
Comparison/Relations: Encourages depth of wisdom.

Sloka (Sanskrit): कर्मण्येवाधिकारस्ते मा फलेषु कदाचन। मा कर्मफलहेतुर्भूर्मा ते सङ्गोऽस्त्वकर्मणि।।
Sloka (English Translation): You have a right to perform your duties, but never to the fruits of your actions. Do not be attached to the results, nor be idle.
Meaning/Interpretation: Stresses performing duty selflessly.
Famous Quotes: Do your work, but never be attached to its results.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects karma yoga principles.

Sloka (Sanskrit): योगस्थः कुरु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा धनञ्जय। सिद्ध्यसिद्ध्योः समो भूत्वा समत्वं योग उच्यते।।
Sloka (English Translation): Perform your duty with equanimity, abandoning attachment. Success and failure are the same — this is yoga.
Meaning/Interpretation: Defines yoga as balance.
Famous Quotes: Yoga is the art of awareness on the canvas of body, mind, and soul.
Comparison/Relations: Connects yoga to inner balance.

Sloka (Sanskrit): दूरेण ह्यवरं कर्म बुद्धियोगाद्धनञ्जय। बुद्धौ शरणमन्विच्छ कृपणाः फलहेतवः।।
Sloka (English Translation): O Arjuna, action guided by wisdom is superior to mere ritualistic actions. Seek refuge in this wisdom.
Meaning/Interpretation: Encourages wisdom-driven action.
Famous Quotes: Wisdom is the power to put our time and knowledge to proper use.
Comparison/Relations: Promotes thoughtful effort.

Sloka (Sanskrit): बुद्धियुक्तो जहातीह उभे सुकृतदुष्कृते। तस्माद्योगाय युज्यस्व योगः कर्मसु कौशलम्।।
Sloka (English Translation): The wise abandon both good and evil deeds in this life. Therefore, practice yoga — it is the art of work.
Meaning/Interpretation: Connects yoga with skillful action.
Famous Quotes: Skill is the unified force of experience, intellect, and passion.
Comparison/Relations: Links yoga to excellence.

Sloka (Sanskrit): कर्मजं बुद्धियुक्ता हि फलं त्यक्त्वा मनीषिणः। जन्मबन्धविनिर्मुक्ताः पदं गच्छन्त्यनामयम्।।
Sloka (English Translation): Endowed with wisdom, renouncing the fruits of actions, the wise are freed from the bondage of birth and attain the blissful state.
Meaning/Interpretation: Highlights freedom through detachment from results.
Famous Quotes: Freedom is not worth having if it does not include the freedom to make mistakes.
Comparison/Relations: Connects wisdom with liberation.

Sloka (Sanskrit): यदा ते मोहकलिलं बुद्धिर्व्यतितरिष्यति। तदा गन्तासि निर्वेदं श्रोतव्यस्य श्रुतस्य च।।
Sloka (English Translation): When your intellect crosses beyond the confusion of illusion, you will become indifferent to all that has been heard and all that is yet to be heard.
Meaning/Interpretation: Encourages overcoming illusion through intellect.
Famous Quotes: Truth is ever to be found in simplicity, and not in the multiplicity and confusion of things.
Comparison/Relations: Promotes clarity of thought.

Sloka (Sanskrit): श्रुतिविप्रतिपन्ना ते यदा स्थास्यति निश्चला। समाधावचला बुद्धिस्तदा योगमवाप्स्यसि।।
Sloka (English Translation): When your mind is unwavering and steady in meditation, beyond the conflicting teachings, you will attain the path of true yoga.
Meaning/Interpretation: Describes unwavering focus in yoga.
Famous Quotes: Meditation brings wisdom; lack of meditation leaves ignorance.
Comparison/Relations: Encourages mental stability.

Sloka (Sanskrit): अर्जुन उवाच स्थितप्रज्ञस्य का भाषा समाधिस्थस्य केशव। स्थितधीः किं प्रभाषेत किमासीत व्रजेत किम्।।
Sloka (English Translation): Arjuna said: O Keshava, what are the signs of one whose mind is steady and merged in deep meditation? How does such a person speak, sit, and walk?
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna inquires about a wise person's qualities.
Famous Quotes: A wise man never loses his self-control.
Comparison/Relations: Seeks the attributes of a wise person.

Sloka (Sanskrit): श्रीभगवानुवाच प्रजहाति यदा कामान्सर्वान्पार्थ मनोगतान्। आत्मन्येवात्मना तुष्टः स्थितप्रज्ञस्तदोच्यते।।
Sloka (English Translation): The Blessed Lord said: When one discards all selfish desires and cravings of the mind and is content within the self, that person is called a sage of steady wisdom.
Meaning/Interpretation: Defines a wise person as free from desire.
Famous Quotes: He who is contented is rich.
Comparison/Relations: Describes inner contentment.

Sloka (Sanskrit): दुःखेष्वनुद्विग्नमना: सुखेषु विगतस्पृहः। वीतरागभयक्रोधः स्थितधीर्मुनिरुच्यते।।
Sloka (English Translation): One whose mind remains undisturbed by sorrow, who is free from desire for pleasure, and who is without fear and anger — such a sage is said to have a steady mind.
Meaning/Interpretation: Promotes emotional stability.
Famous Quotes: Peace comes from within. Do not seek it without.
Comparison/Relations: Describes inner peace.

Sloka (Sanskrit): यः सर्वत्रानभिस्नेहस्तत्तत्प्राप्य शुभाशुभम्। नाभिनन्दति न द्वेष्टि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता।।
Sloka (English Translation): He who remains unattached under all conditions, neither rejoicing in good nor resenting evil — such a person is firmly established in wisdom.
Meaning/Interpretation: Advocates for equanimity.
Famous Quotes: Happiness depends upon ourselves.
Comparison/Relations: Encourages mental balance.

Sloka (Sanskrit): यदा संहरते चायं कूर्मोऽङ्गानीव सर्वशः। इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता।।
Sloka (English Translation): When one withdraws the senses from sense objects, like a tortoise withdrawing its limbs, his wisdom is firmly established.
Meaning/Interpretation: Describes self-control.
Famous Quotes: He who controls others may be powerful, but he who has mastered himself is mightier still.
Comparison/Relations: Teaches self-restraint.

Sloka (Sanskrit): विषया विनिवर्तन्ते निराहारस्य देहिनः। रसवर्जं रसोऽप्यस्य परं दृष्ट्वा निवर्तते।।
Sloka (English Translation): The sense objects withdraw from the abstinent person, but the taste for them remains. Even this taste disappears when one experiences the Supreme.
Meaning/Interpretation: Explains how true detachment arises.
Famous Quotes: He who has overcome his fears will truly be free.
Comparison/Relations: Promotes transcending sensory desires.

Sloka (Sanskrit): यततो ह्यपि कौन्तेय पुरुषस्य विपश्चितः। इन्द्रियाणि प्रमाथीनि हरन्ति प्रसभं मनः।।
Sloka (English Translation): Even for a wise person striving for self-control, the senses can forcibly carry away the mind.
Meaning/Interpretation: Acknowledges the struggle of self-discipline.
Famous Quotes: Mastering others is strength. Mastering yourself is true power.
Comparison/Relations: Highlights the difficulty of self-mastery.

Sloka (Sanskrit): तानि सर्वाणि संयम्य युक्त आसीत मत्परः। वशे हि यस्येन्द्रियाणि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता।।
Sloka (English Translation): Having restrained them all, one should sit steadfast, intent on Me. His wisdom is steady whose senses are under control.
Meaning/Interpretation: Emphasizes sense control and focus on the divine.
Famous Quotes: Rule your mind or it will rule you.
Comparison/Relations: Supports mastery over senses.

Sloka (Sanskrit): ध्यायतो विषयान्पुंसः सङ्गस्तेषूपजायते। सङ्गात्सञ्जायते कामः कामात्क्रोधोऽभिजायते।।
Sloka (English Translation): While contemplating the objects of the senses, a person develops attachment to them; from attachment arises desire, and from desire arises anger.
Meaning/Interpretation: Explains how desire and anger arise.
Famous Quotes: Desire is the root cause of all suffering.
Comparison/Relations: Shows the chain reaction of thoughts.

Sloka (Sanskrit): क्रोधाद्भवति सम्मोहः सम्मोहात्स्मृतिविभ्रमः। स्मृतिभ्रंशाद्बुद्धिनाशो बुद्धिनाशात्प्रणश्यति।।
Sloka (English Translation): From anger comes delusion, from delusion confusion of memory, from confusion of memory loss of reason, and from loss of reason one goes to complete ruin.
Meaning/Interpretation: Describes the downward spiral caused by anger.
Famous Quotes: Anger is one letter short of danger.
Comparison/Relations: Warns about the destruction caused by uncontrolled anger.

Sloka (Sanskrit): रागद्वेषवियुक्तैस्तु विषयानिन्द्रियैश्चरन्। आत्मवश्यैर्विधेयात्मा प्रसादमधिगच्छति।।
Sloka (English Translation): But the self-controlled person, moving among objects with senses under restraint, free from attraction and repulsion, attains peace.
Meaning/Interpretation: Highlights the balance needed for inner peace.
Famous Quotes: Peace begins with a smile.
Comparison/Relations: Suggests detachment for inner tranquility.

Sloka (Sanskrit): प्रसादे सर्वदुःखानां हानिरस्योपजायते। प्रसन्नचेतसो ह्याशु बुद्धिः पर्यवतिष्ठते।।
Sloka (English Translation): In that peace, all pains are destroyed; for the intellect of the tranquil-minded soon becomes steady.
Meaning/Interpretation: Links peace of mind with wisdom.
Famous Quotes: An eye for an eye will only make the whole world blind.
Comparison/Relations: Emphasizes serenity.

Sloka (Sanskrit): नास्ति बुद्धिरयुक्तस्य न चायुक्तस्य भावना। न चाभावयतः शान्तिरशान्तस्य कुतः सुखम्।।
Sloka (English Translation): There is no knowledge in the unsteady, nor is there meditation in the unsteady; and for one without meditation there is no peace. And how can there be happiness for one lacking peace?
Meaning/Interpretation: Explains the necessity of a peaceful mind for true happiness.
Famous Quotes: Calmness is the cradle of power.
Comparison/Relations: Stresses meditation and inner peace.

Sloka (Sanskrit): इन्द्रियाणां हि चरतां यन्मनोऽनुविधीयते। तदस्य हरति प्रज्ञां वायुर्नावमिवाम्भसि।।
Sloka (English Translation): Just as a strong wind sweeps away a boat on the waters, even one of the roaming senses on which the mind focuses can carry away a person's intelligence.
Meaning/Interpretation: Warns about the mind's distractions.
Famous Quotes: You will not be punished for your anger, you will be punished by your anger.
Comparison/Relations: Illustrates the danger of uncontrolled senses.

Sloka (Sanskrit): तस्माद्यस्य महाबाहो निगृहीतानि सर्वशः। इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता।।
Sloka (English Translation): Therefore, O mighty-armed one, he whose senses are restrained from their objects has a steady intellect.
Meaning/Interpretation: Reinforces the importance of sense control.
Famous Quotes: Strength does not come from physical capacity. It comes from an indomitable will.
Comparison/Relations: Stresses discipline.

Sloka (Sanskrit): या निशा सर्वभूतानां तस्यां जागर्ति संयमी। यस्यां जाग्रति भूतानि सा निशा पश्यतो मुनेः।।
Sloka (English Translation): What is night for all beings, the self-controlled one is awake to that. When beings are awake, it is night for the sage who sees.
Meaning/Interpretation: Symbolizes spiritual awakening.
Famous Quotes: Awake, arise, and stop not until the goal is reached.
Comparison/Relations: Contrasts spiritual and worldly awakenings.

Sloka (Sanskrit): आपूर्यमाणमचलप्रतिष्ठं समुद्रमापः प्रविशन्ति यद्वत्। तद्वत्कामा यं प्रविशन्ति सर्वे स शान्तिमाप्नोति न कामकामी।।
Sloka (English Translation): Just as the ocean remains full and unmoved even though water flows into it from all sides, so too, the person who remains unmoved despite all desires attains peace, not the person who craves for desires.
Meaning/Interpretation: Describes desirelessness as the path to peace.
Famous Quotes: Desire less, be at peace.
Comparison/Relations: Illustrates inner fulfillment.

Sloka (Sanskrit): विहाय कामान्यः सर्वान्पुमांश्चरति निःस्पृहः। निर्ममो निरहङ्कारः स शान्तिमधिगच्छति।।
Sloka (English Translation): That man who, having abandoned all desires, moves about without longing, without the sense of 'I' and 'mine', attains peace.
Meaning/Interpretation: Describes the path to true peace through renunciation.
Famous Quotes: The less you want, the richer you are.
Comparison/Relations: Emphasizes letting go of ego and desires.

Sloka (Sanskrit): एषा ब्राह्मी स्थितिः पार्थ नैनां प्राप्य विमुह्यति। स्थित्वास्यामन्तकालेऽपि ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृच्छति।।
Sloka (English Translation): O Arjuna, this is the Brahmi state. Attaining this, none is deluded. Being established therein, even at the hour of death, one attains Brahman.
Meaning/Interpretation: Explains the ultimate spiritual state leading to liberation.
Famous Quotes: Death is not extinguishing the light; it is only putting out the lamp because the dawn has come.
Comparison/Relations: Describes spiritual enlightenment at life’s end.

Sloka (Sanskrit): अर्जुन उवाच: ज्यायसी चेत्कर्मणस्ते मता बुद्धिर्जनार्दन। तत्किं कर्मणि घोरे मां नियोजयसि केशव।।
Sloka (English Translation): Arjuna said: O Janardana, if You consider that knowledge is superior to action, why then do You engage me in this terrible action, O Keshava?
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna questions why Krishna urges him to fight if knowledge is superior.
Famous Quotes: Knowing what's right doesn't mean much unless you do what's right.
Comparison/Relations: Stresses the importance of combining knowledge with action.

Sloka (Sanskrit): व्यामिश्रेणेव वाक्येन बुद्धिं मोहयसीव मे। तदेकं वद निश्चित्य येन श्रेयोऽहमाप्नुयाम्।।
Sloka (English Translation): With these apparently conflicting words, You are bewildering my intelligence. Therefore, please tell me definitely the one path by which I may attain the highest good.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna asks for clarity on the path to spiritual progress.
Famous Quotes: Clarity comes from action, not thought.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects Arjuna’s plea for clear guidance.

Sloka (Sanskrit): श्रीभगवानुवाच: लोकेऽस्मिन् द्विविधा निष्ठा पुरा प्रोक्ता मयानघ। ज्ञानयोगेन साङ्ख्यानां कर्मयोगेन योगिनाम्।।
Sloka (English Translation): The Blessed Lord said: O sinless one, in this world a twofold path was taught by Me in the beginning: the path of knowledge for the contemplative, and the path of action for the active.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains the two spiritual paths: knowledge and action.
Famous Quotes: The path to wisdom is action.
Comparison/Relations: Highlights Krishna's teachings about the twofold spiritual path.

Sloka (Sanskrit): न कर्मणामनारम्भान्नैष्कर्म्यं पुरुषोऽश्नुते। न च संन्यसनादेव सिद्धिं समधिगच्छति।।
Sloka (English Translation): A person does not attain freedom from action by merely abstaining from action; nor does he attain perfection merely by renunciation.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna stresses that true freedom requires action, not inaction.
Famous Quotes: Action is the foundational key to all success.
Comparison/Relations: Connects action with success and spiritual growth.

Sloka (Sanskrit): न हि कश्चित्क्षणमपि जातु तिष्ठत्यकर्मकृत्। कार्यते ह्यवशः कर्म सर्वः प्रकृतिजैर्गुणैः।।
Sloka (English Translation): Indeed, none can ever remain even for a moment without performing action; everyone is helplessly made to act according to the qualities born of material nature.
Meaning/Interpretation: No one can remain idle as nature compels all to act.
Famous Quotes: Inaction breeds doubt and fear. Action breeds confidence and courage.
Comparison/Relations: Relates action to overcoming fear and doubt.

Sloka (Sanskrit): कर्मेन्द्रियाणि संयम्य य आस्ते मनसा स्मरन्। इन्द्रियार्थान्विमूढात्मा मिथ्याचारः स उच्यते।।
Sloka (English Translation): He who, restraining the organs of action, sits thinking in his mind about sense objects, that deluded man is called a hypocrite.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna condemns hypocrisy in spiritual practice.
Famous Quotes: Action without intention is meaningless, but intention without action is hypocrisy.
Comparison/Relations: Highlights Krishna’s warning against false renunciation.

Sloka (Sanskrit): यस्त्विन्द्रियाणि मनसा नियम्यारभतेऽर्जुन। कर्मेन्द्रियैः कर्मयोगमसक्तः स विशिष्यते।।
Sloka (English Translation): But he who controls his senses with his mind and engages in Karma-yoga without attachment, O Arjuna, he excels.
Meaning/Interpretation: True karma-yoga lies in controlled, unattached action.
Famous Quotes: Discipline is choosing between what you want now and what you want most.
Comparison/Relations: Emphasizes detached and disciplined action.

Sloka (Sanskrit): नियतं कुरु कर्म त्वं कर्म ज्यायो ह्यकर्मणः। शरीरयात्रापि च ते न प्रसिद्ध्येदकर्मणः।।
Sloka (English Translation): Perform your prescribed duty, for action is better than inaction. Even the maintenance of your body cannot be accomplished without action.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna encourages performing one’s duties as inaction is detrimental.
Famous Quotes: Without work, all life goes to ruin.
Comparison/Relations: Connects duty and survival.

Sloka (Sanskrit): यज्ञार्थात्कर्मणोऽन्यत्र लोकोऽयं कर्मबन्धनः। तदर्थं कर्म कौन्तेय मुक्तसङ्गः समाचर।।
Sloka (English Translation): Work done as a sacrifice for Vishnu has to be performed; otherwise, work causes bondage in this world. Therefore, O Arjuna, perform your duties without attachment, for the sake of sacrifice.
Meaning/Interpretation: Work without attachment frees one from karmic bondage.
Famous Quotes: The secret of happiness is not doing what one likes, but in liking what one does.
Comparison/Relations: Aligns with Krishna's concept of detached action.

Sloka (Sanskrit): सहयज्ञाः प्रजाः सृष्ट्वा पुरोवाच प्रजापतिः। अनेन प्रसविष्यध्वमेष वोऽस्त्विष्टकामधुक्।।
Sloka (English Translation): In the beginning, having created mankind along with sacrifices, the Lord of Creation said: By this shall you propagate; let this be the milker of your desires.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna speaks of the divine law of sacrifice and creation.
Famous Quotes: Success depends on previous preparation, and without such preparation there is sure to be failure.
Comparison/Relations: Reflects the law of sacrifice in success.

Sloka (Sanskrit): देवान् भावयतानेन ते देवा भावयन्तु वः। परस्परं भावयन्तः श्रेयः परमवाप्स्यथ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Nourish the gods with this sacrifice, and the gods will nourish you. Thus supporting one another, you shall attain the supreme good.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that by performing sacrifices, one nourishes the gods, and in return, the gods bless human beings.
Famous Quotes: “No one has ever become poor by giving.”
Comparison/Relations: The concept of mutual support aligns with selfless giving and cooperation.

Sloka (Sanskrit): इष्टान्भोगान्हि वो देवा दास्यन्ते यज्ञभाविताः। तैर्दत्तानप्रदायैभ्यो यो भुङ्क्ते स्तेन एव सः॥
Sloka (English Translation): The gods, nourished by sacrifices, will give you the desired objects. He who enjoys these gifts without offering them in return is verily a thief.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna emphasizes the importance of returning favors and contributing to the collective good.
Famous Quotes: “We make a living by what we get, but we make a life by what we give.”
Comparison/Relations: The Bhagavad Gita and Churchill both highlight the value of giving and reciprocity.

Sloka (Sanskrit): यज्ञशिष्टाशिनः सन्तो मुच्यन्ते सर्वकिल्बिषैः। भुञ्जते ते त्वघं पापा ये पचन्त्यात्मकारणात्॥
Sloka (English Translation): The righteous who eat food offered first in sacrifice are freed from all sins. But the selfish who prepare food only for themselves verily eat sin.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that selfless offerings purify, while selfish acts taint.
Famous Quotes: “It is not what you gather but what you scatter that tells what kind of life you have lived.”
Comparison/Relations: Both convey the significance of selflessness and sharing.

Sloka (Sanskrit): अन्नाद्भवन्ति भूतानि पर्जन्यादन्नसम्भवः। यज्ञाद्भवति पर्जन्यो यज्ञः कर्मसमुद्भवः॥
Sloka (English Translation): All living beings subsist on food, food is produced by rain, rain ensues from sacrifice, and sacrifice is born of action.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna elaborates on the natural cycle linking action, sacrifice, and sustenance.
Famous Quotes: “Every action has an equal and opposite reaction.”
Comparison/Relations: Reflects the interconnected cycle of cause and effect.

Sloka (Sanskrit): कर्म ब्रह्मोद्भवं विद्धि ब्रह्माक्षरसमुद्भवम्। तस्मात्सर्वगतं ब्रह्म नित्यं यज्ञे प्रतिष्ठितम्॥
Sloka (English Translation): Action arises from the Vedas, and the Vedas spring from the imperishable. Therefore, the all-pervading Brahman is ever established in sacrifice.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna links eternal truths to actions and rituals.
Famous Quotes: “Eternal truth is the foundation of all righteous action.”
Comparison/Relations: Aligns with the idea that righteous actions have a divine origin.

Sloka (Sanskrit): एवं प्रवर्तितं चक्रं नानुवर्तयतीह यः। अघायुरिन्द्रियारामो मोघं पार्थ स जीवति॥
Sloka (English Translation): He who does not follow the wheel of creation set in motion lives a sinful and vain life, delighting in sensual pleasures.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna warns against ignoring cosmic laws and living selfishly.
Famous Quotes: “Life’s most persistent question is: What are you doing for others?”
Comparison/Relations: Both stress purpose and contributing to the greater good.

Sloka (Sanskrit): यस्त्वात्मरतिरेव स्यादात्मतृप्तश्च मानवः। आत्मन्येव च सन्तुष्टस्तस्य कार्यं न विद्यते॥
Sloka (English Translation): He who rejoices in the self, is satisfied with the self, and is content within the self, has no duty.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna describes a self-realized individual, beyond material obligations.
Famous Quotes: “Happiness depends upon ourselves.”
Comparison/Relations: Both convey the idea that true contentment comes from within.

Sloka (Sanskrit): नैव तस्य कृतेनार्थो नाकृतेनेह कश्चन। न चास्य सर्वभूतेषु कश्चिदर्थव्यपाश्रयः॥
Sloka (English Translation): He has nothing to gain from work done or left undone, and no dependence on any being.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna highlights self-sufficiency and non-attachment.
Famous Quotes: “Self-sufficiency is the greatest of all wealth.”
Comparison/Relations: Both emphasize independence and detachment.

Sloka (Sanskrit): तस्मादसक्तः सततं कार्यं कर्म समाचर। असक्तो ह्याचरन्कर्म परमाप्नोति पुरुषः॥
Sloka (English Translation): Perform your duty constantly without attachment; by doing work without attachment, a person attains the supreme.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna encourages detached action as a path to liberation.
Famous Quotes: “Do your duty and a little more and the future will take care of itself.”
Comparison/Relations: Both emphasize duty and the importance of dispassionate work.

Sloka (Sanskrit): जनकादयः कर्मणैव हि संसिद्धिमास्थिता:। लोकसङ्ग्रहमेवापि संपश्यन्कर्तुमर्हसि॥
Sloka (English Translation): Indeed, by action alone, Janaka and others attained perfection. You should perform your duty for the welfare of the world.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna points to great kings like Janaka as examples of selfless action.
Famous Quotes: “The best way to find yourself is to lose yourself in the service of others.”
Comparison/Relations: Both stress serving the greater good through selfless actions.

Sloka (Sanskrit): यद्यदाचरति श्रेष्ठस्तत्तदेवेतरो जनः। स यत्प्रमाणं कुरुते लोकस्तदनुवर्तते॥
Sloka (English Translation): Whatever a great man does, others will follow. Whatever standards he sets, the world will adopt.
Meaning/Interpretation: Leaders set examples for others, and their actions shape societal norms.
Famous Quotes: Example is not the main thing in influencing others. It is the only thing.
Comparison/Relations: Both highlight the influence of leadership and role models.

Sloka (Sanskrit): न मे पार्थास्ति कर्तव्यं त्रिषु लोकेषु किञ्चन। नानवाप्तमवाप्तव्यं वर्त एव च कर्मणि॥
Sloka (English Translation): O Partha, there is nothing in the three worlds that I am obliged to do, nor anything unattained that must be attained; yet I am engaged in action.
Meaning/Interpretation: Even without obligation, the wise act for the greater good.
Famous Quotes: The best way to find yourself is to lose yourself in the service of others.
Comparison/Relations: Both stress selfless action despite personal gains.

Sloka (Sanskrit): यदि ह्यहं न वर्तेयं जातु कर्मण्यतन्द्रितः। मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः॥
Sloka (English Translation): If I ever ceased to perform prescribed actions, O Partha, people would follow My path in every way.
Meaning/Interpretation: Actions of the wise guide others; inaction would cause disorder.
Famous Quotes: Your actions speak so loudly, I cannot hear what you are saying.
Comparison/Relations: Both emphasize actions over words as guiding principles.

Sloka (Sanskrit): उत्सीदेयुरिमे लोका न कुर्यां कर्म चेदहम्। सङ्करस्य च कर्ता स्यामुपहन्यामिमा: प्रजा:॥
Sloka (English Translation): If I did not perform action, these worlds would perish. I would be the cause of confusion and the destroyer of these beings.
Meaning/Interpretation: Inaction by leaders leads to chaos and disorder.
Famous Quotes: He who has a why to live can bear almost any how.
Comparison/Relations: Stresses the necessity of action for the greater order.

Sloka (Sanskrit): सक्ताः कर्मण्यविद्वांसो यथा कुर्वन्ति भारत। कुर्याद्विद्वांस्तथासक्तश्चिकीर्षुर्लोकसंग्रहम्॥
Sloka (English Translation): Just as the ignorant act with attachment to work, O Bharata, so should the wise act without attachment, for the welfare of the world.
Meaning/Interpretation: The wise act selflessly, inspiring the ignorant by example.
Famous Quotes: The best way to inspire others is through your own actions.
Comparison/Relations: Both convey the power of leading by example.

Sloka (Sanskrit): न बुद्धिभेदं जनयेदज्ञानां कर्मसङ्गिनाम्। जोषयेत्सर्वकर्माणि विद्वान्युक्त: समाचरन्॥
Sloka (English Translation): The wise should not unsettle the minds of the ignorant attached to action, but by performing work with devotion, should inspire them.
Meaning/Interpretation: Teach by example rather than by unsettling those who are unaware.
Famous Quotes: Teach by showing, not by telling.
Comparison/Relations: Both highlight gentle guidance through example.

Sloka (Sanskrit): प्रकृतेः क्रियमाणानि गुणैः कर्माणि सर्वशः। अहङ्कारविमूढात्मा कर्ताहमिति मन्यते॥
Sloka (English Translation): All actions are performed by the modes of material nature, but the soul bewildered by false ego thinks, 'I am the doer.'
Meaning/Interpretation: Actions stem from nature's forces, not the ego.
Famous Quotes: Pride goes before destruction, and a haughty spirit before a fall.
Comparison/Relations: Both warn against ego and false pride.

Sloka (Sanskrit): तत्त्ववित्तु महाबाहो गुणकर्मविभागयोः। गुणा गुणेषु वर्तन्त इति मत्वा न सज्जते॥
Sloka (English Translation): But he who knows the truth, O mighty-armed one, about the divisions of the modes and their functions, realizes that the modes act upon modes and remains unattached.
Meaning/Interpretation: The wise remain detached, understanding the play of nature's forces.
Famous Quotes: Detachment is not that you own nothing, but that nothing owns you.
Comparison/Relations: Both teach non-attachment and spiritual wisdom.

Sloka (Sanskrit): प्रकृतेर्गुणसम्मूढाः सज्जन्ते गुणकर्मसु। तानकृत्स्नविदो मन्दान्कृत्स्नविन्न विचालयेत्॥
Sloka (English Translation): Those bewildered by the modes of nature are attached to the works of the modes. A person of perfect knowledge should not disturb the mind of the ignorant.
Meaning/Interpretation: The wise must not confuse those unaware of nature's workings.
Famous Quotes: Wisdom is knowing what you don't know.
Comparison/Relations: Both stress the need for compassion toward the ignorant.

Sloka (Sanskrit): मयि सर्वाणि कर्माणि सन्न्यस्याध्यात्मचेतसा। निराशीर्निर्ममो भूत्वा युध्यस्व विगतज्वरः॥
Sloka (English Translation): Surrendering all actions unto Me, with mind intent on the Self, free from hope and ego, fight without anxiety.
Meaning/Interpretation: Act selflessly, dedicating actions to a higher cause.
Famous Quotes: Action is the foundational key to all success.
Comparison/Relations: Both advocate action without attachment to outcomes.

Sloka (Sanskrit): ये मे मतमिदं नित्यमनुतिष्ठन्ति मानवाः। श्रद्धावन्तोऽनसूयन्तो मुच्यन्ते तेऽपि कर्मभिः।।
Sloka (English Translation): Those who constantly practice this teaching of Mine, full of faith and without envy, are freed from the bondage of karma.
Meaning/Interpretation: Following the path taught by Krishna with faith leads to liberation from karma.
Famous Quotes: “Faith is taking the first step even when you don’t see the whole staircase.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna emphasizes faith as a path to liberation, resonating with Martin Luther King Jr.'s message about faith.

Sloka (Sanskrit): ये त्वेतदभ्यसूयन्तो नानुतिष्ठन्ति मे मतम्। सर्वज्ञानविमूढांस्तान्विद्धि नष्टानचेतसः।।
Sloka (English Translation): But those who, out of envy, do not follow this teaching of Mine, are deluded in all knowledge and doomed to destruction.
Meaning/Interpretation: Ignoring Krishna's guidance due to envy leads to ignorance and ruin.
Famous Quotes: “Envy is ignorance.”
Comparison/Relations: Both Krishna and Emerson highlight envy as a source of ignorance and downfall.

Sloka (Sanskrit): सदृशं चेष्टते स्वस्याः प्रकृतेर्ज्ञानवानपि। प्रकृतिं यान्ति भूतानि निग्रहः किं करिष्यति।।
Sloka (English Translation): Even a wise person acts according to their own nature; all living beings follow their nature. What can restraint do?
Meaning/Interpretation: One's nature influences actions, and wisdom alone cannot override natural tendencies.
Famous Quotes: “Nature does not hurry, yet everything is accomplished.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna and Lao Tzu both acknowledge the power of nature over actions.

Sloka (Sanskrit): इन्द्रियस्येन्द्रियस्यार्थे रागद्वेषौ व्यवस्थितौ। तयोर्न वशमागच्छेत्तौ ह्यस्य परिपन्थिनौ।।
Sloka (English Translation): Attachment and aversion are rooted in the senses and their objects. One should not fall under their sway, for they are foes.
Meaning/Interpretation: Senses breed attachment and aversion; control over them is key to inner peace.
Famous Quotes: “He who controls others may be powerful, but he who has mastered himself is mightier still.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna and Lao Tzu emphasize mastery over one's senses and self.

Sloka (Sanskrit): श्रेयान्स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात्। स्वधर्मे निधनं श्रेयः परधर्मो भयावहः।।
Sloka (English Translation): It is better to fail in one's own duty than to succeed in the duty of another. Death in one's own duty is better; the duty of another brings fear.
Meaning/Interpretation: Performing one's own duty, even imperfectly, is superior to doing another's perfectly.
Famous Quotes: “Be yourself; everyone else is already taken.”
Comparison/Relations: Both Krishna and Wilde stress the importance of authenticity and staying true to one's own path.

Sloka (Sanskrit): काम एष क्रोध एष रजोगुणसमुद्भवः। महाशनो महापाप्मा विद्ध्येनमिह वैरिणम्।।
Sloka (English Translation): Desire and anger arise from the mode of passion. They are insatiable and wicked. Know them as your enemies.
Meaning/Interpretation: Desire and anger, rooted in passion, are destructive and must be controlled.
Famous Quotes: “For every minute you remain angry, you give up sixty seconds of peace of mind.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna and Emerson both warn against the corrosive effects of anger.

Sloka (Sanskrit): धूमेनाव्रियते वह्निर्यथादर्शो मलेन च। यथोल्बेनावृतो गर्भस्तथा तेनेदमावृतम्।।
Sloka (English Translation): Just as fire is covered by smoke, mirror by dust, and embryo by the womb, so is wisdom obscured by desire.
Meaning/Interpretation: Desire clouds wisdom, much like smoke obscures fire.
Famous Quotes: “Desire is the root cause of all suffering.”
Comparison/Relations: Both Krishna and Buddha view desire as a major source of suffering and ignorance.

Sloka (Sanskrit): आवृतं ज्ञानमेतेन ज्ञानिनो नित्यवैरिणा। कामरूपेण कौन्तेय दुष्पूरेणानलेन च।।
Sloka (English Translation): O Arjuna, wisdom is covered by this constant enemy of the wise, in the form of insatiable desire, like an unquenchable fire.
Meaning/Interpretation: Desire, an unquenchable fire, constantly threatens wisdom.
Famous Quotes: “You will not be punished for your anger, you will be punished by your anger.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna and Buddha highlight desire and anger as threats to inner peace and wisdom.

Sloka (Sanskrit): इन्द्रियाणि मनो बुद्धिरस्याधिष्ठानमुच्यते। एतैर्विमोहयत्येष ज्ञानमावृत्य देहिनम्।।
Sloka (English Translation): The senses, mind, and intellect are said to be its seat; through these, it deludes the embodied soul by covering its wisdom.
Meaning/Interpretation: Desire infiltrates the senses, mind, and intellect, distorting one's wisdom.
Famous Quotes: “Your mind is your instrument. Learn to be its master and not its slave.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna and Sasson both stress the need to master one's mind to maintain clarity.

Sloka (Sanskrit): तस्मात्त्वमिन्द्रियाण्यादौ नियम्य भरतर्षभ। पाप्मानं प्रजहि ह्येनं ज्ञानविज्ञाननाशनम्।।
Sloka (English Translation): Therefore, O Arjuna, control your senses first and destroy this wicked desire, which is the enemy of wisdom and realization.
Meaning/Interpretation: Controlling senses is key to defeating desire and preserving wisdom.
Famous Quotes: “Rule your mind or it will rule you.”
Comparison/Relations: Both Krishna and Horace urge mastery over the mind and senses to achieve true wisdom.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रीभगवानुवाच |
इमं विवस्वते योगं प्रोक्तवानहमव्ययम् |
विवस्वान्मनवे प्राह मनुरिक्ष्वाकवेऽब्रवीत् || 4.1 ||
Sloka (English Translation): The Supreme Lord said: I instructed this imperishable science of yoga to the sun-god, Vivasvan, and Vivasvan instructed it to Manu, the father of mankind, and Manu in turn instructed it to Ikshvaku.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains the lineage of the knowledge of yoga (spiritual wisdom), stating that this eternal knowledge was first given to Vivasvan (the sun-god), who passed it to Manu (the first man and lawgiver), who then passed it to his son Ikshvaku (founder of the solar dynasty). This establishes that the spiritual knowledge Krishna is sharing is ancient and has been passed down through a divine succession.
Famous Quotes: "Truth is one; sages call it by various names."
Comparison/Relations: This quote from the Rigveda aligns with Krishna's message about the eternal nature of spiritual truth. Just as Krishna describes how the same yoga knowledge has been transmitted through different teachers throughout time, the Rigvedic quote suggests that underlying spiritual truths remain constant, even when expressed in different forms or through different traditions.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
एवं परम्पराप्राप्तमिमं राजर्षयो विदुः |
स कालेनेह महता योगो नष्टः परन्तप || 4.2 ||
Sloka (English Translation): This supreme science was thus received through the chain of disciplic succession, and the saintly kings understood it in that way. But in course of time the succession was broken, and therefore the science as it is appears to be lost.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna continues explaining how this knowledge was passed down through generations of royal sages who preserved and practiced it. However, over time, the chain of transmission was broken, and the true understanding of this spiritual knowledge became obscured or lost to humanity.
Famous Quotes: "What is history but a fable agreed upon?"
Comparison/Relations: Napoleon's quote reflects on how historical knowledge can be lost or distorted over time, similar to Krishna's explanation of how the yoga knowledge became lost over time. Both suggest that important wisdom and truth can fade if not properly preserved through continuous transmission and practice.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
स एवायं मया तेऽद्य योगः प्रोक्तः पुरातनः |
भक्तोऽसि मे सखा चेति रहस्यं ह्येतदुत्तमम् || 4.3 ||
Sloka (English Translation): That very ancient science of the relationship with the Supreme is today told by Me to you because you are My devotee as well as My friend and can therefore understand the transcendental mystery of this science.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna tells Arjuna that he is now revealing this ancient knowledge directly to him because Arjuna is both his devotee and friend. This special relationship makes Arjuna qualified to receive this profound spiritual wisdom that had been lost over time. Krishna implies that such knowledge is not meant for everyone but only for those who have the proper qualifications and relationship with the divine.
Famous Quotes: "The highest education is that which does not merely give us information but makes our life in harmony with all existence."
Comparison/Relations: Tagore's quote emphasizes that true knowledge leads to harmony with existence, which parallels Krishna's teaching that this highest knowledge is given to Arjuna due to their harmonious relationship. Both suggest that the deepest wisdom is not merely intellectual but relational and transformative, bringing one into alignment with a greater reality.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अर्जुन उवाच |
अपरं भवतो जन्म परं जन्म विवस्वतः |
कथमेतद्विजानीयां त्वमादौ प्रोक्तवानिति || 4.4 ||
Sloka (English Translation): Arjuna said: The sun-god Vivasvan is senior by birth to You. How am I to understand that in the beginning You instructed this science to him?
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna expresses confusion about Krishna's claim to have taught this knowledge to Vivasvan (the sun-god) who existed thousands of years before. Since Krishna appears to be a contemporary of Arjuna, this statement seems paradoxical to him. Arjuna's question leads Krishna to explain his divine nature and the concept of his repeated manifestations throughout time.
Famous Quotes: "The most beautiful thing we can experience is the mysterious. It is the source of all true art and science."
Comparison/Relations: Einstein's quote about the mystery being the source of true understanding resonates with Arjuna's questioning. Just as Einstein recognized that confronting mysteries leads to deeper knowledge, Arjuna's willingness to question what seems impossible opens the door to Krishna's revelation about his transcendent nature beyond ordinary time and space.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रीभगवानुवाच |
बहूनि मे व्यतीतानि जन्मानि तव चार्जुन |
तान्यहं वेद सर्वाणि न त्वं वेत्थ परन्तप || 4.5 ||
