Sloka (English Translation): The Blessed Lord said: Many, many births both you and I have passed. I can remember all of them, but you cannot, O subduer of the enemy!
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna begins to reveal his divine nature by explaining that both he and Arjuna have gone through numerous births, but while Krishna can remember all of these past lives, Arjuna cannot. This highlights the difference between the ordinary consciousness of humans (who forget their past lives) and the supreme consciousness of the divine (who maintains awareness across all incarnations).
Famous Quotes: "We are not human beings having a spiritual experience. We are spiritual beings having a human experience."
Comparison/Relations: Chardin's quote reflects Krishna's teaching about the continuity of existence through multiple births. Both suggest that our true identity transcends our current physical manifestation and that we have a spiritual nature that extends beyond the limitations of a single lifetime. Krishna, however, indicates that divine consciousness includes full awareness of this continuity.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अजोऽपि सन्नव्ययात्मा भूतानामीश्वरोऽपि सन् |
प्रकृतिं स्वामधिष्ठाय सम्भवाम्यात्ममायया || 4.6 ||
Sloka (English Translation): Although I am unborn and My transcendental body never deteriorates, and although I am the Lord of all living entities, I still appear in every millennium in My original transcendental form.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that although he is eternal, unborn, and imperishable—the supreme controller of all beings—he still manifests himself in the material world through his own divine power (maya). Unlike ordinary beings who are forced to take birth due to karma, Krishna's appearances are voluntary and part of his divine plan, maintaining his transcendental nature even while appearing in the material world.
Famous Quotes: "The Eternal Being is not to be discovered in the dimension of time."
Comparison/Relations: Heschel's quote about the Eternal Being transcending time aligns with Krishna's description of himself as eternally existing beyond the constraints of birth and death. Both express the paradox of the timeless entering into time—Krishna describing how he, though beyond birth, still appears within the temporal world through his divine power.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यदा यदा हि धर्मस्य ग्लानिर्भवति भारत |
अभ्युत्थानमधर्मस्य तदात्मानं सृजाम्यहम् || 4.7 ||
Sloka (English Translation): Whenever and wherever there is a decline in religious practice, O descendant of Bharata, and a predominant rise of irreligion—at that time I descend Myself.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals the purpose behind his divine incarnations: whenever righteousness (dharma) declines and unrighteousness (adharma) increases in the world, he manifests himself. This verse explains the concept of divine intervention in human affairs, suggesting that God appears in the world at critical moments when human society has strayed too far from spiritual and ethical principles.
Famous Quotes: "Darkness cannot drive out darkness; only light can do that. Hate cannot drive out hate; only love can do that."
Comparison/Relations: Dr. King's quote about light being necessary to overcome darkness parallels Krishna's explanation of his divine purpose to overcome the darkness of adharma with the light of dharma. Both suggest that negative forces cannot be overcome by similar energy but require the introduction of a higher positive force—be it divine intervention (Krishna) or love and light (King).

Sloka (Sanskrit):
परित्राणाय साधूनां विनाशाय च दुष्कृताम् |
धर्मसंस्थापनार्थाय सम्भवामि युगे युगे || 4.8 ||
Sloka (English Translation): To deliver the pious and to annihilate the miscreants, as well as to reestablish the principles of religion, I Myself appear, millennium after millennium.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna continues to explain the purpose of his incarnations: to protect the virtuous, destroy the wicked, and reestablish dharma (righteousness/religious principles). This verse complements the previous one by elaborating on the threefold purpose of divine incarnations and confirming that this is a recurring cycle throughout cosmic history ("age after age").
Famous Quotes: "What you do makes a difference, and you have to decide what kind of difference you want to make."
Comparison/Relations: Goodall's quote about purposeful action making a difference resonates with Krishna's description of his purposeful incarnations. Both emphasize that intentional intervention can transform circumstances and protect what is valuable. While Krishna speaks on a cosmic scale about protecting dharma, Goodall speaks on a human scale about our individual responsibility to make positive changes.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
जन्म कर्म च मे दिव्यमेवं यो वेत्ति तत्त्वतः |
त्यक्त्वा देहं पुनर्जन्म नैति मामेति सोऽर्जुन || 4.9 ||
Sloka (English Translation): One who knows the transcendental nature of My appearance and activities does not, upon leaving the body, take his birth again in this material world, but attains My eternal abode, O Arjuna.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals that understanding the transcendental nature of his birth and activities leads to liberation from the cycle of rebirth. When one truly comprehends that Krishna's appearances are divine and not material like ordinary births, this spiritual knowledge frees them from material bondage. Upon death, instead of being reborn in the material world, such a person attains Krishna's eternal spiritual abode.
Famous Quotes: "The goal of life is to make your heartbeat match the beat of the universe, to match your nature with Nature."
Comparison/Relations: Campbell's quote about aligning with the universal rhythm parallels Krishna's teaching about understanding divine nature. Both suggest that true liberation comes from aligning one's understanding with a higher reality. Krishna specifically states that understanding his divine nature leads to freedom from rebirth and union with him, while Campbell speaks of the harmony that comes from aligning with universal truths.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
वीतरागभयक्रोधा मन्मया मामुपाश्रिताः |
बहवो ज्ञानतपसा पूता मद्भावमागताः || 4.10 ||
Sloka (English Translation): Being freed from attachment, fear and anger, being fully absorbed in Me and taking refuge in Me, many, many persons in the past became purified by knowledge of Me—and thus they all attained transcendental love for Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that many people throughout history have attained spiritual perfection by becoming free from attachment, fear, and anger, while becoming fully absorbed in and surrendered to him. Through knowledge of Krishna's true nature and devotion to him, they were purified and developed transcendental love for him, which is the highest spiritual attainment.
Famous Quotes: "The spiritual journey is the unlearning of fear and the acceptance of love."
Comparison/Relations: Williamson's quote about spirituality involving the unlearning of fear and acceptance of love corresponds closely with Krishna's description of the spiritual path. Both describe a process of transformation where negative emotions like fear (and also attachment and anger in Krishna's teaching) are overcome through connection with a higher spiritual reality, ultimately leading to a state of love and devotion.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ये यथा मां प्रपद्यन्ते तांस्तथैव भजाम्यहम् |
मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः || 4.11 ||
Sloka (English Translation): As all surrender unto Me, I reward them accordingly. Everyone follows My path in all respects, O son of Pritha.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains the reciprocal nature of the divine relationship: he responds to people according to how they approach him. This verse reveals the impartiality of God, who does not discriminate but responds to each person's attitude and level of surrender. It also suggests that all spiritual paths, knowingly or unknowingly, ultimately lead to Krishna, as everyone is following his path in some way or another, even if through different forms or names.
Famous Quotes: "God has no religion."
Comparison/Relations: Gandhi's quote about God transcending religious boundaries reflects Krishna's universal approach to devotees. Both convey that the divine responds to sincere seekers regardless of their formal religious path or tradition. Krishna's statement that he rewards people according to their approach and that all ultimately follow his path parallels Gandhi's understanding that God exists beyond the limitations of any single religious system.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
काङ्क्षन्तः कर्मणां सिद्धिं यजन्त इह देवताः |
क्षिप्रं हि मानुषे लोके सिद्धिर्भवति कर्मजा || 4.12 ||
Sloka (English Translation): Men in this world desire success in fruitive activities, and therefore they worship the demigods. Quickly, of course, men get results from fruitive work in this world.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna observes that people who desire material success worship various demigods (lesser deities) to fulfill their worldly ambitions. He acknowledges that such worship does indeed bring quick results in the material realm. This verse introduces a contrast between worship for material gains and worship of the Supreme for spiritual liberation, setting up Krishna's explanation of the hierarchy of spiritual understanding.
Famous Quotes: "The journey of a thousand miles begins with one step."
Comparison/Relations: Lao Tzu's quote about beginning a journey with small steps parallels Krishna's recognition that worshipping demigods for material success represents an initial step in spiritual evolution. Both acknowledge that people often begin their spiritual journey seeking tangible, immediate results before moving toward higher understanding. Krishna recognizes this approach as valid but limited, while Lao Tzu emphasizes the importance of simply beginning the journey.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
चातुर्वर्ण्यं मया सृष्टं गुणकर्मविभागशः |
तस्य कर्तारमपि मां विद्ध्यकर्तारमव्ययम् || 4.13 ||
Sloka (English Translation): According to the three modes of material nature and the work associated with them, the four divisions of human society are created by Me. And although I am the creator of this system, you should know that I am yet the nondoer, being unchangeable.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that he created the four divisions of society (varna system) based on qualities (gunas) and activities (karma), not by birth. However, he clarifies that though he established this system, he remains detached from it and is not directly involved in its operations. This reveals the paradoxical nature of the divine as both the creator of cosmic order and yet transcendent to it, establishing natural laws while remaining beyond their influence.
Famous Quotes: "True equality means holding everyone to the same standard. But that's not what social justice is. Social justice means giving everyone the same thing."
Comparison/Relations: Sowell's quote distinguishes between equality of standards versus equality of outcomes, which resonates with Krishna's explanation of the varna system based on qualities and actions rather than birth. Both suggest that true social organization should recognize natural differences in abilities and inclinations while maintaining equal dignity. Krishna establishes that the divine order accounts for natural diversity while transcending it, similar to how Sowell suggests standards can be universal while acknowledging individual differences.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
न मां कर्माणि लिम्पन्ति न मे कर्मफले स्पृहा |
इति मां योऽभिजानाति कर्मभिर्न स बध्यते || 4.14 ||
Sloka (English Translation): There is no work that affects Me; nor do I aspire for the fruits of action. One who understands this truth about Me also does not become entangled in the fruitive reactions of work.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that he is not affected by actions nor desires their results, highlighting his complete detachment despite being the supreme controller. He then states that those who truly understand this aspect of his nature can also achieve freedom from the bondage of karma. This verse introduces the important concept that liberation comes through understanding the transcendental nature of God and emulating his detached attitude toward work.
Famous Quotes: "Work is love made visible."
Comparison/Relations: Gibran's quote about work being an expression of love connects with Krishna's teaching about detached action. Both suggest a transcendent approach to work that goes beyond self-interest. While Krishna emphasizes freedom from attachment to results, Gibran points to the transformation of work through love. Both perspectives elevate work from mere labor to a spiritual practice—Krishna through detachment and Gibran through the infusion of love.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
एवं ज्ञात्वा कृतं कर्म पूर्वैरपि मुमुक्षुभिः |
कुरु कर्मैव तस्मात्त्वं पूर्वैः पूर्वतरं कृतम् || 4.15 ||
Sloka (English Translation): All the liberated souls in ancient times acted with this understanding of My transcendental nature. Therefore you should perform your duty, following in their footsteps.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna urges Arjuna to follow the example of previous seekers of liberation who performed their duties with proper understanding of the divine nature. This establishes the authority of tradition and the importance of learning from those who have successfully walked the spiritual path before. Krishna emphasizes that action with proper understanding, not inaction, is the way to spiritual freedom.
Famous Quotes: "Stand on the shoulders of giants."
Comparison/Relations: Newton's famous quote about advancing by building on the achievements of predecessors parallels Krishna's instruction to follow the example of previous liberated souls. Both emphasize the value of learning from those who came before rather than trying to forge an entirely new path. Krishna encourages Arjuna to act with understanding as his predecessors did, just as Newton acknowledged that progress comes through building upon established wisdom.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
किं कर्म किमकर्मेति कवयोऽप्यत्र मोहिताः |
तत्ते कर्म प्रवक्ष्यामि यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात् || 4.16 ||
Sloka (English Translation): Even the intelligent are bewildered in determining what is action and what is inaction. Now I shall explain to you what action is, knowing which you shall be liberated from all misfortune.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna acknowledges that understanding the true nature of action and inaction is confusing even for the wise. He then promises to explain this complex topic to Arjuna, indicating that proper understanding of action is crucial for liberation. This verse highlights the subtle nature of spiritual knowledge, where apparent contradictions (like how to act without being bound by action) require deep insight beyond conventional understanding.
Famous Quotes: "The most important thing is to keep the most important thing the most important thing."
Comparison/Relations: Covey's quote about maintaining clarity on priorities connects with Krishna's emphasis on understanding the essence of action. Both point to the importance of discernment—seeing beyond confusion to grasp fundamental principles. Krishna acknowledges the complexity of distinguishing true action from inaction, while Covey similarly recognizes how easily we can lose sight of what truly matters. Both suggest that wisdom lies in this crucial discernment.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
कर्मणो ह्यपि बोद्धव्यं बोद्धव्यं च विकर्मणः |
अकर्मणश्च बोद्धव्यं गहना कर्मणो गतिः || 4.17 ||
Sloka (English Translation): The intricacies of action are very hard to understand. Therefore one should know properly what action is, what forbidden action is, and what inaction is.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that there are three aspects of action that must be understood: proper action (karma), prohibited action (vikarma), and inaction (akarma). He emphasizes that understanding the nature of action is profound and complex ("the course of action is very deep"). This verse establishes that spiritual understanding requires nuanced discernment rather than simplistic categorization, and that comprehending the mysteries of action and its consequences is essential for spiritual growth.
Famous Quotes: "Between stimulus and response there is a space. In that space is our power to choose our response. In our response lies our growth and our freedom."
Comparison/Relations: Frankl's quote about the space between stimulus and response parallels Krishna's teaching about understanding different types of action. Both point to the importance of conscious discernment in how we act. Krishna emphasizes the need to distinguish between proper action, forbidden action, and inaction, while Frankl highlights the transformative power that comes from awareness of our choices. Both suggest that freedom comes through this deeper understanding of action and its implications.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
कर्मण्यकर्म यः पश्येदकर्मणि च कर्म यः |
स बुद्धिमान्मनुष्येषु स युक्तः कृत्स्नकर्मकृत् || 4.18 ||
Sloka (English Translation): One who sees inaction in action, and action in inaction, is intelligent among men, and he is in the transcendental position, although engaged in all sorts of activities.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals a profound paradox: the truly wise person sees inaction in action and action in inaction. This means recognizing that actions performed without attachment and ego (with spiritual awareness) are actually a form of inaction because they don't create karmic bondage. Conversely, apparent inaction driven by fear, confusion, or attachment is actually binding action. This verse highlights the importance of consciousness and intention over external appearance in determining the spiritual value of action.
Famous Quotes: "What we are is what we have been, and what we will be is what we do now."
Comparison/Relations: Buddha's quote about our present actions determining our future connects with Krishna's teaching about the transformative understanding of action. Both emphasize that the nature and quality of action transcend simple appearance. Krishna reveals that spiritually informed action (seeing inaction in action) liberates rather than binds, which parallels Buddha's teaching that mindful action in the present shapes our future state. Both point to transcending ordinary perceptions of cause and effect through spiritual awareness.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यस्य सर्वे समारम्भाः कामसङ्कल्पवर्जिताः |
ज्ञानाग्निदग्धकर्माणं तमाहुः पण्डितं बुधाः || 4.19 ||
Sloka (English Translation): One is understood to be in full knowledge whose every endeavor is devoid of desire for sense gratification. He is said by sages to be a worker for whom the reactions of work have been burned up by the fire of perfect knowledge.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna describes the person of true wisdom as one whose actions are free from desire and self-centered planning. Such a person's karma (the reactions to their actions) is burned away by the fire of perfect knowledge. This verse emphasizes that liberation comes not from ceasing activity but from transforming the consciousness behind action, performing duties without selfish motivation or attachment to results.
Famous Quotes: "The highest reward for a person's toil is not what they get for it, but what they become by it."
Comparison/Relations: Ruskin's quote about the true reward of work being personal transformation aligns with Krishna's teaching about knowledge-purified action. Both suggest that the highest value of work is not external results but internal transformation. Krishna speaks of actions purified by knowledge that burns away karmic reactions, while Ruskin points to how work transforms the worker. Both perspectives shift focus from the fruits of action to its transformative power.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
त्यक्त्वा कर्मफलासङ्गं नित्यतृप्तो निराश्रयः |
कर्मण्यभिप्रवृत्तोऽपि नैव किञ्चित्करोति सः || 4.20 ||
Sloka (English Translation): Abandoning all attachment to the results of his activities, ever satisfied and independent, he performs no fruitive action, although engaged in all kinds of undertakings.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna describes the state of a person who has abandoned attachment to the fruits of action. Such a person remains internally content and self-sufficient, not dependent on external outcomes for satisfaction. Though actively engaged in various activities, they are not actually "doing" anything in the karmic sense because their actions don't create binding consequences. This verse highlights the paradoxical freedom that comes from acting without attachment—full engagement in the world without being bound by it.
Famous Quotes: "The secret of happiness is freedom, and the secret of freedom is courage."
Comparison/Relations: Thucydides' quote about freedom requiring courage connects with Krishna's description of detached action. Both point to the liberating power of releasing attachment to outcomes. Krishna describes how abandoning attachment to results leads to a state of perpetual contentment and inner freedom, while Thucydides suggests that true happiness comes through freedom, which requires the courage to let go. Both perspectives recognize that liberation comes through relinquishing control rather than grasping for it.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
निराशीर्यतचित्तात्मा त्यक्तसर्वपरिग्रहः |
शारीरं केवलं कर्म कुर्वन्नाप्नोति किल्बिषम् || 4.21 ||
Sloka (English Translation): Such a man of understanding acts with mind and intelligence perfectly controlled, gives up all sense of proprietorship over his possessions, and acts only for the bare necessities of life. Thus working, he is not affected by sinful reactions.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna further describes the enlightened person who has controlled their mind and given up all sense of ownership or possession. Such a person performs actions only for basic maintenance of the body without attachment. By acting without possessiveness and only for necessary purposes, they remain free from the sinful reactions that normally bind actions. This verse emphasizes minimalism and non-attachment as key aspects of liberated action.
Famous Quotes: "The things you own end up owning you."
Persons: Tyler Durden (character from Fight Club by Chuck Palahniuk)
Comparison/Relations: This quote reflects Krishna's teaching about renouncing possessiveness and the sense of ownership. Both suggest that attachment to possessions creates bondage rather than freedom. Krishna describes how one who has given up "all sense of proprietorship" and acts only for essential needs remains free from karmic reactions, while the quote similarly implies that possessions create attachments that ultimately control and limit us rather than serve us.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यदृच्छालाभसन्तुष्टो द्वन्द्वातीतो विमत्सरः |
समः सिद्धावसिद्धौ च कृत्वापि न निबध्यते || 4.22 ||
Sloka (English Translation): He who is satisfied with gain which comes of its own accord, who is free from duality and does not envy, who is steady in both success and failure, is never entangled, although performing actions.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna continues describing the liberated person who remains content with whatever comes naturally, without special effort. Such a person has transcended duality (pleasure/pain, like/dislike), is free from envy, and maintains equanimity in both success and failure. Even while acting in the world, they remain unbound by their actions because of this inner balance and acceptance. This verse highlights contentment and equanimity as essential qualities of spiritual freedom.
Famous Quotes: "Happiness is not having what you want, but wanting what you have."
Persons: Attributed to various sources, including Rabbi Hyman Schachtel
Comparison/Relations: This quote directly parallels Krishna's teaching about being "satisfied with gain which comes of its own accord." Both emphasize that contentment comes from acceptance and appreciation of what naturally arrives rather than striving after desires. Krishna describes freedom as arising from this contentment combined with equanimity toward success and failure, while the quote similarly suggests that happiness comes from aligning desires with reality rather than constantly seeking to change circumstances.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
गतसङ्गस्य मुक्तस्य ज्ञानावस्थितचेतसः |
यज्ञायाचरतः कर्म समग्रं प्रविलीयते || 4.23 ||
Sloka (English Translation): The work of a man who is unattached to the modes of material nature and who is fully situated in transcendental knowledge merges entirely into transcendence.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that for one who has transcended attachment, attained liberation, and established consciousness in spiritual knowledge, all actions become sacred offerings (yajna). Such a person's actions dissolve completely into the transcendental realm, leaving no karmic residue. This verse introduces the concept that through proper consciousness, all activities can be transformed into spiritual practice, dissolving the distinction between mundane and sacred action.
Famous Quotes: "The meaning of life is to find your gift. The purpose of life is to give it away."
Comparison/Relations: Picasso's quote about finding one's gift and giving it away resonates with Krishna's teaching about action performed as sacred offering (yajna). Both suggest a transformation where personal action becomes something offered beyond oneself. Krishna describes how actions of the enlightened dissolve into transcendence when performed without attachment and with spiritual knowledge, while Picasso points to how discovering and sharing one's unique gifts creates meaning through selfless offering.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ब्रह्मार्पणं ब्रह्म हविर्ब्रह्माग्नौ ब्रह्मणा हुतम् |
ब्रह्मैव तेन गन्तव्यं ब्रह्मकर्मसमाधिना || 4.24 ||
Sloka (English Translation): A person who is fully absorbed in Krishna consciousness is sure to attain the spiritual kingdom because of his full contribution to spiritual activities, in which the consummation is absolute and that which is offered is of the same spiritual nature.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna describes the complete unity of spiritual action in which everything involved in the sacrifice is divine: the offering is Brahman (Divine Reality), the oblation is Brahman, the fire is Brahman, the act of offering is performed by Brahman, and the goal to be attained is Brahman. This verse reveals the non-dual nature of spiritualized action where all distinctions dissolve into the unified field of divine consciousness. It indicates that when one perceives the divine in every aspect of action, they attain the supreme state of consciousness.
Famous Quotes: "In a gentle way, you can shake the world."
Comparison/Relations: Gandhi's quote about gentle action having profound impact connects with Krishna's teaching about spiritualized action. Both point to the transformative power that comes from alignment with higher principles. Krishna describes how actions performed with awareness of the all-pervading divine nature lead to the attainment of Brahman, while Gandhi suggests that even small actions, when aligned with truth (a manifestation of Brahman), can transform the world. Both emphasize the potency of action that emerges from spiritual consciousness.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
दैवमेवापरे यज्ञं योगिनः पर्युपासते |
ब्रह्माग्नावपरे यज्ञं यज्ञेनैवोपजुह्वति || 4.25 ||
Sloka (English Translation): Some yogis perfectly worship the demigods by offering different sacrifices to them, and some of them offer sacrifices in the fire of the Supreme Brahman.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna begins describing various types of sacrifices (yajnas) performed by different practitioners. Some yogis perform sacrifices to worship celestial beings (devas), while others offer the sacrifice itself as an offering into the fire of Brahman (the Ultimate Reality). This verse begins a section comparing different spiritual practices, showing how various approaches can all be forms of sacrifice leading to spiritual progress, though with different levels of understanding and efficacy.
Famous Quotes: "There are many paths to the top of the mountain, but the view is always the same."
Comparison/Relations: This Chinese proverb about multiple paths leading to the same summit resonates with Krishna's description of different forms of sacrifice. Both acknowledge the validity of various spiritual approaches while suggesting they ultimately converge. Krishna outlines how some worship deities while others offer directly to Brahman, implying a hierarchy of practice but acknowledging the value of different methods, similar to how the proverb validates diverse paths while affirming they lead to the same ultimate viewpoint.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रोत्रादीनीन्द्रियाण्यन्ये संयमाग्निषु जुह्वति |
शब्दादीन्विषयानन्य इन्द्रियाग्निषु जुह्वति || 4.26 ||
Sloka (English Translation): Some of them sacrifice the hearing process and the senses in the fire of mental control, and others sacrifice the objects of the senses in the fire of the senses.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna continues describing different types of sacrifices, focusing now on sensory discipline. Some practitioners sacrifice the senses themselves (the faculties of perception) in the fire of self-control, while others sacrifice the objects of senses (what is perceived) in the fire of the senses themselves. This verse shows how spiritual practice can involve either withdrawing the senses from their objects (pratyahara) or engaging with sense objects with awareness and discipline—both approaches representing valid but different forms of sacrifice.
Famous Quotes: "The world is full of magic things, patiently waiting for our senses to grow sharper."
Comparison/Relations: Yeats' quote about sharpening the senses to perceive magic relates to Krishna's teaching about the sacrifice of sensory experience. While Krishna describes how some practitioners sacrifice sense objects and others sacrifice the senses themselves in spiritual discipline, Yeats suggests a refinement of sensory perception that reveals deeper dimensions of reality. Both point to the transformation of ordinary perception through spiritual practice, though Krishna's approach emphasizes control while Yeats emphasizes heightened awareness.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सर्वाणीन्द्रियकर्माणि प्राणकर्माणि चापरे |
आत्मसंयमयोगाग्नौ जुह्वति ज्ञानदीपिते || 4.27 ||
Sloka (English Translation): Others, who are interested in achieving self-realization through control of the mind and senses, offer the functions of all the senses, and of the life breath, as oblations into the fire of the controlled mind.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna describes practitioners who offer all sensory activities and vital functions (prana) as oblations into the fire of self-discipline kindled by knowledge. This verse refers to advanced yoga practices where all physiological and psychological functions are brought under conscious control and offered into the illuminated consciousness. This represents a more comprehensive form of sacrifice that integrates control of both external senses and internal life energies through knowledge-guided discipline.
Famous Quotes: "The mind is everything. What you think you become."
Comparison/Relations: Buddha's quote about the mind determining what we become parallels Krishna's teaching about sacrificing all functions into the fire of the controlled mind. Both emphasize the primary importance of mental discipline in spiritual transformation. Krishna describes the practice of offering all sensory and vital functions as sacrifices into the "fire of the controlled mind illumined by knowledge," while Buddha similarly points to the mind as the fundamental determinant of our being and becoming.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
द्रव्ययज्ञास्तपोयज्ञा योगयज्ञास्तथापरे |
स्वाध्यायज्ञानयज्ञाश्च यतयः संशितव्रताः || 4.28 ||
Sloka (English Translation): Having accepted strict vows, some become enlightened by sacrificing their possessions, and others by performing severe austerities, by practicing the yoga of eightfold mysticism, or by studying the Vedas to advance in transcendental knowledge.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna continues cataloging various forms of sacrifice: some sacrifice material possessions (charity), others perform austerities (tapas), some practice the eightfold system of yoga, and others study sacred texts for advancement in knowledge. This verse demonstrates the diverse paths of spiritual practice, all characterized as different forms of sacrifice requiring discipline and commitment. It shows that spiritual advancement can occur through multiple approaches—material renunciation, physical discipline, systematic spiritual practice, or intellectual study.
Famous Quotes: "Knowing others is intelligence; knowing yourself is true wisdom. Mastering others is strength; mastering yourself is true power."
Comparison/Relations: Lao Tzu's quote about self-mastery being true wisdom and power aligns with Krishna's description of various disciplines as paths to enlightenment. Both emphasize the value of self-discipline and inner development. Krishna outlines multiple approaches to spiritual sacrifice—material, physical, yogic, and intellectual—while Lao Tzu similarly distinguishes between external mastery and the superior discipline of self-mastery. Both suggest that true advancement comes through disciplined self-cultivation rather than external conquest.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अपाने जुह्वति प्राणं प्राणेऽपानं तथापरे |
प्राणापानगती रुद्ध्वा प्राणायामपरायणाः |
अपरे नियताहाराः प्राणान्प्राणेषु जुह्वति || 4.29 ||
Sloka (English Translation): Still others, who are inclined to the process of breath restraint to remain in trance, practice by offering the movement of the outgoing breath into the incoming, and the incoming breath into the outgoing, and thus at last remain in trance, stopping all breathing. Others, curtailing the eating process, offer the outgoing breath into itself as a sacrifice.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna describes advanced pranayama (breath control) practices as forms of sacrifice. Some practitioners offer the outgoing breath (prana) into the incoming breath (apana) and vice versa, eventually suspending breath in a state of trance. Others restrict their food intake and offer their life-forces into themselves. This verse details specific yogic techniques involving the control of vital energies as spiritual sacrifice, showing how even physiological functions can be transformed into sacred practice through conscious regulation and internalization.
Famous Quotes: "Breath is the bridge which connects life to consciousness, which unites your body to your thoughts."
Comparison/Relations: Thich Nhat Hanh's quote about breath connecting life, consciousness, and thought aligns with Krishna's teaching about pranayama as spiritual sacrifice. Both recognize the profound significance of breath beyond mere physiology. Krishna describes detailed techniques of offering the breaths into each other and achieving trance through breath control, while Thich Nhat Hanh similarly identifies breath as the connective medium between different dimensions of being—physical, mental, and spiritual.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सर्वेऽप्येते यज्ञविदो यज्ञक्षपितकल्मषाः |
यज्ञशिष्टामृतभुजो यान्ति ब्रह्म सनातनम् || 4.30 ||
Sloka (English Translation): All these performers who know the meaning of sacrifice become cleansed of sinful reactions, and, having tasted the nectar of the results of sacrifices, they advance toward the supreme eternal atmosphere.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna concludes this section by stating that all these various practitioners who understand the true meaning of sacrifice have their impurities destroyed by their sacrificial practices. Having tasted the "nectar of sacrifice" (the spiritual fulfillment that comes from sacred action), they progress toward the eternal Brahman, the supreme reality. This verse emphasizes that despite the diversity of approaches, all authentic sacrificial practices lead to purification and spiritual advancement when performed with proper understanding, ultimately guiding the practitioner toward the same eternal destination.
Famous Quotes: "We are not human beings having a spiritual experience. We are spiritual beings having a human experience."
Comparison/Relations: Chardin's quote about our essential spiritual nature connects with Krishna's teaching about various sacrifices leading to the eternal Brahman. Both point to the transcendent dimension of human existence. Krishna describes how diverse spiritual practices ultimately lead practitioners to the "supreme eternal atmosphere" when performed with understanding, while Chardin similarly suggests that our true identity is spiritual rather than material. Both perspectives emphasize that authentic spiritual practice reconnects us with our eternal nature that transcends temporal existence.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यज्ञशिष्टामृतभुजो यान्ति ब्रह्म सनातनम् ।
नायं लोकोऽस्त्ययज्ञस्य कुतोऽन्यः कुरुसत्तम ॥४-३१॥
Sloka (English Translation): Those who partake of the nectar of the remnants of sacrifices go to the eternal Brahman. This world is not for one who performs no sacrifice; how then can the other world be for him, O best of the Kurus?
Meaning/Interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of yajna (sacrifice) and selfless action. Those who perform actions as sacrifice and partake only of what remains after offering to the divine attain the eternal. Krishna explains that those who live without the spirit of sacrifice cannot find happiness even in this world, let alone spiritual liberation.
Comparison/Relations: Gandhi's quote captures the essence of yajna in modern terms—the sacrifice of one's ego and self-interest in service to others. Just as Krishna teaches that sacrifice leads to the eternal, Gandhi suggests that selfless service leads to self-discovery and fulfillment, echoing the spiritual principle that giving up attachment to fruits of action leads to liberation.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
एवं बहुविधा यज्ञा वितता ब्रह्मणो मुखे ।
कर्मजान्विद्धि तान्सर्वानेवं ज्ञात्वा विमोक्ष्यसे ॥४-३२॥
Sloka (English Translation): Various types of sacrifices are spread out before Brahman (are described in the Vedas). Know them all to be born of action, and having known this, you shall be liberated.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that all forms of sacrifice ultimately stem from action (karma). Understanding that all spiritual practices involve action, and performing these actions without attachment, leads to liberation. This verse highlights the diversity of spiritual paths while emphasizing that all paths involve some form of sacrifice through action.
Comparison/Relations: Gandhi's quote relates to this verse by suggesting that even small actions performed with the right spirit can have profound effects. Similarly, Krishna teaches that liberation comes not from avoiding action but from understanding the nature of action and sacrifice. Both emphasize that transformative power comes through right action rather than inaction.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रेयान्द्रव्यमयाद्यज्ञाज्ज्ञानयज्ञः परन्तप ।
सर्वं कर्माखिलं पार्थ ज्ञाने परिसमाप्यते ॥४-३३॥
Sloka (English Translation): Superior to the sacrifice of material possessions is the sacrifice of knowledge, O scorcher of foes. All actions in their entirety, O Partha, culminate in knowledge.
Meaning/Interpretation: This verse establishes the hierarchy of sacrifices, placing the sacrifice of knowledge (jnana yajna) above material sacrifices. Krishna tells Arjuna that while all forms of sacrifice are valuable, the pursuit of spiritual knowledge is supreme because all actions ultimately find their fulfillment in wisdom. True knowledge leads to the understanding that the self is not the doer.
Comparison/Relations: Socrates' famous statement about wisdom reflects the paradoxical nature of true knowledge that Krishna describes. Just as Krishna places the sacrifice of knowledge above material sacrifices, Socrates suggests that genuine wisdom begins with acknowledging our limitations. Both point to a transcendent understanding that goes beyond conventional knowledge or material concerns.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तद्विद्धि प्रणिपातेन परिप्रश्नेन सेवया ।
उपदेक्ष्यन्ति ते ज्ञानं ज्ञानिनस्तत्त्वदर्शिनः ॥४-३४॥
Sloka (English Translation): Learn that knowledge by prostrating, by questions, and by service. The wise, who have realized the truth, will impart that knowledge to you.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna advises Arjuna on how to acquire spiritual knowledge: through humility (prostration), sincere inquiry (questioning), and service to the teacher. This verse highlights the traditional guru-disciple relationship and the attitudes necessary for receiving spiritual wisdom. True knowledge comes from those who have direct perception of reality.
Comparison/Relations: This Buddhist proverb captures the essence of Krishna's instruction about approaching spiritual teachers. Both emphasize that genuine spiritual knowledge is transmitted through a relationship characterized by the student's readiness and receptivity. The sloka outlines the specific qualities needed—humility, curiosity, and service—while the proverb suggests that these qualities naturally attract the appropriate teacher.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यज्ज्ञात्वा न पुनर्मोहमेवं यास्यसि पाण्डव ।
येन भूतान्यशेषेण द्रक्ष्यस्यात्मन्यथो मयि ॥४-३५॥
Sloka (English Translation): Knowing which, you shall not again fall into delusion, O Pandava; and by that, you shall see all beings in your Self, and also in Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains the transformative power of spiritual knowledge. Once obtained, this knowledge permanently dispels the illusion of separateness, enabling one to perceive the fundamental unity of all existence. The enlightened person sees all beings as existing within their own Self and within the divine, recognizing the interconnectedness of all life.
Comparison/Relations: Ram Dass's quote beautifully mirrors Krishna's teaching about the unity of all beings. Just as Krishna speaks of seeing all beings in oneself and in the divine, Ram Dass expresses the profound recognition that we are all on the same journey toward spiritual home. Both convey the dissolution of separation that comes with spiritual awakening—the understanding that we are not isolated individuals but manifestations of the same consciousness.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अपि चेदसि पापेभ्यः सर्वेभ्यः पापकृत्तमः ।
सर्वं ज्ञानप्लवेनैव वृजिनं सन्तरिष्यसि ॥४-३६॥
Sloka (English Translation): Even if you are the most sinful of all sinners, you will cross over all sin by the raft of knowledge.
Meaning/Interpretation: In this powerful verse, Krishna assures Arjuna that spiritual knowledge has the capacity to transcend all past actions, even the most negative ones. Knowledge is compared to a raft that carries one across the ocean of sin or ignorance. This verse offers hope and emphasizes that spiritual liberation is available to everyone, regardless of past mistakes.
Comparison/Relations: George Eliot's quote resonates with Krishna's message of redemption through knowledge. Both emphasize that our future spiritual potential is not limited by our past. Just as Krishna teaches that even the greatest sinner can transcend past actions through the raft of knowledge, Eliot suggests that our true potential remains available to us regardless of previous choices or circumstances.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यथैधांसि समिद्धोऽग्निर्भस्मसात्कुरुतेऽर्जुन ।
ज्ञानाग्निः सर्वकर्माणि भस्मसात्कुरुते तथा ॥४-३७॥
Sloka (English Translation): As the blazing fire reduces wood to ashes, O Arjuna, so does the fire of knowledge reduce all actions to ashes.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna uses a powerful metaphor of fire consuming wood to illustrate how spiritual knowledge consumes the karmic effects of all actions. Just as fire transforms wood into ashes, the fire of knowledge transforms the binding effects of karma. This verse further elaborates on the transformative power of knowledge introduced in the previous verse.
Comparison/Relations: Emerson's quote captures the irreversible transformative power of knowledge that Krishna describes. Just as Krishna portrays knowledge as a fire that permanently transforms actions to ashes, Emerson suggests that genuine insights permanently expand our consciousness. Both express the idea that true knowledge creates a fundamental and irreversible change in one's being.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
न हि ज्ञानेन सदृशं पवित्रमिह विद्यते ।
तत्स्वयं योगसंसिद्धः कालेनात्मनि विन्दति ॥४-३८॥
Sloka (English Translation): Verily, there is nothing in this world as purifying as knowledge. One who has become perfect in yoga finds it within himself in time.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna declares that nothing in this world purifies like knowledge, highlighting its supreme value. He adds that this knowledge naturally reveals itself within a person who has perfected yoga (the disciplined path of spiritual practice). This verse emphasizes both the purifying power of knowledge and the fact that it arises from within through spiritual discipline over time.
Comparison/Relations: Jesus's statement about the divine kingdom being within parallels Krishna's teaching that spiritual knowledge is found within oneself through yogic practice. Both spiritual teachers point to an internal rather than external source of ultimate truth and transformation. They suggest that the highest spiritual realization comes through turning inward rather than seeking outside ourselves.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रद्धावाँल्लभते ज्ञानं तत्परः संयतेन्द्रियः ।
ज्ञानं लब्ध्वा परां शान्तिमचिरेणाधिगच्छति ॥४-३९॥
Sloka (English Translation): The person of faith, devoted to knowledge, and master of the senses, attains knowledge; and having attained knowledge, quickly reaches supreme peace.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna outlines the qualities needed to attain spiritual knowledge: faith (shraddha), devoted effort, and sensory control. When these qualities are present, knowledge arises naturally, and with it comes supreme peace. This verse offers a practical path to knowledge, emphasizing both the prerequisites and the result of spiritual wisdom.
Comparison/Relations: Dr. King's perspective on faith resonates with Krishna's teaching about shraddha (faith) as the foundation for spiritual knowledge. Both suggest that faith is not blind belief but a confident first step on the spiritual journey. Krishna teaches that faith leads to knowledge and then to peace, while King implies that faith initiates a journey toward goals we cannot yet fully perceive but can trust will unfold.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अज्ञश्चाश्रद्दधानश्च संशयात्मा विनश्यति ।
नायं लोकोऽस्ति न परो न सुखं संशयात्मनः ॥४-४०॥
Sloka (English Translation): The ignorant, the faithless, and the doubter perish. For the doubter, there is neither this world nor the next nor any happiness.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna warns about the consequences of doubt, ignorance, and lack of faith. He emphasizes that the perpetual doubter, unable to commit to a path of knowledge, finds no peace or happiness in any realm. This verse highlights the importance of resolving doubt through committed spiritual practice rather than remaining in a state of perpetual skepticism.
Comparison/Relations: Shakespeare's insight about the self-defeating nature of doubt parallels Krishna's warning. Both suggest that excessive doubt prevents progress and fulfillment. Krishna teaches that the doubting mind finds neither worldly nor spiritual happiness, while Shakespeare identifies doubt as the "traitor" that prevents us from achieving what might otherwise be possible through decisive action.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
योगसंन्यस्तकर्माणं ज्ञानसञ्छिन्नसंशयम् ।
आत्मवन्तं न कर्माणि निबध्नन्ति धनञ्जय ॥४-४१॥
Sloka (English Translation): Actions do not bind one who has renounced action through yoga, whose doubts are rent asunder by knowledge, and who is self-possessed, O conqueror of wealth (Arjuna).
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that one who performs actions with yogic detachment, whose doubts have been dispelled by knowledge, and who has mastered the self, is not bound by actions. This verse describes the liberated state where one acts in the world without creating karmic bondage, having transcended identification with the doer through spiritual understanding.
Comparison/Relations: Gandhi's perspective on freedom complements Krishna's teaching about action without bondage. While Krishna speaks of freedom from the binding effects of action through spiritual knowledge, Gandhi points to the importance of freedom in action itself. Both recognize a form of liberation that doesn't avoid action but transforms one's relationship with it—Krishna through transcendence of identification with action, and Gandhi through embracing the full spectrum of human action including mistakes.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तस्मादज्ञानसम्भूतं हृत्स्थं ज्ञानासिनात्मनः ।
छित्त्वैनं संशयं योगमातिष्ठोत्तिष्ठ भारत ॥४-४२॥
Sloka (English Translation): Therefore, cutting asunder the doubt in your heart born of ignorance with the sword of knowledge, resort to yoga and arise, O Bharata (Arjuna).
Meaning/Interpretation: In the concluding verse of Chapter 4, Krishna directly addresses Arjuna's doubt and hesitation. He urges Arjuna to use the sword of knowledge to cut through doubts born of ignorance, to establish himself in yoga (the disciplined path of action without attachment), and to arise to his duty. This verse serves as both a practical instruction and an inspirational call to action.
Comparison/Relations: Joan Baez's quote echoes Krishna's call to action as a solution to inner conflict. Both suggest that resolute action based on clear understanding is the remedy for psychological paralysis. Krishna advises Arjuna to cut through doubt with knowledge and then act through yoga, while Baez similarly identifies action as the way beyond despair, recognizing that purposeful engagement can overcome the paralysis of uncertainty or negative emotion.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अर्जुन उवाच |
संन्यासं कर्मणां कृष्ण पुनर्योगं च शंससि |
यच्छ्रेय एतयोरेकं तन्मे ब्रूहि सुनिश्चितम् ॥५-१॥
Sloka (English Translation): Arjuna said: O Krishna, You praise both renunciation of action and the path of selfless action. Tell me decisively, which one is better?
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna is confused about Krishna's teachings on renunciation (Sannyasa) and selfless action (Karma Yoga) and seeks clarity on the superior path.
Famous Quotes: The mind is everything. What you think you become.
Comparison/Relations: Buddha's idea resonates with Arjuna’s dilemma—one’s state of mind and approach define the true path to enlightenment.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रीभगवानुवाच |
संन्यासः कर्मयोगश्च नि:श्रेयसकरावुभौ |
तयोस्तु कर्मसंन्यासात्कर्मयोगो विशिष्यते ॥५-२॥
Sloka (English Translation): The Blessed Lord said: Both renunciation and selfless action lead to liberation, but of the two, selfless action is superior.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that while renunciation (giving up worldly duties) and Karma Yoga (acting selflessly) both lead to the ultimate goal, Karma Yoga is more practical and beneficial.
Famous Quotes: Action is the foundational key to all success.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s teaching aligns with Picasso’s belief—action, rather than mere detachment, leads to true fulfillment.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ज्ञेयः स नित्यसंन्यासी यो न द्वेष्टि न काङ्क्षति |
निर्द्वन्द्वो हि महाबाहो सुखं बन्धात्प्रमुच्यते ॥५-३॥
Sloka (English Translation): One who neither hates nor desires is to be recognized as a true renunciate. Being free from dualities, such a person is easily liberated.
Meaning/Interpretation: True renunciation does not mean abandoning work, but letting go of attachment and aversion. A balanced mind leads to liberation.
Famous Quotes: Freedom is not worth having if it does not include the freedom to make mistakes.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s message about detachment aligns with Gandhi’s view—true freedom lies in neutrality and acceptance.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
साङ्ख्ययोगौ पृथग्बालाः प्रवदन्ति न पण्डिताः |
एकमप्यास्थितः सम्यगुभयोर्विन्दते फलम् ॥५-४॥
Sloka (English Translation): Foolish people see Sankhya (knowledge) and Karma Yoga (selfless action) as different, but the wise see them as leading to the same goal.
Meaning/Interpretation: Knowledge and action are not opposing paths but complementary. Those with true wisdom understand that both lead to liberation.
Famous Quotes: Knowledge without action is meaningless.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s view matches Abu Bakr’s—wisdom is incomplete without action, and action without wisdom lacks direction.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यत्साङ्ख्यैः प्राप्यते स्थानं तद्योगैरपि गम्यते |
एकं साङ्ख्यं च योगं च यः पश्यति स पश्यति ॥५-५॥
Sloka (English Translation): The state attained by Sankhya (knowledge) is also reached through Karma Yoga (action). One who sees both as one truly sees.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna affirms that whether through wisdom or selfless work, both lead to the same divine realization. True understanding comes from seeing them as one.
Famous Quotes: The only source of knowledge is experience.
Comparison/Relations: Einstein’s belief that experience (action) leads to knowledge aligns with Krishna’s teaching—wisdom and action are two sides of the same coin.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
संन्यासस्तु महाबाहो दुःखमाप्तुमयोगतः |
योगयुक्तो मुनिर्ब्रह्म नचिरेणाधिगच्छति ॥५-६॥
Sloka (English Translation): O mighty-armed Arjuna, renunciation without yoga (selfless action) is difficult to achieve. But the wise one engaged in Karma Yoga swiftly attains Brahman.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that mere renunciation is challenging unless combined with action. True wisdom is achieved through Karma Yoga.
Famous Quotes: It is not enough to be busy; so are the ants. The question is: What are we busy about?
Comparison/Relations: Thoreau’s words align with Krishna’s teaching—action should be purposeful and lead to enlightenment.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
योगयुक्तो विशुद्धात्मा विजितात्मा जितेन्द्रियः |
सर्वभूतात्मभूतात्मा कुर्वन्नपि न लिप्यते ॥५-७॥
Sloka (English Translation): One who is devoted to yoga, with a pure mind, self-controlled, and has mastery over the senses, remains unattached even while performing actions.
Meaning/Interpretation: A true yogi remains untouched by karma’s effects, staying balanced and detached even while acting.
Famous Quotes: Self-control is strength. Right thought is mastery. Calmness is power.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna's teaching aligns with Allen’s view—mastery over the mind and senses leads to true strength.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
नैव किञ्चित्करोमीति युक्तो मन्येत तत्त्ववित् |
पश्यञ्शृण्वन्स्पृशञ्जिघ्रन्नश्नन्गच्छन्स्वपंश्वसन् ॥५-८॥
Sloka (English Translation): The wise one, who understands the truth, thinks, “I do nothing at all,” even while seeing, hearing, touching, smelling, eating, walking, sleeping, and breathing.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna emphasizes that selfless action arises from realizing that the soul is beyond bodily activities.
Famous Quotes: Be like a lotus. Let the beauty of your heart speak. Be grateful to the mud, water, air, and the light.
Comparison/Relations: Like a lotus remains untouched by water, Krishna teaches that a wise person remains unaffected by actions.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
प्रलपन्विसृजन्गृह्णन्नुन्मिषन्निमिषन्नपि |
इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेषु वर्तन्त इति धारयन् ॥५-९॥
Sloka (English Translation): While speaking, giving, receiving, opening, and closing his eyes, he understands that the senses function among sense objects.
Meaning/Interpretation: A self-realized soul sees all actions as mere interactions of the senses, detached from personal ego.
Famous Quotes: Detach from needing to have things work out a certain way. The universe is perfect and there are no failures.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s teaching matches Chopra’s—letting go of attachment to action leads to inner peace.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ब्रह्मण्याधाय कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा करोति यः |
लिप्यते न स पापेन पद्मपत्रमिवाम्भसा ॥५-१०॥
Sloka (English Translation): One who performs all actions surrendering to the Supreme, abandoning attachment, is untouched by sin—just like a lotus leaf remains unstained by water.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna highlights that actions performed in devotion remain free from karma’s bondage.
Famous Quotes: To love and be loved is to feel the sun from both sides.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna's analogy of the lotus leaf reflects Viscott’s idea—living with devotion and detachment brings divine joy.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
कायेन मनसा बुद्ध्या केवलैरिन्द्रियैरपि |
योगिनः कर्म कुर्वन्ति सङ्गं त्यक्त्वाऽत्मशुद्धये ॥५-११॥
Sloka (English Translation): Yogis perform actions with the body, mind, intellect, and senses, abandoning attachment, for the purification of the self.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna emphasizes selfless action—yogis engage in work without attachment, focusing on inner purity rather than outcomes.
Famous Quotes: Your work is to discover your work and then with all your heart to give yourself to it.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna teaches detachment in work, Buddha emphasizes wholehearted devotion to one’s purpose without attachment to results.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
युक्तः कर्मफलं त्यक्त्वा शान्तिमाप्नोति नैष्ठिकीम् |
अयुक्तः कामकारेण फले सक्तो निबध्यते ॥५-१२॥
Sloka (English Translation): The wise person, renouncing the fruits of action, attains eternal peace, whereas the unwise, driven by desire, remains bound.
Meaning/Interpretation: Renouncing results brings inner peace, whereas attachment to results leads to bondage and suffering.
Famous Quotes: Happiness is not something ready made. It comes from your own actions.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s lesson on detachment aligns with the Dalai Lama’s insight—happiness arises from a peaceful mind, not external achievements.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सर्वकर्माणि मनसा संन्यस्यास्ते सुखं वशी |
नवद्वारे पुरे देही नैव कुर्वन्न कारयन् ॥५-१३॥
Sloka (English Translation): The self-controlled person, renouncing all actions mentally, dwells happily in the city of nine gates (the body), neither acting nor causing action.
Meaning/Interpretation: The enlightened person sees the body as a temporary dwelling and remains untouched by worldly distractions.
Famous Quotes: You have power over your mind—not outside events. Realize this, and you will find strength.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna and Aurelius both emphasize self-mastery—real peace comes from within, not from controlling external events.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
न कर्तृत्वं न कर्माणि लोकस्य सृजति प्रभुः |
न कर्मफलसंयोगं स्वभावस्तु प्रवर्तते ॥५-१४॥
Sloka (English Translation): The Supreme Lord neither creates agency nor actions nor the union of actions and results. These arise due to nature alone.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that actions and consequences are governed by material nature, not by divine will.
Famous Quotes: Nature does not hurry, yet everything is accomplished.
Comparison/Relations: Like Krishna, Lao Tzu highlights that the universe operates on its own rhythm, free from force or compulsion.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
नादत्ते कस्यचित्पापं न चैव सुकृतं विभुः |
अज्ञानेनावृतं ज्ञानं तेन मुह्यन्ति जन्तवः ॥५-१५॥
Sloka (English Translation): The Supreme neither takes anyone’s sins nor merits. But ignorance covers knowledge, and thus beings are deluded.
Meaning/Interpretation: God does not impose sin or virtue; ignorance leads to delusion and suffering.
Famous Quotes: Nothing in life is to be feared, it is only to be understood. Now is the time to understand more.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s wisdom aligns with Curie’s—ignorance causes fear, and knowledge brings clarity and liberation.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ज्ञानेन तु तदज्ञानं येषां नाशितमात्मनः |
तेषामादित्यवज्ज्ञानं प्रकाशयति तत्परम् ॥५-१६॥
Sloka (English Translation): For those whose ignorance is destroyed by knowledge of the self, that wisdom, like the sun, reveals the Supreme Truth.
Meaning/Interpretation: Knowledge removes the darkness of ignorance, just as the sun dispels darkness, leading the seeker toward enlightenment.
Famous Quotes: Education is the movement from darkness to light.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s teaching aligns with Bloom’s perspective—true wisdom dispels ignorance and leads to higher awareness.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तद्बुद्धयस्तदात्मानस्तन्निष्ठास्तत्परायणाः |
गच्छन्त्यपुनरावृत्तिं ज्ञाननिर्धूतकल्मषाः ॥५-१७॥
Sloka (English Translation): Those whose intellect is fixed in that (Supreme), whose self is absorbed in that, and who remain steadfast in that, are freed from impurities and attain liberation.
Meaning/Interpretation: Steady devotion to divine wisdom purifies the soul, leading to ultimate liberation (moksha).
Famous Quotes: The only real prison is ignorance, and the only real freedom is enlightenment.
Comparison/Relations: Both Krishna and Buddha emphasize that liberation comes from knowledge, while ignorance binds one to suffering.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
विद्याविनयसम्पन्ने ब्राह्मणे गवि हस्तिनि |
शुनि चैव श्वपाके च पण्डिताः समदर्शिनः ॥५-१८॥
Sloka (English Translation): The wise see the same divinity in a learned priest, a cow, an elephant, a dog, and an outcast.
Meaning/Interpretation: True wisdom leads to equality, seeing divinity in all beings regardless of their social status or form.
Famous Quotes: Do not judge by appearances; a rich heart may be under a poor coat.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s lesson mirrors this proverb—true wisdom values inner essence over external status.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
इहैव तैर्जितः सर्गो येषां साम्ये स्थितं मनः |
निर्दोषं हि समं ब्रह्म तस्माद् ब्रह्मणि ते स्थिताः ॥५-१९॥
Sloka (English Translation): Those whose minds are established in equality have conquered this world. The flawless Brahman is the same everywhere; thus, they remain in Brahman.
Meaning/Interpretation: A person who attains equanimity, seeing everything as one, transcends worldly limitations and dwells in the divine.
Famous Quotes: When we are no longer able to change a situation, we are challenged to change ourselves.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s teaching on inner transformation aligns with Frankl’s view—true power comes from inner change, not external circumstances.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
न प्रहृष्येत् प्रियम् प्राप्य नोद्विजेत् प्राप्य चाप्रियम् |
स्थिरबुद्धिरसंमूढो ब्रह्मविद् ब्रह्मणि स्थितः ॥५-२०॥
Sloka (English Translation): One who neither rejoices upon receiving something pleasant nor grieves upon receiving something unpleasant, who is steady and wise, is established in Brahman.
Meaning/Interpretation: True wisdom brings equanimity—one remains calm and unshaken by life’s ups and downs.
Famous Quotes: Happiness depends upon ourselves.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna and Aristotle agree—true happiness does not come from external things but from inner stability.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
बाह्यस्पर्शेष्वसक्तात्मा विन्दत्यात्मनि यत्सुखम् |
स ब्रह्मयोगयुक्तात्मा सुखमक्षयमश्नुते ॥५-२१॥
Sloka (English Translation): The one who is unattached to external pleasures and finds joy within the self, being united with Brahman, attains eternal bliss.
Meaning/Interpretation: True happiness is not dependent on external objects but is found within, through spiritual realization.
Famous Quotes: Happiness is not something ready-made. It comes from your own actions.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s words align with the Dalai Lama’s teaching—lasting happiness comes from internal wisdom, not external possessions.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ये हि संस्पर्शजा भोगा दुःखयोनय एव ते |
आद्यन्तवन्तः कौन्तेय न तेषु रमते बुधः ॥५-२२॥
Sloka (English Translation): The pleasures that arise from sense contact are the sources of misery, for they have a beginning and an end. Therefore, the wise do not delight in them.
Meaning/Interpretation: Material pleasures are temporary and often lead to suffering, while true contentment lies beyond them.
Famous Quotes: Pleasure is the bait; the pain is the hook.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s teaching warns against fleeting pleasures, much like Owen’s metaphor of pleasure leading to suffering.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
शक्नोतीहैव यः सोढुं प्राक्शरीरविमोक्षणात् |
कामक्रोधोद्भवं वेगं स युक्तः स सुखी नरः ॥५-२३॥
Sloka (English Translation): The one who can withstand the urges of desire and anger before leaving this body is truly a yogi and a happy person.
Meaning/Interpretation: Self-control over emotions leads to inner peace and ultimate happiness.
Famous Quotes: He who controls others may be powerful, but he who has mastered himself is mightier still.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna and Lao Tzu both emphasize that true strength comes from mastering oneself, not controlling the world.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
योऽन्तःसुखोऽन्तरारामस्तथान्तर्ज्योतिरेव यः |
स योगी ब्रह्मनिर्वाणं ब्रह्मभूतोऽधिगच्छति ॥५-२४॥
Sloka (English Translation): One who finds happiness within, delights within, and whose light is within, that yogi attains liberation in Brahman.
Meaning/Interpretation: True seekers find joy in the self, leading to spiritual liberation and freedom.
Famous Quotes: Peace comes from within. Do not seek it without.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s teaching resonates with Buddha’s words—inner peace is the key to true liberation.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
लभन्ते ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृषयः क्षीणकल्मषाः |
छिन्नद्वैधा यतात्मानः सर्वभूतहिते रताः ॥५-२५॥
Sloka (English Translation): The sages whose impurities are destroyed, whose doubts are cut off, whose minds are disciplined, and who are engaged in the welfare of all beings, attain liberation in Brahman.
Meaning/Interpretation: Selfless service, mental discipline, and purification of doubts lead one to Brahman.
Famous Quotes: The best way to find yourself is to lose yourself in the service of others.
Comparison/Relations: Both Krishna and Gandhi highlight that selflessness is the path to spiritual freedom.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
कामक्रोधवियुक्तानां यतीनां यतचेतसाम् |
अभितो ब्रह्मनिर्वाणं वर्तते विदितात्मनाम् ॥५-२६॥
Sloka (English Translation): For those who are free from desire and anger, who have subdued their minds, and who have realized the Self, liberation in Brahman is near.
Meaning/Interpretation: Self-mastery and freedom from destructive emotions lead one to enlightenment.
Famous Quotes: Conquer yourself rather than the world.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna and Descartes both stress the importance of inner control over external conquests.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
स्पर्शान्कृत्वा बहिर्बाह्यांश्चक्षुश्चैवान्तरे भ्रुवोः |
प्राणापानौ समौ कृत्वा नासाभ्यन्तरचारिणौ ॥५-२७॥
Sloka (English Translation): Keeping external contacts outside, fixing the gaze between the eyebrows, and balancing the incoming and outgoing breath within the nostrils.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna describes meditation techniques that lead to deep concentration and self-realization.
Famous Quotes: Your vision will become clear only when you look into your own heart.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna and Jung both emphasize inner focus as the path to clarity and wisdom.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यतेन्द्रियमनोबुद्धिर्मुनिर्मोक्षपरायणः |
विगतेच्छाभयक्रोधो यः सदा मुक्त एव सः ॥५-२८॥
Sloka (English Translation): The sage who has controlled his senses, mind, and intellect, who is committed to liberation, and who is free from desire, fear, and anger, is forever liberated.
Meaning/Interpretation: Mastery over emotions and unwavering commitment to liberation ensure eternal freedom.
Famous Quotes: Freedom is nothing but a chance to be better.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna and Camus both define true freedom as an opportunity for self-improvement.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
भोक्तारं यज्ञतपसां सर्वलोकमहेश्वरम् |
सुहृदं सर्वभूतानां ज्ञात्वा मां शान्तिमृच्छति ॥५-२९॥
Sloka (English Translation): One who realizes Me as the enjoyer of sacrifices and austerities, the supreme Lord of all worlds, and the friend of all beings, attains peace.
Meaning/Interpretation: Understanding God’s role as the supreme well-wisher brings true peace.
Famous Quotes: When I let go of what I am, I become what I might be.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna and Lao Tzu both teach that surrendering ego leads to peace and divine connection.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अनाश्रितः कर्मफलं कार्यं कर्म करोति यः ।
स संन्यासी च योगी च न निरग्निर्न चाक्रियः ॥६-१॥
Sloka (English Translation): He who performs his duty without attachment to the results, he is both a renunciate and a yogi, not he who is without fire and without action.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna emphasizes that true renunciation and yoga involve performing one's duties without attachment to outcomes. Merely abstaining from rituals or actions doesn't constitute genuine renunciation. Instead, it's the inner detachment from the fruits of actions that defines a true yogi.
Famous Quotes: Do your work with mastery; by detachment, one achieves the highest.
Comparison/Relations: This verse aligns with the earlier teachings in the Gita, where Krishna advocates for selfless action. The essence is to focus on one's responsibilities with dedication, without being swayed by the desire for specific results.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यं संन्यासमिति प्राहुर्योगं तं विद्धि पाण्डव ।
न ह्यसंन्यस्तसङ्कल्पो योगी भवति कश्चन ॥६-२॥
Sloka (English Translation): What they call renunciation, know that to be yoga, O Pandava; for without renouncing desires, no one can become a yogi.
Meaning/Interpretation: Renunciation and yoga are intrinsically linked. To attain the state of a yogi, one must relinquish personal desires and attachments. It's not about abandoning actions but about transcending the selfish motives behind them.
Famous Quotes: Renunciation is not giving up the things of this world, but accepting that they go away.
Comparison/Relations: Swami Turiyananda's perspective resonates with this verse, highlighting that true renunciation is an internal process of letting go of attachments, rather than merely forsaking external possessions or actions.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
आरुरुक्षोर्मुनेर्योगं कर्म कारणमुच्यते ।
योगारूढस्य तस्यैव शमः कारणमुच्यते ॥६-३॥
Sloka (English Translation): For a sage aspiring to attain yoga, action is said to be the means; for the same sage who has attained yoga, tranquility is said to be the means.
Meaning/Interpretation: In the initial stages, disciplined action is essential for spiritual growth. However, once a person attains a higher state of yoga, inner peace and tranquility become paramount, guiding their existence.
Famous Quotes: First, have a definite, clear practical ideal; a goal, an objective. Second, have the necessary means to achieve your ends; wisdom, money, materials, and methods. Third, adjust all your means to that end.
Comparison/Relations: Aristotle's emphasis on having a clear goal and the means to achieve it parallels the progression described in this verse—from active pursuit to achieving a state of tranquility.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यदा हि नेन्द्रियार्थेषु न कर्मस्वनुषज्जते ।
सर्वसङ्कल्पसंन्यासी योगारूढस्तदोच्यते ॥६-४॥
Sloka (English Translation): When a person is not attached to sense objects or to actions, having renounced all desires, then he is said to have ascended to yoga.
Meaning/Interpretation: A true yogi is one who has transcended attachments to sensory pleasures and actions, having relinquished all personal desires. This detachment signifies the attainment of yoga.
Famous Quotes: Freedom is not procured by a full enjoyment of what is desired, but by controlling the desire.
Comparison/Relations: Epictetus, the Stoic philosopher, echoes the sentiment that true freedom arises from mastering one's desires, aligning with the yogic principle of detachment.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
उद्धरेदात्मनात्मानं नात्मानमवसादयेत् ।
आत्मैव ह्यात्मनो बन्धुरात्मैव रिपुरात्मनः ॥६-५॥
Sloka (English Translation): One must elevate oneself by one's own mind, not degrade oneself. The mind alone is the friend of the self, and the mind alone is the enemy of the self.
Meaning/Interpretation: The mind plays a pivotal role in one's spiritual journey. It can be one's greatest ally or adversary. Therefore, it's essential to cultivate and discipline the mind to uplift oneself.
Famous Quotes: All that we are is the result of what we have thought: we are formed and molded by our thoughts.
Comparison/Relations: This Buddhist teaching underscores the power of the mind in shaping our reality, emphasizing the importance of mental discipline, much like Krishna's counsel in this verse.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
बन्धुरात्मात्मनस्तस्य येनात्मैवात्मना जितः ।
अनात्मनस्तु शत्रुत्वे वर्तेतात्मैव शत्रुवत् ॥६-६॥
Sloka (English Translation): For him who has conquered the mind, the mind is the best of friends; but for one who has failed to do so, the mind will remain the greatest enemy.
Meaning/Interpretation: Mastery over the mind transforms it into a supportive ally, guiding one towards liberation. Conversely, an undisciplined mind can lead to one's downfall, acting as an internal adversary.
Famous Quotes: Your worst enemy cannot harm you as much as your own unguarded thoughts.
Comparison/Relations: Buddha's insight aligns with this verse, highlighting the significance of guarding and mastering one's thoughts to ensure inner harmony.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
जितात्मनः प्रशान्तस्य परमात्मा समाहितः ।
शीतोष्णसुखदुःखेषु तथा मानापमानयोः ॥६-७॥
Sloka (English Translation): The Supreme Self of one who is self-controlled and peaceful is unwavering in cold and heat, pleasure and pain, as well as in honor and dishonor.
Meaning/Interpretation: A true yogi, having mastered their mind, remains unshaken by external circumstances. They perceive both suffering and joy, praise and blame, with equal calmness.
Famous Quotes: He who has conquered himself is a far greater hero than he who has defeated a thousand times a thousand men.
Comparison/Relations: Buddha's teaching echoes Krishna's emphasis on inner victory over external battles, reinforcing the idea that true strength lies in self-mastery.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ज्ञानविज्ञानतृप्तात्मा कूटस्थो विजितेन्द्रियः ।
युक्त इत्युच्यते योगी समलोष्टाश्मकाञ्चनः ॥६-८॥
Sloka (English Translation): A person who is satisfied with knowledge and wisdom, unshakable, and has conquered the senses, sees a lump of clay, a stone, and gold as equal — such a person is called a yogi.
Meaning/Interpretation: The enlightened yogi views all material possessions, be it gold or mere clay, with the same indifference. Their inner fulfillment arises from wisdom and self-control, not from external wealth.
Famous Quotes: Wealth consists not in having great possessions, but in having few wants.
Comparison/Relations: Epictetus’ words mirror Krishna’s teachings—true wealth lies in detachment from materialism, fostering inner contentment rather than chasing possessions.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सुहृन्मित्रार्युदासीनमध्यस्थद्वेष्यबन्धुषु ।
साधुष्वपि च पापेषु समबुद्धिर्विशिष्यते ॥६-९॥
Sloka (English Translation): He who regards friends, enemies, the indifferent, the neutral, the hateful, the relatives, the righteous, and even the sinful with an equal mind excels.
Meaning/Interpretation: A yogi treats all beings equally — whether they are kind, hostile, or sinful. Such impartiality shows true spiritual maturity, where one transcends judgment and attachment.
Famous Quotes: When we see others as part of ourselves, we begin to understand the true meaning of compassion.
Comparison/Relations: The Dalai Lama's wisdom aligns with this verse, promoting empathy and equality for all, regardless of how they behave toward us.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
योगी युञ्जीत सततमात्मानं रहसि स्थितः ।
एकाकी यतचित्तात्मा निराशीरपरिग्रहः ॥६-१०॥
Sloka (English Translation): Let the yogi constantly engage the mind in meditation, dwelling alone in solitude, with controlled thoughts and desires, free from possessions and expectations.
Meaning/Interpretation: A yogi should practice continuous meditation in solitude, withdrawing from material attachments and expectations. This focused discipline paves the way to spiritual awakening.
Famous Quotes: Silence is a source of great strength.
Comparison/Relations: Lao Tzu's words resonate with Krishna's advice — solitude and silent reflection strengthen the mind, leading to inner peace and spiritual growth.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
शुचौ देशे प्रतिष्ठाप्य स्थिरमासनमात्मनः ।
नात्युच्छ्रितं नातिनीचं चैलाजिनकुशोत्तरम् ॥६-११॥
Sloka (English Translation): In a clean and sacred place, establish a firm seat for yourself — neither too high nor too low — covered with cloth, deerskin, and kusha grass.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna advises creating a serene and pure space for meditation, emphasizing balance and simplicity. The seat’s moderate height symbolizes stability — neither indulgence nor deprivation aids spiritual focus.
Famous Quotes: Outer order contributes to inner calm.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna suggests maintaining a clean, balanced environment for meditation, Rubin highlights how external order fosters internal peace. Both stress the link between surroundings and mental clarity.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तत्रैकाग्रं मनः कृत्वा यतचित्तेन्द्रियक्रियः ।
उपविश्यासने युञ्ज्याद्योगमात्मविशुद्धये ॥६-१२॥
Sloka (English Translation): Seated there, focusing the mind with one-pointed concentration, controlling thoughts and senses, one should practice meditation for self-purification.
Meaning/Interpretation: Meditation begins with focus and discipline. By mastering the mind and senses, one progresses toward inner purity. Krishna teaches that true spiritual progress starts with unwavering concentration.
Famous Quotes: You have power over your mind — not outside events. Realize this, and you will find strength.
Comparison/Relations: Marcus Aurelius' Stoic philosophy aligns with Krishna's teaching — inner control leads to spiritual strength. Both emphasize mastering thoughts rather than external situations.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
समं कायशिरोग्रीवं धारयन्नचलं स्थिरः ।
सम्प्रेक्ष्य नासिकाग्रं स्वं दिशश्चानवलोकयन् ॥६-१३॥
Sloka (English Translation): Hold the body, head, and neck upright and still, gazing steadily at the tip of the nose, without looking in any other direction.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna instructs on proper posture for meditation — an upright spine and fixed gaze symbolize alertness and focus. Avoiding distractions by controlling physical alignment fosters mental stillness.
Famous Quotes: Posture affects and moderates every physiological function from breathing to hormonal production.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna emphasizes physical discipline for mental clarity, modern science (as highlighted by Dr. Sperry) supports the idea that posture directly impacts internal balance and focus.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
प्रशान्तात्मा विगतभीर्ब्रह्मचारिव्रते स्थितः ।
मनः संयम्य मच्चित्तो युक्त आसीत मत्परः ॥६-१४॥
Sloka (English Translation): With a serene mind, fearless and steadfast in the vow of celibacy, keeping the mind controlled and focused on Me, the yogi should sit, absorbed in Me as the supreme goal.
Meaning/Interpretation: Inner peace, fearlessness, and self-discipline are essential for a yogi. Krishna highlights unwavering devotion, teaching that true focus arises from surrendering to a higher purpose.
Famous Quotes: Fearlessness is the first requisite of spirituality.
Comparison/Relations: Gandhi echoes Krishna's lesson — without fear, the mind can truly focus on the divine. Both stress that courage and devotion walk hand in hand on the spiritual path.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
युञ्जन्नेवं सदात्मानं योगी नियतमानसः ।
शान्तिं निर्वाणपरमां मत्संस्थामधिगच्छति ॥६-१५॥
Sloka (English Translation): Thus, always keeping the mind absorbed in yoga, with a disciplined mind, the yogi attains the supreme peace that resides in Me — ultimate liberation.
Meaning/Interpretation: By steady dedication to yoga and a controlled mind, Krishna reveals that the final reward is not just peace — it is unity with the divine. Liberation is not distant but found through persistent spiritual practice.
