Famous Quotes: Peace comes from within. Do not seek it without.
Comparison/Relations: Buddha's words resonate deeply with Krishna's message — true peace and liberation arise from inner spiritual discipline, not external pursuits.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
नात्यश्नतस्तु योगोऽस्ति न चैकान्तमनश्नतः ।
न चातिस्वप्नशीलस्य जाग्रतो नैव चार्जुन ॥६-१६॥
Sloka (English Translation): There is no possibility of achieving yoga for one who eats too much or does not eat at all, nor for one who sleeps too much or does not sleep enough, O Arjuna.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna teaches the importance of balance in life. True spiritual discipline (yoga) cannot thrive in extremes — be it overindulgence or excessive austerity. Harmony in daily habits is key to spiritual progress.
Famous Quotes: Balance is not something you find, it's something you create.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna emphasizes balance in eating, sleeping, and living, Jana Kingsford highlights that balance requires conscious effort. Both suggest that stability in physical life supports inner growth.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
युक्ताहारविहारस्य युक्तचेष्टस्य कर्मसु ।
युक्तस्वप्नावबोधस्य योगो भवति दुःखहा ॥६-१७॥
Sloka (English Translation): He who is moderate in eating, recreation, work, and sleep can by practicing yoga, rid himself of all sorrow.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that a yogi achieves freedom from suffering through moderation in all aspects of life. Neither excess nor deprivation leads to inner peace — the path of balance removes sorrow and fosters clarity.
Famous Quotes: Happiness is not a matter of intensity but of balance, order, rhythm, and harmony.
Comparison/Relations: Thomas Merton's words mirror Krishna’s teaching — true contentment arises not from extremes but from balanced living. Both highlight that measured actions create a foundation for lasting peace.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यदा विनियतं चित्तमात्मन्येवावतिष्ठते ।
निःस्पृहः सर्वकामेभ्यो युक्त इत्युच्यते तदा ॥६-१८॥
Sloka (English Translation): When the disciplined mind is fixed in the Self, free from all desires, then one is said to be established in yoga.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna describes the essence of true yoga — a mind anchored in the Self, unaffected by fleeting desires. Mastery over the mind, rooted in self-awareness, leads to spiritual stability.
Famous Quotes: You will never be free until you free yourself from the prison of your own false thoughts.
Comparison/Relations: Philip Arnold’s insight aligns with Krishna’s message: freedom comes from conquering inner desires and false notions. Both emphasize inner liberation as the foundation for spiritual progress.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यथा दीपो निवातस्थो नेङ्गते सोपमा स्मृता ।
योगिनो यतचित्तस्य युञ्जतो योगमात्मनः ॥६-१९॥
Sloka (English Translation): Just as a lamp does not flicker in a windless place, so is the disciplined mind of a yogi practicing meditation.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna uses a powerful metaphor — the unwavering flame symbolizes the steady mind of a yogi. Inner stillness comes from mastering thoughts, unaffected by external distractions.
Famous Quotes: Calmness is the cradle of power.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s imagery of the steady flame aligns with Holland’s wisdom — true strength arises from calm focus. Both highlight the power found in inner stillness and self-control.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यत्रोपरमते चित्तं निरुद्धं योगसेवया ।
यत्र चैवात्मनात्मानं पश्यन्नात्मनि तुष्यति ॥६-२०॥
Sloka (English Translation): When the mind, restrained through the practice of yoga, becomes still, and when one realizes the Self within, one experiences boundless joy.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna teaches that the ultimate fruit of meditation is a joyful realization of the Self. When thoughts are stilled and awareness turns inward, the yogi finds bliss beyond material experiences.
Famous Quotes: The soul always knows what to do to heal itself. The challenge is to silence the mind.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna's message echoes Caroline Myss' reflection — inner joy arises when the mind's noise fades and the soul’s truth emerges. Both highlight how stillness reveals the Self’s infinite happiness.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सुखमात्यन्तिकं यत्तद्बुद्धिग्राह्यमतीन्द्रियम् ।
वेत्ति यत्र न चैवायं स्थितश्चलति तत्त्वतः ॥६-२१॥
Sloka (English Translation): That infinite bliss which is grasped by the intellect beyond the senses — once established in it, one never swerves from the truth.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna describes the supreme joy experienced in deep meditation. This happiness, rooted beyond sensory pleasures, is understood by the intellect and is unwavering — a sign of spiritual realization.
Famous Quotes: True happiness is not out there. True happiness lies within.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s message parallels the timeless wisdom that real joy doesn’t depend on external factors. It’s an internal experience, just as modern reflections on happiness emphasize inner peace over material gratification.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यं लब्ध्वा चापरं लाभं मन्यते नाधिकं ततः ।
यस्मिन्स्थितो न दुःखेन गुरुणापि विचाल्यते ॥६-२२॥
Sloka (English Translation): Having gained this state, one thinks there is no greater gain. Established in it, even the heaviest sorrow cannot shake one.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna emphasizes that spiritual realization is the ultimate achievement. Once a yogi experiences this inner state, no amount of external suffering can disturb their peace.
Famous Quotes: Peace is not the absence of trouble, but the presence of God.
Comparison/Relations: Like Krishna, Oswald Chambers suggests that true peace comes not from a life without hardship but from a steady inner connection — a spiritual anchoring that transcends external chaos.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तं विद्याद् दुःखसंयोगवियोगं योगसञ्ज्ञितम् ।
स निश्चयेन योक्तव्यो योगोऽनिर्विण्णचेतसा ॥६-२३॥
Sloka (English Translation): Understand that yoga is the disconnection from union with pain. This yoga should be practiced with determination and an unwavering mind.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna defines yoga as a state of freedom from suffering. He stresses the importance of disciplined, resolute practice to break free from the mind's habitual attachment to pain.
Famous Quotes: Discipline is the bridge between goals and accomplishment.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna teaches that yoga requires focused discipline, Jim Rohn highlights that consistent effort bridges the gap between dreams and success. Both stress the need for steadfast practice.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सङ्कल्पप्रभवान्कामांस्त्यक्त्वा सर्वानशेषतः ।
मनसैवेन्द्रियग्रामं विनियम्य समन्ततः ॥६-२४॥
Sloka (English Translation): Abandon all desires born of mental imagination, and fully restrain the senses by the mind from all sides.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna advises yogis to let go of all mentally-created desires. Mastery over the senses and thoughts leads to inner tranquility and spiritual focus.
Famous Quotes: You have power over your mind — not outside events. Realize this, and you will find strength.
Comparison/Relations: Marcus Aurelius’ Stoic wisdom resonates with Krishna’s teaching — both highlight that inner mastery, not external control, brings true strength and freedom.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
शनैः शनैरुपरमेद्बुद्ध्या धृतिगृहीतया ।
आत्मसंस्थं मनः कृत्वा न किञ्चिदपि चिन्तयेत् ॥६-२५॥
Sloka (English Translation): Gradually, step by step, one should withdraw the mind with firm determination and fix it steadily on the Self, thinking of nothing else.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna emphasizes that meditation requires patience and steady effort. The yogi must gently bring the mind back to focus, avoiding distraction, and centering awareness solely on the Self.
Famous Quotes: Success is the sum of small efforts, repeated day in and day out.
Comparison/Relations: Robert Collier’s reflection echoes Krishna’s message — spiritual mastery comes through slow, steady progress. Both highlight that consistent effort, not sudden leaps, leads to success.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यतो यतो निश्चरति मनश्चञ्चलमस्थिरम् ।
ततस्ततो नियम्यैतदात्मन्येव वशं नयेत् ॥६-२६॥
Sloka (English Translation): Whenever the restless and unsteady mind wanders, one should bring it back and repeatedly focus it on the Self.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna acknowledges the mind's tendency to wander but emphasizes the importance of consistently redirecting it towards the Self. Mastery over the mind is achieved through persistence and focus.
Famous Quotes: The mind is like water. When it's turbulent, it's difficult to see. When it's calm, everything becomes clear.
Comparison/Relations: Both Krishna and Buddha highlight the necessity of calming the mind. Krishna advises discipline, while Buddha points out that clarity emerges only when the mind is still — a shared wisdom about inner focus.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
प्रशान्तमनसं ह्येनं योगिनं सुखमुत्तमम् ।
उपैति शान्तरजसं ब्रह्मभूतमकल्मषम् ॥६-२७॥
Sloka (English Translation): The yogi whose mind is fully tranquil, whose passions are calm, who is free from sin, attains the supreme happiness that comes from union with the divine.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna describes the blissful state of a yogi who has conquered the disturbances of the mind and emotions. This serenity opens the path to divine joy and spiritual purity.
Famous Quotes: Peace begins when expectation ends.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s emphasis on inner peace aligns with Sri Chinmoy’s idea that true tranquility arises when one releases desires and expectations. Both suggest that stillness leads to happiness.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
युञ्जन्नेवं सदाऽऽत्मानं योगी विगतकल्मषः ।
सुखेन ब्रह्मसंस्पर्शमत्यन्तं सुखमश्नुते ॥६-२८॥
Sloka (English Translation): The yogi, always practicing in this way, freed from sin, experiences infinite bliss through constant union with the divine.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna emphasizes that ongoing spiritual practice dissolves past impurities. A yogi who remains connected with the divine consistently enjoys boundless inner happiness.
Famous Quotes: Consistent practice leads to mastery.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna's focus on continuous effort echoes Robin Sharma’s idea — mastery, whether spiritual or practical, comes from steady practice and commitment.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सर्वभूतस्थमात्मानं सर्वभूतानि चात्मनि ।
ईक्षते योगयुक्तात्मा सर्वत्र समदर्शनः ॥६-२९॥
Sloka (English Translation): The yogi sees the Self in all beings and all beings in the Self. Such a person, rooted in yoga, views everything with equality.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna highlights the spiritual realization that comes from yoga: a vision of unity. A true yogi perceives no separation between themselves and others, recognizing the divine essence in all.
Famous Quotes: When you see yourself in others, whom can you harm?
Comparison/Relations: Both Krishna and Buddha promote the idea of oneness — understanding that all beings share a divine essence fosters compassion and equality.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यो मां पश्यति सर्वत्र सर्वं च मयि पश्यति ।
तस्याहं न प्रणश्यामि स च मे न प्रणश्यति ॥६-३०॥
Sloka (English Translation): Whoever sees Me in everything and everything in Me, I am never lost to them, nor are they ever lost to Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains the deep connection between the devotee and the divine. When a yogi perceives God's presence everywhere, the bond with the divine becomes unbreakable.
Famous Quotes: The divine is not something high above us. It is in everything.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna's teaching resonates with Ueshiba’s belief — the divine isn’t distant but interwoven in all things. Recognizing this unity strengthens spiritual connection.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सर्वभूतस्थितं यो मां भजत्येकत्वमास्थितः ।
सर्वथा वर्तमानोऽपि स योगी मयि वर्तते ॥६-३१॥
Sloka (English Translation): The yogi who worships Me as abiding in all beings, who perceives unity, remains in Me, regardless of their actions.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna emphasizes that true yogis see the divine in all beings and recognize the oneness of existence. By maintaining this vision, they stay ever connected to Krishna, no matter their external circumstances.
Famous Quotes: To love another person is to see the face of God.
Comparison/Relations: Victor Hugo’s notion of seeing the divine in others mirrors Krishna's teaching — recognizing the presence of God in every being strengthens the spiritual bond and cultivates compassion.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
आत्मौपम्येन सर्वत्र समं पश्यति योऽर्जुन ।
सुखं वा यदि वा दुःखं स योगी परमो मतः ॥६-३२॥
Sloka (English Translation): O Arjuna, the one who, by comparison with oneself, sees the true equality of all beings in both happiness and sorrow is considered the highest yogi.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that supreme yoga is the ability to empathize with others — seeing their joys and sorrows as one's own. This sense of universal empathy and equality marks the highest level of spiritual attainment.
Famous Quotes: Put yourself in someone else's shoes and imagine how they feel.
Comparison/Relations: Harper Lee's advice about empathy reflects Krishna's call for yogis to perceive others’ experiences as their own. Both highlight that true compassion arises from identifying with others’ happiness and pain.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अर्जुन उवाच:
योऽयं योगस्त्वया प्रोक्तः साम्येन मधुसूदन ।
एतस्याहं न पश्यामि चञ्चलत्वात्स्थितिं स्थिराम् ॥६-३३॥
Sloka (English Translation): Arjuna said: O Madhusudana, this yoga of equanimity that You have described seems impractical to me, for the mind is restless and unsteady.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna, expressing human vulnerability, admits that maintaining mental equilibrium feels difficult due to the mind's natural restlessness. This verse reminds us that even the greatest warriors struggle with inner control.
Famous Quotes: You have power over your mind — not outside events. Realize this, and you will find strength.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Arjuna grapples with controlling his mind, Marcus Aurelius' wisdom encourages mastering one's thoughts, reinforcing Krishna’s teachings about inner discipline over external chaos.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
चञ्चलं हि मनः कृष्ण प्रमाथि बलवद्दृढम् ।
तस्याहं निग्रहं मन्ये वायोरिव सुदुष्करम् ॥६-३४॥
Sloka (English Translation): O Krishna, the mind is indeed restless, turbulent, strong, and obstinate. To control it seems as difficult as restraining the wind.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna likens the mind to the wind — wild and uncontrollable — highlighting the universal struggle for mental discipline. This verse reassures seekers that struggling with inner focus is part of the journey.
Famous Quotes: You cannot control the wind, but you can adjust the sails.
Comparison/Relations: Arjuna’s struggle echoes Dolly Parton's metaphor: while the mind may be as untamable as the wind, we can still redirect its course through practice and awareness, aligning with Krishna’s path of discipline.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रीभगवानुवाच:
असंशयं महाबाहो मनो दुर्निग्रहं चलम् ।
अभ्यासेन तु कौन्तेय वैराग्येण च गृह्यते ॥६-३५॥
Sloka (English Translation): The Blessed Lord said: O mighty-armed Arjuna, the mind is undoubtedly restless and difficult to control. But with constant practice and detachment, it can be tamed.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna acknowledges the mind's chaotic nature but reassures Arjuna that self-mastery comes through consistent practice and detachment. Progress, not perfection, is the key to inner control.
Famous Quotes: Success is the sum of small efforts, repeated day in and day out.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s emphasis on "abhyasa" (practice) resonates with Robert Collier’s view of success — steady effort, combined with a sense of detachment, ultimately leads to mastery.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
असंयतात्मना योगो दुष्प्राप इति मे मतिः ।
वश्यात्मना तु यतता शक्योऽवाप्तुमुपायतः ॥६-३६॥
Sloka (English Translation): Yoga is difficult to attain for one whose mind is unbridled, but it can be attained by one who has controlled the mind and strives earnestly using the right means.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna points out that self-discipline is key to success in yoga. While an uncontrolled mind makes spiritual progress hard, steady effort combined with self-control opens the path to realization.
Famous Quotes: Discipline is the bridge between goals and accomplishment.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s focus on discipline as the means to attain yoga parallels Jim Rohn’s idea — without self-discipline, goals remain dreams, but with it, spiritual and worldly success becomes achievable.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अर्जुन उवाच:
अयतिः श्रद्धयोपेतो योगाच्चलितमानसः ।
अप्राप्य योगसंसिद्धिं कां गतिं कृष्ण गच्छति ॥६-३७॥
Sloka (English Translation): Arjuna said: O Krishna, what is the fate of one who, though endowed with faith, strays from the path of yoga due to an unsteady mind and fails to attain perfection?
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna voices a common fear — what happens if someone tries but falls short? This verse reflects human anxiety about spiritual failure, highlighting Arjuna’s concern for those who strive yet stumble.
Famous Quotes: Our greatest glory is not in never falling, but in rising every time we fall.
Comparison/Relations: Arjuna's fear of falling off the spiritual path mirrors the universal fear of failure. Confucius’ wisdom reassures that the real victory lies in persistence, aligning with Krishna’s upcoming reassurance.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
कच्चिन्नोभयविभ्रष्टश्छिन्नाभ्रमिव नश्यति ।
अप्रतिष्ठो महाबाहो विमूढो ब्रह्मणः पथि ॥६-३८॥
Sloka (English Translation): Does such a person, who deviates from yoga, perish like a broken cloud without any support, lost on the path of spirituality?
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna uses the metaphor of a broken cloud to express his worry — does an incomplete spiritual seeker end up lost, gaining neither worldly success nor spiritual fulfillment?
Famous Quotes: Not all those who wander are lost.
Comparison/Relations: While Arjuna worries about lost seekers, Tolkien’s quote suggests that wandering doesn’t mean losing one’s way — Krishna will soon echo this idea, reassuring that no spiritual effort goes to waste.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
एतन्मे संशयं कृष्ण छेत्तुमर्हस्यशेषतः ।
त्वदन्यः संशयस्यास्य छेत्ता न ह्युपपद्यते ॥६-३९॥
Sloka (English Translation): O Krishna, please dispel this doubt of mine completely, for none other than You can destroy this uncertainty.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna acknowledges Krishna’s wisdom and pleads for clarity. This verse reflects the disciple’s trust in their teacher and the desire for spiritual certainty — a key moment of surrender and faith.
Famous Quotes: Doubt is an uncomfortable condition, but certainty is a ridiculous one.
Comparison/Relations: While Arjuna seeks answers, Voltaire’s words remind us that questions are part of growth. Krishna doesn’t dismiss doubt but transforms it into a deeper understanding — embracing uncertainty as part of the journey.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रीभगवानुवाच:
पार्थ नैवेह नामुत्र विनाशस्तस्य विद्यते ।
न हि कल्याणकृत्कश्चिद्दुर्गतिं तात गच्छति ॥६-४०॥
Sloka (English Translation): The Blessed Lord said: O Arjuna, there is no destruction for him either in this world or the next. One who strives for good never comes to grief.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reassures Arjuna that sincere spiritual efforts are never wasted. Even if a seeker stumbles, they carry forward their progress — no honest attempt is ever lost.
Famous Quotes: What we achieve inwardly will change outer reality.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s message — that every spiritual effort counts — resonates with Plutarch’s belief that inner progress transforms the outer world. It’s a hopeful reminder that no sincere act of growth is futile.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
प्राप्य पुण्यकृतां लोकानुषित्वा शाश्वतीः समाः ।
शुचीनां श्रीमतां गेहे योगभ्रष्टोऽभिजायते ॥६-४१॥
Sloka (English Translation): Having attained the worlds of the righteous and dwelt there for countless years, the fallen yogi is born into a family of pure and prosperous individuals.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna assures Arjuna that even those who fail to reach the ultimate goal of yoga in this life are rewarded. They are reborn in noble and spiritual families, giving them a favorable start for continuing their journey.
Famous Quotes: Success is not final, failure is not fatal: it is the courage to continue that counts.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Churchill emphasizes perseverance, Krishna highlights that spiritual effort never ends in failure — it simply resumes in a more favorable environment in future lives.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अथवा योगिनामेव कुले भवति धीमताम् ।
एतद्धि दुर्लभतरं लोके जन्म यदीदृशम् ॥६-४२॥
Sloka (English Translation): Or, he takes birth in a family of wise yogis. Such a birth is indeed rare and is obtained only by great fortune.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals that those with even greater spiritual merit are born into families of enlightened yogis. This privileged birth allows them to resume their path to liberation without much distraction.
Famous Quotes: Not everyone can become great, but greatness can come from anywhere.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna speaks about the rarity and significance of a spiritually advanced birth, this quote from Ratatouille reminds us that while spiritual excellence is rare, anyone can achieve greatness through consistent effort across lifetimes.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तत्र तं बुद्धिसंयोगं लभते पौर्वदेहिकम् ।
यतते च ततो भूयः संसिद्धौ कुरुनन्दन ॥६-४३॥
Sloka (English Translation): There he regains the spiritual intelligence from his previous life, and again he strives towards perfection, O Arjuna.
Meaning/Interpretation: This verse assures that spiritual wisdom from past lives is never lost. When born into a conducive family, the soul quickly reconnects with its previous knowledge and resumes its quest for self-realization.
Famous Quotes: Your past does not determine who you are. Your future is still unwritten.
Comparison/Relations: While Krishna confirms that past spiritual effort shapes our present, this quote adds that every moment is a chance to write a new future, reinforcing the idea of continuous evolution across lifetimes.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
पूर्वाभ्यासेन तेनैव ह्रियते ह्यवशोऽपि सः ।
जिज्ञासुरपि योगस्य शब्दब्रह्मातिवर्तते ॥६-४४॥
Sloka (English Translation): By virtue of the practice of his previous life, he is irresistibly drawn towards yoga, even against his will. A seeker of yoga transcends the rituals prescribed in the scriptures.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals the magnetic pull of past spiritual practice — even if someone appears disconnected, their soul naturally gravitates back to yoga. Such a person transcends mere ritualistic religion and pursues deeper spiritual wisdom.
Famous Quotes: The call to adventure is in every soul.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s words echo Joseph Campbell’s idea of an inner calling — the past practice of yoga stirs the soul, pushing one forward on their spiritual quest, just like every hero’s journey begins with a calling.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
प्रयत्नाद्यतमानस्तु योगी संशुद्धकिल्बिषः ।
अनेकजन्मसंसिद्धस्ततो याति परां गतिम् ॥६-४५॥
Sloka (English Translation): But the yogi who strives with great effort, purified of all sins, attains the highest goal after many births.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna emphasizes that spiritual mastery doesn’t happen overnight — it takes many lifetimes of sincere effort. Ultimately, however, such a dedicated yogi achieves the supreme goal of liberation.
Famous Quotes: Great things are not done by impulse but by a series of small things brought together.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s reminder about sustained effort mirrors Van Gogh’s philosophy — just as spiritual liberation is a culmination of steady practice across lifetimes, great achievements in art or life arise from consistent, patient effort.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तपस्विभ्योऽधिको योगी ज्ञानिभ्योऽपि मतोऽधिकः ।
कर्मिभ्यश्चाधिको योगी तस्माद्योगी भवार्जुन ॥६-४६॥
Sloka (English Translation): The yogi is superior to ascetics, greater than the wise, and surpasses those performing mere rituals. Therefore, O Arjuna, be a yogi!
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna declares the supremacy of a yogi’s path. While ascetics renounce the world and scholars pursue knowledge, a yogi transcends both by combining devotion, wisdom, and action. This verse emphasizes that true spiritual practice lies in disciplined union with the divine, not just in external rituals or intellectual pursuits.
Famous Quotes: Discipline is the bridge between goals and accomplishment.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna's call to Arjuna mirrors Jim Rohn’s message — being a yogi requires steadfast discipline and devotion, combining the strengths of knowledge, action, and spiritual focus to reach true fulfillment.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
योगिनामपि सर्वेषां मद्गतेनान्तरात्मना ।
श्रद्धावान्भजते यो मां स मे युक्ततमो मतः ॥६-४७॥
Sloka (English Translation): Among all yogis, the one who worships Me with faith, his inner self absorbed in Me, is considered by Me to be the most devoted.
Meaning/Interpretation: In this concluding verse of Chapter 6, Krishna identifies the highest yogi as one whose heart and mind are wholly immersed in the divine. Faith and devotion, coupled with spiritual practice, elevate a yogi to the ultimate level — full union with the divine.
Famous Quotes: Faith is taking the first step even when you don’t see the whole staircase.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna's teaching aligns with MLK’s wisdom — the greatest yogi is not just one who practices but one who moves forward in faith, completely absorbed in the divine, even without seeing the final outcome.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रीभगवानुवाच —
मय्यासक्तमना: पार्थ योगं युञ्जन्मदाश्रय: ।
असंशयं समग्रं मां यथा ज्ञास्यसि तच्छृणु ॥७-१॥
Sloka (English Translation):
The Blessed Lord said:
With your mind attached to Me, O Arjuna, and practicing yoga under My protection, you shall know Me completely and without doubt.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna opens this chapter by inviting Arjuna to focus his mind on the divine. He emphasizes that true knowledge comes when one practices yoga with unwavering devotion and seeks divine shelter. This sets the tone for realizing both Krishna’s material and spiritual manifestations.
Famous Quotes: Where focus goes, energy flows.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s guidance mirrors Tony Robbins’ principle — directing one’s full focus on the divine leads to deeper understanding and spiritual clarity.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ज्ञानं तेऽहं सविज्ञानमिदं वक्ष्याम्यशेषत: ।
यज्ज्ञात्वा नेह भूयोऽन्यज्ज्ञातव्यमवशिष्यते ॥७-२॥
Sloka (English Translation): I shall now fully explain to you this knowledge and wisdom, knowing which nothing more remains to be known in this world.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna promises to impart both jnana (theoretical knowledge) and vijnana (experiential wisdom). He highlights that realizing this complete wisdom will leave no mystery unsolved, illuminating the ultimate truth.
Famous Quotes: Knowledge is of no value unless you put it into practice.
Comparison/Relations: Like Krishna’s distinction between knowledge and wisdom, Chekhov emphasizes that true understanding comes not from theory alone but from lived experience — aligning with Krishna’s notion of vijnana.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
मनुष्याणां सहस्रेषु कश्चिद्यतति सिद्धये ।
यततामपि सिद्धानां कश्चिन्मां वेत्ति तत्त्वत: ॥७-३॥
Sloka (English Translation): Among thousands of men, one may strive for perfection; and among those who strive and succeed, hardly one knows Me in truth.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna acknowledges the rarity of true spiritual realization. While many pursue spiritual goals, few attain full enlightenment and even fewer truly comprehend the divine nature of Krishna.
Famous Quotes: The path to success is to take massive, determined action.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna's message about rare spiritual attainment parallels Tony Robbins’ call for relentless effort — both suggest that only a dedicated few reach the pinnacle of their pursuit, whether spiritual or worldly.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
भूमिरापोऽनलो वायुः खं मनो बुद्धिरेव च ।
अहङ्कार इतीयं मे भिन्ना प्रकृतिरष्टधा ॥७-४॥
Sloka (English Translation): Earth, water, fire, air, space, mind, intellect, and ego — these constitute My eightfold separated material energies.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna introduces His material energy, listing the five elements (earth, water, fire, air, and space) and three subtle aspects (mind, intellect, and ego). These eight components form the foundation of the material universe, highlighting the divine's control over creation.
Famous Quotes: Energy cannot be created or destroyed; it can only be changed from one form to another.
Comparison/Relations: Einstein’s law of energy transformation echoes Krishna’s teaching — the elements and energies Krishna describes form the building blocks of the universe, underscoring a timeless scientific-spiritual truth.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अपरेयमितस्त्वन्यां प्रकृतिं विद्धि मे पराम् ।
जीवभूतां महाबाहो ययेदं धार्यते जगत् ॥७-५॥
Sloka (English Translation): Beyond this inferior material nature, O mighty-armed Arjuna, know My superior energy — the living entities — by which this world is sustained.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna contrasts His lower material energy with His higher, spiritual energy — the jiva (living beings). This verse highlights that the soul, as part of Krishna’s divine energy, sustains the universe and transcends mere material existence.
Famous Quotes: You are not a drop in the ocean. You are the entire ocean in a drop.
Comparison/Relations: Rumi’s words reflect Krishna’s teaching — the soul (jiva) contains divine essence, underscoring the spiritual reality that all beings hold a spark of the divine within them.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
एतद्योनीनि भूतानि सर्वाणीत्युपधारय ।
अहं कृत्स्नस्य जगतः प्रभवः प्रलयस्तथा ॥७-६॥
Sloka (English Translation): Understand that all living beings have their source in these two natures. I am the origin of the entire universe and also its dissolution.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals that all creation stems from His two natures — material (lower) and spiritual (higher). He declares Himself the source of both the beginning and end of the universe, reinforcing the idea that He governs all cosmic cycles.
Famous Quotes: Everything comes from something, and something comes from nothing.
Comparison/Relations: This echoes Krishna's teaching — all beings arise from His divine energy, showing that existence has both a visible material cause and an unseen spiritual source.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
मत्त: परतरं नान्यत्किञ्चिदस्ति धनञ्जय ।
मयि सर्वमिदं प्रोतं सूत्रे मणिगणा इव ॥७-७॥
Sloka (English Translation): O Arjuna, there is nothing higher than Me. All this world is strung on Me like pearls on a thread.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna asserts His supremacy — He is the ultimate reality supporting everything, just as a thread holds pearls in a necklace. While material forms appear separate, they are all connected through Krishna’s divine presence.
Famous Quotes: God is the thread that ties us all together.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s metaphor of pearls on a string beautifully conveys the unity underlying diversity, a concept mirrored by spiritual ideas of interconnectedness across traditions.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
रसोऽहमप्सु कौन्तेय प्रभास्मि शशिसूर्ययो: ।
प्रणव: सर्ववेदेषु शब्द: खे पौरुषं नृषु ॥७-८॥
Sloka (English Translation): I am the taste in water, O son of Kunti, the light of the sun and moon, the sacred syllable Om in the Vedas, sound in the ether, and ability in men.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna identifies Himself with the essence of all things — the taste of water, the brilliance of celestial bodies, the eternal Om of the Vedas, and human strength. He shows that His presence pervades every aspect of the universe.
Famous Quotes: God is not in a place — He is every place.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna's teaching resonates with Angelou’s quote — divinity isn’t confined to temples but exists in the simplest experiences, like water’s taste or the sun’s light.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
पुण्यो गन्ध: पृथिव्यां च तेजश्चास्मि विभावसौ ।
जीवनं सर्वभूतेषु तपश्चास्मि तपस्विषु ॥७-९॥
Sloka (English Translation): I am the pure fragrance of the earth and the brilliance in fire. I am the life in all living beings and the penance of the ascetics.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains His divine immanence by linking Himself to nature's elements — the scent of the earth, the heat of fire, and the very essence of life itself. He also embodies spiritual discipline, emphasizing His role in both the material and spiritual realms.
Famous Quotes: Nature is the art of God.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Dante views nature as God’s art, Krishna highlights how His divine essence is manifest in every natural element, reinforcing the sacredness of the world around us.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
बीजं मां सर्वभूतानां विद्धि पार्थ सनातनम् ।
बुद्धिर्बुद्धिमतामस्मि तेजस्तेजस्विनामहम् ॥७-१०॥
Sloka (English Translation): O Arjuna, know Me as the eternal seed of all beings. I am the intelligence of the intelligent and the splendor of the splendid.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna presents Himself as the eternal seed — the source of all creation. He further explains that intelligence and brilliance in any being are reflections of His divine qualities. This verse deepens the idea that every ability stems from the divine.
Famous Quotes: Within you is the light of a thousand suns.
Comparison/Relations: Robert Adams' quote aligns with Krishna’s message — all intelligence, strength, and brilliance come from the divine spark within each being, reinforcing our shared spiritual origin.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
बलं बलवतां चाहं कामरागविवर्जितम् ।
धर्माविरुद्धो भूतेषु कामोऽस्मि भरतर्षभ ॥७-११॥
Sloka (English Translation): I am the strength of the strong, devoid of desire and attachment. O Arjuna, I am the desire in beings that is in accordance with dharma.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna clarifies that He represents pure strength — not driven by selfishness — and righteous desire rooted in duty (dharma). This verse suggests that even desire, when aligned with higher principles, is divine.
Famous Quotes: Strength does not come from physical capacity. It comes from an indomitable will.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna's teaching resonates with Gandhi's quote — strength rooted in discipline and virtue mirrors Krishna's idea of divine, desire-free power.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ये चैव सात्त्विका भावा राजसास्तामसाश्च ये ।
मत्त एवेति तान्विद्धि न त्वहं तेषु ते मयि ॥७-१२॥
Sloka (English Translation): Whatever states of being arise — whether they are sattvic (pure), rajasic (passionate), or tamasic (ignorant) — know that they come from Me. However, I am not in them; they are in Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals that all modes of material nature — purity, passion, and ignorance — originate from Him, yet He transcends them. He is their source but remains unaffected by their influences.
Famous Quotes: You are not a drop in the ocean. You are the entire ocean in a drop.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s transcendence over these states parallels Rumi’s idea — while we may embody different qualities, the divine essence remains whole and untainted.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
त्रिभिर्गुणमयैर्भावैरेभिः सर्वमिदं जगत् ।
मोहितं नाभिजानाति मामेभ्यः परमव्ययम् ॥७-१३॥
Sloka (English Translation): Deluded by these three modes of nature, the entire world fails to recognize Me, who am beyond them and imperishable.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that the world, influenced by material modes (gunas), cannot perceive His true, unchanging nature. Attachment to these modes creates a veil over divine reality.
Famous Quotes: Reality is merely an illusion, albeit a very persistent one.
Comparison/Relations: Einstein’s idea of illusion aligns with Krishna’s teaching — the material world’s appearances often obscure the eternal, transcendent truth behind it.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
दैवी ह्येषा गुणमयी मम माया दुरत्यया ।
मामेव ये प्रपद्यन्ते मायामेतां तरन्ति ते ॥७-१४॥
Sloka (English Translation): This divine illusion of Mine, composed of the three modes of nature, is difficult to overcome. But those who surrender to Me cross beyond it.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna introduces maya — the powerful illusion rooted in material nature. Though it binds beings, He assures that surrendering to Him allows one to transcend it.
Famous Quotes: Surrender is the most powerful tool to connect with the divine.
Comparison/Relations: Like Krishna's message, Chopra emphasizes that true freedom lies in surrender — only by letting go of ego can one overcome illusion and unite with the divine.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
न मां दुष्कृतिनो मूढाः प्रपद्यन्ते नराधमाः ।
माययापहृतज्ञाना आसुरं भावमाश्रिताः ॥७-१५॥
Sloka (English Translation): The deluded, the wicked, the lowest of men — those whose knowledge is stolen by illusion and who embrace demonic natures — do not surrender to Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna highlights that those trapped by maya, corrupted by arrogance or ignorance, are unable to seek Him. Their clouded intellect prevents them from realizing the divine.
Famous Quotes: Your worst enemy cannot harm you as much as your own unguarded thoughts.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna's teaching mirrors Buddha's insight — internal delusion (maya) is a greater obstacle than any external force. True growth begins by overcoming inner ignorance.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
चतुर्विधा भजन्ते मां जनाः सुकृतिनोऽर्जुन ।
आर्तो जिज्ञासुरर्थार्थी ज्ञानी च भरतर्षभ ॥७-१६॥
Sloka (English Translation): O Arjuna, four kinds of pious people worship Me — the distressed, the seeker of knowledge, the seeker of wealth, and the wise.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains the four types of devotees who turn to Him: those seeking relief from suffering, those craving knowledge, those desiring material gains, and those who are wise and self-realized. Each approaches the divine for different reasons, yet all take a step towards Him.
Famous Quotes: Not all who wander are lost.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna acknowledges diverse paths to devotion, Tolkien's quote reminds us that every journey — be it in search of relief, answers, or truth — holds meaning.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तेषां ज्ञानी नित्ययुक्त एकभक्तिर्विशिष्यते ।
प्रियो हि ज्ञानिनोऽत्यर्थमहं स च मम प्रियः ॥७-१७॥
Sloka (English Translation): Among them, the wise one who is always united with Me through exclusive devotion excels. I am very dear to him, and he is dear to Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals that although all four types of devotees are virtuous, the wise devotee — who loves and worships Him with pure, unwavering devotion — holds a special place in His heart. This verse underscores the unique bond between wisdom and heartfelt surrender.
Famous Quotes: Love all, trust a few, do wrong to none.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna honors the selfless devotion of the wise, Shakespeare's words echo a similar sentiment — genuine love and loyalty transcend all.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
उदारा: सर्व एवैते ज्ञानी त्वात्मैव मे मतम् ।
आस्थित: स हि युक्तात्मा मामेवानुत्तमां गतिम् ॥७-१८॥
Sloka (English Translation): All these are indeed noble, but the wise one, who is steadfast in devotion, is like My very self. Such a person is firmly established in Me and attains the highest goal.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna acknowledges the merit of all who seek Him but reiterates that the wise, devoted soul reflects His own nature. By aligning their consciousness with Him, they reach the supreme spiritual destination.
Famous Quotes: What you seek is seeking you.
Comparison/Relations: This Rumi quote parallels Krishna’s idea — the wise devotee's quest for the divine mirrors the divine’s love for the devotee. It’s a reciprocal bond of spiritual unity.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
बहूनां जन्मनामन्ते ज्ञानवान्मां प्रपद्यते ।
वासुदेव: सर्वमिति स महात्मा सुदुर्लभ: ॥७-१९॥
Sloka (English Translation): After many births, the wise person surrenders to Me, realizing that I — Vasudeva — am everything. Such a great soul is indeed very rare.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna highlights the long spiritual journey of the enlightened soul. Only after lifetimes of seeking does one grasp the ultimate truth — that the divine pervades all. This rare realization brings complete surrender and liberation.
Famous Quotes: It takes a long time to become young.
Comparison/Relations: Picasso’s quote reflects Krishna's message — true wisdom is a gradual unfolding process, often taking lifetimes, until one returns to the pure simplicity of divine understanding.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
कामैस्तैस्तैर्हृतज्ञानाः प्रपद्यन्तेऽन्यदेवताः ।
तं तं नियममास्थाय प्रकृत्या नियताः स्वया ॥७-२०॥
Sloka (English Translation): Those whose knowledge is stolen by material desires worship other deities, following specific rules and driven by their own nature.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that those entangled in worldly desires often turn to lesser gods, seeking specific boons or results. Their devotion, though sincere, is shaped by their material cravings rather than the pursuit of ultimate truth.
Famous Quotes: You can’t always get what you want. But if you try sometimes, you just might find, you get what you need.
Comparison/Relations: Like Krishna’s words, this quote reminds us that desires often cloud our judgment, leading us to seek fleeting solutions instead of deeper truths. Real fulfillment lies beyond material wants.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यो यो यां यां तनुं भक्तः श्रद्धयार्चितुमिच्छति ।
तस्य तस्याचलां श्रद्धां तामेव विदधाम्यहम् ॥७-२१॥
Sloka (English Translation): Whatever form a devotee desires to worship with faith, I make that faith steady so that he can devote himself to that form.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna acknowledges the sincerity of all worship. Regardless of the deity or form chosen, it is ultimately He who strengthens the devotee’s faith. This highlights His all-encompassing nature and the inclusivity of spiritual practices.
Famous Quotes: Faith is taking the first step even when you don't see the whole staircase.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna nurtures the faith of all worshippers, Martin Luther King Jr.'s quote underscores how faith sustains and propels us forward, even when the full path remains unseen.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
स तया श्रद्धया युक्तस्तस्याराधनमीहते ।
लभते च ततः कामान्मयैव विहितान्हि तान् ॥७-२२॥
Sloka (English Translation): Endowed with that faith, he strives to worship his chosen deity and obtains his desires. But in reality, those benefits are granted by Me alone.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals that while devotees may attribute their gains to various deities, it is ultimately His divine will that fulfills their desires. He is the source behind all results, whether recognized or not.
Famous Quotes: All the gods, all the heavens, all the hells, are within you.
Comparison/Relations: This aligns with Krishna's teaching — deities are but manifestations of the One divine source. Every gain, though appearing separate, flows from the same universal power.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अन्तवत्तु फलं तेषां तद्भवत्यल्पमेधसाम् ।
देवान्देवयजो यान्ति मद्भक्ता यान्ति मामपि ॥७-२३॥
Sloka (English Translation): The fruits gained by these less intelligent people are temporary. Those who worship the gods go to the gods, but My devotees come to Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna differentiates between temporary and eternal rewards. Worshiping deities for worldly desires brings fleeting results, but those devoted to Krishna directly attain the everlasting divine union.
Famous Quotes: Do not be satisfied with the stories that come before you. Unfold your own myth.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna urges seekers to aim beyond temporary gains, Rumi's words push us to transcend surface-level desires, seeking the deeper spiritual truth.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अव्यक्तं व्यक्तिमापन्नं मन्यन्ते मामबुद्धयः ।
परं भावमजानन्तो ममाव्ययमनुत्तमम् ॥७-२४॥
Sloka (English Translation): The ignorant think of Me as having assumed a form, not knowing My higher, immutable, and supreme existence.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna highlights the limited understanding of those who view Him merely as a physical entity. His true nature transcends form — eternal, formless, and infinite — yet many fail to recognize this ultimate reality.
Famous Quotes: The eye sees only what the mind is prepared to comprehend.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s point reflects this idea — limited perception results in a limited understanding of the divine. True wisdom requires seeing beyond appearances.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
नाहं प्रकाशः सर्वस्य योगमायासमावृतः ।
मूढोऽयं नाभिजानाति लोको मामजमव्ययम् ॥७-२५॥
Sloka (English Translation): I am not manifest to everyone, veiled by My divine Yoga-Maya. The ignorant do not recognize Me as unborn and eternal.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that His true essence remains hidden, concealed by His mystical power (Yoga-Maya). Those with limited insight cannot grasp His timeless, unchanging nature. Only through deep spiritual practice can one pierce this veil.
Famous Quotes: The real voyage of discovery consists not in seeking new landscapes, but in having new eyes.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna describes the hidden nature of divinity, Proust reminds us that true understanding doesn’t come from looking outward but from deepening our perception.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
वेदाहं समतीतानि वर्तमानानि चार्जुन ।
भविष्याणि च भूतानि मां तु वेद न कश्चन ॥७-२६॥
Sloka (English Translation): I know all beings, past, present, and future, O Arjuna, but no one truly knows Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals His omniscience — He is aware of everything that has happened, is happening, and will happen. However, because of Maya (illusion), people fail to recognize His true, eternal nature.
Famous Quotes: The past is never dead. It's not even past.
Comparison/Relations: Like Krishna’s timeless awareness, Faulkner’s words reflect the idea that time is interconnected — past, present, and future coexist, just as Krishna knows them all simultaneously.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
इच्छाद्वेषसमुत्थेन द्वन्द्वमोहेन भारत ।
सर्वभूतानि सम्मोहं सर्गे यान्ति परन्तप ॥७-२७॥
Sloka (English Translation): O Arjuna, all beings are born into delusion, overcome by the dualities of desire and aversion.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna highlights that every soul, from birth, is entangled in dualities — like pleasure and pain, love and hate. These polarities cloud judgment, preventing people from seeing their divine essence.
Famous Quotes: Freedom is the absence of choice.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s teaching aligns with Krishnamurti's idea — true freedom arises when we transcend the constant push and pull of opposites, moving beyond desire and aversion.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
येषां त्वन्तगतं पापं जनानां पुण्यकर्मणाम् ।
ते द्वन्द्वमोहनिर्मुक्ता भजन्ते मां दृढव्रताः ॥७-२८॥
Sloka (English Translation): Those who have freed themselves from sin through righteous actions and are released from the illusion of duality, worship Me with firm resolve.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna teaches that spiritual clarity comes to those who purify themselves with good deeds. Free from confusion caused by dualities, they can dedicate themselves unwaveringly to the divine.
Famous Quotes: Your beliefs become your thoughts, your thoughts become your words, your words become your actions.
Comparison/Relations: Like Krishna's point about righteous actions leading to spiritual liberation, Gandhi emphasizes how internal purity shapes outer actions and, ultimately, one’s path to freedom.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
जरामरणमोक्षाय मामाश्रित्य यतन्ति ये ।
ते ब्रह्म तद्विदुः कृत्स्नमध्यात्मं कर्म चाखिलम् ॥७-२९॥
Sloka (English Translation): Those who strive for liberation from old age and death, taking refuge in Me, know the Brahman, the self, and the entire field of action.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that sincere seekers who yearn for liberation — freedom from the cycle of birth and death — come to understand the ultimate truths of Brahman (the absolute), the soul, and karma.
Famous Quotes: Death is not the opposite of life, but a part of it.
Comparison/Relations: This mirrors Krishna's message: true seekers grasp that transcending death means understanding it as a phase in the soul’s eternal journey, not an end.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
साधिभूताधिदैवं मां साधियज्ञं च ये विदुः ।
प्रयाणकालेऽपि च मां ते विदुर्युक्तचेतसः ॥७-३०॥
Sloka (English Translation): Those who know Me as the Lord of all beings, the ruler of gods, and the master of all sacrifices, with minds steadfast even at the time of death, truly understand Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna asserts that those who recognize Him as the Supreme Being — the source of creation, gods, and all spiritual practices — and keep their focus unwavering, even at the moment of death, achieve ultimate union with Him.
Famous Quotes: He who has a why to live can bear almost any how.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s teaching parallels Nietzsche’s idea: those with a clear, divine purpose can endure any challenge — including death — knowing they move toward spiritual liberation.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अर्जुन उवाच ।
किं तद्ब्रह्म किमध्यात्मं किं कर्म पुरुषोत्तम ।
अधिभूतं च किं प्रोक्तमधिदैवं किमुच्यते ॥८-१॥
Sloka (English Translation): Arjuna said: O Supreme Person, what is Brahman? What is the Self? What is karma? What is the material manifestation, and what is the divine realm?
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna, eager to grasp deeper spiritual concepts, questions Krishna about the nature of Brahman (the Absolute), the individual soul (adhyatma), karma (action), the physical world (adhibhuta), and divine forces (adhidaiva). These inquiries set the stage for a profound discourse on ultimate reality.
Famous Quotes: True wisdom comes to each of us when we realize how little we understand about life, ourselves, and the world around us.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Arjuna seeks clarity about life’s fundamental truths, Socrates' quote reflects the same yearning for deeper understanding — recognizing that wisdom begins with questioning.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अधियज्ञः कथं कोऽत्र देहेऽस्मिन्मधुसूदन ।
प्रयाणकाले च कथं ज्ञेयोऽसि नियतात्मभिः ॥८-२॥
Sloka (English Translation): O Krishna, who is the Lord of sacrifice in the body, and how does He reside there? And how are You to be known at the time of death by the self-controlled?
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna now probes the connection between the divine (adhiyajna) and the physical body, as well as how to remember God at the moment of death — a pivotal question leading to Krishna's explanation of spiritual practice and death’s significance.
Famous Quotes: The soul is dyed with the color of its thoughts.
Comparison/Relations: Marcus Aurelius’ words echo Krishna's teachings: the state of one’s mind at death (colored by thoughts and actions) shapes the soul’s journey forward — reinforcing mindfulness and spiritual focus.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रीभगवानुवाच ।
अक्षरं ब्रह्म परमं स्वभावोऽध्यात्ममुच्यते ।
भूतभावोद्भवकरो विसर्गः कर्मसंज्ञितः ॥८-३॥
Sloka (English Translation): The Blessed Lord said: The eternal, imperishable Brahman is the Supreme. The self (adhyatma) is one's own nature, and karma is the creative force that brings beings into existence.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna answers Arjuna by defining core concepts: Brahman as the unchanging ultimate reality, adhyatma as the soul’s true nature, and karma as the force of action shaping the cycle of birth and rebirth.
Famous Quotes: Change is the law of life, and those who look only to the past or present are certain to miss the future.
Comparison/Relations: Karma embodies constant change through cause and effect. Like Krishna’s definition, JFK highlights how change is an unstoppable law — aligning with karma’s dynamic role in shaping existence.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अधिभूतं क्षरो भावः पुरुषश्चाधिदैवतम् ।
अधियज्ञोऽहमेवात्र देहे देहभृतां वर ॥८-४॥
Sloka (English Translation): The physical realm (adhibhuta) is the perishable nature. The divine (adhidaiva) is the cosmic spirit. I am the Lord of all sacrifices (adhiyajna), dwelling within the body, O best of embodied beings.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna clarifies how the physical world, divine forces, and sacrifices connect. While the body and material world are temporary, He, as the Supreme Being, resides within all beings, guiding their spiritual journeys.
Famous Quotes: Within you is the light of a thousand suns.
Comparison/Relations: This quote reflects Krishna’s message — the divine (adhiyajna) is not a distant force but an inner presence, burning bright within each soul, waiting to be realized.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अन्तकाले च मामेव स्मरन्मुक्त्वा कलेवरम् ।
यः प्रयाति स मद्भावं याति नास्त्यत्र संशयः ॥८-५॥
Sloka (English Translation): And whoever, at the time of death, remembers Me alone while leaving the body, attains My being — of this there is no doubt.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna stresses the importance of one’s final thoughts at the moment of death. If a person dies with their mind fixed solely on Him, they merge into His divine nature — promising eternal union with the Supreme.
Famous Quotes: What we think, we become.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s teaching mirrors Buddha’s wisdom: a soul’s destiny hinges on its last thoughts — what occupies the mind in life shapes the journey beyond death.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अन्तकाले च मामेव स्मरन्मुक्त्वा कलेवरम् ।
यः प्रयाति स मद्भावं याति नास्त्यत्र संशयः ॥८-५॥
Sloka (English Translation): And whoever, at the time of death, remembers Me alone while leaving the body, attains My being — of this there is no doubt.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna stresses the importance of one’s final thoughts at the moment of death. If a person dies with their mind fixed solely on Him, they merge into His divine nature — promising eternal union with the Supreme.
Famous Quotes: What we think, we become.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s teaching mirrors Buddha’s wisdom: a soul’s destiny hinges on its last thoughts — what occupies the mind in life shapes the journey beyond death.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यं यं वापि स्मरन्भावं त्यजत्यन्ते कलेवरम् ।
तं तमेवैति कौन्तेय सदा तद्भावभावितः ॥८-६॥
Sloka (English Translation): Whatever state of being one remembers when he quits his body, O son of Kunti, that state he will attain without fail.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna emphasizes the law of attraction at the time of death — the final thoughts and emotions one holds shape the soul's next journey. This reinforces the importance of constant spiritual mindfulness.
Famous Quotes: Your mind is a powerful thing. When you fill it with positive thoughts, your life will start to change.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s teaching mirrors this idea: the mind's focus at the crucial moment of death determines one's next existence — a spiritual continuation of the law of attraction.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तस्मात्सर्वेषु कालेषु मामनुस्मर युध्य च ।
मय्यर्पितमनोबुद्धिर्मामेवैष्यस्यसंशयः ॥८-७॥
Sloka (English Translation): Therefore, think of Me at all times and fight. With your mind and intellect surrendered to Me, you will surely come to Me. There is no doubt about it.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna advises Arjuna to engage in his duties (like fighting) while keeping his mind fixed on God. This verse teaches balance — fulfilling worldly responsibilities while maintaining spiritual focus.
Famous Quotes: Work as if everything depends on you. Pray as if everything depends on God.
Comparison/Relations: Just like Krishna's message, this quote highlights the harmony between action and devotion — perform your duties wholeheartedly but keep your mind anchored in God.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अभ्यासयोगयुक्तेन चेतसा नान्यगामिना ।
परमं पुरुषं दिव्यं याति पार्थानुचिन्तयन् ॥८-८॥
Sloka (English Translation): By practicing meditation with an unwavering mind and focusing on the Divine Supreme, one surely attains Him, O son of Pritha.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna emphasizes Abhyasa Yoga — the discipline of consistent meditation and concentration on the Supreme Being — as the path to uniting with God.
Famous Quotes: Success is the sum of small efforts, repeated day in and day out.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna highlights constant spiritual practice, Collier reminds us that success — whether worldly or spiritual — stems from steady, focused efforts over time.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
कविं पुराणमनुशासितार
मणोरणीयंसमनुस्मरेद्यः ।
सर्वस्य धातारमचिन्त्यरूप
मादित्यवर्णं तमसः परस्तात् ॥८-९॥
Sloka (English Translation): He who meditates on the omniscient, ancient, and all-controlling Supreme Lord — smaller than the smallest and the supporter of all — who is beyond darkness and glowing like the sun — will surely attain Him.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna paints a vivid picture of the Divine as all-knowing, eternal, and ever-radiant — urging Arjuna to meditate on this cosmic form.
Famous Quotes: The sun does not shine for a few trees and flowers, but for the wide world’s joy.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna likens the Divine to the sun — illuminating all — Beecher’s quote reflects God’s impartial, radiant presence that supports every being, big or small.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
प्रयाणकाले मनसाचलेन
भक्त्या युक्तो योगबलेन चैव ।
भ्रुवोर्मध्ये प्राणमावेश्य सम्यक्
स तं परं पुरुषमुपैति दिव्यम् ॥८-१०॥
Sloka (English Translation): At the time of death, with a steady mind full of devotion, by the power of yoga, and focusing the life force between the eyebrows, one attains the Supreme Divine.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna describes the final moments of a yogi: with unwavering focus, heart full of faith, and mastering prana (life force), one merges with the Divine.
Famous Quotes: The body is the bow, the asana is the arrow, and the soul is the target.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna illustrates mastering the body, breath, and mind to reach God, Iyengar’s words capture the same essence — spiritual realization requires focused alignment of physical, mental, and spiritual forces.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यदक्षरं वेदविदो वदन्ति
विशन्ति यद्यतयो वीतरागाः ।
यदिच्छन्तो ब्रह्मचर्यं चरन्ति
तत्ते पदं सङ्ग्रहेण प्रवक्ष्ये ॥८-११॥
Sloka (English Translation): I will now explain to you briefly that goal which the knowers of the Vedas call the Imperishable, which the ascetics enter free from attachments, and desiring which, they practice celibacy.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna introduces the concept of the Akshara Brahman — the eternal, unchanging reality that Vedic scholars and renunciates strive to realize. This verse highlights the need for detachment and discipline in the spiritual quest.
Famous Quotes: Detachment is not that you should own nothing, but that nothing should own you.
Comparison/Relations: Just like Krishna speaks of freeing oneself from attachments to attain the eternal, this quote emphasizes the same — spirituality does not mean having nothing but ensuring nothing controls you.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सर्वद्वाराणि संयम्य मनो हृदि निरुध्य च ।
मूर्ध्न्याधायात्मनः प्राणमास्थितो योगधारणाम् ॥८-१२॥
Sloka (English Translation): Restraining all the gates of the body, confining the mind in the heart, and fixing the life force in the head, established in yogic concentration — this is the way.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals a deep yogic practice — controlling senses (gates), focusing the mind, and guiding prana (life force) upward through the chakras — a crucial step to attaining divine realization.
Famous Quotes: Mastering others is strength. Mastering yourself is true power.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s teaching of self-restraint and inner focus mirrors Lao Tzu’s wisdom — spiritual strength comes from mastering the mind and body, not just the external world.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ओमित्येकाक्षरं ब्रह्म व्याहरन्मामनुस्मरन् ।
यः प्रयाति त्यजन्देहं स याति परमां गतिम् ॥८-१३॥
Sloka (English Translation): Uttering the single syllable "Om," which is Brahman, and remembering Me, he who departs, giving up his body, attains the Supreme Goal.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna emphasizes the divine power of Om — the universal sound representing Brahman — and how chanting it while remembering God leads to liberation at death.
Famous Quotes: The sound of 'Om' is the primordial sound of the universe — the heartbeat of existence.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna highlights Om as the path to the Supreme, the quote reflects the cosmic significance of this sound — uniting all creation with the Divine.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अनन्यचेताः सततं यो मां स्मरति नित्यशः ।
तस्याहं सुलभः पार्थ नित्ययुक्तस्य योगिनः ॥८-१४॥
Sloka (English Translation): For one who remembers Me without deviation, constantly and with an undivided mind, I am easily attainable, O Arjuna, for that steadfast yogi.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reassures that constant, unwavering devotion (ananya bhakti) makes union with Him simple and certain — for the one fully absorbed in His thoughts, He is ever near.
Famous Quotes: Wherever you are, be all there.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s call for focused devotion aligns with Elliot’s wisdom — true spiritual progress happens when your heart and mind remain entirely devoted to the present moment and to God.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
मामुपेत्य पुनर्जन्म दुःखालयमशाश्वतम् ।
नाप्नुवन्ति महात्मानः संसिद्धिं परमां गताः ॥८-१५॥
Sloka (English Translation): Having attained Me, the great souls never return to this temporary world, which is full of suffering, because they have reached the highest perfection.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains the ultimate goal — once a soul reaches Him, there is no more rebirth into the transient world of sorrow. The liberated ones dwell eternally in divine bliss.
Famous Quotes: Once you awaken, you will have no interest in judging those who sleep.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna describes the liberated soul never returning to the cycle of suffering, Blanchard’s words reflect the same transcendence — awakened souls rise above worldly entanglements and suffering.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
आ ब्रह्मभुवनाल्लोकाः पुनरावर्तिनोऽर्जुन ।
मामुपेत्य तु कौन्तेय पुनर्जन्म न विद्यते ॥८-१६॥
Sloka (English Translation): All the worlds, including the realm of Brahma, are subject to rebirth, O Arjuna. But one who attains Me is never born again.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals that even the highest material realms are bound by the cycle of creation and destruction. True liberation (moksha) lies only in reaching Him — transcending all cycles of rebirth.
Famous Quotes: Freedom is not the absence of commitments, but the ability to choose — and commit to — what is best for you.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna speaks about transcending worldly cycles, Coelho’s quote reminds us that real freedom lies in conscious choice — choosing the spiritual over the material leads to true liberation.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सहस्रयुगपर्यन्तमहर्यद्ब्रह्मणो विदुः ।
रात्रिं युगसहस्रान्तां तेऽहोरात्रविदो जनाः ॥८-१७॥
Sloka (English Translation): Those who know the day of Brahma, which lasts a thousand Yugas, and the night which also lasts a thousand Yugas, understand the true nature of time.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna introduces cosmic time — Brahma’s day and night span thousands of Yugas (eras), underscoring the vastness of creation’s cycles and how fleeting human lifetimes are in comparison.
Famous Quotes: Time is a created thing. To say 'I don't have time' is like saying 'I don't want to'.
Comparison/Relations: While Krishna explains time’s cosmic scale, Lao Tzu’s wisdom highlights a personal truth — time is what we make of it. Krishna urges us to rise above temporal limitations.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अव्यक्ताद्व्यक्तयः सर्वाः प्रभवन्त्यहरागमे ।
रात्र्यागमे प्रलीयन्ते तत्रैवाव्यक्तसंज्ञके ॥८-१८॥
Sloka (English Translation): At the dawn of Brahma's day, all living beings manifest from the unmanifest; at the fall of night, they merge into that which is called the unmanifest again.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals the universe’s cyclical nature — creation and dissolution repeat endlessly, with all beings emerging and dissolving into the unmanifest reality (Avyakta).
Famous Quotes: Everything comes from nothing, and nothing returns to everything.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s teaching about creation and dissolution reflects this quote’s essence — existence flows in cycles, and spiritual wisdom lies in realizing the impermanence of material forms.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
भूतग्रामः स एवायं भूत्वा भूत्वा प्रलीयते ।
रात्र्यागमेऽवशः पार्थ प्रभवत्यहरागमे ॥८-१९॥
Sloka (English Translation): This multitude of beings repeatedly comes into existence at the arrival of Brahma's day and is again annihilated at Brahma's night, helplessly bound by the laws of nature.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna emphasizes that all beings are subject to this cosmic rhythm, helplessly caught in the cycle of birth and death until they transcend through spiritual wisdom.
Famous Quotes: Nature does not hurry, yet everything is accomplished.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna speaks of the steady, inevitable cycles of creation, Lao Tzu reminds us of nature’s pace — slow but certain — mirroring the universe’s unceasing rhythm.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
परस्तस्मात्तु भावोऽन्योऽव्यक्तोऽव्यक्तात्सनातनः ।
यः स सर्वेषु भूतेषु नश्यत्सु न विनश्यति ॥८-२०॥
Sloka (English Translation): Beyond this unmanifest state is another eternal unmanifest existence, which does not perish when all beings cease to exist.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals a higher, eternal reality (Sanatana), beyond even the cycles of cosmic creation and destruction — the supreme, unchanging spiritual realm.
Famous Quotes: There is a reality beyond this reality, and within that lies the eternal truth.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s mention of the imperishable realm echoes Rumi’s wisdom — both point towards an unchanging spiritual existence beyond the physical and material worlds.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अव्यक्तोऽक्षर इत्युक्तस्तमाहुः परमां गतिम् ।
यं प्राप्य न निवर्तन्ते तद्धाम परमं मम ॥८-२१॥
Sloka (English Translation): That which is called the unmanifest and the imperishable is the supreme goal. Having attained it, one never returns. That is My supreme abode.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that the ultimate goal is to reach the Avyakta — the unmanifest, eternal reality. Once a soul unites with this supreme state, it is freed from the cycle of rebirth.
Famous Quotes: True peace comes from within. Do not seek it without.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s concept of the Paramam Dhama (supreme abode) aligns with Buddha’s teaching — peace and liberation lie within, not in external pursuits.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
पुरुषः स परः पार्थ भक्त्या लभ्यस्त्वनन्यया ।
यस्यान्तःस्थानि भूतानि येन सर्वमिदं ततम् ॥८-२२॥
Sloka (English Translation): O Arjuna, that Supreme Divine Personality is attainable only through exclusive devotion. He is the all-pervading Being, within whom all living entities exist and by whom all this is pervaded.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals that the Supreme Divine (Parama Purusha) can only be attained through unwavering, exclusive devotion (Ananya Bhakti). This divine being exists in and through everything.
Famous Quotes: What you seek is seeking you.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna speaks of divine connection through devotion, Rumi’s words remind us that spiritual longing works both ways — the Divine seeks the devotee as much as the devotee seeks the Divine.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यत्र काले त्वनावृत्तिमावृत्तिं चैव योगिनः ।
प्रयाता यान्ति तं कालं वक्ष्यामि भरतर्षभ ॥८-२३॥
Sloka (English Translation): O best of the Bharatas, I shall now explain the time at which yogis depart this world, never to return, and also the time at which they return.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna introduces the concept of the timing of death — how spiritual seekers, depending on the time of departure, may either achieve liberation or return to the cycle of birth.
Famous Quotes: Timing is everything. If it’s meant to happen, it will, at the right time.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s emphasis on the timing of a yogi’s departure mirrors this quote — not just effort, but the right timing influences destiny.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अग्निर्ज्योतिरहः शुक्लः षण्मासा उत्तरायणम् ।
तत्र प्रयाता गच्छन्ति ब्रह्म ब्रह्मविदो जनाः ॥८-२४॥
Sloka (English Translation): Those who depart during the time of fire, light, day, the bright fortnight, and the six months of the northern solstice (Uttarayana) attain the Supreme Brahman.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains the path of light (Shukla Gati), symbolizing spiritual illumination. Departing souls during these auspicious times merge with the Supreme.
Famous Quotes: Light must come from inside. You cannot ask the darkness to leave; you must turn on the light.
Comparison/Relations: The journey through the path of light Krishna describes echoes Rinpoche’s insight — true illumination comes from within, leading to ultimate liberation.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
धूमो रात्रिस्तथा कृष्णः षण्मासा दक्षिणायनम् ।
तत्र चान्द्रमसं ज्योतिर्योगी प्राप्य निवर्तते ॥८-२५॥
Sloka (English Translation): But those who depart during the time of smoke, night, the dark fortnight, and the six months of the southern solstice (Dakshinayana) attain the lunar light and return again.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna describes the path of darkness (Krishna Gati) — those who pass during inauspicious times reach temporary celestial realms but must return to the cycle of rebirth.
Famous Quotes: Even the darkest night will end and the sun will rise.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s teaching about cycles of light and dark parallels Hugo’s words — darkness (ignorance) is temporary; only spiritual wisdom (light) grants eternal liberation.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
शुक्लकृष्णे गती ह्येते जगतः शाश्वते मते ।
एकया यात्यनावृत्तिमन्ययावर्तते पुनः ॥८-२६॥
Sloka (English Translation): These two paths — the path of light (Shukla Gati) and the path of darkness (Krishna Gati) — are considered eternal. By one, a being attains liberation, and by the other, one returns to the cycle of rebirth.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna describes the two eternal paths for the soul. The path of light leads to liberation, while the path of darkness binds one to the cycle of birth and death.
Famous Quotes: There are two ways of spreading light: to be the candle or the mirror that reflects it.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna speaks of two spiritual paths, Edith Wharton’s quote reminds us that light (wisdom or spiritual progress) can be directly pursued or reflected through guidance — both ways matter in one's journey.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
नैते सृती पार्थ जानन्योगी मुह्यति कश्चन ।
तस्मात्सर्वेषु कालेषु योगयुक्तो भवार्जुन ॥८-२७॥
Sloka (English Translation): O Arjuna, knowing these two paths, no yogi is ever deluded. Therefore, at all times, be steadfast in yoga.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna urges Arjuna to stay unwavering in his practice of yoga. Awareness of these spiritual paths empowers a yogi, keeping them from confusion.
Famous Quotes: Be steady and well-ordered in your life so that you can be fierce and original in your work.
Comparison/Relations: Like Krishna’s advice on steadiness in spiritual practice, Flaubert emphasizes balance and order as the foundation for deeper creativity and success — both in life and spirituality.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
वेदेषु यज्ञेषु तपःसु चैव
दानेषु यत्पुण्यफलं प्रदिष्टम् ।
अत्येति तत्सर्वमिदं विदित्वा
योगी परं स्थानमुपैति चाद्यम् ॥८-२८॥
Sloka (English Translation): A yogi who knows this transcends the rewards promised by the Vedas, sacrifices, austerities, and charity. Such a yogi attains the supreme, eternal abode.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna declares that a steadfast yogi surpasses all material rewards — from Vedic rituals, penances, and charity — attaining instead the highest spiritual goal: union with the Supreme.
Famous Quotes: Spirituality is not about getting what you want. It is about becoming who you truly are.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s teaching that a yogi transcends material gains echoes Tolle’s idea — spiritual growth isn't about accumulation but about evolving into one's truest form.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रीभगवानुवाच ।
इदं तु ते गुह्यतमं प्रवक्ष्याम्यनसूयवे ।
ज्ञानं विज्ञानसहितं यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात् ॥९-१॥
Sloka (English Translation): The Blessed Lord said: I shall now reveal to you this most secret knowledge, combined with direct experience. Knowing this, you shall be freed from all misfortune.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna introduces the "royal knowledge" — the supreme spiritual truth — promising that those who learn and experience it will transcend suffering and attain liberation. He highlights the blend of theoretical wisdom and direct spiritual experience.
Famous Quotes: Knowledge is of no value unless you put it into practice.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna's stress on wisdom paired with experience aligns with Chekhov's view — true understanding emerges only when knowledge is lived and practiced.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
राजविद्या राजगुह्यं पवित्रमिदमुत्तमम् ।
प्रत्यक्षावगमं धर्म्यं सुसुखं कर्तुमव्ययम् ॥९-२॥
Sloka (English Translation): This is the king of sciences and the most profound secret. It is supremely purifying, directly realizable, righteous, easy to practice, and imperishable.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna declares this knowledge as the highest and most sacred, offering direct realization of divine truth. It’s a path that's pure, simple, and everlasting — transcending rituals to focus on inner transformation.
Famous Quotes: Simplicity is the ultimate sophistication.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna describes this knowledge as simple yet profound, da Vinci's quote captures how true wisdom often lies in simplicity, not complexity.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अश्रद्दधानाः पुरुषा धर्मस्यास्य परन्तप ।
अप्राप्य मां निवर्तन्ते मृत्युसंसारवर्त्मनि ॥९-३॥
Sloka (English Translation): People who lack faith in this dharma, O Arjuna, cannot attain Me. They repeatedly return to the cycle of birth and death.
Meaning/Interpretation: Faith is crucial for spiritual growth. Krishna warns that without belief in the divine truth, people remain bound to the cycle of rebirth, unable to realize ultimate liberation.
Famous Quotes: Faith is taking the first step even when you don't see the whole staircase.
Comparison/Relations: Like Krishna’s emphasis on faith as the foundation for spiritual progress, MLK Jr.'s words highlight that believing without fully understanding is essential for taking the first steps toward growth.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
मया ततमिदं सर्वं जगदव्यक्तमूर्तिना ।
मत्स्थानि सर्वभूतानि न चाहं तेष्ववस्थितः ॥९-४॥
Sloka (English Translation): All beings abide in Me, but I am not confined to them. Though My unmanifest form pervades the universe, I remain beyond it.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals His omnipresence — He permeates all existence but is not limited by it. This paradox teaches that the divine is both immanent (within everything) and transcendent (beyond all forms).
Famous Quotes: God is a circle whose center is everywhere and circumference nowhere.
Comparison/Relations: Empedocles' view mirrors Krishna’s description of divine omnipresence — present everywhere yet unrestricted by any boundary.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
न च मत्स्थानि भूतानि पश्य मे योगमैश्वरम् ।
भूतभृन्न च भूतस्थो ममात्मा भूतभावनः ॥९-५॥
Sloka (English Translation): And yet, the beings do not abide in Me — behold My divine mystery! Though I am the creator and sustainer of all beings, My true self remains detached.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna presents a divine mystery: though He creates and supports all life, He remains untouched by it. This verse reflects the paradox of divine involvement without attachment — a core concept in spiritual philosophy.
Famous Quotes: Be in the world but not of the world.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna's teaching echoes Jesus' wisdom — to engage with the world without being consumed by it — embodying spiritual detachment amidst worldly duties.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यथाकाशस्थितो नित्यं वायुः सर्वत्रगो महान् ।
तथा सर्वाणि भूतानि मत्स्थानीत्युपधारय ॥९-६॥
Sloka (English Translation): Just as the great wind, moving everywhere, always remains in the sky, so do all beings rest in Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna uses the analogy of wind in the sky to explain how all beings exist within Him, yet He remains unaffected. This highlights His omnipresence and detachment — He holds the universe together without being bound by it.
Famous Quotes: God is within everything, but not confined by anything.
Comparison/Relations: Both Krishna and Eckhart describe divinity as all-pervading yet unbounded, reinforcing the concept of detached omnipresence.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सर्वभूतानि कौन्तेय प्रकृतिं यान्ति मामिकाम् ।
कल्पक्षये पुनस्तानि कल्पादौ विसृजाम्यहम् ॥९-७॥
Sloka (English Translation): At the end of a cosmic cycle, all beings merge into My material nature, and at the beginning of the next, I create them again.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna speaks of the cosmic rhythm — creation, dissolution, and recreation — governed by His will. It reflects the eternal cycle of existence, where all beings dissolve into Him and re-emerge at His command.
Famous Quotes: Every end is a new beginning.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s words about cosmic renewal echo Seneca's philosophy — endings are merely transitions to new beginnings — reinforcing the eternal cycle of life and rebirth.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
प्रकृतिं स्वामवष्टभ्य विसृजामि पुनः पुनः ।
भूतग्राममिमं कृत्स्नमवशं प्रकृतेर्वशात् ॥९-८॥
Sloka (English Translation): Controlling My material nature, I repeatedly create the multitude of beings, who are helplessly subject to its laws.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna emphasizes that creation is an ongoing process, driven by His command, but the beings are bound by the laws of nature. Despite His control, the material world operates under a set divine order.
Famous Quotes: Nature is the art of God.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna's control over nature mirrors Dante’s view — nature is a reflection of divine will, intricately designed yet governed by its own rules.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
न च मां तानि कर्माणि निबध्नन्ति धनञ्जय ।
उदासीनवदासीनमसक्तं तेषु कर्मसु ॥९-९॥
Sloka (English Translation): O Arjuna, these actions do not bind Me. I remain indifferent and unattached to all these works.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna clarifies that, though He orchestrates creation and dissolution, He remains detached. His actions are not motivated by desire, emphasizing the principle of selfless action.
Famous Quotes: Do your work with all your heart, but never let it bind you.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna's stance on detached action aligns with Lao Tzu’s philosophy — work wholeheartedly but without attachment — a core teaching of both spiritual traditions.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
मयाध्यक्षेण प्रकृतिः सूयते सचराचरम् ।
हेतुनानेन कौन्तेय जगद्विपरिवर्तते ॥९-१०॥
Sloka (English Translation): Under My supervision, material nature produces both the moving and the non-moving; thus, O Arjuna, the world revolves.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals that He governs the universe, overseeing the dynamic interaction of nature, yet remains above it. The world operates through divine orchestration.
Famous Quotes: The universe is not outside of you. Look inside yourself; everything that you want, you already are.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna's role as the overseer of creation resonates with Rumi’s idea — divinity shapes the outer world, yet its essence resides within each being.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अवजानन्ति मां मूढा मानुषीं तनुमाश्रितम् ।
परं भावमजानन्तो मम भूतमहेश्वरम् ॥९-११॥
Sloka (English Translation): Fools deride Me when I descend in the human form. They do not know My transcendental nature as the Supreme Lord of all beings.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna addresses how ignorant beings fail to recognize His divinity when He takes a human form. His true essence goes beyond physicality — He remains the Lord of all creation despite appearing in a relatable, mortal guise.
