Famous Quotes: Do not judge by appearances; a rich heart may be under a poor coat.
Comparison/Relations: This aligns with Krishna's message — outward appearances can deceive. His divine form is hidden, just as wisdom or greatness often lies beneath humble exteriors.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
मोघाशा मोघकर्माणो मोघज्ञाना विचेतसः ।
राक्षसीमासुरीं चैव प्रकृतिं मोहिनीं श्रिताः ॥९-१२॥
Sloka (English Translation): Those who are bewildered are attracted by demonic and atheistic views. Their hopes, actions, and knowledge are all in vain.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna warns that those led by ignorance and selfish desires fall into demonic tendencies. Their aspirations and actions, lacking a higher purpose, yield no true fulfillment.
Famous Quotes: Without knowledge, action is useless, and knowledge without action is futile.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Abu Bakr highlights the futility of misguided actions, Krishna emphasizes that without spiritual wisdom, even the most ambitious efforts are fruitless.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
महात्मानस्तु मां पार्थ दैवीं प्रकृतिमाश्रिताः ।
भजन्त्यनन्यमनसो ज्ञात्वा भूतादिमव्ययम् ॥९-१३॥
Sloka (English Translation): But the great souls, O Arjuna, who take shelter in the divine nature, know Me as the imperishable source of all beings and worship Me with undivided minds.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna contrasts the enlightened souls with the ignorant ones. Great souls, rooted in divine consciousness, recognize His eternal nature and worship Him with unwavering devotion.
Famous Quotes: The soul that sees beauty may sometimes walk alone.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna's "great souls" reflect Goethe's idea — those who perceive divine truth may walk a path of solitude and inner devotion, undistracted by worldly illusions.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सततं कीर्तयन्तो मां यतन्तश्च दृढव्रताः ।
नमस्यन्तश्च मां भक्त्या नित्ययुक्ता उपासते ॥९-१४॥
Sloka (English Translation): Always chanting My glories, striving with determination, bowing before Me in devotion — these souls worship Me constantly with steadfast resolve.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna describes the devotion of true seekers — they continuously glorify Him, driven by unwavering dedication. Their focus is constant, reflecting their spiritual commitment.
Famous Quotes: Success is not final, failure is not fatal: it is the courage to continue that counts.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna praises determined seekers, Churchill's quote reflects the same resilience — devotion requires relentless dedication, despite life’s ups and downs.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ज्ञानयज्ञेन चाप्यन्ये यजन्तो मामुपासते ।
एकत्वेन पृथक्त्वेन बहुधा विश्वतोमुखम् ॥९-१५॥
Sloka (English Translation): Others, engaging in the yajña of knowledge, worship Me in various ways — seeing Me as one with everything, as separate, or in multiple forms.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna acknowledges diverse spiritual paths. Some view Him as the all-encompassing One, others as a distinct divine being, while some worship His many forms. All approaches ultimately lead to Him.
Famous Quotes: There are many paths to the top of the mountain, but the view is always the same.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s inclusivity of multiple spiritual views mirrors this proverb — the paths may differ, but the destination (divine realization) remains the same.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अहं क्रतुरहं यज्ञः स्वधाहमहमौषधम् ।
मन्त्रोऽहमहमेवाज्यमहमग्निरहं हुतम् ॥९-१६॥
Sloka (English Translation): I am the ritual, I am the sacrifice, I am the offering to the ancestors, I am the healing herb, I am the sacred chant, I am the clarified butter, I am the fire, and I am the act of offering.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna declares that He is the essence of all spiritual practices — the rituals, sacrifices, and offerings. Everything in a spiritual act stems from Him, reinforcing His omnipresence.
Famous Quotes: God is not in the sky or far away. He is within you, in your heart.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna identifies Himself as the core of all practices, Gandhi reminds us that the divine is not distant but an inseparable part of our being.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
पिताहमस्य जगतो माता धाता पितामहः ।
वेद्यं पवित्रमोंकार ऋक्साम यजुरेव च ॥९-१७॥
Sloka (English Translation): I am the father of this universe, the mother, the support, and the grandsire. I am the object of knowledge, the purifier, and the syllable Om. I am also the Rig, Sama, and Yajur Vedas.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna transcends gender roles — He is both mother and father, creator and sustainer. His essence pervades all spiritual knowledge, as symbolized by the sacred Vedas and Om.
Famous Quotes: All that we are is the result of what we have thought.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna embodies all cosmic elements, Buddha emphasizes that our thoughts shape our reality — both concepts highlight the interconnectedness of all things.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
गतिर्भर्ता प्रभुः साक्षी निवासः शरणं सुहृत् ।
प्रभवः प्रलयः स्थानं निधानं बीजमव्ययम् ॥९-१८॥
Sloka (English Translation): I am the goal, the sustainer, the master, the witness, the abode, the refuge, and the most dear friend. I am the creation, dissolution, the basis of all, the resting place, and the eternal seed.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna describes His many roles — He is not just a distant God but also a friend, witness, and protector. He is present at every stage of existence — creation, preservation, and dissolution.
Famous Quotes: You are never alone. You are eternally connected with everyone.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s assurance of His constant presence mirrors Amit Ray’s belief in universal connection — we are never truly isolated, for the divine resides within us.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तपाम्यहमहं वर्षं निगृह्णाम्युत्सृजामि च ।
अमृतं चैव मृत्युश्च सदसच्चाहमर्जुन ॥९-१९॥
Sloka (English Translation): I give heat, I withhold and send forth rain. I am immortality and also death. I am both the being and the non-being, O Arjuna.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that He governs natural forces like rain and heat. He transcends dualities — life and death, existence and non-existence — showing that all opposites merge into His divine nature.
Famous Quotes: Everything in the universe has a rhythm, everything dances.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s control over life’s cycles reflects Angelou’s concept of universal rhythm — every act of nature, from rain to death, moves in harmony with the divine.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
त्रैविद्या मां सोमपाः पूतपापा यज्ञैरिष्ट्वा स्वर्गतिं प्रार्थयन्ते ।
ते पुण्यमासाद्य सुरेन्द्रलोकमश्नन्ति दिव्यान्दिवि देवभोगान् ॥९-२०॥
Sloka (English Translation): Those who follow the Vedas, drinking the soma juice and seeking the heavenly realms, worship Me indirectly through sacrifices. They reach the heavens, enjoy divine pleasures, and then return to the mortal world.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna acknowledges those performing rituals for heavenly rewards. However, He hints at the temporary nature of such pleasures, subtly emphasizing that true liberation lies beyond transient joys.
Famous Quotes: The foolish man seeks happiness in the distance; the wise grows it under his feet.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s message aligns with Oppenheim’s wisdom — seeking external rewards (heavenly or worldly) is fleeting. Lasting happiness comes from inner spiritual growth.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ते तं भुक्त्वा स्वर्गलोकं विशालं
क्षीणे पुण्ये मर्त्यलोकं विशन्ति।
एवं त्रयीधर्ममनुप्रपन्ना
गतागतं कामकामा लभन्ते ॥९-२१॥
Sloka (English Translation): Having enjoyed the vast heaven, they return to the mortal world when their merit is exhausted. Thus, those who follow the Vedic rites, seeking desires, repeatedly come and go between the realms of pleasure and suffering.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna points out the impermanence of heavenly rewards. Even those who achieve celestial joys must return to the cycle of birth and death once their merits are depleted — emphasizing the futility of desire-driven rituals.
Famous Quotes: What goes up must come down.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Newton’s law speaks of gravity, Krishna highlights a spiritual version of this truth — temporary joys inevitably fade, pulling one back into the cycle of rebirth.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अनन्याश्चिन्तयन्तो मां
ये जनाः पर्युपासते।
तेषां नित्याभियुक्तानां
योगक्षेमं वहाम्यहम् ॥९-२२॥
Sloka (English Translation): But those who worship Me with exclusive devotion, meditating on Me without distraction — I ensure they lack nothing and protect what they have.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reassures Arjuna that those who focus solely on Him, without chasing worldly desires, will be taken care of. He personally ensures their well-being — both spiritually and materially.
Famous Quotes: Seek first the kingdom of God, and all these things shall be added unto you.
Comparison/Relations: Both Krishna and Jesus emphasize the same truth — when you prioritize the divine, your needs naturally fall into place.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
येऽप्यन्यदेवता भक्ता
यजन्ते श्रद्धयान्विताः।
तेऽपि मामेव कौन्तेय
यजन्त्यविधिपूर्वकम् ॥९-२३॥
Sloka (English Translation): Even those who worship other deities with faith actually worship Me, O Arjuna, though in an improper way.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna clarifies that all forms of worship ultimately reach Him, even if the devotee doesn’t realize it. However, worship that lacks proper understanding remains incomplete.
Famous Quotes: Paths are many, but the truth is one.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Swami Vivekananda taught that all spiritual paths lead to the same truth, Krishna acknowledges that even indirect devotion is still devotion to Him.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अहं हि सर्वयज्ञानां
भोक्ता च प्रभुरेव च।
न तु मामभिजानन्ति
तत्त्वेनातश्च्यवन्ति ते ॥९-२४॥
Sloka (English Translation): I am the only enjoyer and Lord of all sacrifices. But those who do not recognize My true nature fall back into the cycle of birth and death.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna asserts that He is the ultimate recipient of all rituals and offerings. Without realizing His supreme position, people remain bound to the endless cycle of reincarnation.
Famous Quotes: True knowledge comes with deep understanding, not just actions.
Comparison/Relations: Like Krishna’s teaching, Confucius highlights that mere rituals or actions without deeper realization do not lead to enlightenment.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यान्ति देवव्रता देवान्
पितॄन्यान्ति पितृव्रताः।
भूतानि यान्ति भूतेज्या
यान्ति मद्याजिनोऽपि माम् ॥९-२५॥
Sloka (English Translation): Those who worship the gods go to the gods; those who worship the ancestors go to the ancestors; those who worship spirits go to the spirits. But those who worship Me come to Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals a universal spiritual law — the destination of one's soul aligns with their object of worship. If one seeks divine union, only by worshiping Him directly can they break free from lesser realms.
Famous Quotes: You become what you believe.
Comparison/Relations: Oprah’s words resonate with Krishna’s teaching — your beliefs shape your spiritual journey. Worshiping lesser deities may bring temporary rewards, but only faith in the Supreme leads to eternal liberation.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
पत्रं पुष्पं फलं तोयं
यो मे भक्त्या प्रयच्छति।
तदहं भक्त्युपहृतमश्नामि
प्रयतात्मनः ॥९-२६॥
Sloka (English Translation): Whoever offers Me a leaf, a flower, a fruit, or water with devotion — I accept that heartfelt offering from the pure-minded devotee.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna highlights that it's not the material value of an offering that matters — it’s the love and sincerity behind it. Even the simplest gift, if given with devotion, is accepted by Him.
Famous Quotes: It’s not how much we give, but how much love we put into giving.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s teaching mirrors Mother Teresa’s wisdom — genuine intention matters more than lavishness.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यत्करोषि यदश्नासि
यज्जुहोषि ददासि यत्।
यत्तपस्यसि कौन्तेय
तत्कुरुष्व मदर्पणम् ॥९-२७॥
Sloka (English Translation): Whatever you do, whatever you eat, whatever you offer in sacrifice or give as charity — do it as an offering to Me, O Arjuna.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna teaches the path of selfless action — by dedicating every act, no matter how small, to Him, one transcends personal desires and attains spiritual growth.
Famous Quotes: Work done with love is a form of worship.
Comparison/Relations: Just like Rumi’s idea of work as worship, Krishna emphasizes spiritualizing every action through surrender.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
शुभाशुभफलैरेवं
मोक्ष्यसे कर्मबन्धनैः।
सन्न्यासयोगयुक्तात्मा
विमुक्तो मामुपैष्यसि ॥९-२८॥
Sloka (English Translation): By dedicating all your actions to Me, you will be freed from the bondage of karma — both good and bad. Thus liberated, you will attain Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that surrendering all actions to Him neutralizes karma’s binding effects, liberating the soul from the cycle of birth and death.
Famous Quotes: Freedom comes when you learn to let go.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna's words align with Buddha’s philosophy — liberation arises from detachment and selfless devotion.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
समोऽहं सर्वभूतेषु
न मे द्वेष्योऽस्ति न प्रियः।
ये भजन्ति तु मां भक्त्या
मयि ते तेषु चाप्यहम् ॥९-२९॥
Sloka (English Translation): I am equally present in all beings; I neither favor nor hate anyone. But those who worship Me with devotion — they dwell in Me, and I dwell in them.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna stresses His impartiality — He treats all beings equally. Yet, those who approach Him with love form a special connection, merging their souls with His divine presence.
Famous Quotes: Love is the bridge between you and everything
Comparison/Relations: Krishna echoes the universal truth — love and devotion forge a unique bond between the devotee and the Divine.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अपि चेत्सुदुराचरो
भजते मामनन्यभाक्।
साधुरेव स मन्तव्यः
सम्यग्व्यवसितो हि सः ॥९-३०॥
Sloka (English Translation): Even if a person with a sinful past worships Me with unwavering devotion, they are to be considered righteous — for they have resolved to walk the right path.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna offers hope to all — no matter one’s past, sincere devotion purifies the heart. A true change of heart and faith leads to spiritual upliftment.
Famous Quotes: Every saint has a past, and every sinner has a future.
Comparison/Relations: Just like Krishna’s assurance, Wilde reminds us that redemption is always possible. Sincere devotion can transform even the most wayward soul.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
क्षिप्रं भवति धर्मात्मा
शश्वच्छान्तिं निगच्छति।
कौन्तेय प्रतिजानीहि
न मे भक्तः प्रणश्यति ॥९-३१॥
Sloka (English Translation): He quickly becomes virtuous and attains lasting peace. O son of Kunti, declare it boldly: My devotee never perishes.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna assures Arjuna that those who sincerely turn to Him — no matter their past — will soon find righteousness and eternal peace. His devotees are always protected.
Famous Quotes: Faith is taking the first step even when you don't see the whole staircase.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna encourages unwavering faith, Martin Luther King Jr. speaks of stepping forward in trust, even without knowing the full path ahead.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
मां हि पार्थ व्यपाश्रित्य
येऽपि स्यु: पापयोनयः।
स्त्रियो वैश्यास्तथा शूद्रास्तेऽपि यान्ति परां गतिम् ॥९-३२॥
Sloka (English Translation): O Arjuna, those who take refuge in Me — even if they are of lower birth, women, merchants, or laborers — can still attain the supreme goal.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna emphasizes that His love and grace are for all, regardless of caste, gender, or status. Anyone who surrenders to Him with devotion can reach the highest spiritual state.
Famous Quotes: God does not see the face, He sees the heart
Comparison/Relations: This verse reflects the universality of divine love — Krishna breaks social barriers, just as Gandhi promoted equality and compassion for all.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
किं पुनर्ब्राह्मणाः पुण्या
भक्ता राजर्षयस्तथा।
अनित्यमसुखं लोकम्
इमं प्राप्य भजस्व माम् ॥९-३३॥
Sloka (English Translation): How much more, then, for righteous Brahmins and devoted royal sages! Having come into this transient and sorrowful world, engage in My devotion.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna highlights that if those of lower status can achieve liberation, righteous individuals like Brahmins and sages can certainly reach spiritual heights. He urges everyone to devote themselves to Him, as the material world is fleeting.
Famous Quotes: The only permanent thing in this world is change.
Comparison/Relations: Like Krishna’s teaching on life’s impermanence, Heraclitus speaks of constant change — both urging us to seek what is eternal: spiritual connection.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
मन्मना भव मद्भक्तो
मद्याजी मां नमस्कुरु।
मामेवैष्यसि युक्त्वैवमात्मानं
मत्परायणः ॥९-३४॥
Sloka (English Translation): Fix your mind on Me, be devoted to Me, worship Me, and bow to Me. By doing so, you shall certainly come to Me — I promise you this because you are dear to Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna closes the chapter with a powerful message — love, devotion, and surrender will always lead one to Him. He gives His divine assurance to all sincere souls.
Famous Quotes: Where there is love, there is God.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s words reflect the simple truth Tolstoy shared — devotion and love bridge the gap between humanity and divinity.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रीभगवानुवाच |
भूय एव महाबाहो शृणु मे परमं वचः |
यत्तेऽहं प्रीयमाणाय वक्ष्यामि हितकाम्यया ॥१०-१॥
Sloka (English Translation): The Blessed Lord said: O mighty-armed Arjuna, hear again My supreme word, which I shall declare for your benefit, as you are dear to Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna, out of love for Arjuna, begins to reveal His divine glories once again. This verse sets the stage for an exposition of Krishna’s supreme nature, emphasizing that this knowledge is not just theoretical but deeply beneficial for Arjuna's spiritual growth.
Famous Quotes: To love is to know we are a part of something greater than ourselves.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna expresses His divine care for Arjuna by revealing higher wisdom, Rilke’s quote suggests that love connects us to a higher reality. Krishna’s words demonstrate divine affection and the importance of spiritual knowledge, paralleling the way love expands one’s awareness beyond the self.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
न मे विदुः सुरगणाः प्रभवं न महर्षयः |
अहमादिर्हि देवानां महर्षीणां च सर्वशः ॥१०-२॥
Sloka (English Translation): Neither the hosts of gods nor the great sages know My origin, for I am the source of all the gods and the great sages.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna declares that even celestial beings and wise sages cannot fully comprehend His divine nature because He is their ultimate source. This highlights Krishna’s transcendental nature beyond ordinary perception.
Famous Quotes: The mystery of life isn’t a problem to solve, but a reality to experience.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna emphasizes that His divine origin is beyond intellectual understanding, similar to Herbert’s idea that life’s deepest truths are to be experienced rather than merely analyzed. Spiritual realization, like Krishna’s nature, unfolds through devotion rather than logic alone.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यो मामजमनादिं च वेत्ति लोकमहेश्वरम् |
असंमूढः स मर्त्येषु सर्वपापैः प्रमुच्यते ॥१०-३॥
Sloka (English Translation): He who knows Me as unborn, beginningless, and the Supreme Lord of all worlds—such a person, free from delusion, is liberated from all sins.
Meaning/Interpretation: Recognizing Krishna as the eternal, beginningless, and supreme controller of all existence leads to liberation. This verse reinforces the power of divine knowledge in freeing one from worldly bondage.
Famous Quotes: The only real prison is ignorance, and the only real freedom is enlightenment.
Comparison/Relations: Buddha’s idea that ignorance is the root of suffering aligns with Krishna’s teaching that true liberation comes from knowing His divine nature. Both suggest that spiritual wisdom leads to freedom from suffering and sin.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
बुद्धिर्ज्ञानमसम्मोहः क्षमा सत्यं दमः शमः |
सुखं दुःखं भवोऽभावो भयं चाभयमेव च ॥१०-४॥
Sloka (English Translation): Intelligence, wisdom, non-delusion, forgiveness, truth, self-restraint, peace, happiness, sorrow, birth, death, fear, and fearlessness—all these qualities arise from Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna states that all fundamental aspects of existence—both positive and negative—originate from Him. This emphasizes His all-encompassing nature as the source of everything.
Famous Quotes: Everything you can imagine is real.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna explains that all aspects of reality come from Him, just as Picasso’s quote suggests that imagination shapes existence. Both ideas affirm that everything, from thoughts to emotions to experiences, is part of a greater cosmic design.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अहिंसा समता तुष्टिस्तपो दानं यशोऽयशः |
भवन्ति भावा भूतानां मत्त एव पृथग्विधाः ॥१०-५॥
Sloka (English Translation): Non-violence, equanimity, contentment, austerity, charity, fame, and infamy—these different states of beings arise from Me alone.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that not only virtues but even contrasting qualities like fame and infamy originate from Him. This highlights the completeness of His divine presence in all aspects of life.
Famous Quotes: There is nothing either good or bad, but thinking makes it so.
Comparison/Relations: Shakespeare’s words reflect Krishna’s teaching that all qualities arise from the same divine source. The perception of good or bad is subjective, reinforcing the idea that everything exists within the divine will.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
महर्षयः सप्त पूर्वे चत्वारो मनवस्तथा |
मद्भावा मानसा जाता येषां लोक इमाः प्रजाः ॥१०-६॥
Sloka (English Translation): The seven great sages, the four ancient Manus, and others, who were born from My mind, derive their qualities from Me. From them, all the beings in the world have descended.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna declares that the greatest sages and progenitors of mankind originated from Him. This verse highlights His supreme role as the ultimate source of wisdom and creation.
Famous Quotes: The roots of all goodness lie in the soil of appreciation.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna is the source of all beings, the Dalai Lama’s words emphasize how appreciation (or gratitude) nurtures all virtues. Recognizing our divine origin leads to wisdom and righteousness.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
एतां विभूतिं योगं च मम यो वेत्ति तत्त्वतः |
सोऽविकम्पेन योगेन युज्यते नात्र संशयः ॥१०-७॥
Sloka (English Translation): He who truly understands My divine manifestations and yogic power is unshaken in yoga and remains steadfast in devotion. There is no doubt about this.
Meaning/Interpretation: Knowing Krishna’s divine nature strengthens one’s unwavering devotion. This verse highlights how true knowledge leads to spiritual stability and dedication.
Famous Quotes: Faith is taking the first step even when you don’t see the whole staircase.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna teaches that understanding His divine nature leads to unshakable faith. Similarly, Martin Luther King Jr.'s quote encourages trust in the unseen path, which aligns with surrendering to Krishna with devotion.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अहं सर्वस्य प्रभवो मत्तः सर्वं प्रवर्तते |
इति मत्वा भजन्ते मां बुधा भावसमन्विताः ॥१०-८॥
Sloka (English Translation): I am the source of all creation. Everything emanates from Me. The wise, knowing this, worship Me with devotion.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna declares Himself as the origin of all existence, and those who realize this naturally develop devotion towards Him. True wisdom leads to loving surrender.
Famous Quotes: When you realize nothing is lacking, the whole world belongs to you.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna explains that realizing His presence in everything leads to devotion. Similarly, Lao Tzu’s quote suggests that understanding completeness brings fulfillment, just as surrendering to Krishna brings spiritual richness.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
मच्चित्ता मद्गतप्राणा बोधयन्तः परस्परम् |
कथयन्तश्च मां नित्यं तुष्यन्ति च रमन्ति च ॥१०-९॥
Sloka (English Translation): With minds fixed on Me and lives devoted to Me, My devotees inspire one another by speaking about Me and derive joy and satisfaction from constantly glorifying Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Devotees find happiness in sharing Krishna’s divine glories. Spiritual discussions deepen devotion and create a sense of divine companionship.
Famous Quotes: Happiness is only real when shared.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna describes how His devotees find joy in speaking about Him. This reflects McCandless’s insight that true happiness lies in shared experiences, especially when centered on divine consciousness.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तेषां सततयुक्तानां भजतां प्रीतिपूर्वकम् |
ददामि बुद्धियोगं तं येन मामुपयान्ति ते ॥१०-१०॥
Sloka (English Translation): To those who are constantly devoted to Me with love, I give the divine wisdom by which they can come to Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna assures that sincere devotees receive divine guidance. Those who worship Him with love gain the wisdom needed to attain Him.
Famous Quotes: What you seek is seeking you.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s teaching aligns with Rumi’s wisdom—just as seekers of Krishna receive His guidance, the divine also reaches out to those who truly seek it.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तेषामेवानुकम्पार्थमहमज्ञानजं तमः |
नाशयाम्यात्मभावस्थो ज्ञानदीपेन भास्वता ॥१०-११॥
Sloka (English Translation): Out of compassion for them, I, dwelling in their hearts, destroy the darkness of ignorance with the shining lamp of knowledge.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna assures that He personally illuminates the hearts of His sincere devotees, removing ignorance and bestowing divine wisdom. His compassion guides them toward liberation.
Famous Quotes: Education is the movement from darkness to light.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna dispels ignorance with the lamp of knowledge, education helps one transition from darkness to enlightenment. Both emphasize the transformative power of true wisdom.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अर्जुन उवाच |
परं ब्रह्म परं धाम पवित्रं परमं भवान् |
पुरुषं शाश्वतं दिव्यमादिदेवमजं विभुम् ॥१०-१२॥
Sloka (English Translation): Arjuna said: You are the Supreme Brahman, the Supreme Abode, the Ultimate Purifier, the Eternal Divine Being, the Primal God, the Unborn, and the Greatest.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna acknowledges Krishna’s divine nature, recognizing Him as the Supreme Truth, the eternal source of purity and existence. This verse marks Arjuna’s deep realization of Krishna’s divinity.
Famous Quotes: Recognizing the divine within yourself leads to recognizing it in everything.
Comparison/Relations: Arjuna’s realization mirrors Tolle’s insight—acknowledging Krishna’s divine presence helps one see divinity in all creation.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
आहुस्त्वामृषयः सर्वे देवर्षिर्नारदस्तथा |
असितो देवलो व्यासः स्वयं चैव ब्रवीषि मे ॥१०-१३॥
Sloka (English Translation): All the great sages—Devarishi Narada, Asita, Devala, and Vyasa—have declared You to be the Supreme Divine Person, and now You Yourself are revealing this truth to me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna emphasizes that not only does he believe in Krishna’s divinity, but renowned sages have also affirmed it. Krishna is the ultimate authority, validated by ancient wisdom.
Famous Quotes: Truth stands the test of time.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna’s divinity is confirmed by sages, true wisdom is eternal and withstands the passage of time.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सर्वमेतदृतं मन्ये यन्मां वदसि केशव |
न हि ते भगवन्व्यक्तिं विदुर्देवा न दानवाः ॥१०-१४॥
Sloka (English Translation): O Keshava, I accept everything You have told me as the absolute truth. Neither the gods nor the demons truly understand Your divine manifestations.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna expresses his full faith in Krishna’s words, acknowledging that even celestial beings struggle to comprehend His vast divine nature.
Famous Quotes: Faith is not the absence of doubt, but the courage to trust beyond it.
Comparison/Relations: Arjuna’s unwavering faith in Krishna reflects the essence of true belief—trusting the divine wisdom even when it surpasses human understanding.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
स्वयमेवात्मनात्मानं वेत्थ त्वं पुरुषोत्तम |
भूतभावन भूतेश देवदेव जगत्पते ॥१०-१५॥
Sloka (English Translation): O Supreme Person, You alone know Yourself by Yourself. You are the source of all beings, the Lord of all creatures, the God of gods, and the ruler of the universe.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna acknowledges that Krishna alone knows His true divine essence. He recognizes Krishna as the ultimate creator and sovereign ruler of the cosmos.
Famous Quotes: The one who knows himself, knows the universe.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s self-awareness mirrors Socrates’ wisdom—understanding oneself leads to deeper universal knowledge. Krishna, as the divine self, embodies this ultimate truth.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
वक्तुमर्हस्यशेषेण दिव्या ह्यात्मविभूतयः |
याभिर्विभूतिभिर्लोकानिमांस्त्वं व्याप्य तिष्ठसि ॥१०-१६॥
Sloka (English Translation): Please describe to me in detail Your divine glories, by which You pervade and exist throughout all the worlds.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna requests Krishna to reveal more about His divine manifestations that sustain and pervade the universe. He seeks a deeper understanding of Krishna’s omnipresence.
Famous Quotes: The more we understand, the more we realize there is yet to be understood.
Comparison/Relations: Like Arjuna’s thirst for divine knowledge, Aristotle’s quote reflects the idea that true wisdom lies in acknowledging the infinite scope of knowledge.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
कथं विद्यामहं योगिंस्त्वां सदा परिचिन्तयन् |
केषु केषु च भावेषु चिन्त्योऽसि भगवन्मया ॥१०-१७॥
Sloka (English Translation): O Yogeshwara, how shall I meditate on You? In what various aspects of Your being should I contemplate You, O Blessed Lord?
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna asks Krishna how he should meditate upon Him, desiring guidance on the correct perception of His divine presence in various forms.
Famous Quotes: What we think, we become.
Comparison/Relations: Arjuna’s inquiry about meditation aligns with Buddha’s wisdom—focusing one’s mind on the divine leads to spiritual transformation.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
विस्तरेणात्मनो योगं विभूतिं च जनार्दन |
भूयः कथय तृप्तिर्हि श्रृण्वतो नास्ति मेऽमृतम् ॥१०-१८॥
Sloka (English Translation): O Janardana, please describe again in detail Your divine manifestations and yogic power, for I am never satisfied in hearing Your nectar-like words.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna expresses that Krishna’s words are like divine nectar, and he yearns to hear more about His glories, reinforcing his devotion and admiration.
Famous Quotes: The more we learn, the more we want to learn.
Comparison/Relations: Arjuna’s endless thirst for divine wisdom parallels Einstein’s view—true seekers of knowledge always desire more understanding.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रीभगवानुवाच |
हन्त ते कथयिष्यामि दिव्या ह्यात्मविभूतयः |
प्राधान्यतः कुरुश्रेष्ठ नास्त्यन्तो विस्तरस्य मे ॥१०-१९॥
Sloka (English Translation): The Blessed Lord said: Yes, I shall now declare to you My divine glories, but only the principal ones, O best of the Kurus, for there is no end to My infinite manifestations.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna agrees to describe His divine manifestations but emphasizes that His glories are boundless and beyond complete enumeration.
Famous Quotes: Infinity is not something to be understood but experienced.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s infinite glories resonate with Sagan’s perspective—divine vastness cannot be fully grasped but can be felt through devotion.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अहमात्मा गुडाकेश सर्वभूताशयस्थितः |
अहमादिश्च मध्यं च भूतानामन्त एव च ॥१०-२०॥
Sloka (English Translation): O Arjuna, I am the Self, seated in the hearts of all beings. I am the beginning, the middle, and also the end of all beings.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna declares Himself as the Supreme Self residing in all living beings, signifying His eternal presence as the source, sustainer, and ultimate destiny of all existence.
Famous Quotes: Within you is the light of a thousand suns.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s declaration of being the indwelling Self aligns with Vivekananda’s teaching—divinity resides within every individual.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
आदित्यानामहं विष्णुर्ज्योतिषां रविरंशुमान् |
मरीचिर्मरुतामस्मि नक्षत्राणामहं शशी ॥१०-२१॥
Sloka (English Translation): Among the Adityas, I am Vishnu; among luminous bodies, I am the radiant sun. Among the Maruts, I am Marichi, and among the stars, I am the moon.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna describes His divine presence in various celestial manifestations, symbolizing His omnipresence as light, life, and cosmic energy.
Famous Quotes: Even after all this time, the sun never says to the earth, 'You owe me.' Look what happens with a love like that—it lights up the whole sky.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s identification with the sun reflects Hafiz’s wisdom—true divine love, like the sun’s light, is unconditional and illuminates everything.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
वेदानां सामवेदोऽस्मि देवानामस्मि वासवः |
इन्द्रियाणां मनश्चास्मि भूतानामस्मि चेतना ॥१०-२२॥
Sloka (English Translation): Among the Vedas, I am the Sama Veda; among the gods, I am Indra. Among the senses, I am the mind, and among living beings, I am consciousness.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna identifies Himself with the most significant aspects of knowledge, leadership, perception, and awareness, reinforcing His role as the Supreme Source.
Famous Quotes: The mind is everything. What you think, you become.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna describes Himself as the mind, Buddha’s wisdom highlights how our thoughts shape our reality, making the mind a gateway to spiritual transformation.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
रुद्राणां शङ्करश्चास्मि वित्तेशो यक्षरक्षसाम् |
वसूनां पावकश्चास्मि मेरुः शिखरिणामहम् ॥१०-२३॥
Sloka (English Translation): Among the Rudras, I am Shiva; among the Yakshas and Rakshasas, I am Kubera. Among the Vasus, I am Agni, and among mountains, I am Meru.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna associates Himself with the forces of destruction, wealth, fire, and grandeur, emphasizing His control over power, prosperity, and nature’s elements.
Famous Quotes: True strength is not in power but in mastery of oneself.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna, like Shiva, represents destruction and transformation, showing that true power lies in self-mastery and the ability to create and dissolve.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
पुरोधसां च मुख्यं मां विद्धि पार्थ बृहस्पतिम् |
सेनानीनामहं स्कन्दः सरसामस्मि सागरः ॥१०-२४॥
Sloka (English Translation): Among priests, O Arjuna, know Me to be Brihaspati. Among generals, I am Skanda; among bodies of water, I am the ocean.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna represents wisdom (Brihaspati), leadership in battle (Skanda), and the vastness of nature (the ocean), showing His supremacy in intellect, warfare, and natural forces.
Famous Quotes: Wisdom is not a product of schooling but of the lifelong attempt to acquire it.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna embodies wisdom, leadership, and expansiveness, aligning with Einstein’s view that true wisdom is an ever-evolving pursuit.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
महर्षीणां भृगुरहं गिरामस्म्येकमक्षरम् |
यज्ञानां जपयज्ञोऽस्मि स्थावराणां हिमालयः ॥१०-२५॥
Sloka (English Translation): Among great sages, I am Bhrigu; among sounds, I am the sacred syllable "Om." Among sacrifices, I am the silent prayer (Japa), and among immovable things, I am the Himalayas.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna associates Himself with the eternal wisdom of sages, the vibration of creation (Om), meditative devotion, and the unshakable grandeur of the Himalayas.
Famous Quotes: Silence is a source of great strength.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna as Japa (silent prayer) mirrors Lao Tzu’s belief in the power of stillness—deep devotion is often expressed in quiet surrender rather than outward rituals.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अश्वत्थः सर्ववृक्षाणां देवर्षीणां च नारदः |
गन्धर्वाणां चित्ररथः सिद्धानां कपिलो मुनिः ॥१०-२६॥
Sloka (English Translation): Among all trees, I am the Ashvattha (sacred fig tree); among celestial sages, I am Narada. Among Gandharvas, I am Chitraratha, and among perfected beings, I am the sage Kapila.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna symbolizes the eternal and sacred aspects of nature, wisdom, celestial artistry, and profound philosophical knowledge.
Famous Quotes: A tree with deep roots laughs at storms.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna as the Ashvattha tree represents eternal wisdom, just as this quote emphasizes the strength and endurance of deep-rooted knowledge.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
उच्चैःश्रवसमश्वानां विद्धि माममृतोद्भवम् |
ऐरावतं गजेन्द्राणां नराणां च नराधिपम् ॥१०-२७॥
Sloka (English Translation): Among horses, I am Ucchaihshravas, born of nectar. Among elephants, I am Airavata, and among men, I am the king.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna represents majestic beings, supreme power, and leadership, indicating the divine influence behind strength, royalty, and noble creatures.
Famous Quotes: Leadership is not about being in charge. It is about taking care of those in your charge.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna as a king aligns with true leadership qualities—serving and guiding others, rather than merely holding power.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
आयुधानामहं वज्रं धेनूनामस्मि कामधुक् |
प्रजनश्चास्मि कन्दर्पः सर्पाणामस्मि वासुकिः ॥१०-२८॥
Sloka (English Translation): Among weapons, I am the thunderbolt (Vajra); among cows, I am Kamadhenu. Among causes of procreation, I am Kamadeva, and among serpents, I am Vasuki.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna represents immense power (thunderbolt), divine abundance (Kamadhenu), the force of attraction (Kamadeva), and leadership in hidden energies (Vasuki).
Famous Quotes: Power is not revealed by striking hard or often, but by striking true.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna as Vajra symbolizes focused power, Balzac’s words emphasize that true strength lies in precision and purpose rather than sheer force.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अनन्तश्चास्मि नागानां वरुणो यादसामहम् |
पितॄणामर्यमा चास्मि यमः संयमतामहम् ॥१०-२९॥
Sloka (English Translation): Among Nagas (divine serpents), I am Ananta; among water deities, I am Varuna. Among ancestors, I am Aryama, and among enforcers of discipline, I am Yama.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna embodies infinity, sovereignty over waters, divine lineage, and justice, reflecting His control over the cosmic order.
Famous Quotes: Justice will not be served until those who are unaffected are as outraged as those who are.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna as Yama, the lord of justice, aligns with Franklin’s belief—true justice requires universal awareness and action, not just from the affected.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
प्रह्लादश्चास्मि दैत्यानां कालः कलयतामहम् |
मृगाणां च मृगेन्द्रोऽहं वैनतेयश्च पक्षिणाम् ॥१०-३०॥
Sloka (English Translation): Among the Daityas (demons), I am Prahlada; among time-measurers, I am Time itself. Among beasts, I am the lion, and among birds, I am Garuda.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna signifies unwavering devotion (Prahlada), the unstoppable nature of time, the courage of a lion, and the swiftness of Garuda, the divine eagle.
Famous Quotes: Time is what we want most, but what we use worst.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna as Time itself reminds us of Penn’s wisdom—time is the most powerful force, yet we often fail to harness it wisely.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
पवनः पवतामस्मि रामः शस्त्रभृतामहम् |
झषाणां मकरश्चास्मि स्रोतसामस्मि जाह्नवी ॥१०-३१॥
Sloka (English Translation): Among purifiers, I am the wind; among warriors, I am Rama. Among aquatic creatures, I am the makara (crocodile), and among rivers, I am the Ganges.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna represents the cleansing force of the wind, the ideal warrior in Rama, the strength of aquatic creatures, and the sacredness of the Ganges.
Famous Quotes: The river cuts through rock, not because of its power, but because of its persistence.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna as the Ganges symbolizes spiritual purification and persistence, this quote highlights the unstoppable force of determination.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सर्गाणामादिरन्तश्च मध्यं चैवाहमर्जुन |
अध्यात्मविद्या विद्यानां वादः प्रवदतामहम् ॥१०-३२॥
Sloka (English Translation): Of all creations, I am the beginning, middle, and end, O Arjuna. Among all knowledge, I am the knowledge of the self, and among arguments, I am logical reasoning.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna embodies the entirety of creation, self-realization, and the essence of wisdom through logic and understanding.
Famous Quotes: Knowing yourself is the beginning of all wisdom.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna as the knowledge of the self aligns with Aristotle’s insight—true wisdom starts with self-awareness.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अक्षराणामकारोऽस्मि द्वन्द्वः सामासिकस्य च |
अहमेवाक्षयः कालो धाताहं विश्वतोमुखः ॥१०-३३॥
Sloka (English Translation): Among letters, I am the first letter ‘A’; among compound words, I am the dual form. I am the infinite Time, and I am the Sustainer of the universe, with faces in all directions.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna represents the foundation of language, the endless nature of time, and His omnipresent sustaining power.
Famous Quotes: Language is the road map of a culture. It tells you where its people come from and where they are going.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna as the first letter of language signifies the fundamental nature of speech, much like how language shapes culture and history.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
मृत्युः सर्वहरश्चाहमुद्भवश्च भविष्यताम् |
कीर्तिः श्रीर्वाक्च नारीणां स्मृतिर्मेधा धृतिः क्षमा ॥१०-३४॥
Sloka (English Translation): I am death, which takes away everything, and I am the origin of all things to come. Among feminine qualities, I am fame, fortune, speech, memory, intelligence, steadfastness, and patience.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna embodies both the inevitable force of death and the nurturing feminine attributes essential for life.
Famous Quotes: Do not fear death so much, but rather the inadequate life.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s role as both death and life’s sustainer aligns with Brecht’s message—life should be lived meaningfully rather than feared for its end.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
बृहत्साम तथा साम्नां गायत्री छन्दसामहम् |
मासानां मार्गशीर्षोऽहमृतूनां कुसुमाकरः ॥१०-३५॥
Sloka (English Translation): Among hymns of the Sama Veda, I am the Brihat-Sama; among meters, I am the Gayatri. Among months, I am Margashirsha, and among seasons, I am the season of flowers (spring).
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna represents the most sacred hymns, the purest poetic meter, the most revered month, and the beauty of renewal in spring.
Famous Quotes: Spring is nature’s way of saying, ‘Let’s party!’
Comparison/Relations: Krishna as the season of flowers reflects joy and renewal, much like Robin Williams’ humorous take on spring’s vibrance.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
द्यूतं छलयतामस्मि तेजस्तेजस्विनामहम् |
जयोऽस्मि व्यवसायोऽस्मि सत्त्वं सत्त्ववतामहम् ॥१०-३६॥
Sloka (English Translation): Among deceitful activities, I am gambling. Among the splendid, I am splendor. I am victory, I am determination, and I am the goodness of the virtuous.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna highlights His presence in all aspects of life, even in unexpected places like gambling, while also representing brilliance, success, and righteousness.
Famous Quotes: Victory belongs to the most persevering.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna as victory and determination aligns with Napoleon’s belief that perseverance leads to success.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
वृष्णीनां वासुदेवोऽस्मि पाण्डवानां धनञ्जयः |
मुनीनामप्यहं व्यासः कवीनामुशना कविः ॥१०-३७॥
Sloka (English Translation): Among the Vrishnis, I am Vasudeva (Krishna). Among the Pandavas, I am Arjuna. Among sages, I am Vyasa, and among poets, I am Ushanas.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna identifies with the most significant figures in different domains—Himself as Vasudeva, Arjuna as the best warrior, Vyasa as the wisest sage, and Ushanas as the finest poet.
Famous Quotes: A poet is, before anything else, a person who is passionately in love with language.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna as Ushanas, the greatest poet, reflects Auden’s view of poets as masters of language.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
दण्डो दमयतामस्मि नीतिरस्मि जिगीषताम् |
मौनं चैवास्मि गुह्यानां ज्ञानं ज्ञानवतामहम् ॥१०-३८॥
Sloka (English Translation): Among those who discipline, I am punishment. Among those who seek victory, I am moral law. Among secrets, I am silence, and among the wise, I am knowledge.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna embodies discipline, morality, silence as a source of wisdom, and the ultimate truth that knowledge represents.
Famous Quotes: Silence is the sleep that nourishes wisdom.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna as silence mirrors Bacon’s view that silence helps cultivate wisdom.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यच्चापि सर्वभूतानां बीजं तदहमर्जुन |
न तदस्ति विना यत्स्यान्मया भूतं चराचरम् ॥१०-३९॥
Sloka (English Translation): I am the seed of all living beings, O Arjuna. There is nothing, moving or non-moving, that can exist without Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna emphasizes that He is the fundamental cause of existence, present in all that is living and non-living.
Famous Quotes: To understand the world, you must first understand yourself.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna as the seed of all beings aligns with Socrates' philosophy that self-realization leads to deeper knowledge.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
नान्तोऽस्ति मम दिव्यानां विभूतीनां परन्तप |
एष तूद्देशतः प्रोक्तो विभूतेर्विस्तरो मया ॥१०-४०॥
Sloka (English Translation): There is no end to My divine glories, O Arjuna. What I have described to you is only a mere glimpse of My vast magnificence.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that His divine manifestations are limitless, and what has been described is just a fraction of His grandeur.
Famous Quotes: The more I learn, the more I realize how much I don't know.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s limitless glories reflect Einstein’s realization that true knowledge leads to greater awareness of the unknown.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यद्यद्विभूतिमत्सत्त्वं श्रीमदूर्जितमेव वा |
तत्तदेवावगच्छ त्वं मम तेजोंऽशसंभवम् ॥१०-४१॥
Sloka (English Translation): Whatever possesses splendor, prosperity, or power, know that it arises from but a spark of My divine energy.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals that all greatness, strength, and beauty seen in the world are mere manifestations of His divine energy.
Famous Quotes: All that we see or seem is but a dream within a dream.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s words about everything being a fraction of His divine power echo Poe’s idea of reality being just an illusion of a greater truth.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अथवा बहुनैतेन किं ज्ञातेन तवार्जुन |
विष्टभ्याहमिदं कृत्स्नमेकांशेन स्थितो जगत् ॥१०-४२॥
Sloka (English Translation): But why, O Arjuna, must you know all this in detail? With a mere fraction of Myself, I pervade and support this entire universe.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna concludes by stating that even a small part of His being is enough to sustain and govern the entire cosmos.
Famous Quotes: God is a circle whose center is everywhere and circumference nowhere.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s omnipresence is reflected in Voltaire’s idea of a divine force existing everywhere without limits.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अर्जुन उवाच।
मदनुग्रहाय परमं गुह्यमध्यात्मसंज्ञितम्।
यत्त्वयोक्तं वचस्तेन मोहोऽयं विगतो मम॥ ११-१॥
Sloka (English Translation): Arjuna said: Out of compassion, You have spoken to me about the supreme mystery concerning the Self. By these words, my delusion is now dispelled.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna acknowledges that Krishna's teachings have cleared his confusion. The profound spiritual wisdom imparted by Krishna has opened Arjuna's mind, helping him grasp the deeper truths of existence.
Famous Quotes: The only real voyage of discovery consists not in seeking new landscapes, but in having new eyes.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Arjuna's delusion fades through Krishna's guidance, Proust highlights how true understanding arises not from external change but from inner transformation.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
भवाप्ययौ हि भूतानां श्रुतौ विस्तरशो मया।
त्वत्तः कमलपत्राक्ष माहात्म्यमपि चाव्ययम्॥ ११-२॥
Sloka (English Translation): I have heard in detail from You about the creation and dissolution of beings, O Lotus-eyed One, and also about Your eternal glory.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna reiterates his growing awareness of Krishna's divine nature. Understanding the cycle of birth and death and Krishna's role in the universe strengthens Arjuna's faith.
Famous Quotes: He who has a why to live can bear almost any how.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna reveals the deeper "why" behind existence, just as Nietzsche emphasizes how purpose brings strength to endure any circumstance.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
एवमेतद्यथात्थ त्वमात्मानं परमेश्वर।
द्रष्टुमिच्छामि ते रूपमैश्वरं पुरुषोत्तम॥ ११-३॥
Sloka (English Translation): O Supreme Lord, You have truly described Yourself. Yet, O Best of Persons, I wish to see Your divine cosmic form.
Meaning/Interpretation: Though Arjuna understands Krishna's words, he yearns for direct experience — a vision of Krishna’s universal form. This moment marks Arjuna's desire to witness the infinite rather than just comprehend it intellectually.
Famous Quotes: Seeing is believing, but sometimes the most real things in the world are the things we can’t see.
Comparison/Relations: Like Arjuna’s wish to see Krishna’s cosmic form, this quote emphasizes that deeper realities often transcend what the eyes can perceive — a balance between faith and direct experience.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
मन्यसे यदि तच्छक्यं मया द्रष्टुमिति प्रभो।
योगेश्वर ततो मे त्वं दर्शयात्मानमव्ययम्॥ ११-४॥
Sloka (English Translation): If You think it is possible for me to see Your divine form, O Lord of Yoga, then please reveal Your eternal Self to me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna humbly requests Krishna to grant him the vision of His divine form — acknowledging Krishna's power while expressing his deep yearning for direct spiritual revelation.
Famous Quotes: Ask, and it shall be given you; seek, and ye shall find.
Comparison/Relations: Like Arjuna’s humble request for divine sight, this biblical teaching highlights the idea that sincere seeking leads to revelation and wisdom.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रीभगवानुवाच।
पश्य मे पार्थ रूपाणि शतशोऽथ सहस्रशः।
नानाविधानि दिव्यानि नानावर्णाकृतीनि च॥ ११-५॥
Sloka (English Translation): The Blessed Lord said: Behold, O Arjuna, My hundreds and thousands of divine forms, of various kinds, colors, and shapes.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna responds to Arjuna’s request by inviting him to witness the infinite manifestations of His divine form. This sets the stage for the grand revelation of Krishna's cosmic form.
Famous Quotes: The universe is not only stranger than we imagine, it is stranger than we can imagine.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna prepares Arjuna to witness His boundless cosmic form, Haldane's quote reflects the mind-boggling vastness and mystery of the universe — far beyond human comprehension.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
पश्यादित्यान्वसून्रुद्रानश्विनौ मरुतस्तथा।
बहून्यदृष्टपूर्वाणि पश्याश्चर्याणि भारत॥ ११-६॥
Sloka (English Translation): Behold the Adityas, the Vasus, the Rudras, the Ashvins, and the Maruts. O Arjuna, witness many wonders never seen before.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna invites Arjuna to see the vast array of divine beings within His cosmic form — showcasing the endless wonders that transcend human perception.
Famous Quotes: The world is full of magic things, patiently waiting for our senses to grow sharper.
Comparison/Relations: Like Arjuna witnessing unseen wonders, Yeats reminds us that the universe holds untold marvels, waiting for us to open our eyes to their magic.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
इहैकस्थं जगत्कृत्स्नं पश्याद्य सचराचरम्।
मम देहे गुडाकेश यच्चान्यद् द्रष्टुमिच्छसि॥ ११-७॥
Sloka (English Translation): Behold now the entire universe, with all its moving and unmoving entities, united in My body, O Arjuna, and whatever else you wish to see.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals that the whole cosmos — all of existence — resides within Him, offering Arjuna a glimpse of His all-encompassing divine form.
Famous Quotes: To see a world in a grain of sand and a heaven in a wildflower...
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna contains the universe within Himself, Blake poetically highlights how the infinite can be reflected in the smallest of things.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
न तु मां शक्यसे द्रष्टुमनेनैव स्वचक्षुषा।
दिव्यं ददामि ते चक्षुः पश्य मे योगमैश्वरम्॥ ११-८॥
Sloka (English Translation): But you cannot see Me with your physical eyes. Therefore, I grant you divine vision. Behold My majestic yoga power!
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna acknowledges Arjuna’s human limitations, gifting him divine sight to witness His cosmic form — a revelation beyond ordinary perception.
Famous Quotes: We do not see things as they are, we see them as we are.
Comparison/Relations: Like Krishna granting divine vision, Anaïs Nin emphasizes how perception is shaped by one’s inner capacity — and sometimes, a higher vision is needed to grasp true reality.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सञ्जय उवाच।
एवमुक्त्वा ततो राजन्महायोगेश्वरो हरिः।
दर्शयामास पार्थाय परमं रूपमैश्वरम्॥ ११-९॥
Sloka (English Translation): Sanjaya said: O King, having spoken thus, the Supreme Lord of Yoga, Krishna, revealed to Arjuna His supreme, divine form.
Meaning/Interpretation: Sanjaya, narrating to King Dhritarashtra, describes how Krishna finally unveils His boundless cosmic form — marking a pivotal moment in Arjuna’s spiritual journey.
Famous Quotes: What we see depends mainly on what we look for.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna’s divine form was revealed to Arjuna due to his sincere desire for truth, Lubbock reminds us that perception aligns with intention — we see what we seek.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अनेकवक्त्रनयनमनेकाद्भुतदर्शनम्।
अनेकदिव्याभरणं दिव्यानेकोद्यतायुधम्॥ ११-१०॥
Sloka (English Translation): Krishna's form had many mouths and eyes, displaying countless divine wonders. It was adorned with numerous celestial ornaments and held many divine weapons raised high.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna's cosmic form transcends human comprehension — a spectacle of infinite faces, divine jewelry, and glowing weapons, symbolizing His omnipresence and power.
Famous Quotes: The universe is wider than our views of it.
Comparison/Relations: Much like Krishna’s cosmic form exceeding all imagination, Thoreau's words remind us that reality's vastness extends far beyond human understanding.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
दिव्यमाल्याम्बरधरं दिव्यगन्धानुलेपनम्।
सर्वाश्चर्यमयं देवमनन्तं विश्वतोमुखम्॥ ११-११॥
Sloka (English Translation): Clad in divine garments, adorned with celestial garlands, and anointed with heavenly fragrances, Krishna's form was full of wonders—limitless and facing in all directions.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna’s cosmic form is beyond time and space, reflecting the infinite and all-pervading nature of the Divine, visible in all directions at once.
Famous Quotes: Limitations live only in our minds. But if we use our imaginations, our possibilities become limitless.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna's form is infinite, Paolinetti reminds us that human potential is also boundless when we transcend self-imposed limits.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
दिवि सूर्यसहस्रस्य भवेद्युगपदुत्थिता।
यदि भाः सदृशी सा स्याद्भासस्तस्य महात्मनः॥ ११-१२॥
Sloka (English Translation): If a thousand suns were to blaze forth in the sky all at once, their radiance might resemble the splendor of that Supreme Being.
Meaning/Interpretation: The brilliance of Krishna’s form surpasses anything seen before—it is as if a thousand suns rose simultaneously, illuminating all of existence.
Famous Quotes: We are all made of stardust.
Comparison/Relations: Sagan’s insight aligns with Krishna’s radiance—just as everything in the universe is interconnected and luminous, so too is the divine presence in all beings.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तत्रैकस्थं जगत्कृत्स्नं प्रविभक्तमनेकधा।
अपश्यद्देवदेवस्य शरीरे पाण्डवस्तदा॥ ११-१३॥
Sloka (English Translation): Within that divine form, Arjuna saw the entire universe divided into countless parts, yet all unified within the body of the Supreme Lord.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals that all creation—past, present, and future—is contained within Him. The oneness of existence is beautifully displayed in this divine vision.
Famous Quotes: Everything is connected; we are all part of the same whole.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna shows the entire universe as one within Him, da Vinci expresses the interconnected nature of all things in existence.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ततः स विस्मयाविष्टो हृष्टरोमा धनञ्जयः।
प्रणम्य शिरसा देवं कृताञ्जलिरभाषत॥ ११-१४॥
Sloka (English Translation): Then, Arjuna, overwhelmed with awe, with hair standing on end, bowed down with folded hands before Krishna and spoke with deep reverence.
Meaning/Interpretation: Seeing this divine revelation, Arjuna is filled with wonder and humility, realizing his own insignificance before the infinite majesty of the Supreme Lord.
Famous Quotes: A mind that is stretched by a new experience can never go back to its old dimensions.
Comparison/Relations: Like Arjuna’s transformation after witnessing Krishna’s form, Holmes reminds us that profound realizations forever change our perspectives.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अर्जुन उवाच।
पश्यामि देवांस्तव देव देहे
सर्वांस्तथा भूतविशेषसङ्घान्।
ब्रह्माणमीशं कमलासनस्थम्
ऋषींश्च सर्वानुरगांश्च दिव्यान्॥ ११-१५॥
Sloka (English Translation): Arjuna said: O Lord, I behold within Your divine form all the gods and various groups of living beings. I see Lord Brahma seated on the lotus, all the sages, and celestial serpents.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna recognizes that all divine beings and sages, including Brahma, exist within Krishna, reaffirming that He is the source of all creation and existence.
Famous Quotes: The journey of discovery is not in seeking new landscapes, but in having new eyes.
Comparison/Relations: Like Arjuna’s realization of Krishna’s universal presence, Proust reminds us that true transformation comes from expanding our vision, not just exploring new places.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अनादिमध्यान्तमनन्तवीर्य-
मनन्तबाहुं शशिसूर्यनेत्रम्।
पश्यामि त्वां दीप्तहुताशवक्त्रं
स्वतेजसा विश्वमिदं तपन्तम्॥ ११-१६॥
Sloka (English Translation): I see You without beginning, middle, or end. Your power is infinite, Your arms are countless, and the sun and moon are Your eyes. Your blazing mouth scorches the entire universe with its radiance.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna's form is eternal and boundless, symbolizing His omnipresence and omnipotence. His eyes, represented by the sun and moon, illuminate and govern the cosmos.
Famous Quotes: The universe is not outside of you. Look inside yourself; everything that you want, you already are.
Comparison/Relations: Rumi’s wisdom aligns with Arjuna’s realization—Krishna encompasses all that exists, both externally and internally.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
किरीटिनं गदिनं चक्रिणं च
तेजोराशिं सर्वतो दीप्तिमन्तम्।
पश्यामि त्वां दुर्निरीक्ष्यं समन्ताद्
दीप्तानलार्कद्युतिमप्रमेयम्॥ ११-१७॥
Sloka (English Translation): I see You adorned with a crown, wielding a mace and a discus. Your brilliance is overwhelming, shining everywhere like a blazing fire and the radiance of the sun, nearly impossible to behold.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna’s divine weapons symbolize His power to uphold dharma. His radiance signifies spiritual enlightenment that is difficult to perceive with ordinary vision.
Famous Quotes: There is a crack in everything, that’s how the light gets in.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s divine light, though intense, represents ultimate truth—just as Cohen suggests that even in imperfection, light finds a way to illuminate.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
त्वमक्षरं परमं वेदितव्यं
त्वमस्य विश्वस्य परं निधानम्।
त्वमव्ययः शाश्वतधर्मगोप्ता
सनातनस्त्वं पुरुषो मतो मे॥ ११-१८॥
Sloka (English Translation): You are the Supreme, the eternal truth to be known. You are the ultimate refuge of the universe, the imperishable protector of eternal dharma. You are the timeless Divine Person.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna acknowledges Krishna as the eternal truth and ultimate shelter, reaffirming that He alone upholds the cosmic order.
Famous Quotes: Truth is like the sun. You can shut it out for a time, but it ain't goin' away.
Comparison/Relations: Like Krishna’s eternal presence, truth cannot be hidden—sooner or later, it reveals itself, just as the sun always rises.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अनादिमध्यान्तमनन्तवीर्यं
अनन्तबाहुं शशिसूर्यनेत्रम्।
पश्यामि त्वां दीप्तहुताशवक्त्रं
स्वतेजसा विश्वमिदं तपन्तम्॥ ११-१९॥
Sloka (English Translation): I see You as the infinite, without beginning, middle, or end. Your boundless energy spreads everywhere, and Your radiance burns the universe like an all-consuming fire.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna’s universal form embodies infinite energy, illuminating and sustaining everything while also signifying transformation and destruction.
Famous Quotes: Energy cannot be created or destroyed, it can only be changed from one form to another.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Krishna’s cosmic energy is eternal, Einstein’s law of energy conservation reflects the same universal truth—nothing is truly lost, only transformed.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
द्यावापृथिव्योरिदमन्तरं हि
व्याप्तं त्वयैकेन दिशश्च सर्वाः।
दृष्ट्वाद्भुतं रूपमुग्रं तवेदं
लोकत्रयं प्रव्यथितं महात्मन्॥ ११-२०॥
Sloka (English Translation): O Great Soul, You alone fill the entire space between heaven and earth and all the directions. Seeing Your marvelous and terrifying form, the three worlds tremble in fear.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna’s form pervades all existence, overwhelming even celestial beings with awe and fear, revealing His immense power.
Famous Quotes: Fear arises when we imagine that everything depends on us.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s vast form reminds us of the divine’s supreme control over all existence—fear diminishes when we trust in a greater cosmic force.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अमी हि त्वां सुरसङ्घा विशन्ति
केचिद्भीताः प्राञ्जलयो गृणन्ति।
स्वस्तीत्युक्त्वा महर्षिसिद्धसंघाः
स्तुवन्ति त्वां स्तुतिभिः पुष्कलाभिः॥ ११-२१॥
Sloka (English Translation): Indeed, hosts of gods enter into You. Some, with folded hands, sing Your praises in fear. Great sages and perfected beings glorify You with abundant hymns, saying, "May all be well!"
Meaning/Interpretation: Even divine beings experience awe and fear at Krishna’s cosmic form. While some approach with reverence, others seek blessings for the universe’s well-being.
Famous Quotes: The more I study the universe, the more I believe in a higher power.
Comparison/Relations: Just as scientists like Einstein sense divine intelligence in the cosmos, celestial beings in the Gita acknowledge Krishna’s supreme presence.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
रुद्रादित्या वसवो ये च साध्या
विश्वेऽश्विनौ मरुतश्चोष्मपाश्च।
गन्धर्वयक्षासुरसिद्धसंघा
वीक्षन्ते त्वां विस्मिताश्चैव सर्वे॥ ११-२२॥
Sloka (English Translation): The Rudras, Adityas, Vasus, Sadhyas, Vishwadevas, the twin Ashwins, Maruts, ancestors, Gandharvas, Yakshas, Asuras, and perfected beings—all gaze upon You in amazement.
Meaning/Interpretation: All celestial beings, whether divine or demonic, stare in astonishment at Krishna’s vast universal form, recognizing its immense power and authority.
Famous Quotes: Wonder is the beginning of wisdom.
Comparison/Relations: Just as true wisdom begins with awe, Krishna’s cosmic form evokes astonishment even among celestial beings, revealing the truth of His supremacy.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
रूपं महत्ते बहुवक्त्रनेत्रं
महाबाहो बहुबाहूरुपादम्।
बहूदरं बहुदंष्ट्राकरालं
दृष्ट्वा लोकाः प्रव्यथितास्तथाहम्॥ ११-२३॥
Sloka (English Translation): O mighty-armed one, seeing Your immense form with multiple faces and eyes, many arms, thighs, and feet, many bellies, and terrifying fangs, the worlds tremble, and so do I.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna is overwhelmed by the sheer vastness of Krishna’s divine manifestation, realizing the boundless and sometimes fearsome nature of absolute divinity.
Famous Quotes: To fear the Lord is wisdom, and to turn away from evil is understanding.
Comparison/Relations: The fear and reverence Arjuna experiences align with wisdom traditions that emphasize deep respect for the divine.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
नभःस्पृशं दीप्तमनेकवर्णं
व्यात्ताननं दीप्तविशालनेत्रम्।
दृष्ट्वा हि त्वां प्रव्यथितान्तरात्मा
धृतिं न विन्दामि शमं च विष्णो॥ ११-२४॥
Sloka (English Translation): O Vishnu, seeing You touching the sky, blazing in many colors, with wide-open mouths and large, fiery eyes, my inner self trembles. I find neither steadiness nor peace.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna’s mind is overwhelmed by Krishna’s infinite power. He struggles to process the grandeur, feeling both astonishment and fear.
Famous Quotes: We are not afraid of the unknown. We are afraid of what we think we know about the unknown.
Comparison/Relations: Arjuna’s reaction mirrors human fears—facing something beyond our comprehension shakes us, yet it can also be transformative.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
दंष्ट्राकरालानि च ते मुखानि
दृष्ट्वैव कालानलसन्निभानि।
दिशो न जाने न लभे च शर्म
प्रसीद देवेश जगन्निवास॥ ११-२५॥
Sloka (English Translation): Seeing Your fierce mouths with terrifying fangs, resembling the fire of destruction, I lose my sense of direction. I find no peace. O Lord of gods, O refuge of the universe, have mercy!
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna is terrified by Krishna’s form, which represents cosmic destruction. He pleads for divine grace, realizing his own insignificance.
Famous Quotes: Power without mercy is tyranny.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s overwhelming power is balanced by compassion. Like Seneca’s wisdom, true divinity includes both might and grace.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अमी च त्वां धृतराष्ट्रस्य पुत्राः
सर्वे सहैवावनिपालसंघैः।
भीष्मो द्रोणः सूतपुत्रस्तथासौ
सहास्मदीयैरपि योधमुख्यैः॥ ११-२६॥
Sloka (English Translation): All the sons of Dhritarashtra, along with the kings of the earth, Bhishma, Drona, Karna, and even our foremost warriors, are entering Your fierce mouths.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna sees the great warriors of both sides helplessly drawn into Krishna’s cosmic form, symbolizing their inevitable destruction in the war.
Famous Quotes: Destiny is not a matter of chance; it is a matter of choice.
Comparison/Relations: The warriors’ fate is sealed by their past choices, much like Krishna's revelation that destiny unfolds as per one’s karma.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
वक्त्राणि ते त्वरमाणा विशन्ति
दंष्ट्राकरालानि भयावहनि।
केचिद्विलग्ना दशनान्तरेषु
संदृश्यन्ते चूर्णितैरुत्तमाङ्गैः॥ ११-२७॥
Sloka (English Translation): They rush headlong into Your terrible mouths with fierce fangs. Some are seen trapped between Your teeth, with their heads crushed.
Meaning/Interpretation: This horrifying vision reveals Krishna as Kala (Time), the ultimate force that destroys all beings. The warriors are powerless against divine time.
Famous Quotes: Time, which sees all things, has found you out.
Comparison/Relations: Like Krishna’s revelation, Sophocles reminds us that time spares no one, uncovering all truths.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यथा नदीनां बहवोऽम्बुवेगाः
समुद्रमेवाभिमुखा द्रवन्ति।
तथा तवामी नरलोकवीरा
विशन्ति वक्त्राण्यभिविज्वलन्ति॥ ११-२८॥
Sloka (English Translation): As numerous rivers flow swiftly toward the ocean, so too do the warriors of the world enter Your blazing mouths.
Meaning/Interpretation: Just as rivers are destined to merge into the ocean, these warriors are drawn into Krishna’s cosmic form, symbolizing the inescapable flow of fate.
Famous Quotes: We must all obey the great law of change. It is the most powerful law of nature.
Comparison/Relations: This aligns with Krishna’s teaching that change (including destruction) is an essential aspect of life.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यथा प्रदीप्तं ज्वलनं पतङ्गाः
विशन्ति नाशाय समृद्धवेगाः।
तथैव नाशाय विशन्ति लोकाः
तवापि वक्त्राणि समृद्धवेगाः॥ ११-२९॥
Sloka (English Translation): As moths rush with great speed into a blazing fire to perish, so do these warriors swiftly enter Your mouths, rushing toward destruction.
Meaning/Interpretation: The warriors, blinded by their illusions, rush toward death, much like moths drawn to flames.
Famous Quotes: Men willingly believe what they wish.
Comparison/Relations: Like the moths, the warriors believe in their own strength, ignoring the ultimate truth of their destruction.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
लेलिह्यसे ग्रसमानः समन्तात्
लोकान्समग्रान्वदनैर्ज्वलद्भिः।
तेजोभिरापूर्य जगत्समग्रं
भासस्तवोग्राः प्रतपन्ति विष्णो॥ ११-३०॥
Sloka (English Translation): You devour all worlds, licking them with Your blazing mouths. Your fierce radiance fills the universe, scorching everything, O Vishnu!
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna’s divine form as Time consumes all. The universe is engulfed in His brilliance, representing the inevitable end of all creation.
Famous Quotes: I am become Death, the destroyer of worlds.
Comparison/Relations: Oppenheimer quoted this verse when witnessing the first atomic bomb, realizing that destruction is an inseparable part of existence.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
आख्याहि मे को भवानुग्ररूपो
नमोऽस्तु ते देववर प्रसीद।
विज्ञातुमिच्छामि भवन्तमाद्यं
न हि प्रजानामि तव प्रवृत्तिम्॥ ११-३१॥
Sloka (English Translation): Tell me, who are You in this terrifying form? O divine Lord, I bow before You and seek Your grace. I wish to understand You, for I do not comprehend Your purpose.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna, filled with fear and awe, surrenders before Krishna and desperately seeks to understand the meaning of this divine vision.
Famous Quotes: True wisdom comes to each of us when we realize how little we understand about life, ourselves, and the world around us.
Comparison/Relations: Like Arjuna, Socrates emphasizes that recognizing one’s ignorance is the first step toward wisdom.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्री भगवानुवाच:
कालोऽस्मि लोकक्षयकृत्प्रवृद्धो
लोकान्समाहर्तुमिह प्रवृत्तः।
ऋतेऽपि त्वां न भविष्यन्ति सर्वे
येऽवस्थिताः प्रत्यनीकेषु योधाः॥ ११-३२॥
Sloka (English Translation): The Supreme Lord said: I am Time (Kala), the great destroyer of the world, engaged in annihilating all beings. Even without your participation, all the warriors here shall perish.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals Himself as Kala (Time), the unstoppable force of destruction. The outcome of the war is already destined, and Arjuna is merely an instrument.
Famous Quotes: I am become Death, the destroyer of worlds.
Comparison/Relations: Oppenheimer quoted this verse upon witnessing the first atomic bomb explosion, recognizing the immense destructive power of time and fate.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तस्मात्त्वमुत्तिष्ठ यशो लभस्व
जित्वा शत्रून् भुङ्क्ष्व राज्यं समृद्धम्।
मयैवैते निहताः पूर्वमेव
निमित्तमात्रं भव सव्यसाचिन्॥ ११-३३॥
Sloka (English Translation): Therefore, arise and attain glory! Conquer your enemies and enjoy a prosperous kingdom. They are already slain by Me; you are only an instrument, O Arjuna.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna urges Arjuna to perform his duty without hesitation, for destiny has already been written. He must act as an instrument of the divine will.
Famous Quotes: Do your work with all your heart, and you will succeed—there is so little competition.
Comparison/Relations: Like Krishna’s advice, Hubbard emphasizes taking action with determination rather than doubting fate.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
द्रोणं च भीष्मं च जयद्रथं च
कर्णं तथान्यानपि योधवीरान्।
मया हतांस्त्वं जहि मा व्यथिष्ठा
युद्धस्य जेतासि रणे सपत्नान्॥ ११-३४॥
Sloka (English Translation): Drona, Bhishma, Jayadratha, Karna, and other brave warriors have already been slain by Me. Do not hesitate; fight! You shall vanquish your enemies in battle.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reassures Arjuna that great warriors are already fated to die. His role is merely to carry out his duty without attachment.
Famous Quotes: Courage is not the absence of fear, but the ability to act despite it.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna encourages Arjuna to act without fear, just as Twain suggests that courage is taking action despite doubts.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सञ्जय उवाच:
एतच्छ्रुत्वा वचनं केशवस्य
कृताञ्जलिर्वेपमानः किरीटी।
नमस्कृत्वा भूय एवाह कृष्णं
सगद्गदं भीतभीतः प्रणम्य॥ ११-३५॥
Sloka (English Translation): Sanjaya said: Hearing these words of Krishna, Arjuna, trembling with folded hands, bowed down repeatedly in great fear. Overwhelmed, he spoke to Krishna in a choked voice.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna, realizing Krishna’s immense power, is shaken by awe and fear. This marks the moment of his complete surrender.
Famous Quotes: The moment of surrender is not when life is over, it’s when it begins.
Comparison/Relations: Like Williamson’s idea, Arjuna’s surrender to Krishna does not mark defeat but a new beginning—the path of true wisdom.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अर्जुन उवाच:
स्थाने हृषीकेश तव प्रकीर्त्या
जगत्प्रहृष्यत्यनुरज्यते च।
रक्षांसि भीतानि दिशो द्रवन्ति
सर्वे नमस्यन्ति च सिद्धसंघाः॥ ११-३६॥
Sloka (English Translation): Arjuna said: O Hrishikesha (Krishna), it is right that the world rejoices in singing Your glories. Demons flee in fear from all directions, and hosts of sages bow before You in reverence.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna acknowledges that both the righteous and the wicked react differently to Krishna's divine form—devotees worship Him, while evil forces tremble in fear.
Famous Quotes: The whole secret of a successful life is to find out what is one’s destiny to do, and then do it.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Arjuna realizes Krishna’s cosmic role, Ford emphasizes the importance of discovering and following one’s destiny.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
कस्माच्च ते न नमेरन्महात्मन्
गरीयसे ब्रह्मणोऽप्यादिकर्त्रे।
अनन्त देवेश जगन्निवास
त्वमक्षरं सत्यमसत्तत्परं यत्॥ ११-३७॥
Sloka (English Translation): O Great One! Why should they not bow before You, the eternal creator of even Brahma? You are the infinite, supreme refuge of the universe. You are imperishable—both the eternal truth and that which transcends it.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna is beyond creation and destruction, and even Brahma (the creator) comes from Him. Arjuna acknowledges Krishna’s infinite power.
Famous Quotes: When we are no longer able to change a situation, we are challenged to change ourselves.
Comparison/Relations: Like Frankl’s wisdom, Arjuna realizes that accepting Krishna’s supremacy brings clarity rather than resistance.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
त्वमादिदेवः पुरुषः पुराणः
त्वमस्य विश्वस्य परं निधानम्।
वेत्तासि वेद्यं च परं च धाम
त्वया ततं विश्वमनन्तरूप॥ ११-३८॥
Sloka (English Translation): You are the Primeval God, the original Divine Person. You are the Supreme Abode of this entire universe. You are the Knower, the Object of Knowledge, and the Highest Goal. The whole cosmos is pervaded by Your infinite form.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna is both the seeker and the sought-after goal. His presence encompasses everything in creation.
Famous Quotes: The mind is everything. What you think, you become.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s divine nature mirrors Buddha’s teaching—everything is interconnected, and realization leads to enlightenment.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
वायुर्यमोऽग्निर्वरुणः शशाङ्कः
प्रजापतिस्त्वं प्रपितामहश्च।
नमो नमस्तेऽस्तु सहस्रकृत्वः
पुनश्च भूयोऽपि नमो नमस्ते॥ ११-३९॥
Sloka (English Translation): You are the wind, death, fire, water, the moon, and the progenitor of all beings. O Supreme Lord, I offer countless prostrations unto You again and again!
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna realizes Krishna’s omnipresence—He exists in all elements, all deities, and every force of nature.
Famous Quotes: Gratitude turns what we have into enough.
Comparison/Relations: Just as gratitude brings peace, Arjuna’s deep reverence leads him to surrender completely.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
नमः पुरस्तादथ पृष्ठतस्ते
नमोऽस्तु ते सर्वत एव सर्व।
अनन्तवीर्यामितविक्रमस्त्वं
सर्वं समाप्नोषि ततोऽसि सर्वः॥ ११-४०॥
Sloka (English Translation): I bow to You from all directions—front, behind, and everywhere! O Infinite Power, Your strength is limitless, and You pervade all of existence.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna is boundless, beyond any one form, time, or space. Arjuna’s surrender is complete and unconditional.
Famous Quotes: The more you let go, the higher you rise.
Comparison/Relations: Like this saying, Arjuna rises spiritually by letting go of his ego and surrendering to Krishna.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सखेति मत्वा प्रसभं यदुक्तं
हे कृष्ण हे यादव हे सखेति।
अजानता महिमानं तवेदं
मया प्रमादात्प्रणयेन वापि॥ ११-४१॥
Sloka (English Translation): Thinking of You as my friend, I may have rashly addressed You as "Krishna," "Yadava," or "my dear companion," unaware of Your supreme majesty.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna recalls how he casually interacted with Krishna as a friend and now regrets his ignorance. He realizes Krishna is not just a friend but the Supreme Lord.
Famous Quotes: The greatest wisdom is seeing through appearances.
Comparison/Relations: Like Buddha’s wisdom, Arjuna now sees beyond Krishna’s human form and recognizes His divine identity.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यच्चावहासार्थमसत्कृतोऽसि
विहारशय्यासनभोजनेषु।
एकोऽथवाप्यच्युत तत्समक्षं
तत्क्षामये त्वामहमप्रमेयम्॥ ११-४२॥
Sloka (English Translation): Whether in jest, in rest, in meals, or in solitude, O Achyuta (Infallible One), I may have disrespected You unknowingly. I now seek Your forgiveness, O Incomprehensible One.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna humbly seeks pardon for any moments where he took Krishna’s presence lightly, realizing now that Krishna is beyond human perception.
Famous Quotes: To err is human, to forgive divine.
Comparison/Relations: Just as Pope emphasizes forgiveness, Arjuna hopes Krishna, in His divine nature, will forgive his past mistakes.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
पितासि लोकस्य चराचरस्य
त्वमस्य पूज्यश्च गुरुर्गरीयान्।
न त्वत्समोऽस्त्यभ्यधिकः कुतोऽन्यो
लोकत्रयेऽप्यप्रतिमप्रभाव॥ ११-४३॥
Sloka (English Translation): You are the Father of this entire world—both moving and non-moving beings. You are most revered, the greatest Guru! There is no one equal to You, let alone greater than You, in all the three worlds.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna fully surrenders—he now sees Krishna as the Supreme Guru, the Universal Father, and the Most Worshiped.
Famous Quotes: The only real teacher is the one who shows you where to look, but doesn’t tell you what to see.
Comparison/Relations: Like a true guru, Krishna has revealed the ultimate reality, allowing Arjuna to see the truth on his own.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तस्मात्प्रणम्य प्रणिधाय कायं
प्रसादये त्वामहमीशमीड्यम्।
पितेव पुत्रस्य सखेव सख्युः
प्रियः प्रियायार्हसि देव सोढुम्॥ ११-४४॥
Sloka (English Translation): Therefore, bowing down fully, I seek Your grace, O Worshipable Lord! Just as a father forgives his son, a friend forgives a friend, or a beloved forgives a loved one, O Lord, please forgive me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna compares Krishna’s compassion to a father’s love, a friend’s loyalty, and a beloved’s kindness. He pleads for forgiveness with deep sincerity.
Famous Quotes: Forgiveness does not change the past, but it does enlarge the future.
Comparison/Relations: Like Boese’s wisdom, Arjuna realizes that seeking Krishna’s forgiveness allows him to move forward spiritually.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अर्जुन उवाच
एवं सततयुक्ता ये भक्तास्त्वां पर्युपासते।
ये चाप्यक्षरमव्यक्तं तेषां के योगवित्तमाः॥ १२-१॥
Sloka (English Translation):
Arjuna asked:
Among those who worship You personally with devotion, and those who worship the formless, imperishable Brahman, who is more perfect in yoga?
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna is curious—should one worship Krishna personally (Saguna Bhakti) or meditate on the formless Brahman (Nirguna Bhakti)?
