Famous Quotes: The way is not in the sky. The way is in the heart.
Comparison/Relations: Like Buddha, Krishna will soon explain that devotion from the heart is superior to abstract intellectual worship.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रीभगवानुवाच
मय्यावेश्य मनो ये मां नित्ययुक्ता उपासते।
श्रद्धया परयोपेतास्ते मे युक्ततमा मताः॥ १२-२॥
Sloka (English Translation):
Krishna replied:
Those who fix their minds on Me, worship Me constantly with faith and love—I consider them the most perfect in yoga.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna directly answers—those who surrender with love and devotion (Bhakti Yoga) attain Him easily and joyfully.
Famous Quotes: Faith is taking the first step even when you don’t see the whole staircase.
Comparison/Relations: Just like faith in devotion leads to union with Krishna, King Jr. speaks of faith leading to progress in life.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ये त्वक्षरमनिर्देश्यमव्यक्तं पर्युपासते।
सर्वत्रगमचिन्त्यं च कूटस्थमचलंध्रुवम्॥ १२-३॥
Sloka (English Translation): But those who worship the formless, indescribable, all-pervading, unchanging, eternal Brahman,
Meaning/Interpretation: Here, Krishna acknowledges Nirguna Bhakti—devotion to the formless Supreme Reality (Brahman).
Famous Quotes: The soul always knows what to do to heal itself. The challenge is to silence the mind.
Comparison/Relations: Like Nirguna Bhakti, inner silence and deep meditation lead to self-realization.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सन्नियम्येन्द्रियग्रामं सर्वत्र समबुद्धयः।
ते प्राप्नुवन्ति मामेव सर्वभूतहिते रताः॥ १२-४॥
Sloka (English Translation): By controlling their senses, being equal-minded to all, and being dedicated to the welfare of all beings, they too attain Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals that both paths (Personal Bhakti & Nirguna Bhakti) lead to Him, but self-discipline & service are required for Nirguna Bhakti.
Famous Quotes: The best way to find yourself is to lose yourself in the service of others.
Comparison/Relations: Like Krishna’s words, Gandhi highlights selfless service as a path to realization.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
क्लेशोऽधिकतरस्तेषामव्यक्तासक्तचेतसाम्।
अव्यक्ता हि गतिर्दुःखं देहवद्भिरवाप्यते॥ १२-५॥
Sloka (English Translation): The path of the formless Absolute is difficult for those attached to the body, as it is troublesome and requires intense effort.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna warns that Nirguna Bhakti (meditation on the formless) is very hard, while Saguna Bhakti (personal devotion) is easier and filled with joy.
Famous Quotes: Simplicity is the ultimate sophistication.
Comparison/Relations: Krishna implies that a simple, loving devotion is the easiest and most fulfilling spiritual path.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ये तु सर्वाणि कर्माणि मयि संन्यस्य मत्पराः।
अनन्येनैव योगेन मां ध्यायन्त उपासते॥ १२-६॥
Sloka (English Translation): But those who surrender all actions to Me, considering Me as their supreme goal, and worship Me with unwavering devotion,
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna highlights that surrendering all actions to Him and having undivided devotion makes the path easier.
Famous Quotes: Let go and let God.
Comparison/Relations: True Bhakti means complete surrender, just as faith teaches us to trust in a higher power.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तेषामहं समुद्धर्ता मृत्युसंसारसागरात्।
भवामि नचिरात्पार्थ मय्यावेशितचेतसाम्॥ १२-७॥
Sloka (English Translation): For such devoted souls, I quickly rescue them from the ocean of birth and death.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna personally takes care of those who fully surrender to Him.
Famous Quotes: God is closest to those with broken hearts.
Comparison/Relations: When life becomes difficult, true devotion (Bhakti) brings divine protection.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
मय्येव मन आधत्स्व मयि बुद्धिं निवेशय।
निवसिष्यसि मय्येव अत ऊर्ध्वं न संशयः॥ १२-८॥
Sloka (English Translation): Fix your mind and intellect on Me alone—then you will surely live in Me. No doubt about it!
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna assures that meditating on Him leads to eternal bliss & divine presence.
Famous Quotes: You become what you think about most of the time.
Comparison/Relations: Just as our thoughts shape our reality, devotion to Krishna transforms one’s life.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अथ चित्तं समाधातुं न शक्नोषि मयि स्थिरम्।
अभ्यासयोगेन ततो मामिच्छाप्तुं धनञ्जय॥ १२-९॥
Sloka (English Translation): If you cannot fix your mind on Me, then try again and again through practice (Abhyasa Yoga).
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna understands that full surrender is difficult, so He recommends practice and patience.
Famous Quotes: Practice makes perfect.
Comparison/Relations: Like learning a new skill, Bhakti requires consistent practice.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अभ्यासेऽप्यसमर्थोऽसि मत्कर्मपरमो भव।
मदर्थमपि कर्माणि कुर्वन्सिद्धिमवाप्स्यसि॥ १२-१०॥
Sloka (English Translation): If you cannot practice constant meditation, then just do all your actions for My sake—this will also lead to perfection.
Meaning/Interpretation: If full surrender & meditation are hard, Krishna advises dedicating actions to Him as a simple way to attain Him.
Famous Quotes: Work done in the spirit of service is the highest form of worship.
Comparison/Relations: Even if one cannot meditate daily, doing selfless work in the name of Krishna is another powerful spiritual path.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अथैतदप्यशक्तोऽसि कर्तुं मद्योगमाश्रितः।
सर्वकर्मफलत्यागं ततः कुरु यतात्मवान्॥ १२-११॥
Sloka (English Translation): If you are unable to dedicate your actions to Me, then simply renounce the fruits of your actions with self-control.
Meaning/Interpretation: If surrender, meditation, and devotional service seem difficult, then the simplest form of Bhakti is to let go of attachment to results and perform duties selflessly.
Famous Quotes: Do your work with all your heart, and you will succeed—there’s so little competition.
Comparison/Relations: Renouncing results and working sincerely allows peace and spiritual growth, similar to performing work without expectations.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रेयो हि ज्ञानमभ्यासाज्ज्ञानाद्ध्यानं विशिष्यते।
ध्यानात्कर्मफलत्यागस्त्यागाच्छान्तिरनन्तरम्॥ १२-१२॥
Sloka (English Translation): Better than practice is knowledge, better than knowledge is meditation, and better than meditation is renouncing the fruits of action—for that brings peace.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna offers a progressive path: practice → knowledge → meditation → renunciation of results, where peace is the ultimate reward of selfless action.
Famous Quotes: The secret of happiness is freedom, and the secret of freedom is courage.
Comparison/Relations: By letting go of expectations, one achieves inner peace, just as detachment leads to true freedom.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अद्वेष्टा सर्वभूतानां मैत्रः करुण एव च।
निर्ममो निरहंकारः समदुःखसुखः क्षमी॥ १२-१३॥
Sloka (English Translation): One who is free from hatred, friendly and compassionate, without possessiveness and ego, and remains calm in pleasure and pain, that devotee is dear to Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna describes the qualities of His dearest devotees: kindness, humility, patience, and equanimity in all situations.
Famous Quotes: The fragrance always stays in the hand that gives the rose.
Comparison/Relations: A true devotee, like a generous giver, spreads kindness and remains unshaken by difficulties.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
संतुष्टः सततं योगी यतात्मा दृढनिश्चयः।
मय्यर्पितमनोबुद्धिर्यो मद्भक्तः स मे प्रियः॥ १२-१४॥
Sloka (English Translation): One who is always content, disciplined, self-controlled, and firm in resolve, with mind and intellect dedicated to Me, that devotee is dear to Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: A devotee who finds joy in devotion, stays disciplined, and remains firm in faith is truly loved by Krishna.
Famous Quotes: Happiness depends upon ourselves.
Comparison/Relations: Just as true happiness comes from within, spiritual contentment comes from surrendering to God.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यस्मान्नोद्विजते लोको लोकान्नोद्विजते च यः।
हर्षामर्षभयोद्वेगैर्मुक्तो यः स च मे प्रियः॥ १२-१५॥
Sloka (English Translation): One who does not disturb others nor is disturbed by others, who is free from joy, anger, fear, and anxiety, that devotee is dear to Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains that a true devotee neither causes harm nor gets affected by external disturbances, living in peace and harmony.
Famous Quotes: The best way to find yourself is to lose yourself in the service of others.
Comparison/Relations: Just as a selfless person remains unshaken, a devotee immersed in love for Krishna stays peaceful and undisturbed.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अनपेक्षः शुचिर्दक्ष उदासीनो गतव्यथः।
सर्वारम्भपरित्यागी यो मद्भक्तः स मे प्रियः॥ १२-१६॥
Sloka (English Translation): One who is free from expectations, pure, skillful, indifferent, free from distress, and renounces all undertakings—such a devotee is dear to Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna describes the ideal devotee as self-sufficient, pure in heart, efficient in action, detached from worldly distractions, and without personal motives.
Famous Quotes: Expect nothing. Live frugally on surprise.
Comparison/Relations: A life without expectations brings peace, just as devotion without attachment leads to inner contentment.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यो न हृष्यति न द्वेष्टि न शोचति न काङ्क्षति।
शुभाशुभपरित्यागी भक्तिमान्यः स मे प्रियः॥ १२-१७॥
Sloka (English Translation): One who neither rejoices nor hates, neither grieves nor desires, who renounces both good and evil, and is full of devotion—that devotee is dear to Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: A true devotee remains unaffected by pleasure or pain, accepting life as it comes without attachment to outcomes.
Famous Quotes: Peace comes from within. Do not seek it without.
Comparison/Relations: Inner peace is achieved by giving up extremes of emotion, just as Krishna teaches detachment from worldly happiness and sorrow.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
समः शत्रौ च मित्रे च तथा मानापमानयोः।
शीतोष्णसुखदुःखेषु समः सङ्गविवर्जितः॥ १२-१८॥
Sloka (English Translation): One who is equal towards friend and foe, honor and dishonor, heat and cold, pleasure and pain, and is free from all attachment—that devotee is dear to Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna emphasizes equanimity in all situations—treating enemies and friends alike and remaining unshaken by external circumstances.
Famous Quotes: The measure of intelligence is the ability to change.
Comparison/Relations: True intelligence and devotion come from adapting to life’s changes without losing inner balance.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तुल्यनिन्दास्तुतिर्मौनी सन्तुष्टो येन केनचित्।
अनिकेतः स्थिरमतिर्भक्तिमान्मे प्रियो नरः॥ १२-१९॥
Sloka (English Translation): One who regards praise and criticism alike, is silent, content with whatever comes, without a fixed home, and is steady in mind—that devotee is dear to Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: A devotee should not be affected by flattery or insult and must find peace within, regardless of external circumstances.
Famous Quotes: Do not dwell in the past, do not dream of the future, concentrate the mind on the present moment.
Comparison/Relations: Living in the present without attachment leads to mental stability, as Krishna teaches.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ये तु धर्म्यामृतमिदं यथोक्तं पर्युपासते।
श्रद्दधाना मत्परमा भक्तास्तेऽतीव मे प्रियाः॥ १२-२०॥
Sloka (English Translation): Those who follow this path of immortal righteousness, with faith and devotion, making Me their supreme goal, are exceedingly dear to Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna concludes Bhakti Yoga by stating that those who follow these virtues with unwavering faith are the closest to Him.
Famous Quotes: Faith is taking the first step even when you don’t see the whole staircase.
Comparison/Relations: True faith, like devotion, requires trust in the unseen path and surrender to the divine.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रीभगवानुवाच । इदं शरीरं कौन्तेय क्षेत्रमित्यभिधीयते ।
 एतद्यो वेत्ति तं प्राहुः क्षेत्रज्ञ इति तद्विदः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The Blessed Lord said: This body, O Arjuna, is called the field, and he who knows it is called the knower of the field by those who know the truth.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna introduces the concept of the body as a field (Kshetra) and the soul as the knower of that field (Kshetrajna).
Famous Quotes: “Know thyself.”
Comparison/Relations: Just as Socrates emphasized self-knowledge, Krishna urges Arjuna to understand the body and the soul's relation to it.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
क्षेत्रज्ञं चापि मां विद्धि सर्वक्षेत्रेषु भारत ।
 क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञयोर्ज्ञानं यत्तज्ज्ञानं मतं मम ॥
Sloka (English Translation): O scion of Bharat, know Me also to be the Knower in all fields; the knowledge of the field and its knower I consider to be true knowledge.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals that He is the supreme Knower in all bodies, emphasizing the unity of consciousness across all beings.
Famous Quotes: “The divine is not distant; it is within all.”
Comparison/Relations: Upanishadic teachings echo Krishna’s idea of universal consciousness.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तत्क्षेत्रं यच्च यादृक्च यद्विकारि यतश्च यत् ।
 स च यो यत्प्रभावश्च तत्सामासेन मे श्रृणु ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Hear from Me briefly about what the field is, its nature, modifications, origin, and also the knower’s powers.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna outlines the aspects of the body and consciousness to build a foundation for spiritual knowledge.
Famous Quotes: “To understand life, understand its roots.”
Comparison/Relations: Understanding the components of the self aligns with Jung's analytical psychology.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ऋषिभिर्बहुधा गीतं छन्दोभिर्विविधैः पृथक् ।
 ब्रह्मसूत्रपदैश्चैव हेतुमद्भिर्विनिश्चितैः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The sages have sung about the field and its knower in various ways, in different Vedic hymns and in the well-reasoned and conclusive Brahma Sutras.
Meaning/Interpretation: This knowledge has been validated by ancient rishis and scriptures, establishing its authenticity.
Famous Quotes: “Truth is one, sages call it by many names.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna references scriptural consistency, just like Rigveda’s pluralistic wisdom.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
महाभूतान्यहंकारो बुद्धिरव्यक्तमेव च ।
 इन्द्रियाणि दशैकं च पञ्च चेन्द्रियगोचराः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The great elements, ego, intellect, the unmanifest, the ten senses and one mind, and the five objects of the senses —
Meaning/Interpretation: Breaks down the constitution of the body into physical and subtle components.
Famous Quotes: “We are not human beings having a spiritual experience; we are spiritual beings having a human experience.”
Comparison/Relations: This holistic view aligns with Krishna’s explanation of our physical and spiritual nature.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
इच्छा द्वेषः सुखं दुःखं संघातश्चेतना धृतिः ।
 एतत्क्षेत्रं समासेन सविकारमुदाहृतम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Desire, hatred, happiness, sorrow, the aggregate, consciousness, and firmness — this is the field with its modifications briefly described.
Meaning/Interpretation: These psychological and emotional elements complete the description of the body.
Famous Quotes: “Mastering others is strength. Mastering yourself is true power.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna's view reflects inner mastery which Lao Tzu also emphasized.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अमानित्वमदम्भित्वमहिंसा क्षान्तिरार्जवम् ।
 आचार्योपासनं शौचं स्थैर्यमात्मविनिग्रहः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Humility, unpretentiousness, non-violence, patience, uprightness, service to the teacher, cleanliness, steadiness, and self-control.
Meaning/Interpretation: Lists virtues that constitute true knowledge and spiritual progress.
Famous Quotes: “Humility is the solid foundation of all virtues.”
Comparison/Relations: Virtue ethics in Confucianism echo Krishna’s teachings on self-cultivation.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
इन्द्रियार्थेषु वैराग्यमनहंकार एव च ।
 जन्ममृत्युजराव्याधिदुःखदोषानुदर्शनम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Detachment from sense objects, absence of egoism, and awareness of the evils of birth, death, old age, and disease.
Meaning/Interpretation: Detachment and awareness of life’s transient pain are key to wisdom.
Famous Quotes: “Detachment is not that you own nothing, but that nothing owns you.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s view of non-attachment aligns with spiritual detachment taught in Islam.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
असक्तिरनभिष्वङ्गः पुत्रदारगृहादिषु ।
 नित्यं च समचित्तत्वमिष्टानिष्टोपपत्तिषु ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Absence of attachment, non-clinging to family, and equanimity in favorable and unfavorable situations.
Meaning/Interpretation: Emphasizes balance in relationships and circumstances.
Famous Quotes: “Happiness is not in having everything, but in being detached from everything.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna's call for equanimity is deeply reflected in Osho's vision of inner detachment.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
मयि चानन्ययोगेन भक्तिरव्यभिचारिणी ।
 विविक्तदेशसेवित्वमरतिर्जनसंसदि ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Unwavering devotion to Me, love of solitude, and distaste for social engagements.
Meaning/Interpretation: Encourages single-minded devotion and introspective living.
Famous Quotes: “Silence is a source of great strength.”
Comparison/Relations: The solitary path of devotion aligns with Taoist value for silence and introspection.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अध्यात्मज्ञाननित्यत्वं तत्त्वज्ञानार्थदर्शनम् ।
 एतज्ज्ञानमिति प्रोक्तमज्ञानं यदतोऽन्यथा ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Constancy in spiritual knowledge and the pursuit of understanding the truth—this is declared as knowledge; all else is ignorance.
Meaning/Interpretation: True knowledge lies in consistent spiritual pursuit and the ability to discern truth from illusion.
Famous Quotes: “To know oneself is the beginning of all wisdom.”
Comparison/Relations: Both Krishna and Aristotle place the self at the center of wisdom.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ज्ञेयं यत्तत्प्रवक्ष्यामि यज्ज्ञात्वामृतमश्नुते ।
 अनादिमत्परं ब्रह्म न सत्तन्नासदुच्यते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): I will explain what is to be known, knowing which one attains immortality. It is the beginningless Supreme Brahman, which is said to be neither being nor non-being.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna introduces Brahman, the supreme consciousness beyond dualities.
Famous Quotes: “The Tao that can be told is not the eternal Tao.”
Comparison/Relations: Brahman’s formless nature mirrors the Tao in Taoist philosophy.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सर्वतः पाणिपादं तत्सर्वतोऽक्षिशिरोमुखम् ।
 सर्वतः श्रुतिमल्लोके सर्वमावृत्य तिष्ठति ॥
Sloka (English Translation): With hands and feet everywhere, eyes, heads and mouths everywhere, It exists in all beings, enveloping the whole world.
Meaning/Interpretation: Describes the omnipresence of the Supreme as pervading all forms of life.
Famous Quotes: “God is an infinite circle whose center is everywhere and circumference nowhere.”
Comparison/Relations: Both portray the divine as limitless and all-pervading.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सर्वेन्द्रियगुणाभासं सर्वेन्द्रियविवर्जितम् ।
 असक्तं सर्वभृच्चैव निर्गुणं गुणभोक्तृ च ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Though It appears to possess all senses, It is devoid of senses; unattached, yet sustaining all; beyond qualities, yet the enjoyer of qualities.
Meaning/Interpretation: The divine being transcends all contradictions—without attributes but interacting with them.
Famous Quotes: “He acts without doing, and without effort he accomplishes all.”
Comparison/Relations: Resonates with Taoist non-action (wu wei) and divine detachment.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
बहिरन्तश्च भूतानामचरं चरमेव च ।
 सूक्ष्मत्वात्तदविज्ञेयं दूरस्थं चान्तिके च तत् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): It exists both outside and inside all beings; moving and unmoving. Being subtle, it is unknowable; it is far and near.
Meaning/Interpretation: Explains the subtle yet all-pervading nature of divine reality.
Famous Quotes: “The kingdom of God is within you.”
Comparison/Relations: Both Krishna and Jesus highlight the indwelling presence of the divine.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अविभक्तं च भूतेषु विभक्तमिव च स्थितम् ।
 भूतभर्तृ च तज्ज्ञेयं ग्रसिष्णु प्रभविष्णु च ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Undivided, yet seeming divided in beings; It is to be known as the supporter, destroyer, and creator of all.
Meaning/Interpretation: Although whole, the divine appears in all forms and functions in creation and dissolution.
Famous Quotes: “Unity in diversity is the highest possible attainment.”
Comparison/Relations: This reflects the essence of Advaita: One in many.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ज्योतिषामपि तज्ज्योतिस्तमसः परमुच्यते ।
 ज्ञानं ज्ञेयं ज्ञानगम्यं हृदि सर्वस्य विष्ठितम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): It is the light of lights, beyond darkness. It is knowledge, the object of knowledge, and the goal of knowledge, dwelling in the hearts of all.
Meaning/Interpretation: The divine is the source and aim of all wisdom, hidden in the heart.
Famous Quotes: “The light shines in the darkness, and the darkness has not overcome it.”
Comparison/Relations: Both speak of divine light as the supreme wisdom within.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
इति क्षेत्रं तथा ज्ञानं ज्ञेयं चोक्तं समासतः ।
 मद्भक्त एतद्विज्ञाय मद्भावायोपपद्यते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Thus, the field, knowledge, and the knowable have been briefly explained. My devotee, knowing this, attains My divine nature.
Meaning/Interpretation: Knowledge of self, the body, and the divine leads to liberation.
Famous Quotes: “Truth will set you free.”
Comparison/Relations: True understanding leads to liberation—core to both Krishna and Christ’s teachings.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
प्रकृतिं पुरुषं चैव विद्ध्यनादी उभवपि ।
 विकारांश्च गुणांश्चैव विद्धि प्रकृतिसम्भवान् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Know both Nature and the soul to be beginningless, and know that all modifications and qualities arise from Nature.
Meaning/Interpretation: Differentiates between eternal consciousness (soul) and dynamic nature.
Famous Quotes: “You are not a drop in the ocean. You are the entire ocean in a drop.”
Comparison/Relations: This reflects the coexistence of individuality and universality.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
कार्यकारणकर्तृत्वे हेतुः प्रकृतिरुच्यते ।
 पुरुषः सुखदुःखानां भोक्तृत्वे हेतुरुच्यते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Nature is the cause of all action; the soul is the cause of experiencing pleasure and pain.
Meaning/Interpretation: Explains the dual role of prakriti and purusha in creation and experience.
Famous Quotes: “Pain is inevitable. Suffering is optional.”
Comparison/Relations: Aligns with Krishna’s view that soul experiences outcomes of nature’s activities.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
पुरुषः प्रकृतिस्थो हि भुङ्क्ते प्रकृतिजान्गुणान् ।
 कारणं गुणसङ्गोऽस्य सदसद्योनिजन्मसु ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The soul, residing in nature, enjoys the qualities born of nature. Attachment to these qualities is the cause of birth in good and evil wombs.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains how attachment to material qualities binds the soul to the cycle of birth.
Famous Quotes: “Desire is the root cause of all suffering.”
Comparison/Relations: Both Krishna and Buddha link attachment with rebirth and suffering.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
उपद्रष्टानुमन्ता च भर्ता भोक्ता महेश्वरः ।
 परमात्मेति चाप्युक्तो देहेऽस्मिन्पुरुषः परः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The Supreme Soul in this body is called the observer, the approver, the supporter, the enjoyer, the great Lord, and the Supreme Self.
Meaning/Interpretation: The divine is distinct from the individual soul—always witnessing, permitting, and guiding.
Famous Quotes: “God is closer to you than your own breath.”
Comparison/Relations: Similar to Krishna's view of the indwelling Supreme Self.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
य एवं वेत्ति पुरुषं प्रकृतिं च गुणैः सह ।
 सर्वथा वर्तमानोऽपि न स भूयोऽभिजायते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): He who understands the soul and nature with its qualities is not born again, regardless of his way of life.
Meaning/Interpretation: Self-realization liberates one from the cycle of birth and death.
Famous Quotes: “Liberation is not somewhere else—it’s here and now.”
Comparison/Relations: Both emphasize inner awakening over external rituals.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ध्यानेनात्मनि पश्यन्ति केचिदात्मानमात्मना ।
 अन्ये साङ्ख्येन योगेन कर्मयोगेन चापरे ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Some perceive the Self within by meditation, others by Sankhya yoga, and still others by selfless action (karma yoga).
Meaning/Interpretation: Different spiritual paths lead to the same realization of the Self.
Famous Quotes: “Many paths, one destination.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna promotes unity in diversity among spiritual paths.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अन्ये त्वेवमजानन्तः श्रुत्वान्येभ्य उपासते ।
 तेऽपि चातितरन्त्येव मृत्युं श्रुतिपरायणाः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Still others, not knowing this way, begin to worship after hearing from others; they too, being devoted to what they have heard, transcend death.
Meaning/Interpretation: Even faith and devotion through hearing leads to liberation.
Famous Quotes: “Faith is taking the first step even when you don't see the whole staircase.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna values sincerity and trust, regardless of the method.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यावत्सञ्जायते किञ्चित्सत्त्वं स्थावरजङ्गमम् ।
 क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञसंयोगात्तद्विद्धि भरतर्षभ ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Know, O best of the Bharatas, that whatever is born—whether moving or unmoving—is due to the union of the field and its knower.
Meaning/Interpretation: Creation arises from the interplay of matter and spirit.
Famous Quotes: “Spirit and matter are not separate; they are complementary.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s metaphysics align with holistic views in science and spirituality.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
समं सर्वेषु भूतेषु तिष्ठन्तं परमेश्वरम् ।
 विनश्यत्स्वविनश्यन्तं यः पश्यति स पश्यति ॥
Sloka (English Translation): He truly sees who sees the Supreme Lord existing equally in all beings, the imperishable in the perishable.
Meaning/Interpretation: True wisdom lies in recognizing the divine in all beings.
Famous Quotes: “The soul is the same in all living creatures, although the body of each is different.”
Comparison/Relations: Universal divinity and equality of beings is a shared truth.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
समं पश्यन्हि सर्वत्र समवस्थितमीश्वरम् ।
 न हिनस्त्यात्मनात्मानं ततो याति परां गतिम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Seeing the Lord equally present in all, one does not degrade the self by the self and thus reaches the supreme goal.
Meaning/Interpretation: Divine equality prevents egoistic harm and leads to liberation.
Famous Quotes: “Do unto others as you would have them do unto you.”
Comparison/Relations: The ethic of spiritual equality echoes in multiple traditions.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
प्रकृत्यैव च कर्माणि क्रियमाणानि सर्वशः ।
 यः पश्यति तथात्मानमकर्तारं स पश्यति ॥
Sloka (English Translation): All actions are performed by nature alone. He who sees the self as actionless truly sees.
Meaning/Interpretation: The self is a witness, not the doer of actions.
Famous Quotes: “You are not the doer; you are the observer.”
Comparison/Relations: Self-realization means witnessing without attachment to doing.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यदा भूतपृथग्भावमेकस्थमनुपश्यति ।
 तत एव च विस्तारं ब्रह्म सम्पद्यते तदा ॥
Sloka (English Translation): When one sees the diversity of beings rooted in One and spreading out from It, then one attains Brahman.
Meaning/Interpretation: Realizing the oneness behind all multiplicity leads to union with Brahman.
Famous Quotes: “From unity comes multiplicity, and to unity all returns.”
Comparison/Relations: This vision of oneness behind diversity is key in Vedanta and Neoplatonism alike.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यदा भूतपृथग्भावमेकस्थमनुपश्यति ।
 तत एव च विस्तारं ब्रह्म सम्पद्यते तदा ॥
Sloka (English Translation): When one sees all diverse beings situated in One and emanating from it, then one attains Brahman.
Meaning/Interpretation: Realizing the unity behind diversity is the path to divine union.
Famous Quotes: “Unity is not something we are going to create. It's something we must recognize.”
Comparison/Relations: This sloka reflects the recognition of oneness, central to mysticism and Vedanta.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अनादित्वान्निर्गुणत्वात्परमात्मायमव्ययः ।
 शरीरस्थोऽपि कौन्तेय न करोति न लिप्यते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Being beginningless and without qualities, the Supreme Self, though dwelling in the body, neither acts nor is tainted.
Meaning/Interpretation: The soul remains pure and unaffected despite being in the body.
Famous Quotes: “You are not a body with a soul. You are a soul with a body.”
Comparison/Relations: This distinction between the eternal self and the body is a core spiritual principle.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यथा सर्वगतं सौक्ष्म्यादाकाशं नोपलिप्यते ।
 सर्वत्रावस्थितो देहे तथात्मा नोपलिप्यते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): As the all-pervading space is not tainted because of its subtlety, so too the soul, though present in the body, is not tainted.
Meaning/Interpretation: The soul is like space—subtle, ungraspable, and unaffected.
Famous Quotes: “The soul can never be tainted by the world; it only watches.”
Comparison/Relations: Both affirm the soul’s untouched and pure nature despite bodily involvement.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यथा प्रकाशयत्येकः कृत्स्नं लोकमिमं रविः ।
 क्षेत्रं क्षेत्री तथा कृत्स्नं प्रकाशयति भारत ॥
Sloka (English Translation): As the one sun illumines the entire world, so does the knower of the field illumine the whole field, O Bharata.
Meaning/Interpretation: The soul illuminates the body and mind just as the sun reveals the world.
Famous Quotes: “The light of the self shines brighter than a thousand suns.”
Comparison/Relations: This reflects the Upanishadic vision of the atman as the source of inner illumination.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञयोरेवं अन्तरं ज्ञानचक्षुषा ।
 भूतप्रकृतिमोक्षं च ये विदुर्यान्ति ते परम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Those who see with the eye of knowledge the difference between the field and the knower, and the liberation of beings from material nature, they attain the Supreme.
Meaning/Interpretation: Liberation comes through discerning the eternal self from the changing body and nature.
Famous Quotes: “Liberation is seeing things as they truly are.”
Comparison/Relations: This final verse ties together knowledge and detachment as the path to transcendence.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रीभगवानुवाच
 परं भूयः प्रवक्ष्यामि ज्ञानानां ज्ञानमुत्तमम् ।
 यज्ज्ञात्वा मुनयः सर्वे परां सिद्धिमितो गताः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The Blessed Lord said: I shall again declare the supreme knowledge, the best of all knowledge, by knowing which all the sages have attained the highest perfection.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna introduces the knowledge of the three gunas, which leads to spiritual liberation.
Famous Quotes: “The highest education is that which does not merely give us information but makes our life in harmony with all existence.”
Comparison/Relations: Like Krishna’s promise of supreme knowledge, Tagore emphasizes holistic and transformative wisdom.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
इदं ज्ञानमुपाश्रित्य मम साधर्म्यमागताः ।
 सर्गेऽपि नोपजायन्ते प्रलये न व्यथन्ति च ॥
Sloka (English Translation): By becoming fixed in this knowledge, one attains a nature similar to Mine. The soul is not born at the time of creation, nor is it disturbed at the time of dissolution.
Meaning/Interpretation: The enlightened soul transcends cycles of birth and death, remaining unaffected.
Famous Quotes: “What the caterpillar calls the end, the master calls a butterfly.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna emphasizes immortality and transformation through knowledge, like spiritual metamorphosis.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
मम योनिर्महद्ब्रह्म तस्मिन्गर्भं दधाम्यहम् ।
 सम्भवः सर्वभूतानां ततो भवति भारत ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The total material substance, known as Brahman, is My womb, wherein I place the seed. Thus, all beings are born from it, O Bharata.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna presents Himself as the origin of all beings by uniting spirit and matter.
Famous Quotes: “In the beginning, God created the heavens and the earth.”
Comparison/Relations: Both texts describe divine origin of all life through a unifying principle.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सर्वयोनिषु कौन्तेय मूर्तयः सम्भवन्ति याः ।
 तासां ब्रह्म महद्योनिरहं बीजप्रदः पिता ॥
Sloka (English Translation): It should be understood that all species of life are made possible by birth in this material nature, and I am the seed-giving father.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna is the divine source of all varieties of life.
Famous Quotes: “All life is one, and all creation is kin.”
Comparison/Relations: This reflects the deep ecological and spiritual view of divine unity in life.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सत्त्वं रजस्तम इति गुणाः प्रकृतिसम्भवाः ।
 निबध्नन्ति महाबाहो देहे देहिनमव्ययम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Material nature consists of three modes—goodness, passion, and ignorance. When the eternal soul comes in contact with nature, these modes bind it to the body.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna introduces the three gunas that influence human behavior and bondage.
Famous Quotes: “You are not the mind, but the one who watches it.”
Comparison/Relations: Understanding the gunas helps in witnessing mental tendencies without identification.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तत्र सत्त्वं निर्मलत्वात्प्रकाशकमनामयम् ।
 सुखसङ्गेन बध्नाति ज्ञानसङ्गेन चानघ ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Of these, the mode of goodness, being pure, is illuminating and free from disease. It binds one by attachment to happiness and knowledge.
Meaning/Interpretation: Even goodness binds if one is attached to joy and knowledge.
Famous Quotes: “Even virtue, when pursued for self-interest, becomes a chain.”
Comparison/Relations: Goodness must also be transcended to reach true freedom.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
रजो रागात्मकं विद्धि तृष्णासङ्गसमुद्भवम् ।
 तन्निबध्नाति कौन्तेय कर्मसङ्गेन देहिनम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Know that the mode of passion is born of desire and attachment. It binds the soul through attachment to action and its results.
Meaning/Interpretation: Passion leads to endless activity and desire, keeping the soul restless.
Famous Quotes: “Desire is the cause of all action.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna and Western philosophy both analyze desire as the root of entanglement.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तमस्त्वज्ञानजं विद्धि मोहनं सर्वदेहिनाम् ।
 प्रमादालस्यनिद्राभिस्तन्निबध्नाति भारत ॥
Sloka (English Translation): And know the mode of ignorance to be born of darkness, which deludes all beings. It binds through negligence, laziness, and sleep.
Meaning/Interpretation: Ignorance causes delusion and inertia, preventing spiritual progress.
Famous Quotes: “Ignorance, allied with power, is the most ferocious enemy justice can have.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna describes ignorance as a destructive force, echoing modern social critique.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सत्त्वं सुखे सञ्जयति रजः कर्मणि भारत ।
 ज्ञानमावृत्य तु तमः प्रमादे सञ्जयत्युत ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Sattva attaches one to happiness, rajas to action, and tamas, covering knowledge, binds to negligence.
Meaning/Interpretation: Each guna directs consciousness toward different outcomes—joy, action, or delusion.
Famous Quotes: “Our character is the product of our conduct.”
Comparison/Relations: The gunas shape the patterns that form personal destiny.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
रजस्तमश्चाभिभूय सत्त्वं भवति भारत ।
 रजः सत्त्वं तमश्चैव तमः सत्त्वं रजस्तथा ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Sometimes sattva prevails over rajas and tamas, sometimes rajas over sattva and tamas, and at other times tamas prevails over sattva and rajas.
Meaning/Interpretation: The gunas constantly compete for dominance in a person’s life.
Famous Quotes: “Life is a balance of holding on and letting go.”
Comparison/Relations: Inner balance involves understanding the flow of these modes.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सर्वद्वारेषु देहेऽस्मिन्प्रकाश उपजायते ।
 ज्ञानं यदा तदा विद्याद्विवृद्धं सत्त्वमित्युत ॥
Sloka (English Translation): When all the gates of the body are illumined by knowledge, then it should be known that sattva is predominant.
Meaning/Interpretation: Signs of sattva include clarity, wisdom, and inner illumination.
Famous Quotes: “Enlightenment is the end of suffering.”
Comparison/Relations: Both Krishna and Buddha link awareness with liberation.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
लोभः प्रवृत्तिरारम्भः कर्मणामशमः स्पृहा ।
 रजस्येतानि जायन्ते विवृद्धे भरतर्षभ ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Greed, activity, initiation of actions, unrest, and craving arise when passion increases.
Meaning/Interpretation: Symptoms of excessive rajas include restlessness and insatiable desire.
Famous Quotes: “You will never be satisfied if your hunger is driven by the ego.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna’s view mirrors modern psychological insight into the ego’s desires.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अप्रकाशोऽप्रवृत्तिश्च प्रमादो मोहेव च ।
 तमस्येतानि जायन्ते विवृद्धे कुरुनन्दन ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Darkness, inactivity, madness, and delusion arise when tamas predominates.
Meaning/Interpretation: Tamas creates inner confusion and external stagnation.
Famous Quotes: “Darkness cannot drive out darkness; only light can do that.”
Comparison/Relations: Only through rising above tamas can one access higher states of being.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यदा सत्त्वे प्रवृद्धे तु प्रलयं याति देहभृत् ।
 तदोतमविदां लोकानमलान्प्रतिपद्यते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): When one dies during the predominance of sattva, they attain the pure higher realms of the wise.
Meaning/Interpretation: Death in sattva leads to elevated spiritual worlds.
Famous Quotes: “As you live your days, so shall you die.”
Comparison/Relations: The state of consciousness at death determines one’s next stage.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
रजसि प्रलयं गत्वा कर्मसङ्गिषु जायते ।
 तथा प्रलीनस्तमसि मूढयोनिषु जायते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): When one dies in rajas, he is born among those attached to action. Dying in tamas, he is born in the wombs of the ignorant.
Meaning/Interpretation: The prevailing guna at death shapes the next birth's nature.
Famous Quotes: “You are what you repeatedly do.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna emphasizes how habits and states of being carry forward into future lives.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
कर्मणः सुकृतस्याहुः सात्त्विकं निर्मलं फलम् ।
 रजसस्तु फलं दुःखं अज्ञानं तमसः फलम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The fruit of good action is said to be pure and in the mode of goodness; the fruit of passion is sorrow, and the fruit of ignorance is ignorance.
Meaning/Interpretation: Each action produces a result according to its motive and mode.
Famous Quotes: “Every action has its consequences.”
Comparison/Relations: Karma and its consequences reflect universal moral principles.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सत्त्वात्सञ्जायते ज्ञानं रजसो लोभ एव च ।
 प्रमादमोहौ तमसो भवतोऽज्ञानमेव च ॥
Sloka (English Translation): From sattva arises knowledge, from rajas arises greed, and from tamas arise negligence, delusion, and ignorance.
Meaning/Interpretation: Each guna gives rise to a distinct psychological and behavioral pattern.
Famous Quotes: “Greed is a bottomless pit.”
Comparison/Relations: Rajas and tamas distort perception, while sattva enables clarity.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ऊर्ध्वं गच्छन्ति सत्त्वस्था मध्ये तिष्ठन्ति राजसाः ।
 जघन्यगुणवृत्तिस्था अधो गच्छन्ति तामसाः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Those in sattva rise upward, the rajasic remain in the middle, and the tamasic, functioning in the lowest qualities, go downward.
Meaning/Interpretation: Spiritual evolution or regression depends on one’s dominant guna.
Famous Quotes: “You rise by lifting others.”
Comparison/Relations: Sattva uplifts consciousness, while tamas leads to degeneration.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
नान्यं गुणेभ्यः कर्तारं यदा द्रष्टानुपश्यति ।
 गुणेभ्यश्च परं वेत्ति मद्भावं सोऽधिगच्छति ॥
Sloka (English Translation): When one perceives no doer other than the modes of nature and knows the Supreme beyond the gunas, he attains My divine nature.
Meaning/Interpretation: True wisdom sees beyond the gunas and realizes the Supreme.
Famous Quotes: “You are not the mind; you are beyond it.”
Comparison/Relations: Disidentification from nature reveals the eternal self.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
गुणानेतानतीत्य त्रीन्देही देहसमुद्भवान् ।
 जन्ममृत्युजरादुःखैर्विमुक्तोऽमृतमश्नुते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Transcending these three gunas associated with the body, the embodied self becomes free from birth, death, old age, and sorrow, and attains immortality.
Meaning/Interpretation: The goal of life is to go beyond the gunas and realize the immortal soul.
Famous Quotes: “Freedom is not found in things but in detachment from them.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna and the Buddha both point toward transcending worldly limitations.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अर्जुन उवाच
 कैर्लिङ्गैस्त्रीन्गुणानेतानतीतो भवति प्रभो ।
 किमाचारः कथं चैतांस्त्रीन्गुणानतिवर्तते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Arjuna said: By what marks is one known who has transcended the three gunas? What is his conduct, and how does he go beyond the gunas?
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna seeks practical signs and methods for transcending material modes.
Famous Quotes: “The beginning of wisdom is the definition of terms.”
Comparison/Relations: Like a true seeker, Arjuna asks for clarity before pursuit.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रीभगवानुवाच
 प्रकाशं च प्रवृत्तिं च मोहमेव च पाण्डव ।
 न द्वेष्टि सम्प्रवृत्तानि न निवृत्तानि काङ्क्षति ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The Lord said: O Pandava, he neither hates illumination, activity, and delusion when they arise, nor desires them when they cease.
Meaning/Interpretation: The transcendent one remains impartial to the fluctuations of the gunas.
Famous Quotes: “Equanimity is the hallmark of spiritual maturity.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna describes a neutral, aware, and stable consciousness.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
उदासीनवदासीनो गुणैर्यो न विचाल्यते ।
 गुणा वर्तन्त इत्येवं योऽवतिष्ठति नेङ्गते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): He who sits like one unconcerned, unshaken by the gunas, knowing that the gunas are operating—he is established in self-realization.
Meaning/Interpretation: Liberation is achieved through detachment from the forces of nature.
Famous Quotes: “Be still, and know that I am God.”
Comparison/Relations: Stillness and non-reactivity are keys to spiritual depth in many paths.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
समदुःखसुखः स्वस्थः समलोष्टाश्मकाञ्चनः ।
 तुल्यप्रियाप्रियो धीरस्तुल्यनिन्दात्मसंस्तुतिः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): He is balanced in pleasure and pain, established in the self, regarding a clod, stone, and gold as equal; the wise remain alike in praise and blame.
Meaning/Interpretation: A realized soul treats all dualities with equal vision.
Famous Quotes: “To live content with small means and to be rich in self.”
Comparison/Relations: Detachment from external judgments is a sign of inner wealth.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
मानापमानयोस्तुल्यस्तुल्यो मित्रारिपक्षयोः ।
 सर्वारम्भपरित्यागी गुणातीतः स उच्यते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): He who is the same in honor and dishonor, the same to friend and enemy, who has renounced all undertakings—such a person is said to have transcended the modes.
Meaning/Interpretation: Freedom from social dualities marks the transcendent being.
Famous Quotes: “The sage is indifferent to praise or blame.”
Comparison/Relations: This aligns with Daoist values of inner constancy.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
मां च योऽव्यभिचारेण भक्तियोगेन सेवते ।
 स गुणान्समतीत्यैतान्ब्रह्मभूयाय कल्पते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): He who serves Me with unwavering devotion transcends the gunas and becomes fit for realization of Brahman.
Meaning/Interpretation: Devotion to the divine purifies and elevates consciousness beyond nature.
Famous Quotes: “Love is the bridge between you and everything.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna affirms bhakti as the supreme purifier.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ब्रह्मणो हि प्रतिष्ठाहममृतस्याव्ययस्य च ।
 शाश्वतस्य च धर्मस्य सुखस्यैकान्तिकस्य च ॥
Sloka (English Translation): I am the basis of the impersonal Brahman, the immortal, the imperishable, the eternal law and the ultimate bliss.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals Himself as the foundation of Brahman and eternal truth.
Famous Quotes: “I am the way, the truth, and the life.”
Comparison/Relations: This sloka resonates with ultimate divine realization beyond form and formless.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रीभगवानुवाच
 ऊर्ध्वमूलमधःशाखमश्वत्थं प्राहुरव्ययम् ।
 छन्दांसि यस्य पर्णानि यस्तं वेद स वेदवित् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The Blessed Lord said: They speak of the indestructible Peepul tree having its root above and branches below, whose leaves are the Vedic hymns. One who knows this tree is a knower of the Vedas.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna describes the material world as an inverted tree rooted in the Supreme, symbolizing illusion and eternal law.
Famous Quotes: “As above, so below.”
Comparison/Relations: The cosmic tree imagery appears in multiple traditions as a symbol of life and illusion.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अधश्चोर्ध्वं प्रसृतास्तस्य शाखा
 गुणप्रवृद्धा विषयप्रवालाः ।
 अधश्च मूलान्यनुसन्ततानि
 कर्मानुबन्धीनि मनुष्यलोके ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Its branches extend downward and upward, nourished by the modes of nature. Sense objects are its buds. And its roots, spread downward, are bound to action in the human world.
Meaning/Interpretation: The tree of life is fed by the gunas and keeps humans bound through karma.
Famous Quotes: “The roots of suffering are attachment and craving.”
Comparison/Relations: Desire-driven actions are the roots of bondage in both Hindu and Buddhist teachings.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
न रूपमस्येह तथोपलभ्यते
 नान्तो न चादिर्न च संप्रतिष्ठा ।
 अश्वत्थमेनं सुविरूढमूलं
 असङ्गशस्त्रेण दृढेन छित्त्वा ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Its form here cannot be perceived; it has neither beginning, nor end, nor foundation. Cutting this firmly rooted Ashvattha tree with the strong axe of detachment—
Meaning/Interpretation: The illusory nature of the material world can only be overcome through detachment.
Famous Quotes: “Only in detachment lies true freedom.”
Comparison/Relations: Like Krishna, modern mystics teach that liberation begins with letting go.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ततः पदं तत्परिमार्गितव्यं
 यस्मिन्गता न निवर्तन्ति भूयः ।
 तमेव चाद्यं पुरुषं प्रपद्ये
 यतः प्रवृत्तिः प्रसृता पुराणी ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Then one must seek that supreme abode, from which souls never return, surrendering to the primeval Person from whom the ancient activity has emanated.
Meaning/Interpretation: After detachment, the soul turns toward the eternal, unchanging Divine Source.
Famous Quotes: “Not all who wander are lost.”
Comparison/Relations: Spiritual journey leads to the ultimate reality beyond birth and death.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
निर्मानमोहा जितसङ्गदोषा
 अध्यात्मनित्या विनिवृत्तकामाः ।
 द्वन्द्वैर्विमुक्ताः सुखदुःखसंज्ञैर्गच्छन्त्यमूढाः पदमव्ययं तत् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Free from pride and delusion, having conquered attachment, dwelling in the Self, desires vanished, liberated from dualities of pleasure and pain—such sages reach the eternal goal.
Meaning/Interpretation: Self-realized beings are beyond ego and duality, established in bliss.
Famous Quotes: “Pride makes us artificial and humility makes us real.”
Comparison/Relations: Spiritual wisdom is grounded in humility, self-control, and clarity.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
न तद्भासयते सूर्यो न शशाङ्को न पावकः ।
 यद्गत्वा न निवर्तन्ते तद्धाम परमं मम ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Neither the sun nor the moon nor fire illumines that Supreme Abode, reaching which they do not return. That is My supreme abode.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna describes the spiritual world as self-luminous and beyond material existence.
Famous Quotes: “The light shines in the darkness, and the darkness has not overcome it.”
Comparison/Relations: Eternal realms in all traditions are described as luminous and free from decay.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ममैवांशो जीवलोके जीवभूतः सनातनः ।
 मनःषष्ठानीन्द्रियाणि प्रकृतिस्थानि कर्षति ॥
Sloka (English Translation): An eternal portion of Myself becomes the soul in the living world. It draws the five senses and the mind into material nature.
Meaning/Interpretation: The individual soul is divine in essence but trapped in nature through the senses.
Famous Quotes: “You are not a drop in the ocean. You are the entire ocean in a drop.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna affirms the soul’s divinity despite its worldly entanglement.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
शरीरं यदवाप्नोति यच्चाप्युत्क्रामतीश्वरः ।
 गृहीत्वैतानि संयाति वायुर्गन्धानिवाशयात् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): When the soul leaves the body or enters a new one, it carries the mind and senses with it, just as the wind carries fragrances from one place to another.
Meaning/Interpretation: The subtle body, made of desires and impressions, follows the soul after death.
Famous Quotes: “You take yourself wherever you go.”
Comparison/Relations: The soul carries its tendencies across lifetimes.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रोत्रं चक्षुः स्पर्शनं च रसनं घ्राणमेव च ।
 अधिष्ठाय मनश्चायं विषयानुपसेवते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Presiding over the ear, eye, touch, tongue, nose, and the mind, the soul experiences the sense objects.
Meaning/Interpretation: The soul operates the body through the senses and mind.
Famous Quotes: “The body is a servant of the mind.”
Comparison/Relations: Mind and senses are instruments of the indwelling soul.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
उत्क्रामन्तं स्थितं वापि भुञ्जानं वा गुणान्वितम् ।
 विमूढा नानुपश्यन्ति पश्यन्ति ज्ञानचक्षुषः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The ignorant do not see the soul when it leaves or stays or enjoys, but those with the eye of knowledge behold it.
Meaning/Interpretation: Spiritual vision allows one to perceive the soul's journey through life and death.
Famous Quotes: “It is only with the heart that one can see rightly.”
Comparison/Relations: Inner wisdom reveals the truths hidden from the senses.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यतन्तो योगिनश्चैनं पश्यन्त्यात्मन्यवस्थितम् ।
 यतन्तोऽप्यकृतात्मानो नैनं पश्यन्त्यचेतसः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Striving yogis perceive the soul within, but the unintelligent, lacking discipline, cannot see it.
Meaning/Interpretation: Effort and discipline are necessary to realize the self.
Famous Quotes: “What you seek is seeking you.”
Comparison/Relations: Spiritual realization requires effort and purity of intent.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यदादित्यगतं तेजो जगद्भासयतेऽखिलम् ।
 यच्चन्द्रमसि यच्चाग्नौ तत्तेजो विद्धि मामकम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The light that shines from the sun, moon, and fire—know that light to be Mine.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna identifies Himself as the essence behind all sources of light.
Famous Quotes: “God said, ‘Let there be light,’ and there was light.”
Comparison/Relations: The Divine is seen as the source of illumination in all spiritual texts.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
गामाविश्य च भूतानि धारयाम्यहमोजसा ।
 पुष्णामि चौषधीः सर्वाः सोमो भूत्वा रसात्मकः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Entering the earth, I sustain all beings with My energy. Becoming the moon, I nourish all plants with the essence of life.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna is the sustaining force in nature’s processes.
Famous Quotes: “Nature is not a place to visit. It is home.”
Comparison/Relations: Divinity operates through nature’s sustaining mechanisms.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अहं वैश्वानरो भूत्वा प्राणिनां देहमाश्रितः ।
 प्राणापानसमायुक्तः पचाम्यन्नं चतुर्विधम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Becoming the fire of digestion in the bodies of living beings, I join with the vital breaths and digest the four kinds of food.
Meaning/Interpretation: Even bodily functions are sustained by the Divine.
Famous Quotes: “God dwells in every heartbeat, every breath.”
Comparison/Relations: The Divine operates in the smallest functions of life.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सर्वस्य चाहं हृदि सन्निविष्टो
 मत्तः स्मृतिर्ज्ञानमपोहनं च ।
 वेदैश्च सर्वैरहमेव वेद्यो
 वेदान्तकृद्वेदविदेव चाहम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): I am seated in the heart of all beings. From Me come memory, knowledge, and forgetfulness. I am to be known through the Vedas, and I am the author and knower of the Vedas.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna is the indwelling source of all knowledge and experience.
Famous Quotes: “God is closer to you than your jugular vein.”
Comparison/Relations: The Divine as the inner witness and guide is a shared truth across traditions.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
द्वाविमौ पुरुषौ लोके क्षरश्चाक्षर एव च ।
 क्षरः सर्वाणि भूतानि कूटस्थोऽक्षर उच्यते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): There are two kinds of beings in the created world—the perishable and the imperishable. All beings in the material world are perishable, but the soul is imperishable.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna differentiates between the temporary body and the eternal soul.
Famous Quotes: “The body is perishable, but the soul is eternal.”
Comparison/Relations: This verse aligns with Vedanta’s view of the self as eternal and beyond decay.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
उत्तमः पुरुषस्त्वन्यः परमात्मेत्युधाहृतः ।
 यो लोकत्रयमाविश्य बिभर्त्यव्यय ईश्वरः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): But there is another, the Supreme Person, who is known as the Paramatma. He enters the three worlds and sustains them.
Meaning/Interpretation: Beyond the individual soul is the Supreme Soul, who supports all existence.
Famous Quotes: “God dwells in all beings, but all beings do not dwell in God.”
Comparison/Relations: The Paramatma pervades all but remains above all, reflecting divine transcendence.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यस्मात्क्षरमतीतोऽहमक्षरादपि चोत्तमः ।
 अतोऽस्मि लोके वेदे च प्रथितः पुरुषोत्तमः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Because I am beyond both the perishable and the imperishable, I am celebrated in the world and in the Vedas as the Supreme Person (Purushottama).
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reveals His supreme identity as the highest being beyond time and change.
Famous Quotes: “I am the Alpha and the Omega, the beginning and the end.”
Comparison/Relations: The concept of an ultimate, all-transcending divinity is universal across faiths.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यो मामेवमसम्मूढो जानाति पुरुषोत्तमम् ।
 स सर्वविद्भजति मां सर्वभावेन भारत ॥
Sloka (English Translation): He who knows Me as the Supreme Person, without a doubt, knows everything and worships Me with all his heart, O Bharata.
Meaning/Interpretation: Recognizing Krishna as the Supreme leads to wholehearted devotion and wisdom.
Famous Quotes: “To know God is to love Him.”
Comparison/Relations: True knowledge results in unwavering devotion, across all traditions.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
इति गुह्यतमं शास्त्रमिदमुक्तं मयानघ ।
 एतद्बुद्ध्वा बुद्धिमान्स्यात्कृतकृत्यश्च भारत ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Thus, the most secret of scriptures has been declared by Me. Understanding this, one becomes enlightened and fulfills the purpose of life, O Bharata.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna concludes by stating that knowing this wisdom leads to ultimate fulfillment.
Famous Quotes: “The purpose of life is to know God and serve Him.”
Comparison/Relations: Self-realization and divine union mark the culmination of life’s journey.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रीभगवानुवाच
 अभयं सत्त्वसंशुद्धिर्ज्ञानयोगव्यवस्थितिः ।
 दानं दमश्च यज्ञश्च स्वाध्यायस्तप आर्जवम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The Blessed Lord said: Fearlessness, purity of heart, steadfastness in knowledge and yoga, charity, self-control, sacrifice, study of scriptures, austerity, and uprightness—
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna begins listing divine qualities necessary for spiritual growth.
Famous Quotes: “Courage is resistance to fear, mastery of fear—not absence of fear.”
Comparison/Relations: Spiritual development begins with courage and inner discipline.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अहिंसा सत्यमक्रोधस्त्यागः शान्तिरपैशुनम् ।
 दया भूतेष्वलोलुप्त्वं मार्दवं ह्रीरचापलम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Non-violence, truthfulness, absence of anger, renunciation, peace, restraint from fault-finding, compassion to all beings, absence of greed, gentleness, modesty, and lack of fickleness—
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna emphasizes virtues of compassion and peaceful conduct.
Famous Quotes: “The weak can never forgive. Forgiveness is the attribute of the strong.”
Comparison/Relations: Ahimsa and compassion are core to both Krishna's and Gandhi’s teachings.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तेजः क्षमा धृतिः शौचमद्रोहो नातिमानिता ।
 भवन्ति सम्पदं दैवीमभिजातस्य भारत ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Vigor, forgiveness, fortitude, purity, freedom from hatred, and absence of pride—these qualities, O Bharata, belong to one born of divine nature.
Meaning/Interpretation: These qualities define a person with divine disposition.
Famous Quotes: “True strength lies in gentleness.”
Comparison/Relations: Spiritual strength manifests as calm endurance and humility.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
दम्भो दर्पोऽभिमानश्च क्रोधः पारुष्यमेव च ।
 अज्ञानं चाभिजातस्य पार्थ सम्पदामासुरीम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Hypocrisy, arrogance, pride, anger, harshness, and ignorance—these, O Partha, are qualities of those born with demoniac nature.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna contrasts divine and demoniac traits, urging self-reflection.
Famous Quotes: “Pride goes before destruction.”
Comparison/Relations: Pride and anger are universally warned against in spiritual texts.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
दैवी सम्पद्विमोक्षाय निबन्धायासुरी मता ।
 मा शुचः सम्पदं दैवीमभिजातोऽसि पाण्डव ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The divine qualities lead to liberation, the demoniac to bondage. Do not grieve, O Arjuna, for you are born with divine qualities.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna reassures Arjuna of his spiritual potential and dharmic nature.
Famous Quotes: “You are the light of the world.”
Comparison/Relations: Encouragement of inner divinity is common in divine revelations.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
द्वौ भूतसर्गौ लोकेऽस्मिन्दैव आसुर एव च ।
 दैवो विस्तरशः प्रोक्त आसुरं पार्थ मे शृणु ॥
Sloka (English Translation): There are two types of created beings in this world—the divine and the demoniac. I have described the divine; now hear from Me about the demoniac.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna sets the stage to explain how contrasting natures affect destiny.
Famous Quotes: “You must know both light and shadow to understand life.”
Comparison/Relations: Understanding good and evil is part of self-realization.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
प्रवृत्तिं च निवृत्तिं च जना न विदुरासुराः ।
 न शौचं नापि चाचारो न सत्यं तेṣu विद्यते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The demoniac do not know what to do and what to avoid. They lack purity, proper conduct, and truth.
Meaning/Interpretation: The absence of moral compass characterizes the demoniac nature.
Famous Quotes: “Without conscience, there is no morality.”
Comparison/Relations: The Gita and philosophy both root morality in awareness.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
असत्यमप्रतिष्ठं ते जगदाहुरनीश्वरम् ।
 अपरस्परसम्भूतं किमन्यत्कामहैतुकम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): They say the world is without truth, without a basis, without God, and born of desire with no cause other than lust.
Meaning/Interpretation: Such views deny spiritual order, leading to moral chaos.
Famous Quotes: “Where there is no vision, the people perish.”
Comparison/Relations: Faith in a higher principle anchors moral life.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
एतां दृष्टिमवष्टभ्य नष्टात्मानोऽल्पबुद्धयः ।
 प्रभवन्त्युग्रकर्माणः क्षयाय जगतोऽहिताः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Clinging to such a view, the lost souls, of small intelligence, engage in terrible acts meant to destroy the world.
Meaning/Interpretation: Ignorant actions born of delusion create destruction.
Famous Quotes: “The root of all evil is ignorance.”
Comparison/Relations: Both Krishna and philosophers like Plato blame ignorance for chaos.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
काममाश्रित्य दुष्पूरं दम्भमानमदान्विताः ।
 मोहाद्गृहीत्वासद्ग्राहान्प्रवर्तन्तेऽशुचिव्रताः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Taking shelter in insatiable desire, filled with hypocrisy, pride, and arrogance, they act impurely, clinging to false beliefs.
Meaning/Interpretation: Uncontrolled desires and ego distort actions and beliefs.
Famous Quotes: “He who conquers himself is the mightiest warrior.”
Comparison/Relations: Victory over desire is the root of all true greatness.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
चिन्तामपरिमेयां च प्रलयान्तामुपाश्रिताः ।
 कामोपभोगपरमा एतावदिति निश्चिताः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Obsessed with endless anxieties that end only with death, they believe that gratification of desires is the highest goal.
Meaning/Interpretation: Materialistic minds remain trapped in anxiety and false fulfillment.
Famous Quotes: “Desire never ends, it only changes form.”
Comparison/Relations: Insatiable craving breeds inner unrest and suffering.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
आशापाशशतैर्बद्धाः कामक्रोधपरायणाः ।
 ईहन्ते कामभोगार्थमन्यायेनार्थसञ्चयान् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Bound by hundreds of desires and addicted to lust and anger, they seek wealth unjustly for the gratification of their desires.
Meaning/Interpretation: When craving and anger dominate, injustice follows.
Famous Quotes: “Corruption begins where desire outweighs duty.”
Comparison/Relations: The Gita echoes this political and moral truth.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
इदमद्य मया लब्धमिमं प्राप्स्ये मनोरथम् ।
 इदमस्तीदमपि मे भविष्यति पुनर्धनम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): ‘This today I have gained; this desire I shall fulfill. I have this wealth, and more will come to me again.’
Meaning/Interpretation: Such minds are absorbed in material possessions and future hoarding.
Famous Quotes: “He who knows he has enough is rich.”
Comparison/Relations: True wealth is contentment, not accumulation.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
असौ मया हतः शत्रुर्हनिष्ये चापरानपि ।
 ईश्वरोऽहमहं भोगी सिद्धोऽहं बलवान्सुखी ॥
Sloka (English Translation): ‘I have slain this enemy, and others I will slay. I am the lord, the enjoyer, the perfect, powerful, and happy.’
Meaning/Interpretation: Such pride and ego blind one to reality and righteousness.
Famous Quotes: “Power tends to corrupt, and absolute power corrupts absolutely.”
Comparison/Relations: Arrogance and domination lead to downfall.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
आढ्योऽभिजनवानस्मि कोऽन्योऽस्ति सदृशो मया ।
 यक्ष्ये दास्यामि मोदिष्य इत्यज्ञानविमोहिताः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): ‘I am rich and well-born. Who is equal to me? I shall perform sacrifices, give charity, and rejoice.’ Thus deluded by ignorance.
Meaning/Interpretation: Even good acts done with ego are spiritually empty.
Famous Quotes: “Pride is concerned with who is right. Humility is concerned with what is right.”
Comparison/Relations: Real devotion is ego-free; pride taints spiritual practice.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अननेकचित्तविभ्रान्ता मोहजालसमावृताः ।
 प्रसक्ताः कामभोगेषु पतन्ति नरकेऽशुचौ ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Perplexed by many thoughts, entangled in delusion, addicted to sensual enjoyment, they fall into a foul hell.
Meaning/Interpretation: Distraction and attachment lead to spiritual downfall.
Famous Quotes: “A confused mind cannot discern the truth.”
Comparison/Relations: Mental clarity is essential for spiritual direction.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
आत्मसम्भाविता स्तब्धा धनमानमदान्विताः ।
 यजन्ते नामयज्ञैस्ते दम्भेनाविधिपूर्वकम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Self-conceited, stubborn, filled with pride and wealth, they perform sacrifices in name only, with hypocrisy and not according to scriptural rules.
Meaning/Interpretation: True spiritual acts must be rooted in humility and sincerity.
Famous Quotes: “Rituals without meaning are like a body without soul.”
Comparison/Relations: Intent behind action defines its spiritual value.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अहङ्कारं बलं दर्पं कामं क्रोधं च संश्रिताः ।
 मामात्मपरदेहेषु प्रद्विषन्तोऽभ्यसूयकाः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Given over to ego, power, arrogance, desire, and anger, they hate Me in others and in themselves.
Meaning/Interpretation: Those ruled by lower traits reject the Divine within and without.
Famous Quotes: “He who despises others is truly blind to himself.”
Comparison/Relations: Divine presence must be recognized in all forms.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तानहं द्विषतः क्रूरान्संसारेषु नराधमान् ।
 क्षिपाम्यजस्रमशुभानासुरीष्वेव योनिषु ॥
Sloka (English Translation): These malicious, cruel, and impure people I repeatedly cast into demoniac wombs in the cycle of birth.
Meaning/Interpretation: Egoic and harmful actions lead to lower births and suffering.
Famous Quotes: “You reap what you sow.”
Comparison/Relations: Karma governs rebirth and consequences across traditions.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
आसुरीं योनिमापन्ना मूढा जन्मनि जन्मनि ।
 मामप्राप्यैव कौन्तेय ततो यान्त्यधमां गतिम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Falling into such demoniac births life after life, these deluded souls never approach Me, and gradually sink to the lowest states.
Meaning/Interpretation: Continuous ignorance leads further away from liberation.
Famous Quotes: “The downward spiral begins with self-deception.”
Comparison/Relations: Spiritual regression results from clinging to ignorance.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
त्रिविधं नरकस्येदं द्वारं नाशनमात्मनः ।
 कामः क्रोधस्तथा लोभस्तस्मादेतत्त्रयं त्यजेत् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): There are three gates to self-destructive hell—lust, anger, and greed. Therefore, one must give them up.
Meaning/Interpretation: These three vices are most destructive to the soul’s progress.
Famous Quotes: “Lust, anger, and greed are the three gates to hell.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna offers a timeless guide for spiritual discipline.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
एतैर्विमुक्तः कौन्तेय तमोद्वारैस्त्रिभिर्नरः ।
 आचरत्यात्मनः श्रेयस्ततो याति परां गतिम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): One who is liberated from these three gates of darkness practices what is good for the soul and thus attains the supreme goal.
Meaning/Interpretation: Freedom from lust, anger, and greed leads to enlightenment.
Famous Quotes: “To conquer oneself is a greater victory than to conquer thousands in battle.”
Comparison/Relations: Inner mastery leads to ultimate liberation.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यः शास्त्रविधिमुत्सृज्य वर्तते कामकारतः ।
 न स सिद्धिमवाप्नोति न सुखं न परां गतिम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): He who disregards scriptural injunctions and acts according to desire attains neither perfection, happiness, nor the supreme goal.
Meaning/Interpretation: Desire-led actions without wisdom result in spiritual stagnation.
Famous Quotes: “Discipline is the bridge between goals and accomplishment.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna emphasizes dharma and spiritual order over desire.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तस्माच्छास्त्रं प्रमाणं ते कार्याकार्यव्यवस्थितौ ।
 ज्ञात्वा शास्त्रविधानोक्तं कर्म कर्तुमिहार्हसि ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Therefore, let the scriptures be your guide in deciding what is to be done and what is not. Understanding this, act accordingly.
Meaning/Interpretation: Scriptural wisdom provides the light for rightful living.
Famous Quotes: “Let your conscience be your compass.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna advises us to use higher wisdom as the foundation of action.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अर्जुन उवाच
 ये शास्त्रविधिमुत्सृज्य यजन्ते श्रद्धयान्विताः ।
 तेषां निष्ठा तु का कृष्ण सत्त्वमाहो रजस्तमः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Arjuna said: What is the position of those who worship with faith but disregard the scriptural injunctions, O Krishna? Is it in goodness, passion, or ignorance?
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna inquires about the faith of those who act with devotion but without scriptural guidance.
Famous Quotes: “Faith is taking the first step even when you don’t see the whole staircase.”
Comparison/Relations: Faith must be rightly directed to uplift rather than mislead.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रीभगवानुवाच
 त्रिविधा भवति श्रद्धा देहिनां सा स्वभावजा ।
 सात्त्विकी राजसी चैव तामसी चेति तां शृणु ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The Blessed Lord said: Faith is of three kinds, born of the nature of the embodied being—sattvic, rajasic, and tamasic. Listen to Me about each.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna classifies faith based on the three gunas that govern human nature.
Famous Quotes: “As is your faith, so is your reality.”
Comparison/Relations: Spiritual psychology links belief with personal evolution.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सत्त्वानुरूपा सर्वस्य श्रद्धा भवति भारत ।
 श्रद्धामयोऽयं पुरुषो यो यच्छ्रद्धः स एव सः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Faith corresponds to one’s inherent nature. A person is made of their faith. Whatever their faith is, that they become.
Meaning/Interpretation: Faith shapes identity and destiny.
Famous Quotes: “You become what you believe.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna connects internal beliefs to external outcomes.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यजन्ते सात्त्विका देवान्यक्षरक्षांसि राजसाः ।
 प्रेतान्भूतगणांश्चान्ये यजन्ते तामसा जनाः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Those in sattva worship the gods; in rajas, the yakshas and demons; in tamas, the ghosts and spirits.
Meaning/Interpretation: Faith in various modes attracts different deities or energies.
Famous Quotes: “Where your attention goes, energy flows.”
Comparison/Relations: Your object of reverence reflects your internal state.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अशास्त्रविहितं घोरं तप्यन्ते ये तपो जनाः ।
 दम्भाहङ्कारसंयुक्ताः कामरागबलान्विताः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Those who perform severe austerities not enjoined by scripture, driven by hypocrisy and ego, impelled by desire and attachment—
Meaning/Interpretation: Self-harming acts done out of ego are spiritually unproductive.
Famous Quotes: “Discipline without direction is drudgery.”
Comparison/Relations: True discipline is guided by wisdom and purpose.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
कर्षयन्तः शरीरस्थं भूतग्राममचेतसः ।
 मां चैवान्तःशरीरस्थं तान्विद्ध्यासुरनिश्चयान् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): They torture the bodily elements and Me within, unwise and demoniac in nature.
Meaning/Interpretation: Harming the body dishonors the indwelling Divine.
Famous Quotes: “Your body is a temple of the Holy Spirit.”
Comparison/Relations: Both traditions honor the body as divine residence.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
आहारस्त्वपि सर्वस्य त्रिविधो भवति प्रियो ।
 यज्ञस्तपस्तथा दानं तेषां भेदमिमं शृणु ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Even food preferred by all is of three kinds. So are sacrifice, austerity, and charity. Hear the distinctions among them.
Meaning/Interpretation: The mode of one's food and actions reflects their nature.
Famous Quotes: “Tell me what you eat, and I will tell you what you are.”
Comparison/Relations: Our choices reflect our spiritual alignment.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
आयुःसत्त्वबलारोग्यसुखप्रीतिविवर्धनाः ।
 रस्याः स्निग्धाः स्थिरा हृद्या आहाराः सात्त्विकप्रियाः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Foods that increase life, purity, strength, health, happiness, and satisfaction, that are juicy, fatty, wholesome, and pleasing are dear to those in sattva.
Meaning/Interpretation: Sattvic food nourishes body and soul.
Famous Quotes: “Let food be thy medicine and medicine be thy food.”
Comparison/Relations: Nutrition is a cornerstone of a sattvic lifestyle.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
कट्वम्ललवणात्युष्णतीक्ष्णरूक्षविदाहिनः ।
 आहारा राजसस्येष्टा दुःखशोकामयप्रदाः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Foods that are too bitter, sour, salty, hot, pungent, dry, and burning are liked by the rajasic, and cause pain, sorrow, and disease.
Meaning/Interpretation: Rajasic food disturbs the balance of the body and mind.
Famous Quotes: “You are what you eat, so don't be fast, cheap, easy, or fake.”
Comparison/Relations: Food reflects inner tendencies and influences behavior.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यातयामं गतरसं पूति पर्युषितं च यत् ।
 उच्छिष्टमपि चामेध्यं भोजनं तामसप्रियम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Food that is stale, tasteless, putrid, decomposed, and impure is dear to the tamasic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Tamasic food diminishes clarity and spiritual energy.
Famous Quotes: “Clean food is not a diet, it's a lifestyle.”
Comparison/Relations: Clean and mindful eating supports spiritual clarity.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अफलाकाङ्क्षिभिर्यज्ञो विधिदृष्टो य इज्यते ।
 यष्टव्यमेवेति मनः समाधाय स सात्त्विकः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): A sacrifice performed according to scriptural instructions with no expectation of reward, with the mind fixed on the act itself, is sattvic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Sattvic sacrifice is selfless and aligned with dharma.
Famous Quotes: “Act without expectation.”
Comparison/Relations: True virtue lies in unselfish action.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अभिसंधाय तु फलं दम्भार्थमपि चैव यत् ।
 इज्यते भरतश्रेष्ठ तं यज्ञं विद्धि राजसम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): But sacrifice performed with expectation of result or for show, O best of the Bharatas, is rajasic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Desire taints even good acts, making them self-centered.
Famous Quotes: “Vanity spoils the best of intentions.”
Comparison/Relations: True devotion is free of ego and show.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
विधिहीनमसृष्टान्नं मन्त्रहीनमदक्षिणम् ।
 श्रद्धाविरहितं यज्ञं तामसं परिचक्षते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): A sacrifice done without regard for scriptural rules, without food, mantras, or faith, is declared to be tamasic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Faithless rituals are spiritually void.
Famous Quotes: “Without heart, no ritual has power.”
Comparison/Relations: Ritual must be energized by sincerity and love.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
देवद्विजगुरुप्राज्ञपूजनं शौचमार्जवम् ।
 ब्रह्मचर्यमहिंसा च शारीरं तप उच्यते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Worship of gods, the wise, teachers, cleanliness, straightforwardness, celibacy, and nonviolence—this is called physical austerity.
Meaning/Interpretation: True bodily discipline supports spiritual growth.
Famous Quotes: “Cleanliness is next to godliness.”
Comparison/Relations: Purity in body reflects purity in mind and soul.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अनुद्वेगकरं वाक्यं सत्यं प्रियहितं च यत् ।
 स्वाध्यायाभ्यसनं चैव वाङ्मयं तप उच्यते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Speech that is non-offensive, truthful, pleasant, beneficial, and practiced in scriptural study is austerity of speech.
Meaning/Interpretation: Spiritual speech uplifts both speaker and listener.
Famous Quotes: “Kind words can be short and easy to speak, but their echoes are truly endless.”
Comparison/Relations: Speech becomes sacred when rooted in truth and compassion.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
मनःप्रसादः सौम्यत्वं मौनमात्मविनिग्रहः ।
 भावसंशुद्धिरित्येतत्तपो मानसमुच्यते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Serenity of mind, gentleness, silence, self-restraint, and purity of thought are called mental austerity.
Meaning/Interpretation: Mental discipline purifies and stabilizes inner awareness.
Famous Quotes: “Peace comes from within. Do not seek it without.”
Comparison/Relations: Spiritual growth depends on mastering the mind.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रद्धया परया तप्तं तपस्तत्त्रिविधं नरैः ।
 अफलाकाङ्क्षिभिर्युक्तैः सात्त्विकं परिचक्षते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): This threefold austerity performed with supreme faith and without desire for results is said to be sattvic.
Meaning/Interpretation: True austerity is selfless and sustained by devotion.
Famous Quotes: “The reward of a thing well done is to have done it.”
Comparison/Relations: Acting without attachment is a mark of sattva.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सत्कारमानपूजार्थं तपो दम्भेन चैव यत् ।
 क्रियते तदिह प्रोक्तं राजसं चलमध्रुवम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Austerity performed for gaining respect, honor, and worship is rajasic, unstable, and impermanent.
Meaning/Interpretation: Rajasic acts are motivated by ego and desire for recognition.
Famous Quotes: “Fame is a vapor, popularity an accident, and riches take wings.”
Comparison/Relations: External rewards don’t reflect true spiritual gain.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
मूढग्राहेणात्मनो यत्पीडया क्रियते तपः ।
 परस्योत्सादनार्थं वा तत्तामसमुदाहृतम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Austerity performed with foolishness, causing self-torture or harm to others, is said to be tamasic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Tamasic discipline is misguided and destructive.
Famous Quotes: “Discipline without understanding is punishment.”
Comparison/Relations: True austerity uplifts, not harms.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
दत्तव्यं इति यद्दानं दीयतेऽनुपकारिणे ।
 देशे काले च पात्रे च तद्दानं सात्त्विकं स्मृतम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Charity given to a worthy recipient without expectation, at the right time and place, is sattvic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Selfless giving is rooted in sattva and spiritual wisdom.
Famous Quotes: “The best way to find yourself is to lose yourself in the service of others.”
Comparison/Relations: Charity in sattva is an expression of compassion.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यत्तु प्रत्युपकारार्थं फलमुद्दिश्य वा पुनः ।
 दीयते च परिक्लिष्टं तद्दानं राजसं स्मृतम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Charity given with expectation of return or reluctantly is said to be rajasic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Giving driven by self-interest lacks true merit.
Famous Quotes: “A gift, with strings attached, is a transaction.”
Comparison/Relations: Intention matters more than the act.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अदेशकाले यद्दानमपात्रेभ्यश्च दीयते ।
 असत्कृतमवज्ञातं तत्तामसमुदाहृतम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Charity given at the wrong time or place, to unworthy persons, or without respect, is said to be tamasic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Tamasic giving reflects carelessness and delusion.
Famous Quotes: “Giving without grace is taking in disguise.”
Comparison/Relations: Wisdom guides true generosity.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ॐ तत्सदिति निर्देशो ब्रह्मणस्त्रिविधः स्मृतः ।
 ब्राह्मणास्तेन वेदाश्च यज्ञाश्च विहिताः पुरा ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Om Tat Sat is considered the triple designation of the Absolute Truth. By this, the Brahmanas, Vedas, and sacrifices were created in ancient times.
Meaning/Interpretation: Om Tat Sat represents the eternal essence behind spiritual practice.
Famous Quotes: “Truth is one; sages call it by many names.”
Comparison/Relations: Spiritual traditions converge on unity and truth.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तस्मादोमित्युदाहृत्य यज्ञदानतपःक्रियाः ।
 प्रवर्तन्ते विधानोक्ताः सततं ब्रह्मवादिनाम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Therefore, acts of sacrifice, charity, and austerity prescribed by scripture are always begun with Om by those who understand Brahman.
Meaning/Interpretation: Om is the sacred seed of all noble endeavors.
Famous Quotes: “In the beginning was the Word.”
Comparison/Relations: The divine sound initiates sacred action across traditions.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तदित्यनभिसन्धाय फलं यज्ञतपःक्रियाः ।
 दानक्रियाश्च विविधाः क्रियन्ते मोक्षकाङ्क्षिभिः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): With the word Tat, acts of sacrifice, austerity, and charity are performed without expectation of reward by seekers of liberation.
Meaning/Interpretation: Tat symbolizes detachment from fruit of action.
Famous Quotes: “Do your work, and then step back. The only path to serenity.”
Comparison/Relations: Non-attachment is key to spiritual progress.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सद्भावे साधुभावे च सदित्येतत्प्रयुज्यते ।
 प्रशस्ते कर्मणि तथासत् शब्दः पार्थ युज्यते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Sat is used in the sense of truth and goodness. It also denotes auspicious action, O Partha.
Meaning/Interpretation: Sat refers to sincerity, reality, and noble conduct.
Famous Quotes: “Truth alone triumphs.”
Comparison/Relations: Truth and virtue are the foundation of dharma.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यज्ञे तपसि दाने च स्थितिः सदिति चोच्यते ।
 कर्म चैव तदर्थीयं सदित्येवाभिधीयते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Steadfastness in sacrifice, austerity, and charity is also called Sat. Any action performed for that purpose is called Sat.
Meaning/Interpretation: Consistency and purpose in spiritual effort is noble.
Famous Quotes: “Great acts are made up of small deeds done well.”
Comparison/Relations: Persistence in virtue affirms one’s spiritual sincerity.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अश्रद्धया हुतं दत्तं तपस्तप्तं कृतं च यत् ।
 असदित्युच्यते पार्थ न च तत्प्रेत्य नो इह ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Whatever is offered, given, or done, and any austerity performed without faith is called Asat; it is useless both in this life and the next.
Meaning/Interpretation: Faith is the foundation of all spiritual value.
Famous Quotes: “Faith is the bird that feels the light and sings while the dawn is still dark.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna emphasizes sincerity as the soul of spiritual life.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अर्जुन उवाच
 सन्न्यासस्य महाबाहो तत्त्वमिच्छामि वेदितुम् ।
 त्यागस्य च हृषीकेश पृथक्केशिनिषूदन ॥
