Sloka (English Translation): Arjuna said: O Mighty-armed, I wish to understand the true nature of renunciation (sannyāsa) and the giving up of actions (tyāga), O Hrishikesha, O slayer of Kesi.
Meaning/Interpretation: Arjuna seeks to understand the difference between renunciation of actions and renunciation of desires.
Famous Quotes: “Renunciation is not getting rid of the things of this world, but accepting that they pass away.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna encourages inquiry into the balance between action and detachment.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रीभगवानुवाच
 काम्यानां कर्मणां न्यासं सन्न्यासं कवयो विदुः ।
 सर्वकर्मफलत्यागं प्राहुस्त्यागं विचक्षणाः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The Blessed Lord said: Giving up actions done with a desire for rewards is called renunciation (sannyāsa), while giving up the fruits of all actions is called tyāga by the wise.
Meaning/Interpretation: Sannyāsa is giving up desire-driven actions, while tyāga is surrendering the results.
Famous Quotes: “Do your duty without attachment to results.”
Comparison/Relations: This is the core Karma Yoga principle of the Gita.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
त्याज्यं दोषवदित्येके कर्म प्राहुर्मनीषिणः ।
 यज्ञदानतपःकर्म न त्याज्यमिति चापरे ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Some sages say action should be renounced as evil, while others say that acts of sacrifice, charity, and penance should never be given up.
Meaning/Interpretation: There are differing views on what kinds of action should be renounced.
Famous Quotes: “There is no virtue in inaction.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna guides us to balanced renunciation, not escape.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
निश्चयं शृणु मे तत्र त्यागे भरतसत्तम ।
 त्यागो हि पुरुषव्याघ्र त्रिविधः सम्प्रकीर्तितः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Hear from Me, O best of the Bharatas, My final judgment on renunciation, for renunciation is declared to be of three kinds.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna promises to clarify the nature and types of renunciation.
Famous Quotes: “The truth is simple—only the wise understand it simply.”
Comparison/Relations: Clarity comes from divine guidance, not speculation.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यज्ञदानतपःकर्म न त्याज्यं कार्यमेव तत् ।
 यज्ञो दानं तपश्चैव पावनानि मनीषिणाम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Acts of sacrifice, charity, and penance should not be abandoned; they must be performed. These purify even the wise.
Meaning/Interpretation: Selfless service and discipline are purifying and essential.
Famous Quotes: “Discipline is the refining fire by which talent becomes ability.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna emphasizes purification through noble action.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
एतान्यपि तु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा फलानि च ।
 कर्तव्यानीति मे पार्थ निश्
Sloka (English Translation): Even these actions must be done by giving up attachment and desire for results. This is My firm and best opinion, O Arjuna.
Meaning/Interpretation: Perform duties without attachment—this is the path of wisdom.
Famous Quotes: “Let go of the outcome. Focus on the process.”
Comparison/Relations: Spiritual maturity means acting without clinging.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
नियतस्य तु सन्न्यासः कर्मणो नोपपद्यते ।
 मोहात्तस्य परित्यागस्तामसः परिकीर्तितः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Renunciation of prescribed duties is not proper. Abandoning such duties due to delusion is declared to be tamasic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Giving up duties out of confusion is ignorance, not renunciation.
Famous Quotes: “Delusion leads to inertia, not enlightenment.”
Comparison/Relations: True wisdom discerns what should and shouldn't be done.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
दुःखमित्येव यत्कर्म कायक्लेशभयात्त्यजेत् ।
 स कृत्वा राजसं त्यागं नैव त्यागफलं लभेत् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): He who gives up action because it is troublesome or painful, thus acting out of fear or discomfort, performs rajasic renunciation and gains no benefit.
Meaning/Interpretation: Avoidance due to pain or fear is rajasic and unproductive.
Famous Quotes: “Avoidance is not peace.”
Comparison/Relations: Genuine renunciation is fearless and conscious.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
कार्यमित्येव यत्कर्म नियतं क्रियतेऽर्जुन ।
 सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा फलं चैव स त्यागः सात्त्विको मतः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): When one performs obligatory action only because it should be done, giving up attachment and reward, that is called sattvic renunciation.
Meaning/Interpretation: Sattvic tyāga is selfless and wise.
Famous Quotes: “Duty performed without selfish motive purifies the heart.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna defines the highest kind of renunciation.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
न द्वेष्ट्यकुशलं कर्म कुशले नानुषज्जते ।
 त्यागी सत्त्वसमाविष्टो मेधावी छिन्नसंशयः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The wise renunciant, imbued with sattva, neither hates inauspicious work nor is attached to auspicious work; he is intelligent and free from doubt.
Meaning/Interpretation: The truly renounced soul transcends judgment and attachment.
Famous Quotes: “Great minds rise above dualities.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna emphasizes equanimity over preference.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
न हि देहभृता शक्यं त्यक्तुं कर्माण्यशेषतः ।
 यस्तु कर्मफलत्यागी स त्यागीत्यभिधीयते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): It is not possible for an embodied being to completely renounce all actions, but one who renounces the fruits of action is truly a renunciant.
Meaning/Interpretation: Renunciation is not about inactivity but detachment from outcome.
Famous Quotes: “Be in the world, but not of it.”
Comparison/Relations: Spiritual freedom comes from internal detachment, not withdrawal.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अनिष्टमिष्टं मिश्रं च त्रिविधं कर्मणः फलम् ।
 भवत्यत्यागिनां प्रेत्य न तु सन्न्यासिनां क्वचित् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The threefold results of action—desirable, undesirable, and mixed—accrue to one who has not renounced. But never to the renunciant.
Meaning/Interpretation: Only attachment brings bondage of karma; renunciation brings freedom.
Famous Quotes: “Freedom lies in surrendering the outcome.”
Comparison/Relations: Renunciation dissolves karmic consequences.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
पञ्चैतानि महाबाहो कारणानि निबोध मे ।
 सांख्ये कृतान्ते प्रोक्तानि सिद्धये सर्वकर्मणाम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Learn from Me, O Mighty-armed, the five causes of the accomplishment of all actions as stated in the Sankhya philosophy.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna outlines the five factors behind action, reinforcing metaphysical clarity.
Famous Quotes: “Knowing the cause is half the cure.”
Comparison/Relations: Understanding action prevents false identification.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अधिष्ठानं तथा कर्ता करणं च पृथग्विधम् ।
 विविधाश्च पृथक्चेष्टा दैवं चैवात्र पञ्चमम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The body, the doer, the instruments of action, various efforts, and destiny—these are the five causes of action.
Meaning/Interpretation: Multiple elements interplay in producing any action or result.
Famous Quotes: “No man is an island, entire of itself.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna acknowledges individual, collective, and divine roles.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
शरीरवाङ्मनोभिर्यत्कर्म प्रारभते नरः ।
 न्याय्यं वा विपरीतं वा पञ्चैते तस्य हेतवः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Whatever action a man performs with his body, speech, and mind—whether right or wrong—is caused by these five factors.
Meaning/Interpretation: All human action arises from a mix of internal and external causes.
Famous Quotes: “You are responsible for your actions, but not for the results.”
Comparison/Relations: Understanding the cause of action leads to clarity and humility.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तत्रैवं सति कर्तारमात्मानं केवलं तु यः ।
 पश्यत्यकृतबुद्धित्वान्न स पश्यति दुर्मतिः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): He who sees the Self alone as the doer due to an untrained understanding—such a person does not truly see and is of poor intellect.
Meaning/Interpretation: Attributing all actions solely to oneself reflects ignorance.
Famous Quotes: “The ego is the false self born out of fear and defensiveness.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna cautions against egocentric perception.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यस्य नाहंकृतो भावो बुद्धिर्यस्य न लिप्यते ।
 हत्वाऽपि स इमाँल्लोकान्न हन्ति न निबध्यते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): He who is free from ego and whose intellect is not tainted—even though he kills, he does not kill and is not bound by karma.
Meaning/Interpretation: Selfless action rooted in dharma does not create bondage.
Famous Quotes: “Action performed without attachment is freedom.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna emphasizes intention over mere action.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ज्ञानं ज्ञेयं परिज्ञाता त्रिविधा कर्मचोदना ।
 करणं कर्म कर्तेति त्रिविधः कर्मसंग्रहः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Knowledge, the object of knowledge, and the knower are the three factors that motivate action. The instrument, the act, and the doer are the threefold basis of action.
Meaning/Interpretation: Understanding action requires knowing its source, process, and aim.
Famous Quotes: “To know thyself is the beginning of wisdom.”
Comparison/Relations: True knowledge integrates self, action, and awareness.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ज्ञानं कर्म च कर्ता च त्रिधैव गुणभेदतः ।
 प्रोच्यते गुणसङ्ख्याने यथावच्छृणु तान्यपि ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Knowledge, action, and the agent are declared to be of three kinds according to the gunas. Hear of these as described in the philosophy of the gunas.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna explains how nature influences our perception and action.
Famous Quotes: “Human nature is not a machine to be built after a model.”
Comparison/Relations: Awareness of guna influence leads to wise action.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सर्वभूतेषु येनैकं भावमव्ययमीक्षते ।
 अविभक्तं विभक्तेषु तज्ज्ञानं विद्धि सात्त्विकम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): That knowledge by which one sees the one imperishable reality in all diverse beings—that knowledge is sattvic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Unity in diversity is the highest wisdom.
Famous Quotes: “The wise see all beings as equal.”
Comparison/Relations: Sattvic knowledge perceives oneness beyond form.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
पृथक्त्वेन तु यज्ज्ञानं नानाभावान्पृथग्विधान् ।
 वेत्ति सर्वेषु भूतेषु तज्ज्ञानं विद्धि राजसम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): That knowledge which sees diversity in all beings as separate from each other—that knowledge is rajasic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Rajasic knowledge divides rather than unifies.
Famous Quotes: “Division is the root of conflict.”
Comparison/Relations: Misguided knowledge leads to confusion and separation.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यत्तु कृत्स्नवदेकस्मिन्कार्ये सक्तमहीतुकम् ।
 अतत्त्वार्थवदल्पं च तत्तामसमुदाहृतम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Knowledge clinging to one object as if it were the whole, without reason or truth, and narrow—is declared to be tamasic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Tamasic knowledge is rigid, biased, and misleading.
Famous Quotes: “Ignorance is not lack of knowledge, but refusal to learn.”
Comparison/Relations: True knowledge is expansive and self-aware.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
नियतं सङ्गरहितमरागद्वेषतः कृतम् ।
 अफलप्रेप्सुना कर्म यत्तत्सात्त्विकमुच्यते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Action performed with detachment, without longing or aversion, by one not seeking results—that action is sattvic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Sattvic action is pure and selfless.
Famous Quotes: “Do the right thing, not for a reward, but because it's right.”
Comparison/Relations: Sattvic karma reflects dharma over desire.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यत्तु कामेप्सुना कर्म साहङ्कारेण वा पुनः ।
 क्रियते बहुलायासं तद्राजसमुदाहृतम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Action performed with ego, craving, and intense effort is said to be rajasic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Rajasic actions drain energy and inflate ego.
Famous Quotes: “Ego is the anesthesia that deadens the pain of stupidity.”
Comparison/Relations: Effort without wisdom leads to burnout.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अनुबन्धं क्षयं हिंसामनपेक्ष्य च पौरुषम् ।
 मोहादारभ्यते कर्म यत्तत्तामसमुच्यते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Action undertaken out of delusion, without regard for consequences or harm to others, is tamasic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Tamasic actions are ignorant and harmful.
Famous Quotes: “Blind action is worse than inaction.”
Comparison/Relations: Wisdom must precede action.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
मुक्तसङ्गोऽनहंवादी धृत्युत्साहसमन्वितः ।
 सिद्ध्यसिद्ध्योर्निर्विकारः कर्ता सात्त्विक उच्यते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The doer who is free from attachment, ego, resolute, and even-minded in success and failure is called sattvic.
Meaning/Interpretation: The sattvic doer is balanced and detached.
Famous Quotes: “True power is calmness and clarity.”
Comparison/Relations: Sattva enables grace in all outcomes.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
रागी कर्मफलप्रेप्सुर्लुब्धो हिंसात्मकोऽशुचिः ।
 हर्षशोकान्वितः कर्ता राजसः परिकीर्तितः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The doer who is attached, greedy, violent, impure, and affected by joy and sorrow is said to be rajasic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Rajasic doers are emotionally driven and restless.
Famous Quotes: “Desire is never satisfied; it grows by indulgence.”
Comparison/Relations: Unchecked desire leads to emotional instability.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अयुक्तः प्राकृतः स्तब्धः शठो नैष्कृतिकः अलसः ।
 विषादी दीर्घसूत्री च कर्ता तामस उच्यते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The doer who is undisciplined, vulgar, stubborn, deceitful, lazy, despondent, and procrastinating is said to be tamasic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Tamasic doers are disoriented and destructive.
Famous Quotes: “Laziness travels so slowly that poverty soon overtakes him.”
Comparison/Relations: Tamas creates decay in thought and action.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
बुद्धेर्भेदं धृतेश्चैव गुणतस्त्रिविधं शृणु ।
 प्रोच्यमानमशेषेण पृथक्त्वेन धनञ्जय ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Listen, O Dhananjaya, to the threefold distinction of intellect and resolve, declared according to the gunas.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna will now describe how intellect and determination vary by guna.
Famous Quotes: “Wisdom begins in wonder.”
Comparison/Relations: Self-awareness refines wisdom and willpower.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
प्रवृत्तिं च निवृत्तिं च कार्याकार्ये भयाभये ।
 बन्धं मोक्षं च या वेत्ति बुद्धिः सा पार्थ सात्त्विकी ॥
Sloka (English Translation): That intellect which understands the path of action and renunciation, what should be done and avoided, fear and fearlessness, bondage and liberation—that intellect is sattvic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Sattvic intellect discerns wisely and clearly.
Famous Quotes: “Discrimination is the first step to liberation.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna praises reason grounded in truth and clarity.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यया धर्ममधर्मं च कार्यं चाकार्यमेव च ।
 अयथावत्प्रजानाति बुद्धिः सा पार्थ राजसी ॥
Sloka (English Translation): That intellect which incorrectly understands dharma and adharma, what ought to be done and not done—that intellect, O Partha, is rajasic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Rajasic intellect confuses virtue and vice due to ego and desire.
Famous Quotes: “The greatest enemy of knowledge is not ignorance, it is the illusion of knowledge.”
Comparison/Relations: Rajasic reasoning often rationalizes desires as duties.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अधर्मं धर्ममिति या मन्यते तमसावृता ।
 सर्वार्थान्विपरीतांश्च बुद्धिः सा पार्थ तामसी ॥
Sloka (English Translation): That intellect, O Partha, which is covered by darkness and sees adharma as dharma and all things pervertedly—that intellect is tamasic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Tamasic intellect inverts values, leading to delusion and harm.
Famous Quotes: “Blind belief in authority is the greatest enemy of truth.”
Comparison/Relations: Ignorant perception leads to downfall.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
धृत्या यया धारयते मनःप्राणेन्द्रियक्रियाः ।
 योगेनाव्यभिचारिण्या धृतिः सा पार्थ सात्त्विकी ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The firmness by which the mind, the life-force, and the senses are held in single-pointed concentration through unwavering yoga is sattvic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Sattvic determination is steady, focused, and spiritually aligned.
Famous Quotes: “Self-control is strength. Right thought is mastery.”
Comparison/Relations: Discipline rooted in truth is liberating.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यया तु धर्मकामार्थान्धृत्या धारयतेऽर्जुन ।
 प्रसङ्गेन फलाकाङ्क्षी धृतिः सा पार्थ राजसी ॥
Sloka (English Translation): But the determination with which one clings to dharma, wealth, and pleasure with desire for results—that is rajasic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Rajasic determination is driven by craving and attachment.
Famous Quotes: “Attachment is the root of suffering.”
Comparison/Relations: Desire-directed will can lead to imbalance.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यया स्वप्नं भयं शोकं विषादं मदमेव च ।
 न विमुञ्चति दुर्मेधा धृतिः सा पार्थ तामसी ॥
Sloka (English Translation): That determination by which a person does not give up sleep, fear, grief, despair, and arrogance—that is tamasic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Tamasic will clings to negativity and inertia.
Famous Quotes: “Fear is the path to the dark side.”
Comparison/Relations: Negativity sustained by ignorance leads to suffering.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सुखं त्विदानीं त्रिविधं श्रृणु मे भरतर्षभ ।
 अभ्यासाद्रमते यत्र दुःखान्तं च निगच्छति ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Now hear from Me of the threefold kind of happiness, O best of the Bharatas. That in which one delights through practice, and which ends all suffering—
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna introduces the classification of happiness based on the gunas.
Famous Quotes: “True happiness is not attained through self-gratification but through fidelity to a worthy purpose.”
Comparison/Relations: Spiritual joy transcends sensory pleasure.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यत्तदग्रे विषमिव परिणामेऽमृतोपमम् ।
 तत्सुखं सात्त्विकं प्रोक्तमात्मबुद्धिप्रसादजम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): That which is like poison in the beginning but nectar at the end, born of self-purification and clarity—that happiness is sattvic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Sattvic joy comes from effort and leads to lasting peace.
Famous Quotes: “Difficult paths often lead to beautiful destinations.”
Comparison/Relations: Spiritual growth often involves short-term discomfort.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
विषयेन्द्रियसंयोगात्यत्तदग्रेऽमृतोपमम् ।
 परिणामे विषमिव तत्सुखं राजसं स्मृतम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): That happiness arising from contact of senses with objects, which seems like nectar at first but is poison in the end—is called rajasic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Rajasic pleasure is temporary and leads to suffering.
Famous Quotes: “All that glitters is not gold.”
Comparison/Relations: Indulgence gives way to emptiness.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यदग्रे चानुबन्धे च सुखं मोहनमात्मनः ।
 निद्रालस्यप्रमादोत्थं तत्तामसमुदाहृतम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): That happiness which deludes the self in the beginning and the end, born of sleep, laziness, and carelessness—is said to be tamasic.
Meaning/Interpretation: Tamasic pleasure numbs and binds the soul.
Famous Quotes: “Comfort is the enemy of progress.”
Comparison/Relations: Ease without awareness leads to decay.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
न तदस्ति पृथिव्यां वा दिवि देवेषु वा पुनः ।
 सत्त्वं प्रकृतिजैर्मुक्तं यदेभिः स्यात्त्रिभिर्गुणैः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): There is no being on earth, or even among the gods in heaven, that is free from the three gunas born of nature.
Meaning/Interpretation: All beings are influenced by sattva, rajas, and tamas.
Famous Quotes: “Nature never deceives us; it is we who deceive ourselves.”
Comparison/Relations: Understanding the gunas is essential to self-mastery.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ब्राह्मणक्षत्रियविशां शूद्राणां च परन्तप ।
 कर्माणि प्रविभक्तानि स्वभावप्रभवैर्गुणैः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The duties of the Brahmanas, Kshatriyas, Vaishyas, and Shudras are distributed according to the qualities born of their nature.
Meaning/Interpretation: Varna system is based on guna and karma, not birth.
Famous Quotes: “Ability is what you’re capable of doing.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna emphasizes nature over social label.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
शमो दमस्तपः शौचं क्षान्तिरार्जवमेव च ।
 ज्ञानं विज्ञानमास्तिक्यं ब्राह्मकर्म स्वभावजम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Peacefulness, self-control, austerity, purity, forgiveness, honesty, knowledge, wisdom, and faith are the natural duties of a Brahmana.
Meaning/Interpretation: A Brahmana upholds wisdom and spiritual integrity.
Famous Quotes: “Knowledge is power but wisdom is peace.”
Comparison/Relations: True spiritual leadership is marked by virtue.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
शौर्यं तेजो धृतिर्दाक्ष्यं युद्धे चाप्यपलायनम् ।
 दानमीश्वरभावश्च क्षात्रं कर्म स्वभावजम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Valor, strength, firmness, skill, not fleeing in battle, generosity, and leadership are natural duties of Kshatriyas.
Meaning/Interpretation: Kshatriyas embody protection, courage, and service.
Famous Quotes: “Leadership is service, not position.”
Comparison/Relations: Righteous power serves the people.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
कृषिगौरक्ष्यवाणिज्यं वैश्यकर्म स्वभावजम् ।
 परिचर्यात्मकं कर्म शूद्रस्यापि स्वभावजम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Farming, cow protection, and trade are natural duties of Vaishyas. Service is the natural duty of Shudras.
Meaning/Interpretation: All work done with dedication contributes to society.
Famous Quotes: “No duty is small when done with sincerity.”
Comparison/Relations: Every role has spiritual significance.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
स्वे स्वे कर्मण्यभिरतः संसिद्धिं लभते नरः ।
 स्वकर्मनिरतः सिद्धिं यथा विन्दति तच्छृणु ॥
Sloka (English Translation): A person achieves perfection by being devoted to their natural duty. Hear how one attains success by such performance.
Meaning/Interpretation: Doing one’s duty sincerely leads to spiritual fulfillment.
Famous Quotes: “Bloom where you are planted.”
Comparison/Relations: Excellence comes from doing your best in your own role.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यतः प्रवृत्तिर्भूतानां येन सर्वमिदं ततम् ।
 स्वकर्मणा तमभ्यर्च्य सिद्धिं विन्दति मानवः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): By worshipping the source of all beings through one's own work, man attains perfection.
Meaning/Interpretation: Work becomes worship when dedicated to the Divine.
Famous Quotes: “Work is love made visible.”
Comparison/Relations: Duty becomes devotion with the right intent.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रेयान्स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात् ।
 स्वभावनियतं कर्म कुर्वन्नाप्नोति किल्बिषम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Better is one’s own imperfect duty than another’s well-performed. One does not incur sin while performing duties aligned with their nature.
Meaning/Interpretation: Authenticity in action is more valuable than imitation.
Famous Quotes: “Be yourself; everyone else is already taken.”
Comparison/Relations: Stay true to your dharma, not someone else's.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सहजं कर्म कौन्तेय सदोषमपि न त्यजेत् ।
 सर्वारम्भा हि दोषेण धूमेनाग्निरिवावृताः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): One should not abandon one’s natural duty, O Kaunteya, even if it is imperfect; for all endeavors are clouded by faults, just as fire is covered by smoke.
Meaning/Interpretation: Perfection lies in sincerity, not flawlessness.
Famous Quotes: “Perfection is not attainable, but if we chase perfection we can catch excellence.”
Comparison/Relations: Krishna teaches that spiritual merit lies in sincere effort, not flawlessness.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
असक्तबुद्धिः सर्वत्र जितात्मा विगतस्पृहः ।
 नैष्कर्म्यसिद्धिं परमां सन्न्यासेनाधिगच्छति ॥
Sloka (English Translation): He whose intellect is unattached everywhere, who has subdued the self and is free from desires, attains the supreme perfection of actionlessness through renunciation.
Meaning/Interpretation: Freedom from attachment leads to liberation even amid action.
Famous Quotes: “In detachment lies the wisdom of uncertainty.”
Comparison/Relations: Renunciation of desire—not action—brings peace.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सिद्धिं प्राप्तो यथा ब्रह्म तथाप्नोति निबोध मे ।
 समासेनैव कौन्तेय निष्ठा ज्ञानस्य या परा ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Learn from Me briefly, O Kaunteya, how one who has attained perfection reaches Brahman, the supreme state of knowledge.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna prepares to describe the final stage of self-realization.
Famous Quotes: “Ultimate knowledge leads to unity with the Absolute.”
Comparison/Relations: Brahman realization is the goal of spiritual life.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
बुद्ध्या विशुद्धया युक्तो धृत्यात्मानं नियम्य च ।
 शब्दादीन्विषयान्त्यक्त्वा रागद्वेषौ व्युदस्य च ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Endowed with a pure intellect, controlling the self by firmness, renouncing sound and other sense objects, giving up attraction and aversion—
Meaning/Interpretation: Self-mastery begins with purity of intellect and sense control.
Famous Quotes: “He who conquers himself is the mightiest warrior.”
Comparison/Relations: Inner victory is the path to peace.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
विविक्तसेवी लघ्वाशी यतवाक्कायमानसः ।
 ध्यानयोगपरो नित्यं वैराग्यं समुपाश्रितः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Living in solitude, eating lightly, controlling speech, body, and mind, constantly engaged in meditation,
Meaning/Interpretation: Spiritual evolution requires renouncing the ego and turning inward.
Famous Quotes: “Silence is the language of God.”
Comparison/Relations: Solitude and inner quietude reveal the Self.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अहङ्कारं बलं दर्पं कामं क्रोधं परिग्रहम् ।
 विमुच्य निर्ममः शान्तो ब्रह्मभूयाय कल्पते ॥
Sloka (English Translation): free from ego, strength, arrogance, desire, anger, and possessiveness—such a peaceful person is fit for Brahman.
Meaning/Interpretation: Spiritual evolution requires renouncing the ego and turning inward.
Famous Quotes: “Silence is the language of God.”
Comparison/Relations: Solitude and inner quietude reveal the Self.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ब्रह्मभूतः प्रसन्नात्मा न शोचति न काङ्क्षति ।
 समः सर्वेषु भूतेषु मद्भक्तिं लभते पराम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): One who has realized Brahman is joyful, does not grieve or desire, and treats all beings equally. Such a one attains supreme devotion to Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Equanimity and joy arise from self-realization.
Famous Quotes: “He who sees all beings in himself, and himself in all beings, loses all fear.”
Comparison/Relations: Union with Brahman leads to pure devotion.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
भक्त्या मामभिजानाति यावान्यश्चास्मि तत्त्वतः ।
 ततो मां तत्त्वतो ज्ञात्वा विशते तदनन्तरम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Through devotion, one truly knows Me, and knowing Me in truth, enters into Me completely.
Meaning/Interpretation: True devotion leads to oneness with the Divine.
Famous Quotes: “The goal of life is to know God and become one with Him.”
Comparison/Relations: Real knowledge of God is born from deep love.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सर्वकर्माण्यपि सदा कुर्वाणो मद्व्यपाश्रयः ।
 मत्प्रसादादवाप्नोति शाश्वतं पदमव्ययम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Though engaged in all actions, one who takes refuge in Me attains the eternal, imperishable abode by My grace.
Meaning/Interpretation: Divine grace uplifts the devoted beyond karma.
Famous Quotes: “Do your best and leave the rest to God.”
Comparison/Relations: Surrender brings divine protection.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
चेतसा सर्वकर्माणि मयि संन्यस्य मत्परः ।
 बुद्धियोगमुपाश्रित्य मच्चित्तः सततं भव ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Mentally renounce all actions to Me, be devoted to Me, take refuge in the yoga of wisdom, and always think of Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna urges Arjuna to act with unwavering focus and surrender.
Famous Quotes: “The heart of spirituality is surrender.”
Comparison/Relations: Total surrender integrates action and devotion.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
मच्चित्तः सर्वदुर्गाणि मत्प्रसादात्तरिष्यसि ।
 अथ चेत्त्वमहङ्कारान्न श्रोष्यसि विनङ्क्ष्यसि ॥
Sloka (English Translation): If your mind is fixed on Me, by My grace you shall overcome all difficulties. But if you act through ego and do not listen, you shall perish.
Meaning/Interpretation: Surrender leads to success; ego leads to downfall.
Famous Quotes: “Ego is the veil between you and God.”
Comparison/Relations: Grace operates where ego dissolves.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यदहङ्कारमाश्रित्य न योत्स्य इति मन्यसे ।
 मिथ्यैष व्यवसायस्ते प्रकृतिस्त्वां नियोक्ष्यति ॥
Sloka (English Translation): If, driven by ego, you think ‘I will not fight,’ your resolve is false. Your own nature will compel you to act.
Meaning/Interpretation: You may believe you can avoid your duties through sheer will, but your inner nature—your dharma—will pull you toward them anyway.
Famous Quotes: You can ignore reality, but you can’t ignore the consequences of ignoring reality.
Comparison/Relations: Many avoid responsibilities (like leadership, career shifts, or truth in relationships), but in time, life steers us back to them.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
स्वभावजेन कौन्तेय निबद्धः स्वेन कर्मणा ।
 कर्तुं नेच्छसि यन्मोहात्करिष्यस्यवशोऽपि तत् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Bound by your own karma born of nature, O Kaunteya, even if unwilling, you will be compelled to act.
Meaning/Interpretation: Our inborn tendencies and duties cannot be denied. Even reluctance cannot override the script written by one’s nature.
Famous Quotes: The only way out is through.
Comparison/Relations: People often try to escape what they are naturally built for—parenting, purpose, passion—but eventually return to it.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
ईश्वरः सर्वभूतानां हृद्देशेऽर्जुन तिष्ठति ।
 भ्रामयन्सर्वभूतानि यन्त्रारूढानि मायया ॥
Sloka (English Translation): The Supreme Lord dwells in the hearts of all beings, O Arjuna, and by His Maya, causes them to revolve as if mounted on a machine.
Meaning/Interpretation: Life operates like a divine simulation—while we seem independent, the divine resides and guides within.
Famous Quotes: The universe is not outside of you. Look inside yourself; everything that you want, you already are.
Comparison/Relations: From the subconscious to divine will—modern psychology and spirituality agree: we are shaped by unseen forces within.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तमेव शरणं गच्छ सर्वभावेन भारत ।
 तत्प्रसादात्परां शान्तिं स्थानं प्राप्स्यसि शाश्वतम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Surrender to Him with your whole being, O Bharata. By His grace, you shall attain eternal peace and the supreme abode.
Meaning/Interpretation: True peace comes not from external achievements but internal surrender to the divine rhythm.
Famous Quotes: Surrender is the simple but profound wisdom of yielding to rather than opposing the flow of life.
Comparison/Relations: People who align with purpose and let go of control often experience clarity and deep peace—personally and professionally.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
इति ते ज्ञानमाख्यातं गुह्याद्गुह्यतरं मया ।
 विमृश्यैतदशेषेण यथेच्छसि तथा कुरु ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Thus, the most profound wisdom has been revealed to you by Me. Reflect on it fully, and act as you wish.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna values Arjuna's free will, even after offering divine truth. Wisdom is shared, but action is always a choice.
Famous Quotes: You are free to choose, but you are not free from the consequences of your choice.
Comparison/Relations: Leadership, parenting, coaching—effective guidance respects autonomy while offering direction.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सर्वगुह्यतमं भूयः शृणु मे परमं वचः ।
 इष्टोऽसि मे दृढमिति ततो वक्ष्यामि ते हितम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Hear once again My supreme word, the most secret of all. You are dearly beloved to Me, therefore I speak this for your good.
Meaning/Interpretation: When love meets wisdom, it becomes personal, not just philosophical.
Famous Quotes: The friend who gives honest counsel is a true friend.
Comparison/Relations: When a mentor believes in you, even difficult truths become gifts.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
मन्मना भव मद्भक्तो मद्याजी मां नमस्कुरु ।
 मामेवैष्यसि सत्यं ते प्रतिजाने प्रियोऽसि मे ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Think of Me always, be devoted to Me, offer worship to Me, and bow to Me. Surely you will come to Me—this I promise, for you are dear to Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: The path to the Divine is not complex—it is love, remembrance, and reverence.
Famous Quotes: To love God is the greatest romance; to seek Him, the greatest adventure.
Comparison/Relations: Love is the most powerful spiritual technology—simple and transformative.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सर्वधर्मान्परित्यज्य मामेकं शरणं व्रज ।
 अहं त्वां सर्वपापेभ्यो मोक्षयिष्यामि मा शुचः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Abandon all forms of duties and surrender unto Me alone. I shall deliver you from all sins. Do not fear.
Meaning/Interpretation: Krishna gives the ultimate spiritual shortcut—let go and trust fully.
Famous Quotes: When I let go of what I am, I become what I might be.
Comparison/Relations: When we surrender outcomes to the Divine or the universe, life flows easier.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
इदं ते नातपस्काय नाभक्ताय कदाचन ।
 न चाशुश्रूषवे वाच्यं न च मां योऽभ्यसूयति ॥
Sloka (English Translation): This should never be spoken to one who is not disciplined, not devoted, unwilling to listen, or who mocks Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Wisdom is sacred. It requires purity, reverence, and readiness to receive.
Famous Quotes: Don't cast pearls before swine.
Comparison/Relations: Some truths are meant for hearts that are ready—not critics or cynics.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
य इदं परमं गुह्यं मद्भक्तेष्वभिधास्यति ।
 भक्तिं मयि परां कृत्वा मामेवैष्यत्यसंशयः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): He who teaches this most sacred knowledge to My devotees, with supreme devotion, will surely come to Me.
Meaning/Interpretation: Teaching spiritual wisdom is among the highest acts of devotion.
Famous Quotes: A teacher affects eternity; he can never tell where his influence stops.
Comparison/Relations: When you share wisdom, you're not just informing—you’re transforming lives.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
न च तस्मान्मनुष्येषु कश्चिन्मे प्रियकृत्तमः ।
 भविता न च मे तस्मादन्यः प्रियतरो भुवि ॥
Sloka (English Translation): With supreme devotion, will surely come to Me. No one is more dear to Me than he.
Meaning/Interpretation: Teaching spiritual wisdom is among the highest acts of devotion.
Famous Quotes: A teacher affects eternity; he can never tell where his influence stops.
Comparison/Relations: When you share wisdom, you're not just informing—you’re transforming lives.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अध्येष्यते च य इमं धर्म्यं संवादमावयोः ।
 ज्ञानयज्ञेन तेनाहमिष्टः स्यामिति मे मतिः ॥
Sloka (English Translation): One who studies this sacred dialogue of ours worships Me through the sacrifice of knowledge—this is My belief.
Meaning/Interpretation: Studying the Gita with reverence is itself a form of divine worship.
Famous Quotes: Study to show thyself approved unto God.
Comparison/Relations: In-depth study of values is just as holy as prayer or rituals.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
श्रद्धावाननसूयश्च शृणुयादपि यो नरः ।
 सोऽपि मुक्तः शुभाँल्लोकान्प्राप्नुयात्पुण्यकर्मणाम् ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Even one who listens with faith and without envy attains blessed realms. O Arjuna, did you hear with focused mind
Meaning/Interpretation: Attentive, non-judgmental listening is a spiritual act that liberates.
Famous Quotes: To listen is to lean in, softly, with a willingness to be changed by what we hear.
Comparison/Relations: Spiritual change starts by simply being present and receptive.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
कच्चिदेतच्छ्रुतं पार्थ त्वयैकाग्रेण चेतसा ।
 कच्चिदज्ञानसंमोहः प्रनष्टस्ते धनञ्जय ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Even one who listens with faith and without envy attains blessed realms. O Arjuna, did you hear with focused mind? Has your confusion been dispelled?
Meaning/Interpretation: Attentive, non-judgmental listening is a spiritual act that liberates.
Famous Quotes: To listen is to lean in, softly, with a willingness to be changed by what we hear.
Comparison/Relations: Spiritual change starts by simply being present and receptive.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
अर्जुन उवाच
 नष्टो मोहः स्मृतिर्लब्धा त्वत्प्रसादान्मयाच्युत ।
 स्थितोऽस्मि गतसन्देहः करिष्ये वचनं तव ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Arjuna said: My illusion is gone, memory restored, and doubt destroyed. I am now firm. I will do as You say.
Meaning/Interpretation: The final breakthrough—Arjuna is no longer confused but empowered.
Famous Quotes: Clarity is the elimination of mental clutter.
Comparison/Relations: When we connect deeply to truth, confusion lifts and commitment emerges.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
सञ्जय उवाच...
 यत्र योगेश्वरः कृष्णो यत्र पार्थो धनुर्धरः ।
 तत्र श्रीर्विजयो भूतिर्ध्रुवा नीतिर्मतिर्मम ॥
Sloka (English Translation): Sanjaya said: Wherever there is Krishna, the Master of Yoga, and Arjuna, the archer, there will be prosperity, victory, glory, and righteousness. This is my firm belief.
Meaning/Interpretation: When divine will (Krishna) unites with human action (Arjuna), the result is inevitable success.
Famous Quotes: Victory belongs to the most persevering.
Comparison/Relations: When purpose and alignment come together, success is not a possibility—it’s a certainty.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
संञ्जय उवाच |
 इत्यहं वासुदेवस्य पार्थस्य च महात्मनः |
 संवादमिममश्रौषमद्भुतं रोमहर्षणम् ॥18.74॥
Sloka (English Translation): Sanjaya said: Thus I heard this wonderful dialogue between Krishna and Arjuna, which causes the hair to stand on end.
Meaning/Interpretation: Sanjaya is overwhelmed by the divine conversation he heard between Krishna and Arjuna.
Famous Quotes: ‘Divine words leave divine impressions.’
Comparison/Relations: This verse captures Sanjaya’s awe, symbolizing the effect of divine wisdom on listeners.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
व्यासप्रसादाच्छ्रुतवानेतद्गुह्यमहं परम् |
 योगं योगेश्वरात्कृष्णात्साक्षात्कथयतः स्वयम् ॥18.75॥
Sloka (English Translation): By the grace of Vyasa, I have heard this supreme and most secret yoga directly from Krishna, the Lord of Yoga, who Himself spoke it.
Meaning/Interpretation: Sanjaya acknowledges that it was due to Vyasa’s blessing he could witness this divine dialogue.
Famous Quotes: ‘Blessings open the gateway to the hidden truths.’
Comparison/Relations: Vyasa’s blessing is compared to spiritual enlightenment and inner vision.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
राजन्संस्मृत्य संस्मृत्य संवादमिममद्भुतम् |
 केशवार्जुनयोः पुण्यं हृष्यामि च मुहुर्मुहुः ॥18.76॥
Sloka (English Translation): O King, remembering again and again this marvelous and holy dialogue between Krishna and Arjuna, I rejoice over and over again.
Meaning/Interpretation: He expresses immense joy recalling the sacred discussion between Arjuna and Krishna.
Famous Quotes: ‘Sacred memories are a source of eternal joy.’
Comparison/Relations: Repetition of holy discussions is likened to meditation bringing peace.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
तच्च संस्मृत्य संस्मृत्य रूपमत्यद्भुतं हरेः |
 विस्मयो मे महान् राजन्हृष्यामि च पुनः पुनः ॥18.77॥
Sloka (English Translation): And remembering again and again that most wonderful form of Hari, I am greatly amazed and I rejoice again and again.
Meaning/Interpretation: Sanjaya is amazed and emotionally stirred remembering Krishna’s divine form.
Famous Quotes: ‘The divine form is a vision beyond all wonders.’
Comparison/Relations: The repeated joy parallels the devotion of a bhakta remembering divine leelas.

Sloka (Sanskrit):
यत्र योगेश्वरः कृष्णो यत्र पार्थो धनुर्धरः |
 तत्र श्रीर्विजयो भूतिर्ध्रुवा नीतिर्मतिर्मम ॥18.78॥
Sloka (English Translation): Wherever there is Krishna, the master of yoga, and wherever there is Arjuna, the supreme archer, there also will surely be fortune, victory, prosperity, and sound morality. This is my opinion.
Meaning/Interpretation: He concludes that wherever Krishna and Arjuna are present, victory and righteousness will always prevail.
Famous Quotes: ‘Where there is Krishna and Arjuna, there is sure success.’
Comparison/Relations: The closing verse acts like a spiritual motto asserting divine companionship assures success.
